rationale: Vanessa virginiensis, also known as the American Lady, is found in open habitats with low-lying vegetation, such as meadows, fields, and grasslands throughout much of the Americas. Although it is common throughout much of its range, population size estimates and trends are unknown. Localized population declines due to habitat conversion and agricultural intensification in the Sacramento Valley of California are probably not pervasive across the range of this species. However, additional research on threats and monitoring of population numbers is needed to ensure range wide stability. Despite these localized trends, this species remains widespread, common, and there is little evidence of widespread threats. Therefore, V. virginiensis is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Vanessa virginiensis can be found in a variety of open habitats with low vegetation, including grasslands, meadows, dunes, openings in forests, agricultural fields and gardens (Opler and Wright 1999). Larval host plants include members of the Asteraceae family, such as Cudweed (Gnaphalium spp.), Everlasting (Anaphalis spp.), and Pussytoes (Antennaria spp.), Wormwood (Artemisia spp.), Ironweed (Veronia spp.) and Burdock (Arctium spp.) (Opler and Wright 1999, Lotts and Naberhaus 2017). As adults, this species feeds almost exclusively on Dogbane (Apocynum spp.), Aster (Aster spp.), Goldenrod (Solidago spp.), Marigold (Tagetes spp.), Self-heal (Prunella spp.), Milkweed (Asclepias spp.), and Vetch (Vicia spp., Astragalus spp., and Lathyrus spp.) (Lotts and Naberhaus 2017).

Adults cannot survive extended cold periods, so only inhabit the northern portions of their range, in the United States and Canada, during the summertime (Opler and Wright 1999). This slight migratory behavior never results in the sort of mass migrations seen in the related Painted Lady (V. cardui) (Brock 2008). In the northern portions of their range, there are three or four generations from May through November (Lotts and Naberhaus 2017). From coastal California, the Southwest, and the Deep South in the United States, through the Southern portions of its range, this species can be collected all year and probably has additional generations (Opler and Wright 1999).
threats: In areas where Vanessa virginiensis population declines appear to be taking place, the major threats include habitat conversion, agricultural intensification, and increased neonicotinoid pesticide use (Forister et al. 2011, Forister et al. 2016). While it is unclear which, if any, of these factors poses a threat to this species specifically, there is evidence these threats, as well as climate change, have caused population declines in other species of butterflies (Flockhart et al. 2015, Warren et al. 2001, Forister et al. 2010). Considering the recorded declines in the Sacramento Valley of California, it is clear more research is needed to determine what threats may be impacting this species across its range.
population:
The total population size for this species is unknown. It is reportedly common throughout much of its range and NatureServe (2020) estimates there could be as many as one million individuals globally.

Range wide population trend is also unknown, although declines across a 19 to 31 year period have been recorded at several sites in the Sacramento Valley of California (Forister et al. 2011). In this study, presence/absence data collected biweekly at two sites from 1976 to 2007, and at another two sites from 1988 to 2007, revealed declines of about 4-6% per year (Forister et al. 2011). This equates to a 33-45% decline over a ten year period. It is unlikely declines as high as these are present over the entire range of this species, as the region in question is likely subject to more habitat conversion and agricultural intensification (Forister et al. 2010) than elsewhere across the range. More research is needed to be certain similar declines are not taking place range wide.
range:
Vanessa virginiensis is widespread across the Americas. It is found as a year-round resident from coastal California and southern portions of the United States, throughout much of Mexico, the Caribbean and Central America, to Columbia and Venezuela (Opler and Wright 1999, GBIF 2020). In the springtime, this species migrates north and is found throughout much of the United States, and into southern Canada (Opler and Wright 1999). It has colonized areas outside the Americas, including Hawai’i, and portions of southwest Europe, such as the Canary Islands, Madeira, mainland Portugal and western Spain (Opler and Wright 1999, GBIF 2020). It has been found as far north as Newfoundland and Labrador, and as far east as western Europe, as a vagrant (Opler and Wright 1999).

The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species where it is a resident is almost 18 million km2.  The EOO of the entire range, including the areas where this species spends the summer, but not where it is non-native is closer to 26 million km2.
useTrade: Vanessa virginiensis is utilized by the Butterfly House Industry (BHI). The BHI is estimated to be worth about 100 million dollars (USD) a year, yet little regulation exists (Boppre and Vane-Wright 2012). It is therefore unclear how often this species is traded or collected from wild stock. More research is needed.
conservationActions: Due to the ubiquity of this butterfly species, it likely occurs in many protected areas across the world. In North America, for example, it is found on the species checklist for Yosemite National Parks (NPS 2019, Protected Planet 2020). No specific conservation actions are needed at this time, but more research should be done across the range of this species to ensure regional populations are stable and ample high-quality habitat remains to support the viability of this species. Need for conservation effort should continue to be monitored via butterfly monitoring schemes such as The North American Butterfly Monitoring Network.

rationale: This species is widespread, with no significant threat, and it is therefore classed as Least Concern.
habitat: E. palustris will occur in most types of wetland, including the margins of rivers, ponds, lakes and streams, it will also form large stands in fens, marshes, swamps and wet meadows, and in ditches, dune-slacks and salt marshes. It grows in a wide range of organic and mineral soils, but rarely on acidic peat (Preston et al. 2002).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: This species occurs throughout most of the northern hemisphere, from the Azores, Canary Islands and North Africa to Iceland and throughout Europe east through the Middle East, Nepal, Pakistan, the Caucasus, Kazakhstan and Mongolia to Sakhalin, Japan and China. It also occurs throughout North America from Alaska to Greenland and south to eastern Mexico.
useTrade: There is no evidence to suggest that this species is used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and no evidence of any required.

rationale: This species has an almost worldwide (pantropic) distribution and has no known major threats, hence it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species grows in permanently moist or marshy habitats, along irrigation ditches, in humid thickets, in ponds, in rice fields, and on moist arable  lands.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information on population size or trends in this species but there is no reason to suspect a decline. The population trend is therefore assumed to be stable.
range: This species is widely distributed throughout the tropics and subtropics, from North Africa south to South Africa and east through the Middle East and India to China and south through South-east Asia to Australia, as well as in the Americas from the southern United States south to Argentina.
useTrade: This species is a valuable fodder grass and also a serious weed of rice and other moist fields.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species and none are needed.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern because it is widespread and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This perennial plant (Hemicryptophyte) is found in most wetland habitat types, including marshy grassland, ditches, rivers, streams and rice fields, and in other wet places, frequently in shallow water, but largely above surface. Flowering starts at the end of spring and lasts until the beginning of summer.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: V. anagallis-aquatica is a subcosmopolitan species that occurs from northern Africa, Europe east to West and Central Asia, the Arabian Peninsula, Himalaya (Kashmir to Bhutan), Siberia, China, Korea, Macaronesia and boreal America.  It is also now widely established in the United States.
useTrade: The entire plant is diuretic in action and its decoction promotes menstruation in suffering women. Ethnobotanically it has been used as alterative, bladder, gargle, scurvy, skin, stone and whitlow.  The leaves of Veronica are edible (raw or cooked) and are rich in vitamin C. The roots and leaves are appetizers and induce urination.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: Bolboschoenus maritimus is a cosmopolitan species, widely distributed in South Asia and commonly found in riverine and marshy areas with no major threats affecting the species in the wild. Although it is used extensively for consumption and non-consumptive purposes, these uses are not threatening to the species. It is hence categorized as Least Concern.
habitat: This species commonly grows on the margins of permanent or semi permanent waters, brackish and salt water lagoons, back mangroves and margins of salt marshes (Banerjee et al. 2002). It is considered a weed in rice fields (Cook 1996).
threats: No specific threats are known for the species.
population: It is a common and widespread species found along most river courses and marshy areas.
range: Bolboschoenus maritimus is an almost cosmopolitan species (Cook 1996) widespread in temperate and tropical regions. Its European subpopulations extend east through Siberia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan and the Indian sub-continent. It also occurs throughout much of Africa, with records in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Egypt, South Africa, Namibia, Somalia, Kenya, Tanzania, Angola, Mauritania, Madagascar, Mali and Djibouti, as well as in Mauritius. In the American continent, it occurs throughout northern and western North America (including Hawaii), Central and South America. It has also been recorded in Australia (New South Wales) where it may be naturalized.
useTrade: The roots of Bolboschoenus maritimus have been used in China as an astringent and diuretic, seeds and rhizomes can be ground into flour and baked into bread. The leaves are used for making mats, and as the edging of woven mats and used to warp for sandals as well as warps and twining wefts for making clothing. The rhizomes form a habitat for beneficial bacteria that give these plants excellent water filtering properties. The tubers are dried and powdered and used as baby feed in Kerala, India (J. Augustine pers. comm.).
conservationActions: No conservation action is needed.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern because it is widespread and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species will occur on light sandy soils and loams to and heavy clay soils and will tolerate acid, neutral and basic or even highly alkaline  soils. It is intolerant of shade and typically grows in moist places such as ditches, streams, and  riverbanks, growing best in well drained soils where abundant moisture is  available. It will generally survive where planted, even at high altitudes and drier habitats, however under these conditions it may remain stunted.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information on trends in the native populations of this species. It is very widely introduced and introduction continues, therefore overall the population is probably increasing.
range: According to the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew), this species is native only to a fairly narrow area bounded by Cyprus, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan in the west, the Gulf States in the south and Japan south to Myanmar in the east. The same source describes it as occurring as an introduction from the Atlantic Ocean island groups and the Iberian Peninsula throughout the Mediterranean south through Africa to South Africa, some of the Indian Ocean island groups, Australia, New Zealand and some Pacific Ocean island groups, as well as North and Central America.
useTrade: The leaves are considered to have antibiotic properties and a paste may be applied externally in cutaneous affections. The root is considered to be diaphoretic, diuretic, emollient and galactofuge. An infusion is said to stimulate menstrual discharge and diminish milk flow. A paste of the root is applied to the forehead to treat headaches. Isolated alkaloids have been experimentally shown to raise the blood pressure and contract the intestine and uterus. The rhizome or rootstock is used in the treatment of dropsy. Boiled in wine with honey, the root or rhizome has been used for treating cancer. The plant contains the alkaloid gramine which is said to be a vasopressor, raising the blood pressure in dogs after small doses, causing a fall in larger doses. The stems have been used as splints for broken limbs. Other uses include basketry, biomass, broom, dye, hedge, as a musical instrument, paper; pipes, plant support, soil stabilization, thatching, weaving and windbreak.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species is capable of growing in a very wide range of wetland habitats, from seasonally inundated depressions, through rivers and streams to lake and pond margins, irrigation lane and ditches.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout much of its European range and appears to be increasing as a non-native.
range: This species is globally found in Europe, Africa and Asia. It is considered introduced in Australia and the United States, where it has been recorded from Maine to Wisconsin and South from Illinois to Maryland, as well as in the states of Washington and Oregon.
useTrade: This plant has been used as an astringent although it can be poisonous. The leaves are used to make tea in Russia.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread, able to exploit a range of anthropogenic situations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species is widespread and abundant, occurring wherever suitable habitat occurs. Some populations may be vast and seed-set is considerable. It is a characteristic species of damp muddy habitats, occurring from cattle drinking bays on rivers, through the drawdown zones of large lakes and reservoirs, through damp arable to building sites and damp areas in urban situations. It is also one of the characteristic species of the Bidentalion, a community most typically associated with silt deposits along large lowland rivers.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: This species has a more or less cosmopolitan distribution, it occurs throughout Europe south to the Mediterranean and North Africa, east through the Middle East and Indian sub-continent to East Asia and south to Australia and New Zealand; it also occurs from Canada south through the United States, Central America and the Caribbean to South America and on many Oceanic Island groups (CABI International 2012).
useTrade: This species is ground to make a starch to make a pesticide and treat disease in fish. It is also used for human medicinal purposes.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: E. parviflorum typically occurs in swamps, disturbed wet places near streams, bogs, rivers, open waste slopes and meadows in mountains, from near sea level to 1,500 m asl.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size.
range: E. parviflorum occurs throughout much of Europe and east through Russia, Nepal and Mongolia to China. It is naturalised in New Zealand and North America
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: Poa annua is an extremely common and widespread species with no known threats; it is an early colonizer of bare ground, is a common lawn grass and 'one of the world's worst weeds'; Least Concern is the most appropriate category for this species.
habitat: Poa annua has a widespread ecological distribution, and is one of the world's worst weeds and thrives in anthropogenic habitats. This species is a potential seed contaminant.
threats: There are no particular threats to this species.
population: There is no detailed population information on this species, but it is very widespread and common and is likely to be increasing given its invasive capabilities.
range: This plant is a very widespread and common species with a cosmopolitan distribution throughout temperate regions of both hemispheres, and in tropical highland regions. It is not generally found in arid areas or deserts. The species has historically been introduced in many areas and it is not easy to distinguish the introduced range from the native range. Recorded from sea level up to 4,800 m.<span id="lblTaxonDesc">
useTrade: This plant is used as turf grass.
conservationActions: The species is common, no conservation action is needed. It occurs in many protected areas across its extensive range.

rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The species grows along fresh and brackish marshes, coastal salt marshes, ponds, ditches, shorelines, beaches, and dunes; and in freshwater wetlands  (Encyclopedia of Life 2015).
threats: There are no known widespread threats to the species.
population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA and Provinces in Canada are classed as 'Critically Imperiled' or 'Imperiled'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
range: The species is widespread and native to North America, Mesoamerica and South America.  It has been introduced in Africa, Asia-Temperate, Australasia, Europe and the Pacific (eMonocot Team 2015).
conservationActions: No conservation actions for the species are known, or likely to be needed.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern because it is widespread and does not face any major threats.
habitat: P. maculosa is a characteristic species of damp muddy habitats, occurring from cattle drinking bays on rivers, through the drawdown zones of large lakes and reservoirs, through damp arable to building sites and damp areas in urban situations.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to the survival of this species.
population: P. maculosa is apparently widespread and abundant throughout its European range. It is extremely abundant in the UK, France, Germany, and the Netherlands, but Atlas Flora Europaea shows it as much less common in Scandinavia, Belarus, Ukraine, Russia and in the Mediterranean Basin. It is considered widespread in China, but rare in the Pearl River region.
range: The global distribution of P. maculosa includes Europe (Atlas Flora Europaea), Africa, the Arabian Peninsula (Miller and Cope 1996), north America, and temperate and tropical Asia.
useTrade: This species has medicinal properties. It is antiseptic, astringent, cardiotonic, laxative and tonic. It has been used against asthma, fever, inflammation, etc.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: Vicia sativa L. is so widespread and its populations are stable. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 67,998,632 km2 and its area of occupancy (AOO) is 52,064 km2. The species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Vicia sativa L. is a common pan-temperate and semi-tropical weed of agricultural and disturbed land (Maxted 1995). This species is common in disturbed land, field margins, hedgerows and woodland (Maxted 1995).
threats: This is a very common species found over a wide geographic range and there appears to be no major threats to its populations (Maxted 1995).
population: This species is the most widespread Vicia species, being common and stable throughout its range (Maxted 1995).
range: This species is native across Europe where it is located within, Austria, Belgium, Belarus, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Ireland, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Moldova, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, Ukraine. The species also occurs in Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Cuba, Ecuador, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Japan, Kazakhstan, Kenya, Korea, Kyrgyzstan, Lebanon, Libya, Mauritius, Mexico, Morocco, Oman, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Tajikistan, Taiwan, Tunisia, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Yemen. Vicia sativa L. is widely naturalised elsewhere and widely cultivated (Maxted 1995).
useTrade:
Vicia sativa L. subsp. nigra is cultivated often in a mixture with other species in Europe (Maxted 1995). Vicia sativa L. subsp. sativa is cultivated as fodder in Southeast Europe and the Middle East. The white seeded form was cultivated for human food in the former Soviet Union (Maxted 1995).

Vicia sativa L. is a tertiary wild relative and potential gene donor of Hungarian Vetch (V. pannonica Crantz), Faba Bean (V. faba L.), Narbon Bean (V. narbonensis L.) and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches as the Articulated Vetch (V. articulata Hornem.), Bitter Vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.) and Winter Vetch (V. villosa Roth.) (Maxted 1995).
conservationActions:
The genus Vicia is listed in Annex 1 of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Faba Bean gene pool.

This species is widely represented in ex situ gene banks from throughout its range with over 13,000 accessions according to Genesys (2017). The species is also located in 34 botanical garden collections worldwide (BGCI 2017).

In situ the species is likely to be passively conserved in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as its conservation in these sites is not actively monitored it may be subject to population loss over time from factors such as climate change.

rationale: Vicia lutea is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species with no major threats and ex situ conservation in place. Population monitoring and establishment of in situ reserves in the eastern Mediterranean is recommended for this and other species of Vicia.
habitat: Vicia lutea is found in disturbed and agricultural land and open woodland; it flowers from March to June (Maxted 1995).
threats: There are not thought to be any major threats to this species within its European range as it has a stable population trend (Osborne 2011). The threats facing this species outside of its European range remain unknown. However, association with agricultural and semi natural habitats makes this species vulnerable to changes in agricultural management and other anthropogenic pressures (Keisa et al. 2008). Grazing by wild or domesticated animals in these habitats may present a plausible threat to this species, as species of the genus Vicia generally do not respond well to grazing (Maxted 1995).
population: According to the European Red List assessment for this species, the exact population size is unknown, but the species is considered relatively common throughout its range with a stable population (Maxted 1995, Osborne 2011).
range: Vicia lutea is a widespread species native to northern Africa, Europe, western Asia and the Caucasus, and is also naturalized elsewhere (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). It occurs at elevations between 2 m and 2180 m asl (Maxted 1995).
useTrade:
This species is cultivated in some areas of its range (e.g. northern Italy) and is also likely to be grazed by wild and domesticated species in the pasture and agricultural margins (Osborne 2011).

Vicia lutea L. is a secondary wild relative of Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica Crantz, a tertiary wild relative of Narbon Bean V. narbonensis L. and Common Vetch V. sativa L. and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches including Faba Bean V. faba L., Articulated Vetch, V. articulata Hornem., Bitter Vetch V. ervilia (L.) Willd. and Winter Vetch V. villosa Roth. (Maxted and Douglas 1996). As a result, it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
conservationActions:
The genus Vicia is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) as part of the Faba Bean gene pool (FAO 2009).

This species is well conserved ex situ, with numerous accessions held in national gene banks from throughout the species range (Osborne 2011). Furthermore, Maxted (1995) notes the following institutions with ex situ holdings for this species:
  • Centro de Conservation de Recursos Fitogeneticos (INIA), Alcala de Henares, Madrid, Spain (12 accessions)
  • International Livestock Centre for Africa, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia (two accessions)
  • Vicieae Database Project, Department of Biology Medical and Biological Sciences Building, University of Southampton, UK (19 accessions)
  • Royal Botanic Gardens, Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, Haywards Heath, United Kingdom (two accessions)
  • Western Regional Plant Introduction Station USDA-ARS, Washington State University, Johnson Hall, Pullman, Washington, USA (eight accessions).

There are no genetic in situ reserves specifically established for the protection of Vicia populations, and quantification of active in situ conservation in place is difficult as few reserves have species checklists and those that have been produced are not widely distributed (Maxted 1995). In situ conservation priorities for the genus Vicia (subgenus Vicia) recommended by Maxted (1995) include the establishment of in situ reserves in the eastern Mediterranean where species of this genus are concentrated, especially in the countries of Turkey, Lebanon, Israel, Iraq, Iran, and the Caucasian republics, as the region as a whole is threatened with genetic erosion (IBPGR 1985, Maxted 1995).

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread with no evidence of a decline and does not face any known significant threats.
habitat: This species typically grows in humid or moist walls, cliffs and rocks near or on the margins of streams, usually in shade and usually near permanent water (Wood 1997, Miller and Cope 1996, Miller and Morris 2004). In Oman, it is also found in the weed vegetation on cultivated fields and terraces (Patzelt pers. comm. 2012).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no quantitative information on population trends in this species. However, it has become naturalized throughout much of the world and it is likely that the overall population is increasing.
range: This species has a sub-cosmopolitan distribution, from the Mediterranean south throughout sub-Saharan Africa south to the Cape and east through the Middle East, Russia and the Indian subcontinent to the Far East and south through South-east Asia to Australia. It has apparently been introduced to a number of Pacific Ocean island groups, New Zealand, North, Central and South America (Hassler and Schmidt 2011).
useTrade: This species is widely sold as a house plant.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: Osyris lanceolata is a shrub or small tree found across a vast range of Africa and Asia as well as parts of Europe. It is considered common and widespread in many of these areas. There are some concerns of its over-exploitation outside Europe, however within Europe there are no recognised threats. High demand for this species in the eastern African countries of Burundi, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, and the United Republic of Tanzania has led to its inclusion onto Appendix II of CITES. Outside of this range it is free to trade this species as demand is much lower. It is assumed that globally the population is large, and population relatively stable. There are no major threats to this species. It is listed here as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is an evergreen, highly branched shrub or small tree that grows up to 3 m tall. It grows in evergreen forest, rocky areas or along the margins of dry forest and sometimes (as in Portugal) close to the sea in shrublands. The species has a preference for sunny places and occurs in regions with warm climate, having little tolerance to cold. It has yellow-green flowers that are 2–3 mm across and orange-red drupe fruit that are 7–10 mm in diameter.
threats: Outside Europe, there are concerns subpopulations are being over-exploited in parts of its range due to its scented wood (sandalwood) and essential oil. However, further research is needed to confirm the extent of impact of this threat on these subpopulations and overall global population.
population: A widespread species globally. The species was considered locally frequent on Tenerife (Bramwell and Bramwell 2001), and very common and widespread on Gibraltar (Linares et al. 1996), and it is common in Portugal (A. Carapeto pers. comm. 2017) although no European population estimates are available subpopulations are considered to be stable. In East Africa, some subpopulations are in decline due to exploitation for essential oil and timber. Elsewhere, outside of Europe, subpopulations are large and mostly stable.
range: An extremely widespread species occurring over much of southern, eastern and northern Africa, also found in southern Europe and in Asia from India to China and also on Socotra (to Yemen). It occurs from 50 to 2,700 m.
useTrade: This species is listed under Appendix II of CITES for its East African subpopulations in Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, and the United Republic of Tanzania (CITES 2018). This prevents the exportation of this species across borders of the countries listed above without an appropriate permit. This does not apply to seed, pollen or finished products. The wood has fuel value as a substitute for sandalwood.
conservationActions: There are 12 known ex situ collections of this species in botanic gardens worldwide (BGCI 2017). This species was assessed as Least Concern for the 2013 Chinese Red List (MEPC and CAS 2013) and assessed as Least Concern across its European range (Rivers 2017). The species is listed on CITES Appendix for Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, and the United Republic of Tanzania. This enables monitoring of trade in the species between these countries and restricts trade to only those with correct permits. It is recommended that more information on the threat to East African subpopulations is gathered.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2 in view that it is only known from four sites on three different islands and it is endemic to the Canary Islands. It may possibly qualify as Vulnerable or Endangered under Criterion B, but it is difficult to say because there is little information on population trend, and it is not known whether suitable habitat is stable or decreasing.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2 in view that it is only known from four sites on three different islands and it is endemic to the Canary Islands. It may possibly qualify as Vulnerable or Endangered under Criterion B, but it is difficult to say because there is little information on population trend, and it is not known whether suitable habitat is stable or decreasing.
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. Found in the deadwood of juniper trees (Juniperus sp.) in woodland, but no information is available on any requirements for canopy open-ness.
threats: No information available.
population: There is little information available on the abundance of this species.
range: This species is only found in the Spanish archipelago of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic Ocean. Endemic to the Canary Islands. Known from Tenerife, La Gomera, and El Hierro. Reported from five sites by Gonzáles Peña et al. (2007).
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: No specific conservation measures are in place for this species. It does not appear to occur in any protected areas. Further research is needed to determine what current and potential threats are present for this species.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Endangered (B2ab(iii)) because this species has a relatively small range (area of occupancy less than 500 km²), it is only known from four localities and it occupies pine woodland, a habitat type which is threatened by forest management in the Canary islands and fires.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Endangered (B2ab(iii)) because this species has a relatively small range (area of occupancy less than 500 km²), it is only known from four localities and it occupies pine woodland, a habitat type which is threatened by forest management in the Canary islands and fires.
habitat:
This is an obligate saproxylic species. Pine forests, under the dead bark
of fallen trees and branches, where it feeds on other xylophagous
insects (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009).
threats: Pine forests in the Canary Islands are managed for forestry, so it is possible that the species gets negatively affected if dead trees or large branches are removed from the forest as a part of the 'cleaning' management (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009). Forest fires are also a threat.
population: There is little information available on the abundance of this species. Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala (1981) recorded only two specimens, one from La Palma and the other one from El Hierro; it does not seem to be a very abundant species. Known from four islands, only four localities known (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009).
range: This species is only known from Canary Islands, Spain. Present in four islands: La Palma, Hierro, Tenerife and Gran Canaria (Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala 1981, Izquierdo et al. 2004).
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: Not present in the Red Book of Invertebrates of Spain (Verdú and Galante 2006). It is found in at least one protected area.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Data Deficient because although this species has a small distribution, there is no information regarding its population status, habitat preferences or threats that would allow an assessment to be made. The species is only known from the original specimen described in the 19th century.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Data Deficient because although this species has a small distribution, there is no information regarding its population status, habitat preferences or threats that would allow an assessment to be made. The species is only known from the original specimen described in the 19th century.
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. It was reported from beneath the bark of a felled Spanish chestnut- tree Castanea sativa.
threats: No information available.
population: There is no information available on the abundance of this species - the species is known from just one specimen found over 100 years ago.
range: This species is endemic to the Spanish Archipelago in the Atlantic Ocean, the Canary Islands and known from Tenerife only.
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: None feasible until a live population is discovered.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Least Concern because although the species has a relatively small range and there is no information on the population size or  trends, it is a polyphagous species not dependent on wood of large diameter (rather the opposite) and can tolerate modified habitats, thus making it unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Least Concern because although the species has a relatively small range and there is no information on the population size or  trends, it is a polyphagous species not dependent on wood of large diameter (rather the opposite) and can tolerate modified habitats, thus making it unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. It has been reared from dead branches of Launaea spinosa, a shrub, growing in near-coast habitats (Israelson 1974). It has also been reared from deadwood of Ficus carica (Lesne, 1904) and, in Gran Canaria, from dead branches of Vitis vinifera (Lesne, 1905). Probably, these are only three of a variety of potential hosts.
threats: No information available.
population: In the Canary Islands, the species is recorded from all the islands except for Lanzarote (Machado and Oromi 2000).The population size and trends are unknown, but the species is not restricted to certain habitat types, and perhaps is common at least in some of the islands (Zoological Museum Lund holds 120 specimens).
range: This species only occurs in the Spanish archipelago, the Canary Islands, in the Atlantic Ocean.
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: There is no information regarding the conservation actions for this species; probably none are needed at present.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Least Concern because although the species has a relatively small range and there is no information on the population size or trends, it is a polyphagous species not dependent on wood of large diameter (rather the opposite) and can tolerate modified habitats, thus making it unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Least Concern because although the species has a relatively small range and there is no information on the population size or trends, it is a polyphagous species not dependent on wood of large diameter (rather the opposite) and can tolerate modified habitats, thus making it unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. Its name suggests an association with fig trees (Ficus), but probably it can use a variety of dry woods, including small branches, as is the general rule in the genus Scobicia. It has been collected in woods of Ceratonia siliqua (Lesne 1904) and has been reared from Vitis vinifera (Lesne 1905).
threats: The main overall threat is likely to be degradation or loss of habitat quality, involving structural changes in the tree populations arising from changing land use – affecting age structures and tree density. Exploitation from forestry is often a key immediate issue, but equally damaging can be long-term changes towards canopy closure and loss of ancient trees as a result of non- or minimum-intervention management systems which all too often exclude grazing by large herbivores. Fragmentation and increasing isolation of beetle populations are also key factors.
population: There is little information available on the abundance of this species. In the Canarian archipelago, S. ficicola is present on all major islands except for Fuerteventura (Consejería de Medio Ambiente y Ordenación Territorial). The Zoological Museum Lund holds 30 specimens.
range: This species is only found in the Spanish archipelago, the Canary Islands.
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: The species is present in at least one protected area.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Near Threatened. Although this species has a small geographic range, it is known from many sites where it does occur. The Extent of Occurrence and the Area of Occupancy are both small, but the populations are not believed to be severely fragmented or subject to extreme fluctuations (although there is little information on population trend or fluctuations). The species is present at more than ten locations. Population trend is unknown. This species inhabits laurisilva forests, some of which are protected; however this habitat type has been reduced in area by human activities. This species is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Criterion B).

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Near Threatened. Although this species has a small geographic range, it is known from many sites where it does occur. The Extent of Occurrence and the Area of Occupancy are both small, but the populations are not believed to be severely fragmented or subject to extreme fluctuations (although there is little information on population trend or fluctuations). The species is present at more than ten locations. Population trend is unknown. This species inhabits laurisilva forests, some of which are protected; however this habitat type has been reduced in area by human activities. This species is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Criterion B).
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. Occurs in laurisilva forest; typically inhabits deadwood of laurels Laurus and willows Salix; also Persea indica and Apollonias barbujana.
threats: The main overall threat is likely to be degradation or loss of habitat quality, involving structural changes in the tree populations arising from changing land use – affecting age structures and tree density. Exploitation from forestry is often a key immediate issue, but equally damaging can be long-term changes towards canopy closure and loss of ancient trees as a result of non- or minimum-intervention management systems which all too often exclude grazing by large herbivores. Fragmentation and increasing isolation of beetle populations are also key factors. This species inhabits Apollonias barbujana trees, which are utilized for luxury furniture. However, this species remains widespread in the Canary Islands and is not thought to be under immediate threat, although this situation may change in the shorter term.
population: This species has a restricted distribution, but it is apparently common where it occurs, with many known localities.
range: This species only occurs in the Portuguese and Spanish archipelagos in the Atlantic Ocean, Madeira and Canary Islands, respectively. Endemic to the Canary Islands and Madeira.
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: This species occurs in protected areas. No specific conservation measures are in place or needed.

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Vulnerable (D2), although it is not thought to be under major threat at present, it could be rapidly affected in future by habitat loss and degradation caused by a number of factors including climate change. Moreover, this species has a restricted distribution and occupies a specific habitat type (laurisilva forest); its area of occupancy is likely less than 20 km². It feeds on other saproxylic beetle species and consequently occupies a higher part of the food chain.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Vulnerable (D2), although it is not thought to be under major threat at present, it could be rapidly affected in future by habitat loss and degradation caused by a number of factors including climate change. Moreover, this species has a restricted distribution and occupies a specific habitat type (laurisilva forest); its area of occupancy is likely less than 20 km². It feeds on other saproxylic beetle species and consequently occupies a higher part of the food chain.
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. Both subspecies are present in the laurisilva forest vegetation belt, under the dead bark of fallen trees, where they feed on xylophagous beetles, probably Colydiidae from the genus Tarphius (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009).
threats: Habitat destruction (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009) appears to be a major threat to this species.
population: There is little information available on the abundance of this species. It does not seem to be a very abundant species; Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala (1981) report only three specimens of the nominal subspecies and six from the gomerensis subspecies.
range: This is endemic to the Canary Islands, Spain. Present in four islands: La Palma and Tenerife (L. l. lauricola) and Gomera and El Hierro (L. l. gomerensis) (Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala 1981, Izquierdo et al. 2004).
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: Not present in the Red Book of Invertebrates of Spain (Verdú and Galante 2006). It has been found at the Garajonay National Park in La Gomera (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009).

rationale:
European regional assessment: listed as Near Threatened because this species potentially has a small Area of Occupancy (< 500 km²) and it is monophagous and dependent on a threatened habitat type (indigenous pine forest reduced by cultivation and fire). Therefore there is a continuing decline in the area, extent and quality of the area the species occupies, thus making this species close to qualify for Vulnerable. However there is no data on the extent of fragmentation of the pine forest it occupies, and the Near Threatened category is more appropriate.

EU 27 regional assessment: listed as Near Threatened because this species potentially has a small Area of Occupancy (< 500 km²) and it is monophagous and dependent on a threatened habitat type (indigenous pine forest reduced by cultivation and fire). Therefore there is a continuing decline in the area, extent and quality of the area the species occupies, thus making this species close to qualify for Vulnerable. However there is no data on the extent of fragmentation of the pine forest it occupies, and the Near Threatened category is more appropriate.
habitat: This is an obligate saproxylic species. It occurs in Pinus canariensis forests, for example in the Pinar de Garafia reserve in La Palma (800 ha). Because all other members of Stephanopachys are associated with conifers (especially pines), the Canarian pine is likely to be the only host of the species. Larval development is likely to take place in dead bark.
threats: Indigenous pine forest are suffering reduction through cultivation and forest fires. Pine forest is commercially managed in the Canary Islands and the traditional management of dead wood is not likely to benefit this species.
population: The species is known from the major islands Tenerife, La Palma, El Hierro and Gran Canaria (Consejería de Medio Ambiente y Ordenación Territorial). There is little information available on the abundance of this species. It probably is uncommon like other members of the genus (Zoological Museum Lund holds a few specimens only). Population trend is unknown.
range: This species is only found in the Spanish archipelago of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic Ocean.
useTrade: Saproxylic Coleoptera tend to be popular with beetle collectors although trade is rarely an issue, the only exceptions being a few larger species of more dramatic form or colour.
conservationActions: The species is present in at least one protected area.

rationale: Pontia daplidice is assessed as being of Least Concern as it does not qualify as threatened under any of the assessment criteria. It is a widespread and common butterfly with well-documented migratory tendencies. It utilises a variety of larval host-plants and is not under any known threat.
habitat: This butterfly occurs in a wide variety of open habitats, including semi-desert on the northern edge of the Sahara desert, and at elevations from sea level to almost 3,000 m. Its diet is generalist and it utilizes a variety of larval host-plants.
threats: This species is not affected by any known threats. It occurs in a range of habitats and utilizes a range of larval host-plants which should make it more resistant to habitat loss.
population: No population size estimates currently exist, but this butterfly is common and sometimes abundant, especially in the southern parts of its range. Its range is extended as a result of migration when conditions are favourable.
range: This species occurs from North Africa and some North Atlantic Islands (widespread in the Canary Islands; occasional visitor to Madeira), through southern and western Europe, Turkey, and the Middle East to central and eastern Asia. This butterfly is extremely widespread and therefore the extent of occurrence (EOO) far exceeds 20,000 km<sup>2</sup> and the area of occupancy (AOO) is also undoubtedly far greater than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There is no existing legislation regarding this species and no conservation action is currently required for this species.

rationale: Lotus kunkelii is listed as Critically Endangered because its area of occupancy is 2 km² and its total population size is 41 individuals, in a single location. A continuing decline in its distribution range and the extent and quality of its habitat has been observed due to recreational activities, infrastructure works, and landslides.
habitat:
This plant grows in sandy coastal hills and sandy clays facing northeast, under constant influence of sea spray. A secondary habitat are sandy valleys in the southwest. Frequent accompanying species are Astydamia latifolia, Chenoloides tomentosa, Limonium pectinatum, Polycarpaea nivea, Aizoon canariense and Launaea arborescens.

It is a hermaphrodite species. This entomophilous plant produces flowers from winter to spring.
threats: The only known location has been affected by works in the surrounding areas (Navarro et al. 2004). This location is as well affected by trampling due to the presence of tracks that go through it. Landslides as well as pollution emitted by a close electric plant, have been also reported as threats.
population: Total population is 41 individuals. The species presents annual and interannual fluctuations in the number of individuals (Navarro et al. 2004). Seed production is low and only a few juveniles have been observed in the population. Historically, the species has suffered a significant decline. Decreasing population trends have been reported (Gobierno de Canarias 2004).
range: This plant is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria, Canary Islands, Spain (Navarro et al. 2004). It grows between 10 and 30 m asl in one single location in Playa de Jinámar on the eastern coast of the island. Its area of occupancy has been estimated in 2 km². Regressive trends from the 60's have been reported for its distribution (Gobierno de Canarias 2004).
conservationActions:
Lotus kunkelii is listed as priority species on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species "En peligro de extinción" in the national catalogue of threatened species and in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands. It is listed as Critically Endangered B2ab(iii); D on the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).
The species occurs in the protected area SCI Jinamar. Seeds are stored in the germplasm bank of the Jardín Botánico Viera y Clavijo where the species is also cultivated.

rationale: Sventenia bupleuroides is listed as Endangered because its area of occupancy is 10 km², it occurs at one to four locations, and regressive patterns have been identified for the extent and quality of its habitat. Grazing is the main threat affecting the conservation of this species. This species would also qualify for Vulnerable D1.
habitat:
This is a rupicolous species that settles in cracks and fissures of walls and vertical cliffs, usually in shady, moist areas, generally facing northwest. It occurs within communities Greenovion aureae (Greenovio-Aeonietum caespitosii), along with species such as Greenovia aurea, Dendriopoterium menendezii, Carlina salicifolia, Babcockia platylepis, Convolvulus canariensis, Chrysoprenanthes pendula and Erica arborea.

This perennial plant presents low germination rates. Hybridization phenomena with species of the genus Prenanthes L. (x Prenanthenia Svent.) and Sonchus L. (x Sonchustenia Svent.) with which they usually share habitats, are common.
threats: Predation by grazing animals is the most important threat negatively affecting the expansion of the species (Naranjo Suárez et al. 2006). The presence of climbing paths has been also reported as a threat, as well as droughts and landslides.
population: Total population size has been estimated in 825 individuals (Naranjo Suárez et al. 2006). Germination seems to be low and the low number of seedlings are predated by goats. Progressive population trends are not expected (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
range: This species is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria, the Canary Islands, Spain (Naranjo Suárez et al. 2006), where it appears restricted to the northwest of the island, in Macizo de Tamadaba. The only known population is distributed into four groups: Faneque, Barranco del Palo, Barranco Oscuro and El Trébol, throughout an area relatively wide. Further individuals appear scattered throughout this area. The species tends to appear restricted to sites out of reach of grazing animals (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
conservationActions:
Sventenia bupleuroides is listed on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species "de interés para los ecosistemas canarios" in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands. It is listed as Endangered B2ac(iv) on the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).

It occurs within the protected area Parque Natural de Tamadaba (SCI Tamadaba). Seeds are stored in the Jardín Botánico Canario Viera y Clavijo.

Grazing species should be banned from the area. Visitors to the protected area should be made aware of the importance of respecting the plant and animal species. Population trend monitoring and research about the reproductive biology of the species should be developed.

rationale: Euphorbia handiensis is listed as Vulnerable because it has a restricted distribution, with an area of occupancy of 12 km² and presence confirmed in only two known locations. No regressive trends have been observed for its distribution and population size, but the species appears still very restricted and grazing pressure and collection limit its expansion.
habitat:
It grows on slopes and watercourses of ravines, in stony soils within xerophitic communities Euphorbietum handiensis and Aeonio-Euphorbion canariensis.

It is a hermaphrodite plant adapted to conditions of extreme aridity. Seed production is high and germination rates up to 80% have been observed in ex situ conditions. Seeds are affected by parasites.
threats: No major threats to this species have been described. Uncontrolled grazing and collection are still affecting the species (Marrero Gómez and Carqué Alamo 2004).
population: This species can become locally very abundant. Total population has been estimated in 200,000 individuals (Marrero Gómez and Carqué Alamo 2004). The populations are well structured, with a relative abundance of juvenile individuals. Genetic exchange between the main populations seems to exist. Population size is believed to be stable or slightly increasing (Marrero Gómez and Carqué Alamo 2004, Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
range:
Euphorbia handiensis is endemic to the island of Fuerteventura, the Canary Islands, Spain, where it can be found from 50 to 300 m asl (Marrero Gómez and Carqué Alamo 2004). It occurs in the south of the island at the Jandia Peninsula, mainly in large colluvial valleys. It is distributed into two relatively dense subpopulations: Gran Valle and Valle de los Mosquitos. The area of occupancy is 12 km².
A slight expansive trend has been reported for its distribution (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
useTrade: It has been gathered by collectors.
conservationActions:
Euphorbia handiensis is listed as priority species on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species with “Protección Especial” in the national list of species in regime of special protection of Spain, and as Euphorbia handiense as species "de interés para los ecosistemas canarios" in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands. It is listed as VU D2 in the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).

The species occurs within the protected area Parque Natural de Jandía (Marrero Gómez and Carqué Alamo 2004). A conservation programme of threatened flora in Fuerteventura has been developed, which include among other measures, seed collection and storage in germplasm banks.

Proposed measures include population monitoring, a plagues and diseases monitoring plan and research about genetic variability of the populations.

rationale: Convolvulus lopezsocasii is listed as Endangered because it has a highly restricted area of occupancy of 8 km², is distributed into five subpopulations and decreasing trends have been observed in the number of mature individuals. Landslides, droughts, trampling and predation by roaming goats are the main threats affecting this species.
habitat: This shrub grows in humid cracks and ledges on steep crags and cliffs, probably taking refuge from grazing pressure. It participates in communities of Convolvulo lopezsocasii-Oleetum cerasiformis. Accompanying species include: Olea cerasiformis, Pistacia lentiscus, Phillyrea angustifolia, Lavandula pinnata, Lycium intricatum, Asteriscus intermedius, Bituminaria bituminous var. albomarginata, Maytenus senegalensis and Sideritis pumila.
threats: Main threat to this species are landslides that could considerably reduce the number of mature individuals (Reyes-Betancort et al. 2004). Other threats are droughts, trampling and predation by roaming goats, which force the species to appear restricted to sheltered sites.
population:
Population has been estimated in 301 individuals, unevenly distributed so number of individuals in each location ranges from three to 266 (Reyes-Betancort et al. 2004). Subpopulations sometimes present low numbers of isolated specimens and recruitment is generally low. Germination levels are generally very low or no germination at all is observed. The species also propagates by cuttings.
Number of mature individuals is reported to be 373 in 2006 (Gobierno de Canarias 2009) and population trends are described as regressive.
range: Convolvulus lopezsocasii is endemic to the island of Lanzarote, Canary Islands, Spain, where it can be found from 425 to 600 m asl, restricted to the moist cliffs of Famara, distributed into five subpopulations. Its area of occupancy has been estimated in 8 km² (Reyes-Betancort et al. 2004). Its presence has been also reported in Gran Canaria, but the existence of natural populations in this island is uncertain (Gobierno de Canarias 2004).
useTrade: It is locally used as ornamental plant.
conservationActions:
Convolvulus lopezsocasii is listed as priority species on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species "Vulnerable" in the Spanish catalogue of threatened species and in the regional catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands. It is listed as Endangered C2a(ii) on the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).

The populations are found in the protected area Parque Natural del Archipiélago Chinijo (SCI) (Reyes-Betancort et al. 2004). Seeds are stored in the germplasm bank of the Jardín Botánico Viera y Clavijo.

Proposed measures include the development of research about the reproductive biology of the species and the establishment of reinforcement and benign introduction actions within its potential distribution area. Plant material should be stored in germplasm banks and botanic gardens. Roaming goats should be eradicated in Riscos de Famara.

rationale: Limonium sventenii  is listed as Critically Endangered due to its restricted and fragmented distribution range. It is distributed in four scattered subpopulations, with a low total area of occupancy, of 5 km2. Regressive patterns are observed in its area of occupancy and number of subpopulations. The presence of grazing animals and human-generated impacts, limit the expansion of the species and force it to appear restricted to inaccessible sites within its potential habitat. Subpopulations have been affected by a fire in 2007.
habitat: This small shrub grows in communities Euphorbietum balsamiferae, at the base of crags. It can also be found at the peak of Montaña Amagro and in steep cliffs and paths within rupicolous communities Prenantho pendulae-Taeckholmietum pinnatae (Commission of the European Communities 2009), and in flatter areas within Euphorbio-Cistetum monspeliensis (González González et al. 2004).
threats: Grazing by goats and rabbits have been reported as the main threat affecting this species (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). The presence of a garbage dump near the location of Montaña Amagro could lead to the anthropization of the area and increase competition phenomena with nitrophile species (González González et al. 2004). In El Sao, hybridisation with ornamental Limonium sp. is a potential threat. A fire in 2007 seems to have affected several subpopulations.
population:
Population was estimated in 4,795 individuals in 2003 (González González et al. 2004) and in more than 14,900 individuals in 2007 (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). Population trends have been reported to be positive for Montaña Amagro (which has been reported to include between 6,250 and 14,500 individuals) and El Sao, where the impact of livestock has decreased.

Some subpopulations have not been recently found (Gobierno de Canarias 2009), probably partially due to the impact exerted by a fire in 2007.
range: Limonium sventenii is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria, Canary Islands, Spain (González González et al. 2004), where it grows between 300 and 800 m asl, on the northwestern and western parts of the island. Its area of occupancy has been estimated in 5 km². It is distributed into four subpopulations: Montaña de Amagro, El Sao, El Viso and Güigüí (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). Increasing trends have been reported for the distribution of the species in the subpopulations of Montaña de Amagro and El Sao, and decreasing patterns for the rest.
conservationActions:
This taxon is listed as priority species on Annex II of the Habitat Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species "Vulnerable" in the national catalogue of threatened species of Spain and in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands. It is listed CR B2ab(iii,v) in the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).

It occurs within the protected areas Monumento Natural de Montaña de Amagro (SCI) and Parque Rural del Nublo (SCI). Seeds are stored in the germplasm bank Banco de Germoplasma del Jardín Botánico Viera y Clavijo de Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, where the species is as well cultivated ex situ.

Plant material from every subpopulation should be collected and stored in germplasm banks. Ex situ cultivation and population reinforcement measures should be implemented in El Sao and El Viso. Dumping must be forbidden in Montaña de Amagro. The subpopulation in El Sao must be included in the protected area Parque Rural de Tamadaba (SCI). In El Sao, hybrid individuals Limonium sp.x Limonium sventenii should be removed and substituted by non-hybrid specimens.

rationale: Cheirolophus junonianus is listed as Endangered due to its restricted extent of occurrence of less than 56 km2 and a small area of occupancy of 2 km². It occurs in two subpopulations which are highly affected by anthropogenic pressure and because of its uneven reproductive patterns, characterised by low rates of success in the establishment and survival of seedlings. Although the population trend is stable, tourism and poor recruitment cause the conservation of this species to be highly threatened.
habitat: C. junonianus occurs in xerophilous ruderal shrublands (Artemisio-Rumicetum lunariae) that grow in unstable naturally or human modified substrates within the Canarian vegetation community tabaibal-cardonal (Commission of the European Communities 2009). Its secondary habitat is the tabaibal dulce (Echio-Euphorbietum balsamifera), on more stable rocky substrates. Its common accompanying species are Echium brevirame, Periploca laevigata, Rubia fruticosa, Kleinia neriifolia, Euphorbia obtusifolia, Paronychia canariensis, Aeonium spathulatum and Monanthes muralis (Rodríguez Delgado et al. 2004).
threats: Tourism has been described as the main threat to the species, including trampling, riding and the presence of non-motorised vehicles (Commission of the European Communities 2009). Occasional landslides and game activities have also been reported as threats (Rodríguez Delgado et al. 2004).
population: Its total population size has been estimated in 1,942 individuals and it is considered to have been stable throughout the past decades. A slight trend towards increasing its population size and colonize new areas has been observed (Commission of the European Communities 2009). The species tends to produce a high number of seedlings but these have been reported to show low growth and survival rates (Rodríguez Delgado et al. 2004).
range: Cheirolophus junonianus is endemic to the island of La Palma, the Canary Islands, Spain (Rodríguez Delgado et al. 2004), where it grows at an altitude between 200 and 425 m asl. It has two subpopulations in Fuencaliente, on the southern part of the island. Its area of occupancy is 2 km² and its extent of occurrence is lower than the area of this municipality, which is 56 km² (O. Rodríguez, A.García Gallo and G. Cruz pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: It has medicinal properties as hypoglycemic, cytostatic and antibiotic, due to its content of aguerina.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is classed EN B2ab(iii,v) in the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008). At regional level it is listed as species "de interés para los ecosistemas canarios" in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands.

The two locations are included in the protected area Monumento Natural de los Volcanes de Teneguía. Seeds have been collected and are stored in the germplasm banks Banco de Germoplasma del Jardín Botánico Canario Viera y Clavijo and Banco de Germoplasma de la ETSIA, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid.

In order to ensure the conservation of the species a surveillance and control programme has to be developed.

rationale: Lotus callis-viridis is listed as Endangered because its area of occupancy is 7 km² but fluctuations have been identified, it is found at two locations and there are extreme fluctuations in the number of mature individuals. Grazing, landslides and droughts limit the expansion of this species.
habitat:
This plant grows in small paths and ledges of vertical basaltic cliffs on the western coast of Gran Canaria. It occurs within rupicolous communities or sometimes within slightly nitrophile herbaceous communities, such as Soncho-Aeonion, Frankenio ericifoliae-Astydametum latifoliae and Aeonio-Euphorbion canariensis (Navarro et al. 2004). Frequent accompanying species are Aeonium virgineum, Descurainia artemisiodes, Lycium intricatum, Sonchus brachylobus and Reichardia ligulata.

It is a hermaphrodite species. This entomophilous plant produces flowers gradually from winter to spring. It presents high levels of propagation by cuttings and from seeds in nursery.
threats: The most important threat to this species is grazing (Navarro et al. 2004). Other threats are occasional landslides and droughts which can cause fluctuations in its population size and distribution. Road improvement works have been as well described as a threat to the subpopulation of Andén Verde.
population: Total population size has been reported to be 26,046 individuals (Navarro et al. 2004). Extreme fluctuations in the number of mature individuals have been observed. The location Andén Verde holds 99% of the total population size.
range: Lotus callis-viridis is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria, Canary Islands, Spain, where it grows from 100 to 575 m asl on the western part of the island, distributed into two locations: Andén Verde and Cantiles de Güí-Güí (Navarro et al. 2004). The area of occupancy has been reported to be 7 km² and to suffer from fluctuations.
conservationActions:
Lotus callis-viridis is listed on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species "de interés para los ecosistemas canarios" in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands. It is listed as Endangered B2ac(ii,iv) on the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).

The populations are included in the protected areas Parque Natural de Tamadaba (SCI) and Reserva Natural Especial de Güigüi (SCI). It is cultivated in the botanic garden Viera y Clavijo where there are also seeds stored in the germplasm bank.

Population size fluctuations must be monitored and activities within its distribution range must be controlled.

rationale: Helichrysum gossypinum is listed as Vulnerable due to its restricted distribution, with an area of occupancy of 13.5 km2. Predation and landslides limit its expansion, as well as occassional anthropogenic factors, such as road improvement works.
habitat: This species ocurrs in ridges, cliffs and slopes of ravines, within rupicolous communities such as Soncho-Aeonion (Commission of the European Communities 2009), Reichardio famarae-Helichrysetum gossypini and Aeonietum lancerotensis (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
threats:
Threats for the species are predation on seedlings and accessible individuals. Landslides also affect the species and its habitat has been reported to be geologically instable. Road construction or improvement works have been as well reported as negative factors.
Hybridisation with Helichrysum monogynum is also a threat (Reyes-Betancort and Léon Arencibia 2009).
population: Population has been estimated in 7,076 individuals (Commission of the European Communities 2009). The trend is unknown but believed to present certain stability (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). One subpopulation is fragmented.
range: This plant is endemic to Lanzarote, the Canary Islands (Euro+Med Plantbase 2006-2010). It can be found distributed throughout six subpopulations: El Jurado,  Riscos de Famara, Barranco del Cuchillo, Barranco de Chafarís, Ladera de  Tenegüime and Malpaís del Sobaco. Its area of occupancy is 13.5 km<sup>2</sup> (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species with “Protección Especial” in the national list of species in regime of special protection of Spain. It is listed as VU D2 in the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008).

The subpopulations occur within the protected areas Paisaje Protegido de La Geria, Paisaje Protegido Barranco de Tenegüime and Parque Natural Archipiélago Chinijo. Seeds are stored in the germplasm bank of Jardín Botánico Canario Viera y Clavijo.

rationale: Onopordum nogalesii is listed as Critically Endangered because its area of occupancy is probably lower than 1 km², its population size is estimated to be between 50  and 150 mature individuals, all in one single location, and decreasing trends and extreme fluctuations in the number of mature individuals have been reported. Overgrazing and seed predation by insects limit the expansion of the species.
habitat:
This species grows in slopes of moderate to low inclination, usually near the bottom of the ravine. It has preference for gullies, carved by runoff water, usually on stony clay soils, probably due to their favourable moisture conditions. Frequent accompanying species include Euphorbia regis-jubae, Kleinia neriifolia and Launaea arborescens, Salsola vermiculata, Lycium intricatum and Rubia fruticosa. In winter, dense communities of nitrophilous therophytes such as Chenopodium murale, Patellifolia patellaris, Emex spinosa, Echium bonneti, Reichardia tingitana and Stipa capensis, appear in its habitat.

It is a very adaptable species that can tolerate some presence of  herbivores and soil nitrification. Seed production and germination are very irregular, depending on heavy rains and seed predation by several insects. Pollination is by Hymenoptera, Lepidoptera and Coleoptera.
threats: This species takes profit from the presence of a certain amount of grazing species, due to its nitrophilous character. As livestock pressure increases, an important negative effect on the population can be observed, for flowers are predated (Scholz 2004). Seed predation by birds and insects, low germination rates and low survival of seedlings have also a great influence in population dynamics. A nearby passageway and the construction of tourist infrastructures located 2-3 km from the population is a potential threat. Moreover, it has been observed that it has been collected illegally for ornamental purposes and by scientists.
population: Total population size fluctuates between 50 and 150 individuals (S. Scholz pers. comm. 2011), mainly affected by climatic factors. Scholz reported 70 individuals (2004). In the last few years a decline in the number of individuals has been observed.
range: This plant is endemic to the island of Fuerteventura, Canary Islands, <st1:country-region w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Spain</st1:place></st1:country-region> (Scholz 2004). It can be found between 250 and 450 m asl, in a single known location, in  Valle or Barranco de Vinamar, in the peninsula of Jandía. Its area of occupancy has been estimated in between 1 and 3 km².
useTrade: The species is subject to illegal collection for ornamental or research purposes.
conservationActions:
Onopordum nogalesii is listed as priority species on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and is listed under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species "En peligro de extinción" in the national catalogue of threatened species, and in the catalogue of protected species of the Canary Islands, under the name Onopordon nogalesii. It is classed as CR B2ac(iv); C2a(ii) in the Spanish Red List 2008 (Moreno 2008).

The whole population occurs in the protected area Parque Natural de Jandía (SCI). Seeds are stored in the germplasm bank of the Jardín Botánico Viera y Clavijo and in the E.T.S. de Ingenieros Agrónomos de Madrid.

It is necessary to carry out surveys on the demography and reproductive biology of the species. Proposed conservation measures include the control of livestock in the Parque Natural de Jandía. Seed storage in germplasm banks and reintroduction measures are recommended.

rationale: Crambe laevigata is assessed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is no more than 100 km², its area of occupancy (AOO) is 0.003 km², all individuals are found at three locations, and the extent and quality of its habitat is declining, as is the number of mature individuals.
habitat: This plant has a woody base and grows to 170 cm. It exists within communities of Aeonietum canariensis and Vieraeo-Polycarpaeetum carnosae. It can be found on north-facing basaltic cliffs which are frequently humid due to the influence of trade winds. It is also possible to find it in Echio-Retametum rhodorhizoidis (Commission of the European Communities 2009). It seeks shelter in almost vertical deep ravines in west Tenerife. There is a high competition for the scarce soil on the narrow platforms where it is located, which limits the survival of seedlings.
threats: The main threats are grazing (in the Parque Rural de Teno), tourist paths and routes and the occasional natural events like landslides. <span id="result_box" class="medium_text">
population: The population has been determined in three different localities within the same municipality and has been estimated at 700 individuals.
range: Crambe laevigata is endemic to Tenerife (Macizo de Teno), one of  the Spanish Canary Islands. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 100 km² (Commission of the European Communities 2009).
