Tasartico: 976 individuals
range: This subspecies is endemic to the Gran Canaria in the Canary Islands. It occurs along the El Cedro-Horgazales massif on the west coast of the island.
conservationActions: The subspecies is found in the Special Natural Reserve of Güi-Güi and the Rural Park of El Nublo (LIC). It is in cultivation at the Botanical Garden of Viera and Clavijo and seeds (representing the four subpopulations) are stored in the seedbank at the same botanical garden. A project to investigate the ecology and reproduction of the subspecies has been undertaken.

rationale: The species is found in 12 subpopulations, only 2,000 individuals exist. Its area of occupancy is less than 5 km² and there is continuing decline in habitat and number of mature individuals.
habitat: This perennial herb grows on flat areas, mostly on the summits, in moist and shady fissures. It also colonizes moist talus in the fayal-brezal and monteverde forests.
threats: Traditionally, the major threat was grazing from introduced herbivores. Despite attempts to control the herbivores they are still threatening the species. Competition from other plants and the presence of alien species are also threatening this species.
population:
There are 12 confirmed subpopulations:

2 subpopulations on the summits of Tenerife: 136 individuals
3 subpopulations on the summits of Hierro: 151 individuals
7 subpopulations on the summits of La Palma: 1,057 individuals
range: The species is endemic to the Canary Islands. The subpopulations are found on the  islands of Tenerife, La Palma and El Hierro.
conservationActions:
Actions in Place
All the main subpopulatiuons are included in various natural protected sites (LIC). Seeds are stored in the seedbanks of E.T.S. de Ingenieros Agrónomos and of the Botanical Garden of Viera and Clavijo.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is probably less than 20,000 km², its area of occupancy (AOO) is probably less than 2,000 km² and there is a continuing decline in the AOO and the habitat of the  species due to strong anthropogenic pressure (agriculture, tourism),  thus qualifying the species for Vulnerable.
habitat: The habitats used by Colletes dimidiatus are unknown but likely are open vegetation types (e.g., Mediterranean shrub lands) that are declining on the Canary Islands. No information is available on flower visitation (Müller and Kuhlmann 2008).
threats: Likely threats are the anthropogenic loss (agriculture, touristic developments) of habitat (e.g., open vegetation types with bare soil), nesting sites and host plants, particularly on the dry southern parts of the Canary Islands that are prime tourist destinations.
population: The populations of Colletes dimidiatus are likely to be small and seem to be isolated, presumably with no or little genetic exchange between them. This species is therefore considered severely fragmented given the extent of agricultural land transformation and touristic developments in lower parts of the Canary Islands; however, little information is currently available. A continuous decline in the habitat and also of the population size of the species can be assumed.
range: Colletes dimidiatus is endemic to the Canary Islands where it is known from the islands of Gran Canaria, Tenerife, Gomera, El Hierro and La Palma (Hohmann et al. 1993, Kuhlmann et al. 2012). The extent of occurrence (EOO) in Europe and the EU 27 is 22,196 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 124 km². However the EOO includes unsuitable habitat (e.g., ocean) so the EOO is smaller (less than 20,000 km²). The AOO is probably larger (though less than 2,000 km²), as the species has probably been under-recorded.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
This species is not listed in any National Red List or Red Data Book, and is not the subject of any targeted conservation action. It is recommended to conserve suitable habitats (e.g., open vegetation types with bare soil), nesting sites and the host plants of this species.

Further research is required to establish the current status of the species throughout its range and to identify the existing threats and trends.

It is not known if the species occurs in any protected area.

rationale: Listed  as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,342 km², the  area of occupancy (AOO) is 56 km² (species is under-recorded so AOO is probably larger, although less  than 2,000 km²), the species is severely fragmented and there is a continuing  decline in the AOO and extent and quality of the habitat of the species due to strong anthropogenic  pressure (agriculture, tourism).
habitat: The specific habitats used by Colletes moricei are unknown but likely are open vegetation types (e.g., Mediterranean shrub lands). Within its range the natural habitats have been transformed on large scale as a result of anthropogenic pressure (particularly agriculture and tourism). No information is available on flower visitation (Müller and Kuhlmann 2008).
threats: Likely threats are the anthropogenic loss (agriculture, touristic developments) of habitat (e.g., open vegetation types with bare soil), nesting sites and host plants.
population: The populations of Colletes moricei are likely to be small and fragmented given the extent of agricultural land transformation and touristic developments on the lower parts of the Canary Islands, but little information is currently available. The population trends are unknown.
range: Colletes moricei is endemic to the Canary Islands where it is known from the islands of Gran Canaria, Tenerife, Gomera and La Palma (Hohmann et al. 1993, Kuhlmann et al. 2012). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,342 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 56 km². However, the AOO is probably larger (though less than 2,000 km²), as the species has most likely been under-recorded.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
This species is not listed in any National Red List or Red Data Book, and is not the subject of any targeted conservation action. It is recommended to conserve suitable habitats (e.g., open vegetation types with bare soil), nesting sites and the host plants of this species.

Further research is required to establish the current status of the species throughout its range and to identify the existing threats.

It is not known if the species occurs in any protected area.

rationale: Listed  as Least Concern in view of its overall stable population. However, the species has a small area of occupancy  (AOO) of 52 km² and is potentially threatened by urbanization.
habitat: This species inhabits sandy soils in coastal areas.
threats: The species is probably threatened by urbanization.
population: The species is not rare. The population trend is possibly stable.
range: Halictus concinnus is endemic to the Canary Islands (Ebmer 1972). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 38,124 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 52 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, general ecology and threats of this species.

rationale: Cenchrus ciliaris is widespread throughout its native region of Africa, Indonesia, Arabia, Pakistan, Canary Islands, Madagascar and India. It is a common species and occurs in a variety of habitats and over a range of altitudes, up to 2,000 m asl and, within this very large extent of occurrence (EOO), the area of occupancy (AOO) is also inferred to exceed the values for a threatened category.  The population is currently believed to be stable, the only known threat is a fungal blight, occurring in Texas and India. The species also occurs as an invasive species in a number of other countries. Therefore it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: A common caespitose grass which grows in heavy, limestone and sandy soils, in desert conditions, and dry tropical savannas. It can tolerate low pH, and is drought tolerant (Marshall 2012, CABI 2014).
threats:
The distribution falls within one Conservation International Biodiversity Hotspot of Magagascar. 

There is currently a known threat for this species in Texas, USA, although this is not its native region, as well as in India. A fungal blight caused by the heterothallic ascomycete fungus Magnaporthe grisea is affecting this species. Since Cenchrus ciliaris reproduces by apomixis (an asexual method of seed production), there is very little genetic diversity in its stands. Therefore, strains of Cenchrus ciliaris that are resistant to Magnaporthe grisea are not likely to develop naturally. Until disease resistant strains are developed, the blight will continue to cause enormous damage to Cenchrus ciliaris pastures in Texas (Morisawa 2000). This disease has become a serious threat to both forage and grain production in Pearl Millet in India (Sharma 2013). It is not known whether this will pose a future threat to other populations within its native range, more research will be needed.
population: This species is common and widespread in its native range.
range: Cenchrus ciliaris is native to Africa, (Ghana, Kenya, Mali, Madagascar, Mozambique, Morocco, Namibia, Nigeria, Senegal, Sudan, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, Zimbabwe, South Africa, Botswana, Niger), Indonesia, Pakistan (Sind, Baluchistan, Punjab & N.W.F.P.) Afghanistan, Canary Islands, Egypt, Ethiopia, India, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Syrian Arab Republic, and Sicily (ARS-GRIN) . It occurs at elevations from sea level up to 2,000 m asl. It grows as an introduction in North, Central and South America as well as Australia.
useTrade: This grass is used widely in tropical and sub-tropical arid rangelands around the globe as a pastoral species, due to its high nutritional value to sheep and cattle, high tolerance to drought and an ability to withstand heavy grazing (Marshall 2012). It is a relative of, and potential gene donor to the crop Pearl Millet.
conservationActions:
The National Plant Germplasm System holds 950 germplasm accessions of this species. The Millennium Seed Bank Partnership has 39 accessions. Seed is also conserved ex-situ at the Svalbard Global Seed Vault with 20 germplasm accessions (7,700 seed). With 375 accessions in Australia (Genesys accessed 2017). Seed is collected and stored in situ in Kenya as well as sent to the Millennium Seed Bank Partnership, as part of the Adapting Agriculture to Climate Change project (Dempewolf et al 2014).

According to the Red List of South African Plants and the Jordan Plant Red List, this species is assessed as Least Concern (Fish 2005, Taifour 2014).

There are no known conservation measures specifically for this species, however its native distribution overlaps with several protected areas in Tropical Africa, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) so passive conservation is presumed in these areas. However, there is no evidence of active management or monitoring of this species.

The genus Pennisetum (syn. Cenchrus) is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The species grows in shallow,  still or slow-moving, circumneutral to basic waters of lakes and rivers (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some states in the USA and Provinces in Canada are classed as 'Critically Imperiled', 'Imperiled' or 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011+) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
range: The species is widespread across USA and Canada and it has been introduced in Europe, Asia, Africa and Australia (NatureServe 2014; eMonocot Team 2015).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for the species are known, or likely to be needed.

rationale:
Alpinia zerumbet is assessed as Data Deficient. This species is known to have naturalised in several areas (WCSP 2019) making the natural distribution and status of the natural population uncertain.

It has also been pointed that this species name is applied to multiple taxa within a complex of numerous cryptic species many of which are cultivated as ornametals, leading to the very wide distribution pattern. Further taxonomic studies are needed to better understand the true identity of A. zerumbet and the possible taxa embedded in this complex (J. Leong-Škorničková pers. comm. 2020).
habitat: This is a perennial herb.
threats: Threats to the natural population are unknown.
population: The size and trend of the natural population are unknown.
range: This is a widespread species and has been recorded from South China to Peninsular Malaysia as well as Japan and Taiwan (Persoon 1805, WCSP 2019, ZRC 2019, Larsen and Larsen 2006). It has also naturalised in several countries in and outside of Asia (WCSP 2019). The natural distribution is therefore uncertain.
useTrade: The species is cultivated and traded for its ornamental qualities.
conservationActions:
This species has been recorded by BGCI (2019) to be grown in more than 170 ex situ collections. It is not known if naturally occurring individuals can be found in protected areas.

A national assessment from Taiwan, made in 2012, assessed the species as Least Concern (Wang et al. 2012).

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations throughout most of its range and does not face any major threats.
habitat: The species typically grows on seasonally inundated muddy depressions  the drawdown zones of ponds, lakes and reservoirs, and on islands, bars and the margins of rivers. Competition with perennial plants, particularly grasses, is suppressed either naturally such as by seasonal variation in water levels or anthropogenic actions such as poaching by cattle.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is little information available on populations in the species; it is widespread and abundant throughout much of its European range, although there have been losses in peripheral regions (e.g. Preston et al. 2002).
range: This species occurs from Macaronesia through Europe and the Mediterranean, Yemen, east to China and Viet Nam, it is introduced to North America; it is considered to have been introduced to Canada, the United States and the Leeward Islands (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010).
useTrade: There is no evidence to suggest that this species is used.
conservationActions: In the UK, all sites are protected as SSSIs, the species is protected under the Wildlife and Countryside Act (1981) and it is the subject of a Biodiversity Action Plan (BAP). In the Czech Republic the species is categorized Critically Endangered (Prochazka 2001), in Austria it is classed Vulnerable (Niklfeld and Schratt-Ehrendorfer 1999). Outside these areas there are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: This species has an extremely broad distribution, occurs in a range of habitats and is not subject to any known significant threats. It is therefore classed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species typically occurs in moist alluvial meadows, grassland, swamps, around lake margins and as a weed in gardens and fields (Kukkonen 1998, Lye 1997).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats.
population: There is no information on population trends in this species.
range: In the Old World, this species occurs from the Iberian Peninsula through North Africa south to South Africa, east through the Middle East and the Indian subcontinent to East Asia and south through South-east Asia to Australia It also occurs in the New World from Mexico south through Mesoamerica and the Caribbean to Suriname and Venezuela. In the Arabian Peninsula, this species is found locally in Oman and Yemen (Jongbloed 2003, Al Khulaidi in prep., A. Patzelt pers. comm.), in Saudi Arabia and in Bahrain (S. Knees pers. comm. 2012).
useTrade: There is no evidence that this species is used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread and does not face any known threats.
habitat: This species is found in seasonally inundated grassland and along streams (Kirschner et al. 2002).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range:
This species occurs throughout the Mediterranean countries, east through the Middle East to Turkmenistan and Pakistan (Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Garden, Kew 2012).

J. fontanesii is considered to be polymorphic (no subspecies identified) in most of the western Mediterranean.
- The subspecies pyramidatus is found in Egypt, Italy (Sardinia, Sicily), Greece, Cyprus, Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, Turkey, Iraq, Arabia (Boulos, 2005) and Iran, Ethiopia and Kenya (Maire, 1957).
- The subspecies fontanesii Maire (=eu-fontanesii Maire in J. & M.) is present in Libya (Aïn-Mara), Tunisia (common in the north to Gafsa), Algeria (very common in the the Tell, High Plains and Saharian Atlas), in Morocco (very common in Northern to Anti-Atlas mountains), in Corse (very rare).
- The subspecies brachyanthus has been observed at the banks of Mekerra (western Algeria), in Morocco (Taourirt, Oued Za); common in the mountains (Beni-Snassen, Rif, Atlas and Anti-Atlas). This subspecies, var. melanocephalus particularly, is considered as endemic to Morocco by Maire (1957) and forgotten by Valdès et al. (2002).
useTrade: There is no evidence that this species is used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because it is widespread, able to exploit anthropogenic habitats and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This is a short-lived perennial found in small colonies by permanently wet and often seasonally flooded springs, flushed sea-cliffs, puddles, ditches, lagoons and lake shores. It is limited to very open mesic, often calcareous or somewhat saline soils. Populations are often impermanent, colonizing the small and transient specialized habitats which change as spring lines and water levels shift. Individuals are usually monocarpic, but may take several years to flower (Preston et al. 2002). It has also been reported from reed (Phragmites spp.) stands, wet pastures, and saline meadows.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: This species has an almost cosmopolitan distribution occurring almost worldwide except parts of western Australia, sub-Saharan Africa and South America.
useTrade: There is no evidence that this species is used.
conservationActions: In Hungary, the species is classed as Near Threatened and under national protection (Király 2007) and it is classed as Critically Endangered in Czech Republic (Holub and Procházka 2000). There are no further conservation measures in place or needed at global level.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern at global level as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: R. trichophyllus will occur in most types of mesotrophic to eutrophic water body, from dune slacks and drainage ditches to ponds, lakes, streams and slow-flowing rivers.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information on population trends in this species.
range: Ranunculus trichophyllus occurs throughout much of the Northern Hemisphere, from the Mediterranean east through Siberia, the Caucasus, the Middle East, the Himalayas, Kazakhstan and Mongolia to Kamchatka in the Russian Far East, Japan, China and the Korean Peninsula, it also occurs across central North America.
useTrade: The specie is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern as it is widespread, able to exploit anthropogenic habitats and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species occurs in a wide variety of habitats, from marshes and seasonally inundated grassland to the margins of lakes, ponds, rivers and streams, as well as temporary pools in arable fields.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: This species occurs from Europe south to North Africa and east through the Middle East, the Caucasus, Siberia and Kazakhstan to the Russian Far East and China.
useTrade: There is no evidence that this species is used.
conservationActions: This species is classed as Critically Endangered in Switzerland and Vulnerable in Austria. Otherwise, there are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species typically grows in marshy areas near or on the coast, including the upper limits of salt marshes and wetland systems behind beaches.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout most of the world, with most populations the result of introductions and evidence to suggest that overall the species is increasing. Most populations of this species throughout its European range (and therefore most native populations) appear to be stable, although there is concern over its status in Sweden.
range: This species is apparently native to much of Europe, North Africa, Siberia and the Caucasus, it has been introduced throughout much of the rest of the world and its true native distribution is now almost impossible to establish because it is obscured by introduction. It is certainly considered to be non-native in China (Menglan and Watson 2005) and Australia (Rechinger 1987), other areas of occurrence are very difficult to establish.
useTrade: This cosmopolitan species is cultivated as a vegetable (celery and celeriac) and has been since ancient times; it features in the herbal medicinal traditions of many civilizations. All parts of the plant are used in traditional Chinese medicine as the dietary herb “qin” (also known as “han qin” and “qin cai”) (Menglan and Watson 2005).
conservationActions: This species is listed as Critically Endangered in Sweden, but this is understood to refer to a very small native population in the south and at the northern limits of the native range of the species, rather than a decline.   There are no other conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species occurs in a wide variety of wetland habitats usually on nutrient-rich, neutral soils, such as the margins of rivers, streams, lakes, ponds, canals and ditches as well as in marshy grassland and anthropogenic habitats such as gravel pits.
threats: At the Central European margins of its distribution, eutrophication has been noticed as threat factor. But in most parts of its range there are no known past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout much of its range and the populations are stable or increasing in most parts of its range.
range: This species occurs from the Azores and Canary Islands to North Africa, east to Iraq and the Arabian Peninsula and Pakistan and north to Estonia. It is naturalized in North America (California).
useTrade: There is no evidence that this species is used.
conservationActions: A. nodiflorum is classed as Critically Endangered in Switzerland, and as Vulnerable in Germany. Conservation measures on a local to national scale seem appropriate there and elsewhere in Central Europe. In Bulgaria, it is protected by the national Biodiversity Act. Otherwise, there are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern because it is widespread and does not face any major threats.
habitat: The species is found in open woods, meadows and dry grasslands, often on chalky soils and particularly in seasonally damp, sandy depressions.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its European range, there is no information available on native populations outside this region, but it is naturalized over a wide area where it is likely to be increasing.
range: This species is native throughout Europe, south to North Africa and east through Eastern Europe to the Middle East and Pakistan. It has been introduced to a wide area, including Australia, New Zealand, Canada, the United States and scattered localities in Central and South America.
useTrade: One of the most useful bitter herbs, Centaury strengthens digestive function, especially within the stomach. By increasing stomach secretions it hastens the breakdown of food, it also stimulates the appetite and increases bile production. The plant needs to be take over a number of weeks and an infusion should be slowly sipped so that the components (their bitterness can be detected at a dilution of 1:3,500) can stimulate reflex activity throughout the upper digestive tract. The whole herb is appetizer, aromatic, bitter, cholagogue, diaphoretic, digestive, emetic, weakly febrifuge, hepatic, stomachic and tonic. It acts on the liver and kidneys, purifies the blood and is an excellent tonic for the digestive system. Externally, the fresh green herb is said to be a good application to wounds and sores. It is often used in combination with other herbs such as camomile (Chamaemelum nobile), meadowsweet (Filipendula ulmaria) and marshmallow (Althaea officinalis). The whole plant is harvested when in flower and can be dried for later use. A homeopathic remedy is made from the plant. It is used in the treatment of liver and gall bladder ailments (Plants for a Future 1996-2010).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: Sympetrum fonscolombii is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, its colonizing capacity, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: Sympetrum fonscolombii is found in, and reproduces in, a wide range of habitats (permanent and ephemeral shallow and sunny standing waters, man-made barrage lakes, tanks and ponds, permanent and seasonal rivers and wadis).
threats: This is a widespread and colonizing species which is very common, sometimes in huge numbers, in warm countries. It is not threatened.
population: The species is common and widespread throughout most of its range and is able to (re)colonize promptly formerly dry areas after any rainfall period.
range: Sympetrum fonscolombii is a widespread and common species found from the south to the north of Africa, including Madagascar, southern Europe and eastwards to the Middle East, Central Asia, the Indian Subcontinent and the Indian Ocean Islands. Its African range is often exaggerated (Dumont and Martens 1988). The species becomes scarcer towards the north but has expanded its range considerably in the last decades and is now common in most of Central Europe. It has a nomadic behaviour and shows a strong tendency to migrate, and has been found northwards as far as Scotland, the Swedish island of Öland and Latvia. It is likely that climate change will promote a further northwards expansion in the future.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation action is needed for this species.

rationale: Cyperus nutans is a widely distributed and common plant. There are no major widespread threats known and it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: It is found growing commonly in swamps, rice fields, near river banks, pools, streams and seasonally flooded areas. It is found growing from sea level to 2600 m (Cook 1996, Pulliah 1997).
threats: There are no known threats to this widespread species.
population: It is a common species.
range:
Cyperus nutans is distributed in tropical Africa, Asia and Australia. 
In India it is found in Andhra Pradesh, Maharastra, Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala and Tamil Nadu (Singh et al. 2001, Sharma et al. 1984, Pulliah 1997).  This species is widespread in tropical Africa and Asia to Australia. 
In Africa it occurs in Nigeria, Sudan, Uganda, Angola, Mozambique, Ethiopia and Eritrea.
In the Arabian Peninsula this species has been reported from only one record in Wadi Sarfait on Jabal Qamar in Oman (Radcliffe-Smith 1980).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It occurs in the Mahananda Wildlife Sanctuary, Maharasthtra.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient as there is no information on population size or trends, habitat, ecology, or threats. Further research may increase the threat status of this species, which is restricted to the Canary Islands in Spain, and has a relatively small extent of occurrence (EOO) and a smaller area of occupancy (AOO).
habitat: There are few details of habitat or ecology of this species. However, since Andrena sagittaria belongs to the sub-genus Chlorandrena, it will be a specialist forager on various Asteraceae flowers.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available on either overall population size or trends.
range: Andrena sagittaria is endemic to Tenerife and La Gomera (Canary Islands, Spain) (Kuhlmann et. al 2013).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed on any National Red Lists or Red Data Books and is not the subject of any targeted conservation action. It is not known if the species is found in any protected areas throughout its range. <span lang="EN-GB">Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale:
Listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread throughout the Macaronesian Islands, the populations are presumed to be stable and there are no major threats to the species.

 .
habitat:
Andrena wollastoni occurs throughout a wide spectrum of habitats from the coast line to the hilltop of Pico do Arieiro (Madeira) at an altitude of 1,750 m. This species occurs on sand beaches, slopes covered with shrubs, dry rocky grasslands, ruderal sites and abandoned fields. It is a bivoltine species (it has two generations): the first generation flies from mid January until March while the second generation flies from May until July, and in the mountains until mid-August. 

The females and males have been detected on 26 plant taxa belonging to 11 plant families: Apiaceae (Melanoselinum decipiens), Asteraceae (Argyranthemum frutescens, Agyranthemum pinnatifidum succulentum, Ageratina adenophora, Chrysanthemum segetum, Crepis vesicaria haenseleri, Leontodon taraxacoides, Sonchus oleraceus), Boraginaceae (Echium candicans and Echium nervosum), Brassicaceae (Cakile maritima, Raphanus raphanistrum, Rapistrum rugosum, Sinapis arvensis, Sinapis sp., Sisymbrium officinale), Crassulaceae (Aeonium glandulosum, Aichryson villosum), Euphorbiaceae (Euphorbia sp.), Geraniaceae (Geranium maderense) and Resedaceae (Reseda luteola). Females are thought to give some preference to flowers of Asteraceae species. Females also collect pollen predominantly from native and endemic plants compared with introduced and cultivated plant species (Valido and Olesen 2010, Kratochwil and Scheuchl 2013).
threats: There are no known major threats to the species.
population: The populations of Andrena wollastoni are likely to be stable. In Madeira and the Porto Santo Islands, 37 specimens in 2005, and eight specimens (during only four days) in 2007 were collected.
range:
An endemic species to Macaronesia: the Canary Islands (El Hierro, La Gomera, La Palma, Tenerife and Gran Canaria) as well as Madeira (Saunders 1904, Cockerell 1922, Alfken 1940, Lieftinck 1958, Warncke 1967b, Warncke 1968, Báez and Ortega 1978, Warncke 1993, Fellendorf et al. 1999, Valido and Olesen 2010, Kratochwil and Scheuchl 2013). 

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 141,258 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 192 km².
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas.

rationale: Aegilops geniculata is widely distributed in Europe, western and middle Asia and northern Africa. Its population is noted to be common and stable (van Slageren 1994) and there are no major threats throughout its native range. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern. It is thought to be well conserved ex situ and is presumed to occur in a number of protected areas. However, research is needed to confirm its in situ conservation status and subpopulations require monitoring.
habitat: This plant is found in dry, disturbed habitats such as fallow, wastelands, roadsides and dry rocky slopes of hillsides and mountainsides, as well as growing on the edge of and within olive groves, vineyards, fruit tree plantations and cereal fields (barley and wheat of which it forms natural hybrids; van Slageren 1994). The same author notes that it grows in varying soil types (clay and sandy loam, clay and gravel)  and is able to grow in very stony and rocky soils and under a wide range of average annual rainfall (200–700 mm). It prefers bedrock of limestone but also shales, pillow lava, silicate, Mediterranean terra rosa, karst, basalt and sandstone (van Slageren 1994).
threats: There are no major threats to the species throughout most of its distribution. However, the European regional assessment (Duarte et al. 2013) reports that in the places where the species is adventive, strong winters can cause it to disappear. In Bulgaria the change of land use, such as the intensification of agriculture can affect the species.
population: This species is reported to be common throughout its range (van Slageren 1994).
range: Aegilops geniculata is native to middle, east, southeast and southwest Europe, western Asia, the Caucasus, northern Africa and Macaronesia (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It occurs at elevations between sea level and 1,750 m asl (van Slageren 1994).
useTrade: This species is a secondary wild relative of wheat and has been used to confer disease resistance to the crop, as well as having been identified as having potential to confer pest resistance (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). Specifically, it is recorded to have been used successfully to transfer Hessian fly resistance to wheat (El Khlifi et al. 2004).
conservationActions:
The genus Aegilops is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) as part of the wheat gene pool.

Aegilops geniculata has been assessed as Least Concern (LC) in Bulgaria (Petrova and Vladimirov 2009), in Jordan (Taifour and El-Oqlah 2014), in Europe and EU 27 (Duarte et al. 2013).

There are 1,118 germplasm accessions of wild origin reported by Genesys of which 590 are backed up at a second genebank. Furthermore, 365 accessions are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Seed Vault. Out of the 1,118 accessions, 1043 were collected within the species' native range (170 from Portugal, 171 from Spain, 149 from Turkey, 95 from Greece, 78 from Syria, 51 from Morocco, 47 from France, 44 from Lebanon, 43 from Jordan, 42 from Cyprus, 36 from Algeria, 32 from Italy, 31 from Lybia, 28 from Bulgaria, eight from Tunisia, seven from the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, six from Croatia, three from Croatia and two from Ukraine). Further six accessions were collected from outside the species' known native range (Kazakhstan) and 69 are from undisclosed country of origin (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013), this species has living collections in 13 botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

From its known distribution, and using the GeoCAT tool (Bachman et al. 2011), it is assumed that this species occurs in several protected areas in Italy, Serbia, Romania and Bulgaria, including the Parco Del Somma-Vesuvio e Miglio D'Oro, (Italy) and the Cheile Nerei-Beuşniţa National Park and Scientific Reserve (Romania) (EEA 2013, Information Center for the Environment (ICE) 2013). However, it is unlikely that active in situ conservation measures are in place, therefore research to confirm this and promote population monitoring and management is recommended for these sites.

rationale: This species is documented to be widespread and abundant throughout most of its range and so is globally assessed as Least Concern. However, research into population trends, threats and provision of in situ conservation for this species is recommended.
habitat:
It is usually found in fields, areas formerly cultivated, vineyards and on roadsides; more rarely it can be found on rocky hillsides, cliffs and coastal beaches, and in pine forests (Korpelainen et al. 2013). For example in the UK it occurs near the sea in sandy and rocky areas, as well as in disturbed areas such as old fields and hedge banks, sheltered cliff-slopes, alongside paths and in drainage ditches (Preston et al. 2002).

In Cyprus it occurs in fields and wasteland, or on stony hillsides, especially near the coast; flowering from May to June (Viney 1994). In Spain and Portugal this species has been found in forest clearings, scrub lands, meadows, dunes, cliffs, crop areas, wastelands, marsh, roadsides and salt marshes (Korpelainen et al. 2013).

The altitudinal range of this species is 0–2,000 m (Mathew 1996).
threats: There are no major threats to this widespread species.
population: This species is widespread across south and west Europe, particularly in Mediterranean regions, and has a fairly limited distribution in the UK (found in southwest England, Guernsey, the northern coast of Wales, the east of Northern Island and one locality in Scotland) (Preston et al. 2002, Korpelainen et al. 2013). Korpelainen et al. (2013) highlight the need for further research to gather information about the population size and trend of this species across its full native range.
range:
Allium ampeloprasum is recorded as native to north, east, southeast and southwest Europe, northern Africa, Macaronesia, western Asia, the Caucasus and the Arabian Peninsula; it is naturalized in the Azores (Portugal) and the United States of America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2013) reports that this species is naturalized far beyond its native range, being present in most of eastern Europe (Belarus, Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, throughout northwest, east, south and central European Russia), Pakistan, Australia (New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia), Mexico (central, northeast, northwest and southwest regions), the Caribbean (Cuba, Dominican Republic, Haiti, and Puerto Rico) and northeast Argentina. Additionally, it is reported that Allium ampeloprasum is cultivated in Kenya, temperate and tropical Asia, Australia, Europe, northern America (Mexico, USA) and Chile (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
useTrade: Allium ampeloprasum is a primary wild relative of and potential gene donor to Leek A. porrum L., and a tertiary wild relative of and potential gene donor to a number of other crops in the Allium group, including Onion A. cepa L., Welsh Onion A. fistulosum L., Garlic A. sativum L. and Chives A. schoenoprasum L. (Korpelainen et al. 2013). It has been used as a gene donor in crop improvement programmes for Leek A. porrum for Yellow Stripe Rust resistance (van de Meer 1984) and for Garlic A. sativum utilizing various useful agronomic traits (Yanagino et al. 2003). It is also cultivated in Kenya, temperate and tropical Asia, Australia, Europe, northern America (Mexico, USA) and Chile (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
conservationActions:
Information is needed on the precise distribution, habitat, population size, trend and potential threats, as well as its in situ conservation status.

EURISCO reports 404 accessions of Allium ampeloprasum held in European genebanks, 28 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin. Of the wild accessions, 16 originate from within Europe. Eight of these are recorded as originating from Portugal, one from Greece, six from Yugoslavia and one from Malta (EURISCO Catalogue 2010).

Furthermore, 89 accessions (46,841 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault from three genebanks, as well as a further 66 accessions (34,000 seeds) being conserved from two genebanks under the species name Allium porrum (a synonym of A. ampeloprasum) (SGSV Data Portal 2013).

According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has at least 35 living collections in botanical gardens worldwide, although the origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

rationale: Avena fatua is assessed as Least Concern as it is very widespread throughout Europe, Asia and northern Africa with a stable population and no known threats. It is also able to grow in a wide range of disturbed habitats as a weed. In Europe it is also regionally assessed as Least Concern (Duarte et al. 2011).
habitat: Avena fatua grows as a weed, and is probably one of the most noxious weeds of cultivation in temperate and north-temperate areas. It grows among field crops, in waste places, along disturbed river banks, in orchards, along shoulders of highways, beside railroad tracks, on sand, in oases, beside docks, on limestone rocky soil, in disturbed wood clearings and in valleys. It is normally locally abundant and thrives particularly well in cultivated oat fields and among cereals in general (Baum 1977).
threats: There currently are no major threats to this species (Duarte et al. 2011).
population: It is reported to be common throughout its range in Europe with a stable European population trend (Duarte et al. 2011). Due to its vast global distribution, it is suspected that it is also globally stable.
range: Avena fatua is an extremely widespread species occurring across the majority of Europe, in temperate Asia, India, Nepal and Pakistan in tropical Asia and also in North Africa. There is some uncertainty over its exact native range as it is also widely naturalized across temperate Asia (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2016).
useTrade: Avena fatua is a primary genetic relative of Oats (Avena sativa L.) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (Jellen and Leggett 2005, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).
conservationActions:
The genus Avena is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) (FAO 2009).

The Global Biodiversity Information Facility reports 7,165 accessions in gene banks globally (GBIF 2013). The EURISCO Catalogue (2013) reports 343 accessions for this species, however only 12 of these are known to be of wild origin and the origin is undisclosed for a further 150 of the accessions, which could have originated either from cultivation or from the wild. A total of 1,292 accessions are held in the National Plant Germplasm System, all of which are of wild origin and duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). Furthermore, 242 accessions (110,159 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from six genebanks (SGSV Data Portal 2013).

In addition, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 32 botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

In terms of in situ conservation, this species is known to occur in a number of protected areas throughout its distribution, inferred by GeoCAT using existing distribution data (Bachman et al. 2011).

rationale: Avena sterilis is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread throughout Africa, temperate Asia, the Indian sub-continent and Europe and common throughout this range. It is also regionally assessed as Least Concern in Europe. There are no major threats and its population is stable. It is conserved well ex situ and occurs in a number of protected areas.
habitat: Grows on dry wasteland, cultivated ground and meadows, especially on heavier soils. A. sterilis invades and lowers the quality of a field crop, competes for resources with the crops and contaminates cereal grains and seeds. It has been identified as one of the most serious threats to wheat and barley production in East Africa (CABI Crop Compendium 2012).
threats: There are currently no major threats to the species (Duarte et al. 2011).
population: According to Duarte et al. (2011), it is a common weed of cereal crops and considered as a highly noxious weed because of its strong herbicide resistance. The same authors report that its population is stable across Europe. Its widespread distribution across Europe, North Africa and Asia suggests that its population is also globally stable.
range: Avena sterilis is native to northern Africa, temperate Asia, Pakistan and India in the Indian sub-continent and throughout Europe. It is widely naturalized elsewhere (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
useTrade: Avena sterilis is a primary genetic relative of Oats (Avena sativa) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (Jellen and Leggett 2005, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It is a source of disease resistance and high yields in Oats (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
conservationActions:
The genus Avena is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) (FAO 2009).

Due to the widespread, weedy nature of this species, active in situ conservation is not required. It does, however, already occur in a number of protected areas (Bachman et al. 2011).

EURISCO reports 2,084 germplasm accessions held in European genebanks, 1,654 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin, and 205 of which have no reported information regarding their origin (EURISCO Catalogue 2013). A total of 7,910 germplasm accessions of this species are held in the National Plant Germplasm System, all of which are of wild origin and 7,841 of those are duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). Furthermore, 926 accessions (236,087 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from six genebanks (SGSV Data Portal 2013).

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 19 botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

rationale: Brassica nigra is widely distributed in many parts of Europe, temperate Asia, and northern and northeast tropical Africa with stable subpopulations. As this species is widespread and there are no  major threats reported, it is globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Brassica nigra is found as a ruderal species across Europe, occurring on riverbanks, modified farmland and roadside verges (Korpelainen et al. 2011). According to Preston et al. (2002), this is a lowland species in the United Kingdom, present by rivers, on sea-cliffs, by roadsides, on waste grounds and also at the edges of arable fields. In the Netherlands it occurs in pioneer and ruderal vegetation on fertile and humid soils (Tamis et al. 2003). It is now a weed in waste places (OECD 2016).
threats: There are currently no major threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread in France, Romania and Portugal, forming persistent subpopulations in the United Kingdom and exists in scattered, isolated subpopulations in Spain (Korpelainen et al. 2011). Currently, the species is known to occur in 3,001–10,000 km2 in the Netherlands (Tamis et al. 2003). It is thought to have a stable population trend across Europe (Korpelainen et al. 2011) and it is also thought to be stable across its entire native range.
range: Brassica nigra is thought to be native to many parts of Europe, as well as temperate Asia, and northern and northeast tropical Africa; however, it is widely naturalized and its exact native range is unknown (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019). Its widespread distribution is most probably due to the fact that it is one of the oldest recorded species crops (OECD 2016). According to the available records it occurs from 0 to 2,758 m asl (GBIF.org 2019).
useTrade:
Wild subpopulations of Brassica nigra are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, black mustard. Black mustard was the world's major source of pungent mustard and used to be widely grown for the sharp pungency of its seeds and as a leaf vegetable until the 1950s (OECD 2016). Only a decade afterwards it was completely displaced by the higher yielding and better suited to mechanical harvesting B. juncea (OECD 2016). Currently, it is only cultivated occasionally in warmer, shorter day-length locations of oilseed rape growing regions (OECD 2016). It is the oldest recorded spices as evidenced by the Sanskrit writings of about 3000 BC (Prakash 1961).

It is also a secondary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to Ethiopian cabbage, mustard, broccoli, Brussels sprout, cabbage, cauliflower, kale and perennial wall rocket. It is also a tertiary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to swede, oilseed rape, turnip, radish and white mustard (Vincent et al. 2013). It is widely cultivated as a food additive (black mustard) and is known for its use as a soil improver and for medicinal purposes (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019) since the Greek civilization (Branca and Cartea 2011). This species is also a poison to mammals, a potential seed contaminant (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019) and important for bee pollinators.
conservationActions:
The genus Brassica is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Brassica gene pool (FAO 2009). Brassica nigra is listed as Least Concern in China (Ministry of Environment Protection of the People's Republic of China 2013), Ireland (Wyse Jackson et al. 2016), Jordan (Taifour and El-Oqlah 2014), Luxembourg (Colling 2005), England (Stroh et al. 2014), Great Britain (Cheffings et al. 2005), the Netherlands (Sparrius et al. 2014), Europe (Korpelainen et al. 2011), as well as Data Deficient (DD) in Hungary (Király 2007), Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002) and as "not threatened" in Germany using non-IUCN categories and criteria (Schnittler et al. 1994).
There are 90 germplasm accessions of wild origin reported by Genesys of which 30 are backed up at a second genebank, including 13 duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Seed Vault. Out of the 90 accessions, 68 were collected within the species' native range (23 in Israel, eight in Bulgaria, seven in Spain, six in France and Italy, five in Turkey, four in Ireland, three in Germany, two in Greece, one in Albania, United Kingdom and Ukraine). A further 11 were collected outside the species' native range (three in Portugal, two in Ethiopia and United States, one in Azerbaijan, Chile, Denmark and one from Japan) and 11 come from undisclosed country of origin (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2019).
As it is a very widespread species several subpopulations occur in existing protected areas. Overlaying the species' occurrence data with the existing network of protected areas (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2019), several points fell within protected areas in numerous countries (e.g. Sierra de Aracena y Picos de Aroche Special Protection Area in Spain, Mecklenburgisches Elbetal Special Protection Area in Germany, Ugra UNESCO-MAB Biosphere Reserve in the Russian Federation, Har Meron Nature Reserve in Israel). The presence of the species within these areas requires field confirmation but if they do occur within them, they are unlikely to be actively conserved as there is no indication that these sites are monitored. Management plans could be designed to actively protect this species in these areas. It is recommended that both population and habitat trends are monitored so as to avoid a potential decline of this species, as well as collection of additional accessions from across the species' full range for long-term ex situ conservation.

rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species with no apparent threats and a stable population trend.
habitat: Vicia ervilia is found in scrubland, stoney slopes, screes, field and vineyard margins, roadsides and disturbed areas; it flowers from March to July (Maxted 1995).
threats: There are no major threats to this species. It is found in a variety of   habitats and appears to be stable throughout its range (Maxted 1995).
population: The exact population size is unknown, but the species is considered relatively common throughout its range (Maxted 1995).
range: Vicia ervilia is widespread in Europe, north Africa, the Caucasus, western and central Asia; both cultivated and spontaneous forms occur and it occurs at elevations between sea level and 2,000 m asl (Osborne 2011, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
useTrade:
This species is cultivated in the near east and is also likely to be grazed by wild and domesticated species in the pasture and agricultural margins where is naturally occurs (Osborne 2011).

Vicia ervilia is in the tertiary gene pool of Common Vetch V. sativa, and more remotely Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica and Winter Vetch V. villosa, it is also a tertiary wild relative of Faba Bean V. faba, Narbon Bean V. narbonensis (Maxted 1993, 1995). It belongs to the secondary Taxon Group of Articulated Vetch V. articulata and to Taxon Group 1B of cultivated Bitter Vetch V. ervilia (Kupicha 1976). As a result is has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
conservationActions:
The genus Vicia is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Faba Bean gene pool (FAO 2009).

Ex situ seed samples are available in the numerous national gene banks throughout the species range. EURISCO reports 567 germplasm accessions held in European genebanks, 14 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin. Of the wild accessions, nine originate from within Europe. One from Belgium, five from Bulgaria, one from Czech Republic, one from Macedonia FYR and one from Spain (EURISCO Catalogue 2010).

In situ, the species is likely to be passively conserved in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as its conservation in these sites is not actively monitored it may be subject to population loss over time from factors such as climate change (Osborne 2011).

rationale: Vicia articulata is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread across Europe, also native to Egypt, Iraq and Turkey, with a stable population and no apparent major threats due to its occurrence in a stable climax habitat.
habitat: Vicia articulata is found in woodland, rocky slopes, meadows and macchie in the Mediterranean region (Davis and Plitmann 1970, Maxted 2011).
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown, however Maxted (2011) suggests that because it occurs in stable climax woodland habitats there are likely to be very few major threats.
population: Maxted (2011) states that in Europe this species has medium population sizes that are stable. The majority of this species' range occurs within Europe and so the global population trend is also thought to be stable. However, exact population sizes remain unknown.
range:
Vicia articulata is native to Iraq and Turkey in temperate Asia, the Canary Islands and Egypt in Africa and southern Europe, including the countries of Former Yugoslavia (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). 

The European Red List assessment for this species states that it is more widespread in Europe. In addition to the countries listed in the USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program (2014), it is also native to Austria, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Germany, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Ukraine; it occurs at elevations between 50 m and 800 m asl (Davis and Plitmann 1970, Maxted 2011).
useTrade:
According to the European Red List assessment for this species, it is cultivated as a forage in Turkey but natural wild populations may also be grazed by wild and domesticated species in the forest margins (Maxted 2011).

This species is a tertiary wild relative of Winter Vetch Vicia villosa and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches including Faba Bean V. faba, Narbon Bean V. narbonensis, Hungarian Vetch V. pannonica and Common Vetch V. sativa. It also belongs to Taxon Group 1B of cultivated Monantha Vetch V. articulata and to Taxon Group 2 of Bitter Vetch V. ervilia (Kupicha 1976). As a result, this species has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement.
conservationActions:
The genus Vicia is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) as part of the Faba Bean gene pool (FAO 2009).

Ex situ accessions are held in the following genebanks (Maxted 2011):
  • Departamento de Recursos Genéticos e Melhoramento, Estação Agronómica Nacional, Instituto Nacional de Investigação (Agrária, Portugal) 
  • Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (Germany)
  • Institute for Plant Genetic Resources 'K.Malkov' (Plovdiv, Bulgaria) 
  • Instituto Nacional de Investigación y Tecnología Agraria y Alimentaria (Spain) 
  • Centro de Recursos Fitogenéticos, Spain, Junta de Castilla y León, Instituto Tecnológico Agrario de Castilla y León, Centro de Investigación de Zamadueñas (Spain)
  • N.I. Vavilov All-Russian Scientific Research Institute of Plant Industry (Russian Federation)
  • Ustymivka Experimental Station of Plant Production, Ukraine
  • Syrian National (Douma, Damascus, Syria)
  • Aegean Agricultural Research Institiute (Menemen, Turkey)
  • ICARDA (Aleppo, Syria)
  • University of Reading (Reading, UK).

EURISCO reports 164 germplasm accessions held in European genebanks (EURISCO Catalogue 2014). Of the wild accessions, eight originate from within Europe, two from Bulgaria (stored in Institute for Plant Genetic Resources 'K.Malkov', Bulgaria), one from Hungary (stored in Ustymivka Experimental Station of Plant Production, Ukraine), one from Portugal (stored in Ustymivka Experimental Station of Plant Production, Ukraine) and four from Spain (stored in Instituto Nacional de Investigación y Tecnología Agraria y Alimentaria, Centro de Recursos Fitogenéticos, Spain) (EURISCO Catalogue 2010).

The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA, holds 12 germplasm accessions for this species, four of which are wild material and none of which are duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).

In situ, the species is likely to be passively conserved in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as its conservation in these sites is not actively monitored it may be subject to population loss over time from factors such as climate change (Maxted 2011).

rationale: Medicago turbinata is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread and common species with no apparent threats and a stable population. It is also regionally assessed as Least Concern in Europe. A gap analysis to ensure that ex situ collections are representative of the range of genetic diversity in wild populations in situ is recommended.
habitat: Medicago turbinata is an annual herb that grows on mountains in field and wood margins, open woodland, waste ground, and rocky areas, on sandy and limestone soils (Al-Atawneh et al. 2009). In Spain it is found in grasslands and cultivated fields (Osborne 2011).
threats: There do not appear to be any major threats to European populations of this species, and it is found in a number of European habitats that are not threatened (Osborne 2011). Through the rest of its range it is possibly threatened due to habitat erosion, and it grows in regions threatened by climate change (Prosperi et al. 2001).
population: Medicago turbinata is common throughout its range, more so in the northern Mediterranean countries (Small 2011). European populations are thought to be stable, although exact subpopulation sizes remain unknown (Osborne 2011).
range: Medicago turbinata is native to much of southern Europe, as well as parts of western Asia and northern Africa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). In Spain it is found in the Balearic Islands and coastal areas and in France it occurs in the northern departments of Eure, Aisne and Marne, the central departments of Vienne and Lot, the southwestern department of Pyrénées-Atlantiques, the southern department of Pyrénées Orientales, the southeastern departments of Bouches-du-Rhône and Var and the two departments of Corsica (Association Tela Botanica 2010, Osborne 2011).
useTrade: Medicago turbinata is a primary genetic relative of Barrel Clover M. truncatula and a tertiary genetic relative of Alfalfa M. sativa subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement. It is very occasionally sown as forage but aside from this it is not cultivated on a significant scale (Small 2011).
conservationActions: Medicago turbinata has few accessions available in gene banks. EURISCO reports 61 accessions held in European gene banks, two of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin, and 48 of which have no reported information regarding their origin (EURISCO Catalogue 2013). The European regional Red List assessment for this species reports 11 accessions of wild or weedy origin, all of these wild accessions originate from within Europe: seven from Cyprus (stored in Junta de Extremadura, Servicio de Investigación y Desarrollo Tecnológico, Finca la Orden, Spain), one from Greece (stored in Greek Genebank, Agricultural Research Center of Macedonia and Thrace, National Agricultural Research Foundation, Greece) and three from Spain (stored in Junta de Extremadura, Servicio de Investigación y Desarrollo Tecnológico, Finca la Orden, Spain) (EURISCO Catalogue 2010, Osborne 2011). The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) holds 85 accessions of this species, 54 of which are of wild origin and 49 of those are backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). Furthermore, 198 accessions (59,600 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from three gene banks (SGSV Data Portal 2013). According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in seven botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

rationale: Medicago truncatula is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread and common species with no apparent major threats, it is well conserved ex situ, and is regionally assessed as Least concern in Europe with a stable population trend (Osborne 2011). A gap analysis to ensure that ex situ collections are representative of the full range of genetic diversity found in wild populations in situ is recommended.
habitat: Medicago truncatula is an annual herb with weedy tendencies in ruderal habitats, found in inland Mediterranean grasslands and shrublands, arid slopes, meadows, garrigue, fields, light scrub and alluvial plains; it grows on calcareous, alluvial and terra rosa soils (Al-Atawneh et al. 2009, Small 2011).
threats: There do not appear to be any major threats to this species throughout its native range; in Europe it is found in a number of habitats  that are not threatened (Osborne 2011).
population: The exact population size is unknown, but the species is considered common throughout its range (Small 2011) and populations are thought to be stable (Osborne 2011).
range: Medicago truncatula is native to much of southern and eastern Europe, as well as northern Africa, Macaronesia, western Asia and the Caucasus. It is also naturalized in Australia and parts of South America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). In France it occurs in eight departments along the southern coast, the two departments of Corsica and the departments of Morbihan, Gironde and Pyrénées-Atlantiques on the western coast (Association Tela Botanica 2010).
useTrade: Wild Medicago truncatula is a primary genetic relative of cultivated Barrel Clover M. truncatula and a tertiary genetic relative of cultivated Alfalfa, M. sativa subsp. sativa and so it has potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). It is also widely cultivated, having a higher number of cultivars than any other Medicago species, excluding Alfalfa, which has prompted its development as a model legume in researching gene function (Small 2011). It is used as animal forage and (more rarely) fodder, for soil improvement and the prevention of soil erosion and as a companion crop (Singh 2009, Small 2011).
conservationActions:
Medicago truncatula is a widespread species, with a large number of accessions available in gene banks due to its value in the agricultural industry and as a model legume (Prosperi et al. 2001, Small 2011).

EURISCO reports 241 accessions held in European genebanks, 22 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin and 136 of which have no reported information regarding their origin (EURISCO Catalogue 2013). The European regional assessment for this species reports 81 accessions of wild or weedy origin, with 69 of these originating from within Europe (EURISCO Catalogue 2010, Osborne 2011). The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS, in the USA) holds 388 accessions of this species, 296 of which are of wild origin and 290 of those are duplicated at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014). Furthermore, 1,084 accessions (346,600 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, originating from five gene banks (SGSV Data Portal 2013). According to Botanical Garden Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in six botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

rationale: Lathyrus tingitanus has a large geographic distribution and, although a rare and localised species that occurs in a relatively small area of occupancy (around 408 km2), it has a large and stable global population which does not face major threats. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: It occurs in bush and forest clearings, grassland slopes, river banks and swamps, shrublands and anthropogenic environments such as roadsides. It can grow equally well on acidic or basic soil (Shehadeh et al. in prep). The habitats where this species occurs do not seem to be threatened.
threats: Overgrazing is a threat to this European subpopulations, but is not believed to pose a significant risk (Duarte et al. 2011).
population: It has a scattered distribution and it is rare and localised but populations appear to be stable. It is very common in the Canary Islands (Duarte et al. 2011).
range: Lathryus tingitanus is native to parts of southern Europe (Italy, Portugal and Spain) and northern Africa (Algeria, the Canary Islands, and Morocco) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition it has been listed in Australia, the Azores and Madeira Islands in Portugal, Canada, Costa Rica, France, Mexico, Papua New Guinea, New Zealand and USA (ILDIS 2010, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). However these are not believed to form part of the native distribution, instead naturalised or introduced populations as a result of its cultivation. For example, Borges et al. (2008) showed that the species is introduced in Madeira. These countries are therefore not included in this assessment. Its origin in the Canary Islands is uncertain (Izquierdo et al. 2004) but this area will be included in the assessment. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 1,400,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 408 km2. Based on the large geographical range the species is believed to exist at a high number of locations.
useTrade: This species is rarely cultivated as an ornamental (Yunus 1990) and as fodder (Shehadeh et al. in prep). Wild populations of Lathryus tingitanus are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, Tangier Pea. In addition, it is a secondary genetic wild relative of, and potentially a gene donor to, the cultivated Grass Pea (Sarker et al. 2001). Lathyrus tingitanus is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 2) of, and a potential gene donor to, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea (Vincent et al. 2013), and other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea and Caley Pea (Shehadeh et al. in prep). More remotely, it is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, Cyprus Vetch, and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It may be used in the future to improve their quality by altering the antioxidant content (Pastor-Cavada et al. 2009). It also contains a toxin-free gene which could be used to neutralise the toxicity of the non-protein amino acid ODAP in L. sativus, which can cause the neurological condition lathyrism with excessive consumption (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Grass Pea gene pool.

Lathyrus tingitanus is fairly poorly represented in ex situ germplasm collections. Genesys hold 107 accessions, of which 54 are of wild origin. However, only 23 are known to come from within the native distribution. Of those, four are backed up at a second genebank and five are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). Italy, which forms part of the native distribution of this species is not represented in ex situ genebank collections, and should therefore be prioritised for future collections. According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in 21 botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).Although it occurs in protected areas, there is no active management, but it is likely to be passively conserved in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as the sub-populations in these sites are not actively monitored they may be affected over time from factors such as climate change.

The species has been previously assessed globally and regionally. A 2010 global assessment found the species was not threatened (ILDIS 2010). A 2011 European regional assessment classified the species as Least Concern (Duarte et al. 2011).

rationale: Lathyrus ochrus has a large global distribution, it is common throughout its range and its population is stable. Although it has a fairly small area of occupancy (AOO=1,624 km2) and it is commonly found in anthropogenic habitats and may be threatened by human activities in those habitats, those threats are not believed to pose a significant risk to the persistence of the species in the wild. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occupies mainly coastal, lowland sites. It is found at the borders of woods and in grassy places. Due to its historic cultivation it is found in anthropogenic environments such as roadsides and occasionally in cultivated fields (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
threats: To this day, European subpopulations of this plant are associated with anthropogenic environments and as such may be threatened by modern agricultural practices (Osborne 2011).
population: Subpopulations are known to be common throughout Europe and stable in these areas (Osborne 2011). No information on the subpopulations outside Europe is available.
range:
It is widely distributed throughout the Mediterranean area in north Africa, western Asia and southern Europe (from Shehadeh et al. in prep). It has also been reported as naturalised in the Azores and Madeira islands (Flora-On 2014), and in Iraq, Malta, Mauritius and New Zealand (ILDIS 2010). In France it is confined to eight south and southeastern departments (Alpes-Maritime, Aude, Bouches-du-Rhône, Gard, Hérault, Pyrénées Orientales, Var and Vaucluse) and Corsica. It is also found in the western department of Gironde (Association Tela Botanica 2010). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 5,300,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 1,628 km2.
The cultivation of the species may have resulted in an extension of its distribution. However, as far as possible, this assessment will focus only on wild individuals in the native distribution.
useTrade:
It was cultivated from as early as the bronze ages in southeast Europe, particularly in Greece, and is still cultivated to this day in western Asia as a pulse, and as animal fodder (Sarker et al. 2001, Shehadeh et al. in prep).
Wild populations of L. ochrus are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, Cyprus Vetch (Vincent et al. 2013). It could potentially be used to introduce genes which confer resistance to Ascochyta Blight (Gurung et al. 2002), or to improve the quality of its cultivated counterparts by altering the antioxidant content (Pastor-Cavada et al. 2009). It is also a secondary genetic wild relative of, and potentially a gene donor to, the cultivated Grass Pea (Sarker et al. 2001). More remotely, it is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea, and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea, Caley Pea, and Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

Lathyrus ochrus is well represented in ex situ genebank collections. Genesys report 333 accessions, of which 153 are of wild origin. 134 of the accessions of wild origin are from within the native distribution (Australia 11, Hungary two, India two, Germany two, UK one, not specified one). Of the accessions of wild origin from within the native distribution, 58 are backed up at a second genebank, and 41 are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). Many of the countries which form the native distribution of this species are not represented in ex situ collections, and should therefore be prioritised for future collections. These countries are: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, France, Italy, Lebanon, Libya, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.

According to the Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in 20 botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

There is no active management of L. ochrus in in situ protected areas. However, it is likely to be passively conserved in many existing protected areas throughout its range. As its sub-populations in these sites are not actively monitored they may be affected over time from factors such as climate change. Monitoring of the species in these sites is therefore recommended.

It has been previously assessed globally and regionally. A 2010 global assessment classified the species as not threatened (ILDIS 2010). In Croatia the species was assessed as Critically Endangered (Nikolić and Topić 2007) and in Europe assessed as Least Concern (Osborne 2011).

rationale: Although this species faces threats in parts of its range, the population is sufficiently large and widespread that these do not pose a significant risk of extinction. Lathyrus cicera is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species grows in shrubland, Mediterranean pine forests and forest clearing, rocky slopes, roadsides, and cultivated fields and vineyards (FAO 2010, Shehadeh et al. in prep). It prefers soils with pH between 6.5 and 8.5 (Bennett et al. 1998). It is the most common Lathyrus species in highland and cold temperate sites (Sarker et al. 2001).
threats:
In the Mediterranean, changes in agricultural practice are threatening the diversity of Lathyrus species. Newly cleared cultivated land and the subsequent decline of permanent pastures has led to the disappearance of habitats for wild climax community species (Osborne 2011). Furthermore, the increased use of high input farming and new, uniform varieties replacing traditional landraces is destroying diversity in wild types of Lathyrus cicera (Sarker et al. 2001).
