This species is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires. Increasing fire frequency may potentially threaten this species (Le Houérou 1973). It is also likely to be threatened by overgrazing by wild and domesticated species in the pasture and agricultural margins (Bilz et al. 2011).

These threats are known to affect European subpopulations but may also affect subpopulations in other areas of its native distribution.
population: This species is reasonably common throughout its range, where it is found in several habitats   which are not threatened; population appears to be  stable (Osborne 2011).
range: It is widespread throughout Europe, particularly southern and eastern Europe, west and central Asia, the Caucasus and northern Africa (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition to the countries listed in this assessment, provided by Shehadeh et al. (in prep), the species has also been reported in New Zealand, Saudi Arabia, South Africa and USA (ILDIS 2010, USDA, ARS GRIN 2017), but these are believed to be introduced populations and are therefore not included in this assessment. In France it is widespread across the south of the country, but also found in several departments in the north (Association Tela Botanica 2010). Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 14,000,000 km2, and area of occupancy (AOO) is around 5,000 km2. The species occurs across a large range and is therefore assumed to occur at a high number of different locations, if any.
useTrade: It is rarely cultivated as pulse and fodder in southern Europe, north Africa and western Asia (Sarker et al. 2001). In Spain, there has been a decrease in the production of Lathyrus cicera in recent years due to the replacement by alternative grain and forage legume species. Wild subpopulations of the species are in gene pool 1B (GP1B) of cultivated populations of L. cicera (Vincent et al. 2013). In addition, there is some debate over whether this species is a secondary or tertiary wild relative of the cultivated Grass Pea. Vincent et al. (2013) state it is a tertiary genetic relative, but Yunus (1990) shows that the two species can cross and produce viable seeds. This is sufficient evidence for L. cicera to be classed as a secondary genetic wild relative of the cultivated Grass Pea. This means it may be used as a gene source for Grass Pea improvement, particularly genes for disease resistance (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). Due to its morphological similarity to L. sativus and the ability to produce viable seeds, it is a potential candidate for the progenitor species of Grass Pea (Shehadeh et al. in prep). Lathyrus cicera is also a wild relative (in Taxon Group 2) of, and a potential gene donor to, Sweet Pea (Vincent et al. 2013) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea and Caley Pea (Shehadeh et al. in prep). More remotely, it is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of Cyprus Vetch and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

The species is fairly well represented in ex situ germplasm collections. Genesys reports a total of 816 accessions, 274 of which are of wild origin. The vast majority of the accessions of wild origin originate from within the native distribution, although there are five accessions for which the origin is not specified. 103 of the accessions of wild origin are backed up at a second genebank, and 82 are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017).

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in 11 botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

The species is likely to be passively conserved in situ in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as its subpopulations in these sites are not actively monitored, they may be subject to population loss over time from factors such as climate change.

Many of the countries which form the native distribution of this species are not represented in ex situ genebank collections, and should therefore be prioritised for future collections. These countries are: Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan in Asia; Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Georgia, Hungary, Italy, Macedonia, Malta, Montenegro, Romania, Serbia, Slovenia, Switzerland, Ukraine in Europe; and Egypt and Libya in Africa.

Lathyrus cicera has been previously assessed at the regional and global levels. Assessments in Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002, OFEV 2016) and Andorra (Carrillo et al. 2008) both found that the species was Critically Endangered, but in Europe the species is listed as Least Concern (Osborne 2011). It has been globally assessed as Not Threatened (ILDIS 2010).

rationale: Hordeum murinum is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed throughout Europe, northern Africa and Asia. It is also common with a stable global population. It grows in a range of disturbed habitats and no major threats are known.
habitat:
This species is thought to have originated around seasides, sandy riverbanks and watering holes but now is predominantly found in disturbed habitats as a weed (von Bothmer et al. 2012, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).

The European Red List assessment for this species also suggests it is found predominantly in disturbed habitats such as field margins, roadsides, arable land and pastures (Kell 2011).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: This species is common throughout its native range, especially in places with anthropogenic disturbance, and its global population is stable (von Bothmer et al. 1995). In Europe is it also stable, with reports that the populations in Greece and Britain are stable and populations in Ireland and the Netherlands are increasing (Mennema et al. 1985, Preston et al. 2002, Kell 2011).
range: Hordeum murinum is native throughout Europe, temperate Asia, northern Africa, Macaronesia and in Pakistan on the Indian Subcontinent (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
useTrade: Hordeum murinum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
conservationActions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

Vincent et al. (2012) report 967 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as low priority for ex situ conservation within its genus. EURISCO reports 276 germplasm accessions of H. murinum held in European genebanks, 157 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin. Of the wild accessions, 125 originate from within Europe (EURISCO Catalogue 2010, Kell 2011).

It is thought to occur in protected areas Switzerland, Italy and the Netherlands, inferred by GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011).

rationale: Hordeum marinum is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed across Europe, temperate Asia and northern Africa and is relatively common throughout much of its range with a stable global population trend. However, there are some parts of its native range where it may be in decline (e.g. the Netherlands) and in these locations, the establishment of active in situ management and monitoring of populations is recommended.
habitat: According to Duarte et al. (2011), this species occurs in saline meadows, coastal marshes, riverbeds, wasteland, dry grasslands and as a weed in pasture. In the UK it grows as a lowland, coastal species, often found on trampled margins of dried-up pools and ditches in grazing marshes, on tracks and sea walls, and in salt marshes (Preston et al. 2002, Duarte et al. 2011). It can also grow along salt-treated roads further inland (Preston et al. 2002). In the Netherlands it is found in grasslands with a brackish humid soil (Tamis et al. 2003). Its weedy nature means that it is able to grow in disturbed habitats (von Bothmer et al. 2012).
threats: This species is threatened by coastal development, such as construction of sea defences in the UK (Duarte et al. 2011, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2012).
population: This species is reported to be a relatively common weed (von Bothmer et al. 1995, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014) and so it thought to have a stable global population trend. In Europe, while this species is noted as being relatively common in Portugal, Spain and Italy, it is described as decreasing in Croatia, the Netherlands and the UK (Duarte et al. 2011).
range: Hordeum marinum is native to the majority of Europe, much of temperate Asia, northern Africa, Macaronesia and Pakistan on the Indian Subcontinent; it is widely naturalized in other regions including Australia and the Americas (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
useTrade: Hordeum marinum is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare) and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (von Bothmer et al. 1995). It is also candidate for hybridization with Wheat (Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2012).
conservationActions:
The genus Hordeum is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

This species is classified as Least Concern in Europe (Duarte et al. 2011). It is thought to occur in protected areas in the UK and the Netherlands (Bachman et al. 2011) and due to its widespread distribution it is assumed to occur in many more across Europe, Asia and north Africa.

Vincent et al. (2012) report 317 accessions from seven sources thought to contain the largest collections of wild Hordeum seed accessions, identifying this species as low priority for ex situ conservation within its genus.

rationale: Wild Carrot (Daucus carota L.) has a very wide distribution, large population, is not currently experiencing any major threats and no significant future threats have been identified. This species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Wild carrot is an annual or biennial, erect herb, which grows from a taproot up to 120–150 cm in height when flowering. It is a complex, highly variable species (van der Vossen and Kahangi 2004, CABI 2020).

The species occurs across a range of primary and secondary habitats including rough grasslands, in thickets, along coastal cliffs, in dunes, in weedy meadows and abandoned fields, along roads and railways, and in wasteland areas (CABI 2020). It is found in banks, fields and waysides across Europe (Polunin 1969). In the Mediterranean, it occurs in dry rough open areas, often in waste places and roadsides and field margins including sandy and stony pastures (Blamey and Grey-Wilson 2004, Fletcher 2007). In some situations, it can spread aggressively, and the species is viewed as an invasive weed in some parts of the world (CABI 2020).

It prefers quite infertile, well-drained and calcareous soils in the UK, and can be found within habitats such as on chalk downs, grassland on roadsides, waysides and railway banks, quarries, chalk and gravel pits, and waste ground (Preston et al. 2002). In the Netherlands this species occurs in grasslands with humid and dry, moderately fertile basic soils, and in grasslands which can be humid or dry on poor basic soils (Tamis et al. 2003).
threats: There are no major threats to Wild Carrot at the species level. However, for subspecies with specific habitats or a restricted range, threats include tourism and construction.
population: Wild carrot is widespread and common throughout its range (CABI 2020), and no major threats have been identified at the species level; it is therefore suspected that the population is large and stable. However, Preston et al. (2002) note that it has declined at the northern fringe of its range in the UK.
range:
Wild carrot is native to Europe, temperate Asia and northern Africa, and is naturalized or introduced elsewhere (Castroviejo et al. eds. 2003, Izquierdo et al. eds. 2004, Silva et al. 2005, Borges et al. 2008, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020). In western Europe, the species typically grows below 1,100 m asl, and is often found near sea level (Nobre et al. 2016, Temperate Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020); in Kashmir and Syria, the species has been reported to grow up to 1,800 m asl (Koul et al. 1989, Al-Safadi 2008).

This species is widespread in France (Association Tela Botanica 2000–2010), Great Britain, Northern Ireland and Ireland (Preston et al. 2002) and present throughout the Netherlands but less so in the north eastern part of the country (Mennema et al. 1985).
useTrade:
Daucus carota L. is a primary wild relative of, and potential gene donor to, cultivated carrot, one of the most popular vegetables worldwide (CABI 2020, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020). In areas where they co-occur, wild carrots may spontaneously hybridise with cultivated carrots (Magnussen and Hauser 2007). As the wild progenitor of the cultivated crop, the species has already been investigated for utilisation in breeding programmes (Que et al. 2019).

The species is harvested from the wild for local use as a food, medicine, and as a source of essential oils. Edible plant parts include the cooked root and fried flower clusters; additionally, the aromatic seed is used to flavour stews, and the dried and roasted roots are ground to a powder form for use in coffee (Temperate Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020). The roots may also be used as fodder (van der Vossen and Kahangi 2004).

Wild carrot has also been widely used in traditional medicine, and is the subject of contemporary medical research. Its use is perceived to support liver and kidney function, soothe the digestive tract and stimulate the uterus. The whole plant is anthelmintic, carminative, deobstruent, diuretic, galactogogue, ophthalmic, and stimulant (Temperate Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020). In European folk medicine, the plant is used as a urinary antiseptic and anti-inflammatory remedy for cystitis and prostatitis, and has also been used in the treatment of urinary calculus, gout and lithuria (Shebaby et al. 2013). An infusion of the flowers has been used in the treatment of diabetes, while the grated raw root is administered as a treatment for threadworms. The root is also used to delay menstruation, and in the treatment of urinary stones. Both the root and the seeds are diuretic and can induce uterine contractions. The seeds are also carminative, emmenagogue and anthelmintic, and have been used to treat oedema, flatulence and menstrual issues (Temperate Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020). Traditional medicine and modern phytotherapy have indicated that various parts of the plants exhibit pharmacological activity including antioxidant, analgesic, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antifungal, diuretic, lithontriptic, emmenagogue, hypotensive, gastroprotective, hepatoprotective, aphrodisiac, nephroprotective, antispasmodic, anticancer, antiestrogenic, cardioprotective, and wound healing properties (Bahrami et al. 2018). Essential oils from different plant parts have also exhibited antibacterial and antifungal activity against several species. The oil extract has also demonstrated in vitro anticancer activity against four human cancer cell lines (Shebaby et al. 2013).

An essential oil, derived from the seed, has been used in perfumery, as a food flavouring, and as an ingredient in anti-wrinkle creams (Temperate Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020).

The species is sometimes cultivated as an ornamental, particularly in meadow areas of wildlife gardens (POWO 2019).
conservationActions:
The genus Daucus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

The species has been recorded from multiple protected areas across its range (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2020); passive conservation is presumed in these areas, but it is not known whether active management is practised.

This species is well represented in ex situ conservation. At least 6,000 germplasm accessions of D. carota are held worldwide, more than 500 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin and collected within the native range (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2020). At least 110 botanic gardens are listed as sites of ex-situ conservation for the species (BGCI 2020).

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: S. media is a brackish water plant which can be found in both extreme of saline to fresh water. It colonizes mostly muddy shallow ditches, ponds, as a weed in irrigated gardens, flood plains and is mostly found at the margins of wetlands.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: This species has a wide distribution native in the Old Word in much of the European and Mediterranean countries, N Africa eastwards to Central Asia up to China and Mongolia. In the East Mediterranean countries it is known from Sinai Peninsula, Egypt, Israel, Greece, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, Turkey, Iraq, Iran, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Georgia. It was known as introduced species in New World (Hartman & Rabeler 2005).
conservationActions: The populations of this species are stable and no special measures are needed in the East Mediterranean range. This is a potential invasive plant with a wide ecological range.

rationale: The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The species grows in anthropogenic (man-made or disturbed habitats), forests, meadows and fields, shores of rivers or lakes (New England Wild Flower Society 2011-2015).
threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
population: The species is classed as globally 'Secure' by NatureServe (2014), however the populations in some  Provinces in Canada are classed as 'Critically Imperiled' or 'Vulnerable'. The Canadian Endangered Species Conservation Council (CESCC 2011) also class the species as 'Secure' (for Canada only).
range: The species is widespread across Northern Africa, Macaronesia, Asia Temperate and Asia Tropical, Australasia, Europe, Northern America and South America. Widely naturalized elsewhere (GRIN 2015).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for the species are known, or likely to be needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it has a restricted distribution, it is nearly present in all the islands of the Canary Island archipelago and the species is relatively common and abundant. However there is no information regarding the habitat, ecological requirements and threats to this species, so further research is needed.
habitat: The details about the habitats, the bionomics and ecological requirements of this species are not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: A relatively frequent and common species, found in many collections. Populations are not small, but there is no information available on the population trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, and is present in nearly all the islands of the Canary Island archipelago (Dathe 1993).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: This species is not included in the Spanish Red Data Book. The species is not subject to any targeted conservation action. It is not known if the species occurs in protected areas but it is likely that it occurs.  Further research is required to establish the habitat and ecological requirements and to identify the existing threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information regrading its population size and trend, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. Additional studies are needed to establish the current status of this species.
habitat: The details about the habitats, the bionomics and the ecological requirements of this species are not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. This species has a relatively restricted range and occurs at high altitudes, so it is presumably threatened to some degree by climatic factors. It is likely that global warming will restrict the distribution area of this species. In addition global warming may lead to the species to evade into rather unfavorable areas due to competitive pressure. However there is no published scientific information to support these statements.
population: This species is abundant within its restricted range and therefore populations are probably large, however there is no information available on the population trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands and occurs at high altitudes (above 1,000 m) (Dathe 1993).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: This species is not included in the Spanish Red Data Book. The species is not subject to any targeted conservation action. It is not known if the species occurs in protected areas but it is likely that it occurs.  Further research is required to establish the current status of the species throughout its range, its habitat and ecological requirements and to identify the existing threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the population size and trend, habitat and ecological requirements and threats. Further research is needed to establish the status of this species.
habitat: The details about the habitats, the bionomics and ecological requirements of this species are not known.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: The species appears abundant in the Canary Islands. There is no information about population trends.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Lanzarote, Fuerteventura, Gran Canaria and Tenerife).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions:
This species is not included in a National Red List or Red Data Book. The species is not subject to any targeted conservation action. Further research is necessary to establish the size of the population, the habitat and ecological requirements and also to identify any existing threats.
It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Lotus arabicus is an annual herb which is widespread and common across Africa, Arabia and India. The population is currently believed to be stable and no real threats are known at present.
habitat: L. arabicus is an annual herb which grows on sandy river banks, in shallow water, in muddy pools or dry places. L. arabicus is a common colonizer of bare mud left by receding flood water. The plant is dangerous to stock and is not normally grazed while it is still young. A glycoside, lotusine, is present and this hydrolyzes releasing hydrocyanic acid. When the plant is mature, dry or nearly so, it is safe to eat, and provide good grazed. The seeds are also toxic but sometimes eaten (Burkill 1984).
threats: There are no major known threats to the species.
population: L. arabicus is widespread and common in its natural range.
range: Lotus arabicus is distributed in Angola, Cameroon, Djibouti, Egypt, Ethiopia, Gambia, Kenya, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Morocco, Mozambique, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Sinai, South Africa, Sudan, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. The species distribution extends to Canary Islands, Pakistan and India, but it is not certain whether the species is native or introduced to these countries (Singh and Singh 1982).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures specifically for L. arabicus, but the species is currently known to occur in many protected areas. amples of seed of L. arabicus are held in the Millennium Seed Bank as an ex situ conservaions measure.

rationale: Due to its wide distribution, its existence in protected areas throughout the range of the species and its apparently stable population, Trifolium angustifolium is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Trifolium angustifolium is an annual herb which occurs in fallow fields, steppes, open plant communities and meadows.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: The population size of this species is not known.
range: Species widely distributed in northern Africa and Mediterranean area.
conservationActions: There is many protected areas throughout the range of the species. Seeds have yet to be collected as an ex situ conservation effort. It is not known to occur in any Botanical Garden.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little information available on the population size, trends and specific threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat:
Dioxys atlantica is found on sub-tropical grassland and shrubland. It is a kleptoparasitic species, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species, possibly of Osmia submicans (Saunders 1904).

The flight period runs from February to May (Hohmann et al. 1993) and it was first collected on Echium sp. (Saunders 1904).
threats: The threats to this species are not known, however, it is presumably threatened by habitat loss due to deforestation and habitat degradation through human activities. Agrochemicals produce severe impacts in this and other bees and could lead to a population decline.
population:
There is no information available on the current population abundance of this species as the latest records are from the late eighties (Hohmann et al. 1993).

It is a rare species and due to its island distribution (Tenerife, Gran Canaria and Lanzarote), the population is fragmented and can be said to occur in three localities.
range:
Dioxys atlantica is endemic to the Canary Islands (Hohmann et al. 1993). It is found on Tenerife, Gran Canaria and Lanzarote, up to 900 m (Saunders 1904, Hohmann et al. 1993).

Warncke (1977) also included a record (as subspecies) from Luxor (Egypt), but it has not been recorded in the region since (Hohmann et al. 1993, Ascher and Pickering 2012).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, and specific threats to the species. It occurs within protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: Dioxys lanzarotensis is a kleptoparasitic species, in that parasitises the nests of other bee species, living on a volcanic island (Tkalců 2001). There is no further information on the habitat or ecology.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species has been discovered quite recently and there is still no other information apart from where the holotype was found.
range: Dioxys atlantica is an endemic species to the island of Lanzarote (Tkalců 2001).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not subject to any targeted conservation action. Further research is required to investigate the taxonomy, distribution, population size and trends, ecology and to identify the existing threats. It was found in a protected area.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends and specific threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: The species is thought to occur on volcanic landscapes, subtropical grassland and shrubland. The flying period runs from February to June (Hohmann et al. 1993).
threats: The threats to this species are not known. Generally, it may be threatened by global habitat loss due to deforestation and degradation because of human activities such as residential and commercial development for housing, commercial, industrial, tourism and urban areas, herbicides and pesticides, and also habitat shifting, alteration, droughts and temperature extremes caused by climatic changes. The use of agrochemicals severely impacts this species and many other bees, and could lead to a population decline in them.
population:
It used to be a relatively common species, but there is no information available on the current population abundance of this species because the records are old; the last records were from the late eighties or early nineties (Hohmann et al. 1993).

Its population is fragmented, in that there is little chance of genetic exchange between the separate island subpopulations of La Gomera, Tenerife and Gran Canaria.
range: Pseudoanthidium canariense is an endemic species to the Canary Islands. It occurs on the islands of La Gomera, Tenerife and Gran Canaria, up to 1,800 m asl (Hohmann et al. 1993).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, and specific threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the species is only known from a few records in the Canary Islands and there is no information on the population size and trend, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. Further research is needed to assess the status of this species.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat or ecological requirements of this species. This is a kleptoparasitic species, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species. The host is unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: The population size and trend for this species are unknown. The species is only known from a few records.
range: This species is only known from Gran Canaria and Tenerife in the Canary Islands.
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: This species is not included in any National Red List of Red Data Book. It is not known if the species occur in any protected areas. Further research is needed into the population size and trend, habitat, ecological requirements and threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because, although it is relatively abundant within its small range, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be less than 8,890 km2, the area of occupancy (AOO) is 2,740 km2 and the species is severely fragmented as it has two subpopulations on the islands of Tenerife and La Palma.
habitat: The species inhabits a temperate-type shrubland in a typical high-altitude sub-alpine desert, and visits endemic plant species on Tenerife, such as Erysimum scoparium, Spartocytisus supranubius (Fabaceae), Nepeta teydea (Lamiaceae) (Dupont et al. 2003) and several Aeonium species (Crassulaceae) (Esfeld et al. 2009). It is a major pollinator of the endemic Echium wildpretii (Boraginaceae) (Dupont et al. 2004).
threats: This native Canary Island species could be threatened by the invasive and competitive introduced honey bees, possibly resulting in exploitative competition (Dupont et al. 2004).
population: Although the species has been recorded only from a restricted area in the Canarian Archipelago, it may be locally abundant (Dupont et al. 2003). The population trend is unknown. The species occurs in two localities as it is only found on Tenerife and La Palma, and can therefore be said to be severely fragmented, with very little chance of genetic exchange between these two subpopulations.
range: The species is endemic to the Canary Islands and has been recorded only on Tenerife and La Palma, although all the islands of the archipelago have been surveyed (Báez and Ortega 1978). The maximum extent of occurrence (EOO) is approximately 8,890 km<sup>2 </sup>and the maximum area of occupancy (AOO) is no more than the combined area of Tenerife and La Palma, 2,740 km<sup>2</sup>. The species is found from sea level to 2,150 m above sea level.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: This species occurs within the protected area of the Teide National Park on the Canary Islands. The species is not listed in any National Red List or Red Data Book. Further research should be conducted to determine the population trends and further threats to the species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the species' population size, trends, and threats. The species is found only on the island of Tenerife, which, with an area of 2,034 km2 and approximately one million inhabitants, is the largest and most populated of the Canary Islands. Research is strongly needed to determine if this species warrants a threatened category.
habitat: The islands have a subtropical climate, with long warm summers and moderately warm winters. The species is thought to inhabit sub-tropical forests. The species flies from mid-April to the end of June. There is no further information on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: The species is known only from Tenerife, the largest island among the Canary Islands (Tkalcu 1993, Ortega 2005). It is endemic to the island. Tenerife has an area of 2,034 km<sup>2</sup> and approximately one million inhabitants, and is the largest and most populated of the Canary Islands. The maximum extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) can only be 2,034 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: There appear to be no direct conservation measures in place, but it does occur in the Teide National Park on Tenerife. Research is required to understand the population size and trends, while the habitat, ecology, and threats to this poorly-known species also need to be studied.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the species' population size, trends, and threats. Due to the species' small range, research is strongly needed to determine if this species should be categorized within a threatened category.
habitat: The Canary Islands have a subtropical climate, with long warm summers and moderately warm winters. Lanzarote has the most arid climate and it can presumed that the species inhabits dry subtropical/tropical shrubland and hot desert. The species has been recorded flying in April.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information on the population size and trends for this species.
range: The species is known only from the island of Lanzarote, the most eastern and arid among the Canary Islands (Tkalcu 1993, Ortega 2005). Lanzarote has an area of 845.94 km<sup>2</sup>, approximately 150,000 inhabitants and is the fourth largest of the Canary Island group. The maximum extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) is 846 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: <span lang="EN-GB">The species does not occur in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There appear to be no direct conservation measures in place, and it is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats to this poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the species' population size, trends, and threats. Research should be conducted to assess the status of this species as it could become threatened especially as the species is only known from Gran Canaria.
habitat: The species is kleptoparasitic, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species. There is no further information available on either the habitat or ecology (including hosts) of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range:
The species was described by Warncke (1992) and is endemic to Gran Canaria, the second largest island of the Canary Islands (Warncke 1992).  

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,560 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 80 km2.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. Research should be conducted on the species’ population size, trends, habitat and ecology, and to ascertain if there are any threats to the species. It is unknown whether the species occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Hoplitis zandeni is currently unknown. This species has been found on the following flowers: Launaea arborescens, Phagnalon spp., Heliotropium ramosissimum and Ononis spp. (Hohmann et al. 1993).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The population size and trends of this species are not known.
range: Hoplitis zandeni is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain) (Teunissen and van Achterberg 1992).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia larochei is currently unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia larochei is endemic to the Canary Islands (Tkalcu 2000a).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: This species possibly occurs in Mediterranean-type shrublands, although the habitat has not been described. The ecology of Osmia palmae is currently unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The trend and population size of this species are not known.
range: Osmia palmae is endemic to the Canary Islands, Spain (Tkalcu 2001).
useTrade: There is no current exploitation that could represent a threat to the species as a whole.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species occurs in moist soils and close to freshwater and sometimes brackish water rivers, wastelands, reed beds and gardens. It is a liana which could be invasive and has negative impact on the local vegetation and ochards. It was known in apple, peach, wheat and maize cultivation. By its vigorous growth, it provides a dense canopy above its holding plant and reduces photosynthesis by its holding plant.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: This species is locally abundant.
range: This species occurs throughout the Mediterranean region of Europe, Africa, Asia, southwest and central Asia to western Siberia.
useTrade: No economical usage was known. However, this is sometimes an aggressive weedy species causing serious damages in gardens and some cereal farms.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: Avena strigosa is globally assessed as Data Deficient as there is currently insufficient information available to evaluate this species. The native distribution of this species is remains unknown, though it is widespread across its naturalized range.
habitat: According to Baum (1977) grows in disturbed habitats such as waste grounds and fields. The same author notes that it is commonly found on sandy soils.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: As the native range of this species is unknown, it is not possible to determine the species' population size, distribution or trend.
range: The native distribution of this species is unknown. It is reported to be naturalized in Africa (Canary Islands), Australasia (Australia and New Zealand), Europe (Finland, UK, Austria, Czech Republic, Poland, Slovakia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Russia), and South America (Brazil, Argentina and Chile); it is also cultivated in Europe, northern America and southern America (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).
useTrade: Avena strigosa is a tertiary wild relative and potential gene donor to cultivated Oats, particularly for disease resistance; it also has potential use as a soil improver and is used for forage (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014)
conservationActions:
The genus Avena is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) (FAO 2009).

EURISCO reports 342 accessions held in European genebanks, none of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin, and 229 of which have no reported information concerning acquisition source (EURISCO Catalogue 2013).

The National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS) holds 124 accessions of this species, six of which are of wild origin and backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2014).

Furthermore, 151 accessions (129,197 seeds) are duplicated and conserved ex situ in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault originating from seven genebanks (SGSV Data Portal 2013).

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2013) this species has living collections in 15 botanical gardens worldwide, although the size, state, origin and location of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the population size and trend, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. The species has a restricted distribution with an area of occupancy (AOO) probably less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>, so further research is needed to assess the status of this species as it could be threatened.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species. Melecta canariensis is known to be a kleptoparasitic species, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species, but its host is unknown.
threats: <span lang="EN-GB">The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species. It is very rare, as are the rest of the Melecta species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain) (Hohmann et al. 1993, Rasmont 2014). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is probably smaller than 2,000 km2.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the population size, trends, habitat and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species, as it has a restricted distribution and it could be threatened.
habitat:
There is no information available on the habitat of this species, although it has been recorded in altitudes up to 600 m asl (Hohmann et al. 1993).

The species is kleptoparasitic, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species, but its host is unknown. Its host plants include Aizoaceae, Asteraceae, Brassicaceae, Fabaceae, Frankeniaceae and Oxalidaceae (Hohmann et al. 1993). It is probably bivoltine, in that it has two generations per year, since it has been recorded from February to May and from September and November.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species. It is very rare, as are the rest of the Melecta species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands of Lanzarote and Fuerteventura (Spain) (Hohmann et al. 1993, Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitats and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the population size, trends, habitat and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat:
There is no information available on the habitat of this species, although it has been recorded in altitudes up to 2,300 m asl (Hohmann et al. 1993) and it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrublands.

The species is probably kleptoparasite, as other species of the genus Melecta. The host plants include the families Asteraceae, Boraginaceae, Brassicaceae, Cistaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Fabaceae, Lamiaceae, Liliaceae, Oxalidaceae and Rubiaceae (Hohmann et al. 1993).

It has been recorded from October to June (Hohmann et al. 1993).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species. It is very rare, as are the rest of the Melecta species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Rasmont 2014), where it occurs in La Palma, La Gomera, Tenerife and Gran Canaria (Hohmann et al. 1993).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat:
Thyreus hohmanni has been recorded feeding on Asteraceae, Boraginaceae and Plumbaginaceae species (Hohmann et al. 1993).

There is no information available on the habitat of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrublands.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species. However, it is considered to be rare.
range: This species is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria (Canary Islands, Spain) (Schwarz 2003, Rasmont 2014). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is likely to occur within protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species is widely spread and abundant in the Canary Islands. However, research should be conducted on the population size, trends and threats to the species.
habitat:
Amegilla canifrons has been recorded in altitudes from the sea level up to 1,400 m asl all year-round. The species has been recorded visiting flowers from the following families: Amaryllidaceae, Apiaceae, Apocynaceae, Asteraceae, Bignoniaceae, Boraginaceae, Brassicaceae, Caesalpiniaceae, Convolvulaceae, Cucurbitaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Fabaceae, Lamiaceae, Liliaceae, Nyctaginaceae, Plumbaginaceae, Rosaceae, Scrophulariaceae, Solanaceae and Verbenaceae (Hohmann et al. 1993).

There are no further details on the habitat of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species. However, it seems to be widely spread in the Canary Islands and populations are presumed to be quite common.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain) (Hohmann et al. 1993, Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, but its distribution overlaps with protected areas within its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since it is the most widespread of the Anthophora species from the Canary Islands and it has a presumably large population, foraging on a wide range of plant species. However, research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.
habitat:
There is little information available on its habitat preferences, but A. alluaudi is found in open Pinus canariensis forests at 2,000 m asl in Tenerife, having been recorded up to 2,300 m asl (Hohmann et al. 1993).

It is believed to be polylectic, in that it prefers to forage upon a wide range of flowering plant species, and it has been observed on the following families: Asteraceae, Boraginaceae, Brassicaceae, Cistaceae, Convolvulaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Fabaceae, Geraniaceae, Lamiaceae, Liliaceae, Nyctaginaceae, Oxalidaceae, Rubiaceae, Rutaceae, Scrophulariaceae, Solanaceae, Theaceae and Verbenaceae (Hohmann et al. 1993, Ollerton et al. 2007).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is the most widespread Anthophora of the Canary Islands. However, there is no information available about its population trend.
range: Anthophora alluaudi is endemic to the Canary Islands (Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, but it is present in at least one protected area, the Teide National Park (Tenerife). Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species. In view of its very restricted global distribution, future research may show that A. lanzarotensis warrants a threatened status.
habitat:
The species has been recorded on Asteriscus intermedius (Asteraceae) in altitudes up to 600 m asl, from February to May and then in September (Hohmann et al. 1993).

There is no information on the habitat preferences of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: <span lang="EN-US">This species is endemic to Lanzarote, Canary Islands (Spain) (Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas within its very restricted range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitats and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species. In view of its very restricted global distribution, future research may show that A. lieftincki warrants a threatened status.
habitat:
The species has been recorded nearly all year-round in altitudes up to 400 m asl, collecting on Aizoaceae, Asteraceae, Boraginaceae and Brassicaceae species (Hohmann et al. 1993).

There is no information available on the habitat of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to Fuerteventura and Lanzarote, Canary Islands (Spain) (Hohmann et al. 1993, Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas within its very restricted range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends, ecology and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species. In view of its very restricted global distribution, future research may show that A. orotavae warrants being placed in a threatened category.
habitat:
The species has been recorded up to 1,500 m asl on Asteraceae, Boraginaceae, Brassicaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Fabaceae, Frankeniaceae, Lamiaceae, Liliaceae, Nyctagynaceae, Scrophulariaceae and Solanaceae species (Hohmann et al. 1993). 

It is on the wing from January to June and from November to December, so it is probably bivoltine, in that it has two generations per year. 

There is no further information available on the habitat of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to Tenerife and Gran Canaria, Canary Islands (Spain) (Hohmann et al. 1993, Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas within its very limited global range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends, habitat and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: There is little information available on the habitat and ecology of this specie, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland. It has been recorded at low altitudes (up to 150 m asl) in February and March (Hohmann et al. 1993).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain), where it is known from the islands of Fuerteventura and from Lanzarote (Hohmann et al. 1993, Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the population size, trends, habitat and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: Anthophora pulverosa has been recorded on Heliotropium ramosissimum (Boraginaceae) and Lotus sessilifolius (Fabaceae) (Hohmann et al. 1993) in altitudes up to 500 m asl. It is on the wing from January to June and from November to December (Hohmann et al. 1993), and it is probably bivoltine, in that it has two generations per year. There is no information available on the habitat of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain) (Rasmont 2014), and it has been recorded in Tenerife, Gran Canaria, Fuerteventura and Lanzarote (Hohmann et al. 1993).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on the taxonomy, population size, trends, habitat and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: Anthophora purpuraria has been recorded at low altitudes (up to 400 m asl). There is no further information on the habitats of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland. It has been reported to forage on Echium species (Westrich 1993), Lannaea arborescens and Asteraceae and Boraginaceae species from December to February (Hohmann et al. 1993).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: <span lang="EN-US">This species is endemic to Fuerteventura and Lanzarote, Canary Islands (Spain) (Rasmont 2014).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the taxonomy, population size and trends, habitat and threats to the species.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: A. lanceolatum occurs in a wide variety of habitats, particularly in southern Europe, such as marshes, canals, ditches and on the margins of ponds and lakes. It is know also as a weed in paddy fields in Iran.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There may be local declines, for example in Estonia and Switzerland, but most populations, particularly in southern Europe and the East Mediterranean area, appear to be stable .
range:
The species is a predominantly a temperate Old World species, but occurs from Macaronesia and North Africa north to Scandinavia, east through Siberia, the Caucasus, Turkey, Iraq, Iran, Palestine, Afghanistan, Pakistan, (Dandy 1971, Ghafoor accessed through www.efloras.org), the western Himalayas (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) to China (Wang Quingfeng in prep.). It is naturalised in New Zealand (Allan Herbarium 2000), the west coast of North America (Oregon, California) and Chile (Haynes and Barre-Hellquist 2000).

It is widespread in north and central Europe, but most abundant in the Mediterranean basin. It has an interesting relationship with A. plantago-aquatica with which its range overlaps throughout much of Europe, but the latter species is increasingly relatively abundant in the north, whilst A. lanceolatum more or less replaces A. plantago-aquatica in the south.
conservationActions: Alisma lanceolatum is classed as Extinct in Estonia and Vulnerable in Switzerland. No conservation measures are in place for this species. As a rather common species in the East Mediterranean, it seems that no particular conservation measure are required in this part of its range.

rationale:
This species is classed as Near Threatened as, although it is widespread and even locally abundant, there is good scientific evidence of significant decline throughout its range. It is suspected to be close to reaching the threshold hold for Vulnerable under Criterion A (population size reduction) but more detailed information on the percentages of decline in the European states is needed.

The USDA plant profile (http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=BALDE) reports this species from Washington State and Newfoundland based on literature sources. If these are reliable reports, then it is very difficult to justify retaining the species as Near Threatened However, there is a need to ensure that these records are correct before reducing the species status to Least Concern.
habitat: The species typically occurs along the margins of shallow meso-oligotrophic lakes, ponds, reservoirs and pools, on the shorelines of slow streams, in marshes, fens, brackish dune slacks and bog pools. It can also be found in more anthropogenic or disturbed habitats such as ditches, canals, flooded quarries, man-made dune wetlands, abandoned peat-drains and cuttings, fish ponds, and temporary flooded fields.
threats: Habitat destruction, anthropogenic disturbance, hydrological alterations and changes in water and substrate quality seem to be the most significant threats to the species.
population:
B. ranunculoides appears to be declining throughout most of its range, with healthy populations remaining only in its strongholds of Portugal, Spain, France, the United Kingdom and Ireland. The following breakdown is taken from Kozlowski et al. (2009).
  • Albania - only two highly isolated populations.
  • Belgium - extinct in numerous districts and rare to very rare in Maritime, Kampen and Flander districts.
  • Croatia - still occurs in about eight localities but undergoing a strong decline.
  • Denmark - still present in numerous localities but declining in many areas.
  • Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania - it is not possible to be certain that B. ranunculoides ever occurred in these Baltic states but if it did then it is now extinct.
  • France - still present and locally abundant in several departments in Atlantic and central regions (Normandie, Bretagne, Pays-de-la-Loire, Poitou, Lande, etc.) although there is some evidence of a decline. It is rare to very rare in other departments, especially in the southern and eastern regions (Picardie, Ile-de-France, Champagne, Bourgogne, Dombes, Hautes-Alpes).
  • France, Corsica - scattered throughout the island but restricted to low altitudes close to the coast and therefore, vulnerable to anthropogenic changes.
  • Germany - extinct in many federal states and decreasing in practically all regions. Some new rediscoveries (Rügen) and successful conservation efforts (Nordrhein-Westfalen) have not reversed the general decline.
  • Greece - previously known from only one population but recently discovered in several new localities and now known from a total of 12 localities. However, all of these are isolated and under strong anthropogenic pressure.
  • Ireland - widespread and abundant in the west, although there have been some losses.
  • Italy - extinct in many regions and decreasing in the others with some highly isolated populations.
  • Italy, Sardinia - known from only few isolated localities close to the coast and therefore, vulnerable to anthropogenic changes.
  • Montenegro - only one known population discovered in 2001 in Lake Skadar.
  • Netherlands - very scattered but still present in several localities. Some successful conservation efforts have not reversed the general decline.
  • Poland - three historic records in the northwest around Wolin Island but now considered to be extinct.
  • Portugal - widespread and abundant in many areas but there are reports of local declines.
  • Portugal, Azores - very rare with only one population present on Terceira, which is probably not native.
  • Italy, Sicily - known from only one highly isolated locality in the south of the island and now considered extinct.
  • Slovenia - known from only one locality and now considered extinct.
  • Spain - widespread and abundant in many areas but there are reports of local declines.
  • Spain, Balearic - still present in several islands sites on Menorca and Mallorca.
  • Spain, Canary Islands - no recent data available and therefore, probably extinct.
  • Sweden - still present in numerous localities in coastal regions in the south of the country.
  • Switzerland - lost from all but four populations around the Lake Neuchâtel, three of which are seriously threatened. More than 90% of historical populations have been lost.
  • Turkey - known from one population in European Turkey and four in Turkey in Asia.
  • United Kingdom - widespread and locally abundant, particularly in the southwest and Wales but undergoing a significant decline throughout southern and eastern England.
There is no detailed information on population trends in North African populations. However, all wetlands in the region are threatened and this species is also likely to be declining in the region.

The single population in Newfoundland at Bristol's Hope is well established in a single pond but has shown no signs of spreading between its discovery in 2001 and the most recent observation in 2011 (J.E. Maunder and H. Clase pers. comm.).
range:
The species occurs from the Azores and the Canary Islands through North Africa north to Sweden and east to Turkey and Syria. It is most abundant on the Atlantic Arc, in the Iberian Peninsula, France, Ireland and the United Kingdom. It is limited to a narrow coastal strip in North Africa and populations become sparse and more scattered to the east. There is doubt of the occurrence of this species in the Baltic States (Kozlowski et al. 2009) and while there are populations in the extreme west of the European part of Russia, records from Lithuania and Belarus are in error for small terrestrial plants of Alisma gramineum (Tzvelev 2001).

This species is sold in New Zealand as an ornamental (P. Champion pers. comm. 2013) but is not naturalised (Champion and Clayton 2000)

The species has been recorded naturalised at  a single site in Newfoundland (Clase 2002) where it persisted between its discovery in 2001 and 2011. Although not checked since 2011, it is likely that it still occurs (J. Maunder and H. Clase pers. comm. 2013). Reports of a population at Hicks Lake, Thurston County, Washington State based on specimens in the University of Washington herbarium (WTU) are apparently erroneous (D. Giblin pers. comm. 2013).
conservationActions:
The species has been assessed as:

  • Extinct in Sicily and Slovenia;
  • Critically Endangered in Croatia, Italy and Switzerland;
  • Endangered in Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland and Sweden (although it may be extinct in Poland);
  • Vulnerable in Albania;
  • Near Threatened in Denmark, the Balearic Islands (Spain) and the UK;
  • Least Concern in France, Ireland, Portugal and Spain.

In France it is protected in the following Departments: Haute-Normandie, Champagne-Ardenne, Bourgogne, Franche-Comté and Ile de France.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: C. stagnalis is the typical Callitriche of poached ephemeral pools on woodland rides, heathland, wet corners of pasture, seepages, flushes, lake and river margins, and the margins of ditches. It is the most widespread member of the genus in Europe and can occur in most habitats, but less frequently in deep or fast-flowing water than in shallow, still or slow-flowing water. It has been recorded up to 1,000 m asl in Europe and up to 1,600 m asl in Morocco. C. stagnalis generally occurs with a mixture of terrestrial and amphibious species, most typically Agrostis stolonifera, Apium nodiflorum, Epilobium hirsutum, Isolepis setacea, Juncus articulatus, J. bufonius, J. bulbosus and J. effusus. It rarely occurs with truly aquatic plant species, but may be found with Alisma plantago-aquatica, Baldellia ranunculoides, Eleocharis acicularis, E. palustris, Lemna minor, Ranunculus flammula and R. peltatus. In the southern part of its range it frequently occurs with species typical of temporary pools, such as Juncus pygmaeus, Lythrum junceum and Mentha pulegium. C. stagnalis will, at times, occur with most other European Callitriche species. In particular, it frequently occurs with C. palustris and C. brutia var. brutia in ephemeral wetlands and on the exposed margins of lakes and pools with fluctuating water levels.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size.
range: Callitriche stagnalis occurs throughout Europe, from the Azores to Iceland and east to the western side of the Ural Mountains in Russia. It also occurs as an alien in North America, Australia, New Caledonia and New Zealand.
useTrade: This species is frequently sold for outdoor planting schemes and ponds.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: B. tripartita typically occurs on relatively rich soil in wetlands such as that found beside rivers and lakes, in wet pastures, as well as in peat or gravel excavations and ditches, often associated with some disturbance of the soil. It is a characteristic species of the Bidentalia.
threats: No past, ongoing, or future threats exist to this species
population: It is widespread and abundant in France, the UK, the Netherlands and Germany. There is no evidence of a decline elsewhere in its range and it occurs as an introduced species in Australia.
range: B. tripartita occurs more or less throughout the northern hemisphere, and has been introduced to Australia (Sell and Murrell 2006, Flann 2009).
useTrade: This plant has several medicinal uses, is edible and can also be used as dye. Some of its medicinal properties are antiseptic, aperient, astringent, diuretic, narcotic, and sedative.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: C. paniculata typically occurs in base-rich marshes, fens and wet woodland or carr. It will also grow in shallow-inundated areas on the margins of lakes, ponds, river and canals.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: C. paniculata is widespread and abundant throughout most of its range.
range: C. paniculata occurs in the Canaries and Cape Verde islands and from Morocco north through western Europe to Scandinavia and east to Turkey and the Caucasus. It is naturalised in New Zealand. It is widespread throughout most of Europe becoming more scarce in European Russia and the Mediterranean.
conservationActions: C. paniculata is classed as Near Threatened in Estonia and Vulnerable in Finland and Norway. Otherwise, there are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it appears to be widespread with stable populations, however the level of threat indicated in Switzerland, the United Kingdom, Germany, Spain and France may indicate a more widespread trend.
habitat: S. triqueter typically grows on muddy banks in estuaries, on the margins of rivers, in marshes, bogs and ditches.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: S. triqueter is classed as Critically Endangered in Switzerland and in the UK, Endangered in Germany and Vulnerable in Spain. Outside these areas it appears to be widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size
range: S. triqueter occurs with populations in North Africa and from Europe east through the Caucasus, the Middle East and Kazakhstan to Far Eastern Russia, China and Japan, as well as in the the Himalayas in India and Pakistan. It has been introduced to the Columbia River on the border between Oregon and Washington in the United States. It also occurs in South Africa, where it may have been introduced (Cook 2004).
conservationActions: S. triqueter is classed as Critically Endangered in Switzerland and in the UK, Endangered in Germany and Vulnerable in Spain. It is also protected in the Alsace, Haute-Normandie, Pays de la Loire, Bretagne and Franche-Comté regions of France. Outside these areas there are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: A. stolonifera will occur in most wetland types, as well as many more or less dry habitats. It typically occurs in seasonally inundated grassland, grassland with a high water table, the margins of permanent and temporary flowing and standing water bodies and disturbed ground. It can be a troublesome weed of agriculture. It has a reasonably high degree of salt-tolerance and may extend into the upper levels of salt marshes.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size.
range: A. stolonifera has a circumboreal distribution from Europe, Macaronesia and North Africa east to China and the Korean Peninsula. It has been introduced to North America, Australia, New Zealand and many Pacific Ocean island groups (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Garden, Kew 2013).
useTrade: It is widely cultivated for forage and is used for turf. Wild populations may harbour important genetic diversity for crop improvement.
conservationActions:
Agrostis stolonifera is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture.

EURISCO reports 167 accessions of A. stolonifera held in European genebanks, 61 of which are reported to be of wild or weedy origin. All of these wild accessions originate from Europe in a range of countries, including the Czech Republic, Iceland, Ireland, Poland and Spain (EURISCO Catalogue 2010).

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species is found in muddy, sandy or gravelly margins of pond, lakes, streams and rivers on marshes. It is also present in brackish situations, such as mud and sand-flats, dune-slacks in coastal dune systems, and on the margins of saline and brackish lakes.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size.
range: This species is present in Macaronesia and Mediterranean areas to Afghanistan. In Africa, it has been recorded only from Somalia in North Eastern Africa and from Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Tunisia and Morocco in Northern Africa. It may be present also in South Africa although this needs to be confirmed.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed..
