rationale: There are numerous taxonomic uncertainties regarding this species, which could lead to a Data Deficient category. However, the Iberian Peninsula and Greece seem to have a widespread and common subpopulation. Therefore this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: R. saniculifolius typically occurs floating in temporary pools, as well as artificial water bodies and rivers, sometimes in brackish water.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: This species is abundant in Portugal, Spain, and Greece. There is no information available on the size of or trends on populations in France and Italy, however it appears to not be represented on any national red lists and there are no other reasons to expect that it is of conservation concern.
range: R. saniculifolius is a Mediterranean endemic (although material from the United Kingdom could be assigned to this taxon depending on the taxonomy followed), occurring on the north coast of Africa, in Spain (Mediterranean area, Balearic Islands and Canary Islands), Portugal, France (southwest and Parisian basin), Italy (Sardinia, Sicily, northeast and southeast), Greece with Crete, the Aegean Islands and Turkey in Europe.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed, however there is a need for research into the taxonomy of the subgenus to clarify its taxonomic status.

rationale:
Global and European regional assessment: Data Deficient (DD)
EU 27 regional assessment: Data Deficient (DD)

Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the population size and trend and the threats affecting the species. However the species has a very restricted range so further research is needed to assess the status of the species as it could be threatened.
habitat:
Andrena lineolata flies in April and May, and is known to visit Erysimum scoparium (Brassicaceae).
The habitat of the species is unknown.
threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
population: There are several different sub-populations recorded across Tenerife: Las Cañadas, San Juan de la Rambla, Montaña Negra-Montaña Abejera, La Orotava and Caramujo. There are no data on the size of the population or of trends.
range: Andrena lineolata is endemic to the Canary Islands (Hohmann et al. 1993, Báez and Ortega 1978, Ortiz-Sánchez 2011). It has been recorded in Tenerife only.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions:
Despite the extreme restriction of the range (Tenerife only), the species is not Red Listed or subject of targeted conservation action.
Further research is necessary to determine the ecology of the species, and to understand the details of the population size, trends and threats. It is likely to be present in protected areas.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: It occurs in ponds, ditches, wet meadows, marshes and at the edges of permanent freshwater bodies across a large range of altitudes.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size.
range: This species is a paleo-temperate species native to Eurasia, North and South Africa. It is introduced into North and South America, Java, Australia and New Zealand.
useTrade: The stems of this species are used in basket making, thatching, weaving mats (Plants for a Future 2010)
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because the species is only known from the type specimen collected in the type locality and so there is lack of information on the population size and trend, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. Further research is needed to assess the status of this species.
habitat: There is no information regarding the habitat and ecology for this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information on the population size or trend for this species, as the species is only known from the type specimen collected in the type locality.
range: Dufourea fortunata is endemic to the Canary islands. There is only one known record (Ebmer 1993).
useTrade: This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not included in the Spanish Red Data Book. Further research is needed into the population size and trend, habitat, ecology and threats. It is not known if the species occurs in protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species is common in the Canary Islands and there are no major threats to the species. However, research should be conducted to determine the population trends and ecology of the species.
habitat: The species occurs in sub-tropical habitats such as temperate and sub-tropical grasslands, Mediterranean-type shrublands, sub-tropical shrublands and coastal dunes amongst a variety of others.
threats: There are no major threats to the species.
population: A common species on the islands. There is no further information available for the population size and trend for this species.
range: An endemic species to the Canary Islands. The subspecies viride occurs on Tenerife, La Gomera and El Hierro; the subspecies cabrerai on Lanzarote and Fuerteventura; the subspecies palmae on La Palma; and the subspecies unicolor on Gran Canaria (Warncke 1975, Ebmer 1993 in Hohmann et al. 1993). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 51,699 km² and the area of occurrence (AOO) is 268 km².
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It occurs within protected areas such as Teide National Park on Tenerife. Further research should be conducted to determine the population trends and ecology of the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread within the Canary Islands, the populations are large and believed to be stable and there are no known major threats to the species. However, research should be conducted to determine the population trends for the species as it is endemic to the Canary Islands and it is important to understand if there are any significant declines.
habitat: The species has a sub-tropical habitat and is ubiquitous throughout, including sub-tropical grassland, sub-tropical and Mediterranean-type shrubland. There is no further information available on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: A common and stable species within its very restricted range. There is no further information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: Lasioglossum laetum is endemic to the Canary Islands (Ebmer 1993). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 48,171 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 156 km².
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It occurs within protected areas on the islands. Further research should be conducted to determine the population trends for the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its suspected stable populations, its preference for a wide variety of habitats, and the lack of threats to the species.
habitat: The species inhabits a wide variety of habitats including Mediterranean shrublands and gardens, and is polylectic, in that it forages upon a wide range of plant species.
threats: There are no major threats affecting the species.
population: The species is not common but is thought to be stable (A. Pauly pers. comm. 2013).
range:
Lasioglossum chalcodes is endemic to the Canary Islands (Ebmer 1993, F. la Roche pers. comm. 1992).
The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12,850 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 24 km2.
useTrade: The species is not traded or commercially exploited.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is occurs in protected areas on the Canary Islands. Further research should be conducted on the population status, trends, and future threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread and thought to be quite common on the Canary Islands. Despite the fact that this species is listed as Least Concern, data are still very much lacking and research should be conducted to determine the population trends and any future threats to the species as it is endemic to the Canary Islands.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species, although as it is endemic and quite common on the Canary Islands it can be assumed to be found on Mediterranean-type shrubland amongst other habitat types.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: The species is quite common on the Canary Islands (La Roche unpublished data, A. Pauly pers. comm. 2014).
range: The species is endemic to the Canary Islands and is found on Tenerife (subspecies arctifrons), Hierro (subspecies glandarium), La Palma (subspecies glandarium), and Gran Canaria (subspecies optatum) (Ebmer 1974, 1993, Warncke 1975, Hohmann et al. 1993). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 20,021 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 40 km².
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information on population size, trends and habitats of the species. Further research is needed to establish the status of this species throughout its range.
habitat: Andrena chalcogastra is a bivoltine species, in that it has two generation per year, that flies from January to April and from May to July (Warncke 1968). Males have been recorded visiting: Asteraceae (Calendula arvensis, Launaea arborescens, Sonchus canariensis, Tolpis laciniata), Boraginaceae (Echium aculeatum, Echium auberianum), Brassicaceae (Descurainia bourgeauana, Hirschfeldia incana), Ericaceae (Erica arborea) and Fabaceae (Chamaecytisus proliferus, Lotus sp., Spartocytisus supranubius). The females have been recorded on Boraginaceae (Echium auberianum), Brassicaceae (Erysimum scoparium), Euphorbiaceae (Euphorbia obtusifolia) and Fabaceae (Chamaecytisus proliferus, Lotus campylocladus, Spartocytisus supranubius) (Hohmann et al. 1993). There is no information available for the habitats of this species although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland.
threats: This species is only known from a small area, within which it is presumably threatened to some degree by habitat loss from general conversion of land to intensive agricultural use or through tourist infrastructure development.
population: There is no information available on the population size and trend of this species.
range: Andrena (Taeniandrena) chalcogastra is endemic to the Canary Islands. This species occurs in the four western Islands (La Palma, La Gomera, Tenerife and Gran Canaria) (Gusenleitner and Schwarz 2002).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed on any National Red Lists or Red Data Books and is not the subject of any targeted conservation action. It is not known if the species is found in any protected areas. Further research is needed to establish the population size, trends and habitats of the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information available on population size, trends, habitats and threats. Future research may show that A. damara warrants listing in a threatened category, considering that it is endemic to the Canary Islands and therefore it has a small extent of occurrence (EOO) and an even smaller area of occupancy (AOO).
habitat: Andrena damara has been collected from February to March (Warncke 1968). In common with other members of the sub-genus Chlorandrena, it is probably an oligolectic species, in that it prefers to forage upon a narrow range of flowering plant species, specialising in Asteraceae pollen, with records from Chrysanthemum coronarium, Sonchus sp. and Sonchus tenerrimus (Hohmann et al. 1993). There is no information on the habitat requirements of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are currently unknown.
population: There is no information available on the population size or trend of this species.
range: Andrena damara is a Canary Island endemic species (Ortiz-Sánchez 2011).  The species occurs in the two eastern islands of Fuerteventura and Lanzarote.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed on any National Red Lists or Red Data Books        and is not the subject of any targeted conservation action. It is     not   known if the species is found in any protected areas. Further     research   is required to establish the details of the population  size, trends, habitats and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is only one known described specimen of this species. Therefore, there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitats, ecology and threats to the species.
habitat: There is little is known about the habitat and ecology of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland. According to Warncke (1968), Andrena hillana flies in March, but Hohmann et al. (1993) state that it flies from January to March.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available on the population size or trend of    this species. However, there is only a single known record and so the  species is    assumed to be very rare within its extremely restricted range.
range: Andrena hillana is endemic to the Canary Islands. The species is described and only known from Fuerteventura (Gusenleitner and Schwarz 2002).
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed on any National Red Lists or Red Data Books              and is not the subject of any targeted conservation action. It       is     not   known if the species is found in any protected areas.       Further     research   is required to establish the details of the       population  size    and trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species.

rationale: Carex distachya has been assessed as Least Concern due to its wide range and occurrence in a variety of habitats across Europe and north Africa.
habitat: Reported to occur in dry places across southern Europe (Chater 1980).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: The population size is not known. Recorded as frequent in places.
range: This species is distributed throughout southern Europe, north Africa, Macaronesia and western Asia.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species, although its range does overlap with some protected areas.

rationale: Setaria parviflora has been assessed as Least Concern due to its global widespread distribution. There are also no known threats to this species and it has been listed as a weed (Global Compendium of Weeds).
habitat: Setaria parviflora is a common, native species of moist ground. It is the most morphologically diverse and widely distributed of the indigenous perennial species of Setaria. It grows best on moist or wet sites such as wet sandy soils, sloughs, and acid flatwoods. In Texas and Louisiana, it grows well on salty prairie sites and salt marshes if water level is relatively low.
threats: There are no major threats known to this species.
population: The exact population size is not known but this species is extremely widespread throughout the globe.
range: This species is widespread throughout North America, South America, Europe, Southeast Asia, Australasia and less frequently in South Africa.
useTrade: No information available.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures targeted specifically at this species, however it occurs in many protected areas and seed has been collected and stored ex situ as part of the Millennium Seed Bank project.

rationale: Poa angustifolia has a wide distribution range which extends from west Europe through Asia and Siberia to Japan. The population is currently believed to be stable and no major threats are known at present.
habitat: This species is a grass which occurs in dry grasslands.
threats: There are no known major threats for this species.
population: This species is widespread and common in its natural range.
range: This species occurs from west Europe through Asia, Siberia, India to Japan.
useTrade: There are no known uses for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures specifically for this species, but it is known to grow in some protected areas.

rationale: Ameles gracilis is an endemic mantid of the Canary Islands. It is present on three islands and it is only found in shrubland and uncultivated open areas. At present most of its ecology is unknown and the species taxonomy needs to be better defined (Becerra and Oromi 1999, Becerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). The species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of ca. 7,700 km², an area of occupancy (AOO) of 232-1,500 km², and a severely fragmented population. It is generally rare to encounter and a continuing decline in the number of subpopulations, number of mature individuals and the extent and quality of habitat is inferred where it is not protected. Therefore, the species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU), but it is very close to the Endangered category as its area of occupancy (AOO) is insufficiently known. Further updates need to be done in the near future.
habitat: This species is found in open areas with scrub vegetation and also pastures, usually near laurel and pine forests (Becerra et al. 2001).
threats: Threats to this species are not known in detail. However, considering the small distribution of the species, habitat destruction may be a serious threat. Local changes in the land use and a marked increase of overbuilding are contributing to the destruction of the natural habitats of this species and their real impact needs to be studied in more detail. The use of pesticides may also be a threat that may have a direct influence on this species or indirect by affecting its food source. There is a need for more research on the threats.
population: The population trend is unknown, however this species is rare and it is inferred that there is a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and number of subpopulations in some localities. Distribution records are based on Garcia Becerra et al. (2001) and unpublished records from the assessors. Recent observations from the assessors suggest that there may be a population decline on La Palma, but more research is needed.
range: A. gracilis is an endemic species of the Canary Islands, being found on the islands of La Palma, Tenerife and Gran Canaria (Becerra et al. 2001). The measured area of occupancy (AOO) is 232 km² with an upper estimate of 1,500 km² and the estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is ca. 7,700 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species benefits indirectly by conservation in some protected areas of the Canary Islands Network for Protected Natural Areas, where the natural habitat is preserved. Most of the ecology of this species is unknown and research is needed. Taxonomy of the subfamily Amelinae is also problematic and needs to be solved with further morphological and molecular research (Wieland et al. 2014).

rationale: Ameles limbata is an endemic mantid of the Canary Islands. It is present on two islands and only found in shrubland and uncultivated open areas. At present most of its ecology is unknown and the species taxonomy needs to be better defined (Becerra & Oromi, 1999; Becerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). The species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of ca. 6,600 km², an area of occupancy (AOO) of  472-1,900 km² and a severely fragmented population. It is generally rare and a continuing decline in the number of subpopulations, number of mature individuals and in the extent and quality of habitat is inferred for unprotected areas. Therefore the species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU), but it is close to the Endangered category and further research needs to be done in the near future.
habitat: Ameles limbata lives from coastal areas to the mountains in almost any type of vegetation but usually prefers clearings or open spaces to dense forest. It has not been found on the summit of the Teide mountain on Tenerife but has been recorded at 2,100 m asl on the island of La Palma, at the top of a ravine. It is often found on the plant Bencomia exstipulata Svent (Becerra et al. 2001).
threats: Threats for this species are not known in detail. However, considering the small distribution of the species, habitat destruction may be a serious threat. Local changes in the land use and a marked increase of overbuilding are contributing to the destruction of the natural habitats of this species even if their real impact needs to be studied in detail. The use of pesticides may also be a threat that has a direct influence on this species or indirect, degrading its ecosystem. There is a need for more research on the threats.
population: The population trend is unknown, however this species is rare and it is inferred that there is a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and number of subpopulations in some localities. Distribution records are based on Garcia Becerra et al. (2001) and unpublished records from the assessors. Recent observations from the assessors suggest that there may be a subpopulation decline on La Palma, but more data need to be collected.
range: Ameles limbata is an endemic species of the Canary Islands, being present on the island of Tenerife and La Palma (Becerra et al. 2001). The measured area of occupancy (AOO) is 448 km² with an upper estimate of 1,900 km². The extent of occurrence (EOO) is ca. 6,600 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species benefits indirectly from conservation in some protected areas of the Canary Islands Network for Protected Natural Areas, where the natural habitat is preserved. Most of the ecology of this species is unknown and research is needed. The taxonomy of the subfamily Amelinae is also problematic and needs to be solved with further morphological and molecular research (Wieland et al. 2014).

rationale: Pseudoyersinia betancuriae is an endemic mantid of the island of Fuerteventura. At present most of its ecology is unknown and the taxonomy needs to be better defined (Becerra and Oromi 1999, Becerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). Due to the extremely small amount of available data on this species, it is assessed as Data Deficient (DD). Further field research is strongly encouraged because this species, by the reduced AOO (56-400 km²) and EOO (ca. 1,300 km²) could very well fall into the Endangered category and conservation measures may be urgently required.
habitat: The few collecting records suggest that this species is active at least between February and April (Becerra et al. 2001) and can be found on the herbaceous vegetation or on small bushes like Salsola L. (Perez et al. 2003).
threats: Current threats are unknown but, considering the reduced distribution, habitat destruction from overbuilding or agriculture may be a serious threat to this species.
population: Pseudoyersinia betancuriae was discovered in February 1991 by M. Weimer who, in 1993, described the species from a single specimen found on the slope of Ajuì (Betancuria). In April 1992, J. Martin captured a second specimen in Morro de La Cruz, in this case a juvenile female. R. Garcia and P. Oromí (1999) observed a high number of mantid oothecae in Jandia Peninsula which, presumably because of their small size, could belong to this species. This species was more recently recorded in two localities on Montaña Clara and on the Isla de la Alegranza (Perez et al., 2003). A juvenile probably belonging to this species was recorded in 2003 on Lanzarote, but the presence of a subpopulation on this island needs to be verified.
range: Pseudoyersinia betancuriae is endemic to the Canary Islands archipelago and distributed in the islands of Fuerteventura, Montaña Clara and Isla de Alegranza (Becerra et al. 2001, Perez et al. 2003). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is between 56 and 400 km². Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is ca. 1,300 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species benefits indirect conservation in some protected areas of the Canary Islands Network for Protected Natural Areas, in particular on the small island where the natural habitat is preserved. Most of the ecology of this species is unknown and research is needed. The taxonomy of the subfamily Amelinae is also problematic and needs to be solved with further morphological and molecular research (Wieland et al. 2014), in particular the validity of this species in relation to the other Pseudoyersinae of the Canary Islands needs to be verified.

rationale: Pseudoyersinia canariensis is an endemic mantid from the island La Palma. At present time most of its ecology is unknown and the taxonomy needs to be revised (Becerra and Oromi 1999, Bercerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). The species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of ca. 290 km², an area of occupancy (AOO) of 48-200 km², and it occurs in a single known location. It is generally rare to encounter and a continuing decline in the number of subpopulations, number of mature individuals and in the extent and quality of habitat is inferred. The species is assessed as Endangered (EN) but more research is needed in order to clarify whether the species exists also on other islands.
habitat: Pseudoyersinia canariensis seems to be more abundant in the central part of the island La Palma, where it can be found in open sunny grassland areas and on the external part of the branches of the Canary pine (Pinus canariensis Chr. Sm. ex DC) or on the leaves of many legume plants of scrubland (i.e. Adenocarpus viscosus var. viscosus Webb et Berth, Genista benehoavensis (ex Bolle Svent.) and Spartocytisus supranubius (L. ) Webb & Berth.). Females usually lay ootheca on both vegetation and between rock fragments (Bercerra et al. 2001).
threats: Threats to this species are not known in detail. However, considering the reduced distribution of the species habitat destruction may be a serious threat, expecially in the coastal areas in the North and in the South of the island of La Palma. Local changes in land-use as intensive agriculture or a marked increase of overbuilding are contributing to the destruction of natural habitats of this species, even if their real impact needs to be studied in detail. The use of pesticides may also be a threat that may have a direct influence on this species or indirect by degrading its ecosystem. More research on the threats is needed.
population: The only confirmed subpopulation of Pseudoyersinia canariensis seems to be resticted to the island La Palma, the presence of other subpopulations on Lanzarote and Tenerife needs to be verified.
range: Pseudoyersinia canariensis is an endemic species of the island La Palma in the Canary Islands archipelago. Some authors locate this species also on Lanzarote and Tenerife (Bercerra et al. 2001), but the real distribution need to be verified. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is between 48 and 200 km², the extent of occurrence (EOO) ca. 290 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species benefits from some protected areas of the Canary Islands Network for Protected Natural Areas where the natural habitat is preserved. Most of the ecology of this species is unknown and research is needed. The taxonomy of the subfamily Amelinae is also problematic and needs to be solved with further morphological and molecular research (Wieland et al. 2014). The real distribution needs to be verified.

rationale: At present time most of the ecology of Pseudoyersinia pilipes is unknown and its taxonomy needs to be studied (Becerra and Oromi 1999, Bercerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). The available data suggest that this species has a very limited distribution (AOO is 40-200 km² and EOO is 74-200 km²) and thus could fall under a threatened category. Further field research is strongly encouraged in a near future. The scarcity of known records gives insufficient information on possible threats and its conservation status is not well defined, therefore the species is assessed as Data Deficient (DD).
habitat: From the scarce records available this species seems to be present in the scrubland of the eastern part of the island La Gomera and to be active from March to August (Bercerra et al. 2001).
threats: Threats for this species are unknown.
population: The only confirmed subpopulation of Pseudoyersinia pilipes seems to be resticted to the island La Gomera. The scarcity of collecting records suggests that the population of this species may be extremely small (Bercerra et al. 2001).
range: Pseudoyersinia pilipes is endemic of the island La Gomera, in the Canary Islands archipelago (Bercerra et al. 2001). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 74 km² with an upper estimate of 200 km². The area of occupancy (AOO) is 40 km² with an upper estimate of 200 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: Research on this species is strongly encouraged to understand its ecology and threats which at present time are practically unknown.

rationale: Pseudoyersinia subaptera is an endemic mantid of the Canary Islands. At present, most of its ecology is unknown and taxonomy needs to be better defined (Becerra and Oromi 1999, Bercerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). It is present in two small fragmented subpopulations on two different islands and is linked to particular habitats of endemic vegetation. The species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of ca. 6,500 km², an area of occupancy (AOO) of 336-2,000 km² and a severely fragmented population. It is generally rare and a continuing decline in the number of subpopulations, number of mature individuals and in the extent and quality of habitat is inferred from the ongoing threats. Therefore, the species is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), but it is very close to the Endangered category and further research needs to be done in the near future.
habitat: According to data listed in the bibliography and field observations made by the assessors, this species seems to live on the basal cardonales and tabaibales vegetation and on scrub vegetation present on the slopes of the islands. It is active virtually during all the months of the year, although seems to be more frequent during the spring (Bercerra et al. 2001).
threats: Threats to this species are not known in detail. However, habitat destruction may be a serious threat, expecially in the coastal area of Tenerife which is strongly affected by urbanisation, touristic and industrial development. Local changes in land use as intensive agriculture or a marked increase of overbuilding is contributing to the destruction of natural habitats of this species, even if their real impact needs to be studied in detail. The use of pesticides may also be a threat that may have a direct influence on this species, or indirect by degrading its ecosystem. Research is needed to study the threats.
population: Two subpopulations are known on the islands of Gran Canaria (central part) and Tenerife (SW coast) (Bercerra et al. 2001).
range: Pseudoyersinia subaptera is endemic to the Canary Islands, distributed on the islands of Gran Canaria and Tenerife (Bercerra et al. 2001). The area of occupancy (AOO) is 336 km² with an upper estimate of 2,000 km². The extent of occurrence (EOO) is ca. 6,500 km².
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species benefits from protected areas of the Canary Islands Network for Protected Natural Areas, where the natural habitat is preserved. Most of the ecology of this species is unknown and research is needed. The taxonomy of the subfamily Amelinae is also problematic and needs to be solved with further morphological and molecular research (Wieland et al. 2014).

rationale: Pseudoyersinia teydeana is an endemic mantid of the Canary Islands. At present, most of its ecology is unknown and the taxonomy needs to be revised (Becerra and Oromi 1999, Becerra et al. 2001, Wieland et al. 2014). It is present in only one small subpopulation in a restricted area of the island of Tenerife and is linked to particular habitats and environmental conditions. The data available suggest that if any threats are discovered that this species may fall into a threatened category due to its extremely restricted distribution (AOO: 80-300 km² and EOO: 200-300 km²). Further field research is strongly encouraged in a near future. The scarcity of known records does not give sufficient information on possible threats and its conservation status. Therefore, the species is assessed as Data Deficient (DD).
habitat: It is usually found on scrubs and occasionally in the opens spaces of pine forest (Pinus canariensis Christ. Sm. ex DC) and on various plants such as pajonera grass (Bourgaeana descurainia Webb ex OE Schulz), rosalita (Pterocephalus lasiospermus Link ex Buch) and broom (Spartoeytisus supranubius (L.) Webb & Berth). This species is active virtually all year, although adults are scarce during the winter months and sporadic in the summer, possibly due to the harsh climatic conditions in its habitat. Females usually deposit oothecae under rocks (Bercerra et al. 2001).
threats: Threats for this species are unknown.
population: A single subpopulation is known on the island of Tenerife (Bercerra et al. 2001). Even though the species has a very restricted distribution in the central part of Tenerife it seems relatively common, although never abundant.
range: Pseudoyersinia teydeana is an endemic species of the island of Tenerife, in the Canary Islands archipelago (Bercerra et al. 2001). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 80 km² with an upper estimate of 300 km². Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is between 200 and 300 km².
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: Most of the ecology of this species is unknown. The taxonomy of the Amelinae is also problematic and need to be solved with further morphological and molecular research (Battiston et al. 2010, Wieland et al. 2014). Research on this species is strongly encouraged to understand its ecology and threats, which are at present practically unknown.

rationale: Blepharopsis mendica is widespread in the Palaeartic region and by its wide distribution is here assessed as Least Concern. It is however usually found in low numbers in small local subpopulations and the area of occupancy of this species may be limited and the population fragmented. Further investigations on local distribution, population trend and threats are encouraged to reassess its conservations status.
habitat: This cryptic species lives in more or less xeric areas, including both herbaceous vegetation and spiny bushes. The particular colour and shape of this genus seem to be well suited for mimicry of the leaves and colour pattern of spiny or dry bushes of Mediterranean vegetation (i.e., Sarcopoterium) and oasis vegetation in deserts (i.e., Tamarix) (Becerra et al. 2001). This species usually overwinters as nymphs and the adults appear in spring (Battiston et al. 2010).
threats: This species needs further investigation to understand potential threats. This species probably lives in small local populations that may quickly disappear if threatened.
population: This mantid species is widespread, but locally not abundant and difficult to encounter, even if in some localities its presence is well recorded (e.g., Canary Islands).
range: Blepharopsis mendica is a widespread species, distributed in North Africa and Middle East from the Canary Islands to India (Battiston et al. 2010).
useTrade: This species is sometimes captured in nature as individuals or oothecae and bred as a pet or sold. There is however no information available on the impact of this practice on the natural populations.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place at a global level. However, this species needs to be monitored in nature to understand the real consistence of the local populations and potential threats investigated to confirm its conservation status. The impact of trading also needs to be evaluated.

rationale: Hypsicorypha gracilis is a widespread species which has been recorded from almost all of North Africa, even if it has been recently shown that many historical records were based on misidentifications (Wieland et al. 2014), suggesting that the real distribution of this species could be smaller or even severely fragmented. At present, with the data availble the species is therefore assessed as Least Concern, but further investigation on its real distribution are strongly suggested.
habitat: Hypsicorypha gracilis lives in the the North African and Arabian dry shrubland, from the typical Mediterranean vegetation to semi-desert environments. Its ecology is however almost unknown (Battiston et al. 2010).
threats: Further investigation is needed to understand the threats to this species. The species is widespread, but not common. It may be locally threatened by natural or artificial environmental changes and habitat destruction.
population: Hypsicorypha gracilis is generally not common, but in some places has been recorded as locally abundant (e.g., Canary Islands, Becerra et al. 2001).
range: Hypsicorypha gracilis is a widespread mantid species. Its presence has been historically cited for North Africa from the Canary Islands to Somalia and in the Arabian peninsula (Battiston et al. 2010, Alexandre 2012). This species has been often confused with the similar genus Empusa Illiger, 1798 and some distribution records need to be verified in order to trace out the real distribution of this species.
useTrade: This species is sometimes captured in nature. Individuals or oothecae  are sold or bred as pets. There is however no information on the  impact of this practice on the natural populations.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place. This species needs to be monitored in nature to understand the size and trends of the local subpopulations. Also, research on its ecology and potential threats is needed to confirm its conservation status. Many collecting records are sometimes confused with Empusa (Wieland et al. 2015) and historical distribution reported in literature need to be verified to understand the real distribution of this species.

rationale: This species is globally assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread and common in many parts of its native range. Conservation planning is recommended in Tunisia where it is reported to be threatened. In addition, it would be advisable to determine whether the range of genetic diversity found across this species' full range in situ is sufficiently represented in the accessions stored ex situ. Where this is not the case, additional material should be collected to fill these gaps.
habitat: This species occurs in a range of habitats, notably scrub, matorral, open oak forest, calcareous gravelly soil, rocky limestone and loamy sand; it is mainly restricted to coastal regions (Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 2001, Al-Saghir and Porter 2012). In Greece this species coincides with the distribution of olive trees (Zakynthinos and Rouskas 2001). In Lebanon, in the area of Mount Lebanon, it is generally found at elevations of 0–500 m asl in areas with an annual precipitation of 800–1200 mm; in this area it grows in woodland and shrubland habitats, on hillsides or forest margins, and is associated with Quercus, Pinus, Ceratonia, Olea and Amygdalus species (Talhouk et al. 2001).
threats: In Lebanon this species is threatened by habitat loss from urban expansion and deforestation (Talhouk et al. 2001). The threats in other parts of this species' distributional range remain unknown.
population: This species is reported to be common in coastal regions across much of its Mediterranean range (Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 2001). This is particularly true in Greece, where it is the most common of the Pistacia species present in the country (Zakynthinos and Rouskas 2001). It is assumed to be common in Spain where Batlle et al. (2001) report that it is not endangered and it is widely reported that it is common in Crete, Sardinia and coastal Italy (Pignatti 1982, Garcia-Fayos and Verdu 1998, Fielding and Turland 2005, Delfino 2010). In northern Africa, it is very common in Morocco, where it is well adapted to a range of soil and climatic conditions in the Mediterranean area (Loudyi 2001). In Tunisia it is primarily found in the north of the country, however it is threatened with extinction and rehabilitation planning is required (Ghorbel et al. 2001) and in Egypt, Hussain (2001) reports that is occurs in the northwest coastal zone in Wadi Batoum, south of Sollum. In western Asia it is reported to occur along the Lattakia coast in Syria (Hadj-Hassan 2001), from Tripoli to Batroun and in the Baabda region in Lebanon (it no longer occurs in Beirut or Saida) (Talhouk et al. 2001), and in Turkey is occurs in the Mediterranean and southeast Aegean region and the Eageon region (Atli et al. 2001). Due to its widespread nature and reports that it is common in many of the countries within its native range, the global population is suspected to be stable. This is supported but Chadburn (2014) who reported that this species' population was stable in Europe.
range: Pistacia lentiscus is distributed in the Mediterranean, it is native to northern Africa, southern Europe and western Asia (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013). It grows at elevations between sea level and 2,000 m asl (Al-Saghir and Porter 2012).
useTrade:
Pistacia lentiscus belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Pistachio P. vera and so it has the potential for use as a gene donor for crop improvement (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013).

In addition, the variety chia is cultivated exclusively on Chios island in Greece for gum, aromatic resin, and mastic oil; the product, taken from the bark of the Pistacia lentiscus var. chia, is commonly known as mastic (with many variations in spelling) and is used as a culinary ingredient for the production of confectionery and in the distillery industry (Zakynthinos and Rouskas 2001).
conservationActions:
A total of seven germplasm accessions are held at the National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS), in the USA (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2013) all of which are of wild origin but none of which are duplicated at a second site. No accessions have yet been duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Global Seed Vault (SGSV Data Portal 2013), but living collections are present in 66 botanical gardens worldwide (BGCI 2013). Four germplasm accessions are present in the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew and are duplicated at the National Center for Agricultural Research & Technology Transfer (NCARTT) in Jordan, however, it is unknown whether these are of wild origin. A further three accessions of wild origin are conserved in Madrid, Spain (EURISCO Catalogue 2013).

The in situ conservation status of this species remains unknown. However, it is not thought to be endangered in Spain (Batlle et al. 2001) but is threatened in Tunisia where rehabilitation programmes are recommended (Ghorbel et al. 2001). Chadburn (2014) assessed this species as Least Concern in Europe.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the species' population size, trends, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. Research should be conducted to determine the population size, trends, habitat and if there are any threats to the species as it has such a small extent of occurrence and require a threatened status.
habitat: The species is kleptoparasitic, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species. The habitat of this species is unknown although Andrena chalcogastra is likely to be the host of this cuckoo bee (Warncke 1992).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range:
This species is known to be endemic to the island of Gomera, Canary Islands (Warncke 1992).
The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 20 km2 and the area of occupancy is 20 km2.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not included in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. Research should be conducted on the species’ population size, trends, habitat and ecology, and to ascertain if there are any threats to the species. The species occurs in the Garajonay National Park.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species especially as it is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria and because it could be classified as threatened due to the low extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO).
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range:
This species is endemic to the island of Gran Canaria, the Canary Islands, Spain (Warncke 1992).
The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 860 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 40 km2.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats to the species. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: The species is kleptoparasitic, in that it parasitises the nests of other bee species. There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range:
The species is endemic to Tenerife in the Canary Islands (Warncke 1992).

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 177 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 20 km2.
useTrade: The species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is unknown whether it occurs within any protected areas. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species, especially as it is an island endemic.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern based on its wide distribution and relatively abundant local subpopulations in some areas.
habitat: Aphodius hieroglyphicus is a typical species of semi-arid, arid and desert regions, both in plain as mountainous landscape. According to the known localities, its preferential habitats are steppes and open areas, at low and medium altitude, with semiarid to hyper arid-eremic ombrotype and low vegetation cover; likewise, it lives in oasis with formations of palm trees, Phoenix dactylifera (J.L. Ruiz pers. obs. 1990). It is an euryphagic species, feeding on sheep, cattle, camel and horse dung, but also in dog and human faeces (Schaztmayr 1937, Miessen 2002, Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006b, J.L. Ruiz pers. obs. 1990). Adults are active mainly in autumn, winter (October, November, December, January, February) and early spring (April; Normand 1936, Mateu 1950, Alfieri 1976, Miessen 2002, Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006).
threats: There is no information available on specific threats affecting this species but there are not thought to be any major threats. As for dung beetles in general, this species could be affected by changes in land use, or in agro pastoral practices (livestock abandonment, livestock intensification and some veterinary treatments), which affect soil structure, dung availability and dung quality, which could influence the number of individuals at local and landscape levels (e.g. Lumaret et al. 1993, Hutton and Giller 2003, Lobo et al. 2006, Lumaret et al. 2012).
population: There is no specific information available on the size and trend of the population. It is a quite frequent species (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006). In Tunisia it seems to be rare (I. Labidi pers. obs. 2011). In Morocco it is relatively abundant in some arid areas (J.L. Ruiz pers. obs. 1990, F. Sánchez-Piñero pers. obs. 2013-2014), and according to Tauzin (1990), A. hieroglyphicus is common in southern Morocco. Schatzmayr (1937, 1946) pointed out that this species was very common in northern Libya and Egypt.
range:
This species, described from “Tscheil-el-achterie, Alexandrie”, Egypt (Klug 1845), has a wide distribution in southern and eastern parts of the Mediterranean basin, mainly in northern Africa and the near east, in semiarid and arid lands, from southern Morocco to western Iran, including the Canary Islands (Baraud 1985, Hollande et al. 1998, Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at elevations ranging from sea level to 1,800 m asl. In Canary Island it was recorded from the eastern islands: Lanzarote, Fuerteventura, Gran Canaria and Tenerife (Machado and Oromí 2000, Cabrero-Sañudo and Lobo 2000). In Morocco, A. hieroglyphicus is known from more than 25 localities, distributed throughout the meridional (southern of Middle Atlas) and eastern regions, from Berguent (south of Oujda) to Essaouira and Ifni (e.g. Mateu 1950, Kocher 1953, Kocher 1958, Baraud 1985, Tauzin 1990, Ahrens and Zorn 1996, Miessen 2002, Loboet al. 2010). In Algeria, it is known from over ten localities in arid and predesertic regions in the north of the country (Baraud 1985). In Tunisia, it occupies the central and southern semiarid and desertic regions and it has been recorded from ten localities (Normand 1936, Baraud 1985, Labidi pers. obs. 2010-2012). According to Schatzmayr (1937, 1946) is a very common species in Libya (Cirenaica and Tripolitania) and Egypt; also Alfieri (1976) recorded it from Mayrut and Alexandria regions, in the Egyptian Mediterranean part. Finally, A. hieroglyphicus has been cited generically of Israel, Palestine, Syria, Iran, Lebanon and Jordan (D’Orbigny 1896, Balthasar 1964, Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006, Sabatinelli 2011, Khalaf-Sakerflake 2013, Bunalski et al. 2014). There are some potential habitats in Irak and Arabia Saudi but there are no any species record from those countries.

The ancient record of Iberian Peninsula (Cuenca), sub Aphodius hieroglyphicus castilianus J. Daniel 1903, is erroneous (see Baraud 1986).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species. Parts of the known species distribution are included in areas with legal protection (e.g. Morocco: Sous Massa National Park; Tunisia: Jebil National Park). The presence of sustainable numbers of freely grazing livestock through the area of distribution of the species should be maintained. More research on the distribution, ecology and threats is needed for this species.

rationale: The species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively wide distribution and saprophagous habits.
habitat: It is not strict coprophagous, in Guadix (Spain), the species was more frequent in oak and shrublands litter than in faeces (Sanchez-Piñero 1994). The larvae was described by Verdú and Galante (2000). The species is present in shrublands and open forests (dehesa), semi-arid and arid habitats, active in spring and winter (Verdú and Galante 2000).
threats: There is no information available on the specific threats affecting this species. Because it does not depend exclusively on dung, the species is less affected by changes management of livestock, but habitat loss, fragmentation and intensive agriculture could produce local reductions. There is a potential risk of mortality of larvae when breeding adults use dung contaminated with some veterinary medical products (Lumaret et al. 1993, Hutton and Giller 2003, Lobo et al. 2006).
population: No information but the species is rare in Spain (Verdú pers. obs. 2014).
range: The species is recorded from southern Spain, Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya. from sea level up to 1,300 m. Also found in the Canary Island (Gran Canaria) (Schoolmeesters and Van den Heuvel 2003) but most of the distribution is Mediterranean.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. More research on distribution, ecology and threats is needed for this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern based on a suspected stable population and a lack of ongoing threats.
habitat: It is an eurytopic species but prefers exposed pastures and cleared holm-oak woods. It is a coprophagous species feeding on all kinds of dung but mainly on cow and ovine dung. The adults are active in spring, summer and mainly in autumn, but there is only one generation a year (Veiga 1998).
threats: Apparently there are no major threats affecting this species.
population: In the preferred habitats it is a frequent species (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006). It is sporadic northwards, where the close species A. ictericus is more common (Veiga 1998).
range: The species is widely distributed in the Mediterranean region, from Portugal, Spain and Morocco to Turkey, Lebanon and Israel. It is also recorded from Iran, Saudi Arabia and Iraq. It is distributed from sea level up to 2,000 m asl, but it is more abundant from zero to 1,000 m asl (Baraud 1985, Baraud 1992, Veiga 1998, Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006). There are some potential areas of occurrence in Syria, Albania, Macedonia and Bosnia-Herzegovina but there are no records from these countries.
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: In general for the conservation of dung beetles, the presence of sustainable numbers of freely grazing livestock, through the area of distribution of the species should be maintained. More studies on the distribution and taxonomic status are needed for this species.

rationale: This species is one of the most important tropical and subtropical fruit trees, widely cultivated throughout most tropical and subtropical countries, even becoming invasive in some. Its exact native range is uncertain but likely originated in Mexico and is natively distributed throughout a range of habitats, mainly disturbed areas, in Central America and western South America. The estimated extent of occurrence (15,000,000 km<sup>2</sup>) and area of occupancy (2,500-850,000 km<sup>2</sup>) exceed the thresholds for a threatened category. Although the overall population size and trend of this species are unknown, it is very frequent throughout its range and thrives in disturbed areas. It is assessed at present as Least Concern.
habitat: This species can be a shrub or a tree growing up to c. 12 m in height (Landrum 2017). It is cultivated worldwide and occurs throughout a large range of habitats, thriving mostly on roadsides with occasional abundant water and disturbed areas, including pastures, probably originated in riparian areas with periodic drought (Landrum 2017). It has been listed as an invasive species in various countries, where it invades mainly disturbed, but also undisturbed, areas and grows in dense thickets (Global Invasive Species Database 2018). Its adaptability might be one of the main reasons to be such a serious weed in some areas (Global Invasive Species Database 2018), as well as its allelopathy (Chapla and Campos 2010). It is pollinated mainly by honeybees and is dispersed by birds, monkeys, rats, feral pigs (Global Invasive Species Database 2018), bats and there is even a record of its fruits being eaten by opossums (Pizo 2000).
threats: There are no documented major threats for this species. Although there  are high deforestation rates in parts of its native distribution range,  this species thrives in disturbed areas and might actually benefit from  deforestation.
population: Although this species is very abundant considering its wide range and the number of specimens collected in the wild and from native countries held in different herbaria, the overall population size and trend are unknown.
range: This species probably originated in Mexico and is native from Central and western South America, from Mexico to Argentina. However, its exact native range is uncertain as it has been introduced in most tropical and subtropical countries for its edible fruits (Landrum 2017), including in Southeast Asia, Australia, central and southern Africa and eastern South America (WCSP 2018). It has become naturalised in many of these countries and it has been listed as invasive in other regions, such as Hawaii, Galapagos, southern Africa, New Zealand (Cronk and Fuller 2001) and many other pacific islands (Global Invasive Species Database 2018). Its extent of occurrence (EOO), based on its native distribution, has been calculated as more than 15,000,000 km<sup>2</sup> and its area of occupancy (AOO) is much larger than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is one of the most important tropical and subtropical fruit trees widely cultivated for its edible fruits, rich in vitamin C and eaten raw or processed into jams and preserves, beverages and ice creams (Berry et al. 2003). It is also used medicinally for various purposes such as gastroenteritis, dysentery, stomach (Gutiérrez et al. 2008) and dental infections (Agbor and Naidoo 2015). Researched has showed that its leaves have antioxidant, anti-allergic, anti-inflammatory, analgesic and anti-bacterial properties (Gutiérrez et al. 2008). Its wood is also used in carpentry, construction and manufacture of toys and accessories (Gutiérrez et al. 2008).

rationale: Prunus domestica is considered here as Data Deficient. This species native range is unknown but evidence points to an origin in the Mediterranean and/or the Caucasus. Due to our limited knowledge of its native range, true population information is not known and we do not know what the native habitat and the ecology of the species is. It is therefore essential that research is conducted to resolve these knowledge gaps.
habitat: Prunus domestica is a small tree or large shrub. Its natural habitat is unknown as the species native range is not known. We can infer from its cultivation that the species grows optimally in areas with cold winters and long warm summers as vernalisation is required for flowering. The species can tolerate frost, however, when this occurs after flowering the fruit quality is poor (Lim 2002).
threats: The native range of this species is unknown and so threats remain unknown.
population: Population information is unknown as native range is unknown.
range: Prunus domestica is a widely cultivated species hence its native range is unknown and the species is naturalised in many countries. The species is thought to have originated from Southern Europe or Western Asia near the Caucasus Mountains and the Caspian Sea. This original population may have also occurred in the Balkans and in Mediterranean countries (OECD 2002). Cultivation of the species is estimated to have begun in 500 BC (Lim 2002). The species is hypothesised to be derived from a hybridisation event between Prunus spinosa and Prunus cerasifolia, however the details of such event is still not fully understood (Eryomine 1990, Horvath et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species, commonly known as plum, is widely cultivated for its edible fruit. The fruit is eaten and used to produce food and drink items such as jams, preserves and alcoholic beverages. It is also important as a food source for mammals and birds. The species can also be used to produce timber to be used in musical instrument production (Woodland Trust 2017). The wide cultivation of this species means many horticultural varieties exist. It is also a graftstock relative of apricot (P. armeniaca L.) and Japanese plum (P. salicina Lindl.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
conservationActions: Twenty-six germplasm accessions are found in the NPGS, six of which are wild material. However, none of these collections are documented to be backed up at a second site (USDA, ARS, National Germplasm Resource Program 2013). There are also 59 ex situ collections from across the globe (BGCI 2017). In Switzerland the species is listed as Least Concern (Moser et al. 2002) and Data Deficient in Europe. The species requires research to define its native range and the population size across this range. Threats should also be identified.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat or biology of this species.
threats: <span lang="EN-US">The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available for the population size and trend of this species.
range: The species is only known from the Canary Islands (Ascher and Pickering 2014).
useTrade: <span lang="EN-GB">This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the population size and trend, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. Research should be conducted to determine the status of this species.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat or biology of this species.

population: The species is considered rather common and the population trend is unknown.
range: The species is known only from the Canary Islands (Ascher and Pickering 2014).
useTrade: <span lang="EN-GB">This species is not traded or exploited commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no information available on the population size, trends, habitat, ecology and threats. Research should be conducted in order to determine the status of this species.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: <span lang="EN-US">The threats to this species are not known.
population: <span lang="EN-US">It is a rare species known from only few localities. The population trend is unknown.
range: The species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Ascher and Pickering 2014).

conservationActions: The species is not listed in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is unknown whether its distribution overlaps with any protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted to determine the population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: The Gran Canaria Green Bush-cricket is endemic to Gran Canaria, where it occurs in forested habitats. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 718 km² and there is a continuing decline in the EOO, area of occupancy (AOO), number of subpopulations, extent and quality of habitat as well as number of mature individuals. The main threat to the species is the increasing frequency of wildfires. The species occurs in five locations. It is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN).
habitat: This species occurs in forest habitats. It is not very specialised and can also be found in gardens. Its altitudinal range is 300 - 1,300 m.
threats: This species is mainly threatened by increasing wildfire frequencies on Gran Canaria. A wildfire in 2007 in the southwestern part of the island destroyed c. 25% of its habitat. Based on this threat, the number of locations is estimated to be five. The species may also be affected by the ongoing urbanisation of the island, the increasing number of droughts caused by climate change and the risk of landslides.
population: A recent study showed that the species has lost nearly all subpopulations in the southwestern part of the island, where a large wildfire occurred in 2007 (A. Miller pers. comm. 2013). This fire destroyed c. 25% of its habitat. It is likely that other wildfires on Gran Canaria had similar effects on this species and this threat is likely to continue in the future. The population trend is decreasing, and there is a continuing decline in the extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO), number of subpopulations, extent and quality of habitat and number of mature individuals.
range: This species is endemic to Gran Canaria, where it mainly occurs at the northern solpes and in the centre of the island (Bland et al. 1996, Arnedo et al. 2008). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 718 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions in place for this species, but it occurs in protected areas, such as the Parque Natural de Tamadaba. A proper fire management needs to be implemented to avoid future declines of the species. More research into its population trend is required.

rationale: The Gomera Green Bush-cricket (Calliphona gomerensis) is endemic to the laurel forests of La Gomera. Although its habitats are still quite common and protected on La Gomera, it is threatened by increasing fire frequencies, which have recently even affected the Garajonay National Park. The species is only known from five locations and has a small area of occupancy (AOO) of 32 km² with a maximum estimate of 100 km². Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 142 km² with a maximum estimate of 200 km². There is a continuing decline in the extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO), extent and quality of the habitat, number of subpopulations and the number of mature individuals. It is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN).
habitat: Calliphona gomerensis occurs mainly in laurel forests and other forested habitats. Its altitudinal range is 130 - 1,350 m.
threats: The species is mainly confined to laurel forests, which are still common on La Gomera, but threatened by increasing fire frequencies. A large wildfire in 2012 has destroyed parts of its habitat. On the basis of this threat, the species is known from five locations. It may also be affected by the risk of landslides.
population: The species is quite widespread in the forests of La Gomera, but the population is decreasing as a consequence of recent wildfires.
range: The Gomera Green Bush-cricket is endemic to La Gomera, where it mainly occurs in laurel forest (Pfau and Pfau 2007, Arnedo et al. 2008). Its known extent of occurrence (EOO) is 142 km² with a maximum estimate of 200 km². Its known area of occupancy (AOO) is 32 km² with a maximum estimate of 100 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions in place for this species, but it occurs in protected areas throughout its range. More research on its population trend is needed. Proper fire management is required to avoid future declines, and the destroyed habitat needs to be restored.

rationale:
Silene vulgaris is widespread and often common where it occurs. The population trend appears to be stable at most of the sites due to the frequency of the species, the high number of mature individuals and the population density. The estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy are greater than 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2 respectively. In addition, the threats affecting the species are of low to  medium impact with a small scope and range, they are unlikely to cause the populations to decline quickly in the near future to a threatened category.

Therefore, Silene vulgaris is assessed as Least Concern (LC).
habitat:
Silene vulgaris is found on a wide range of habitats including sandy and stony pastures, meadows, yards, cultivated lawns, banks, roadsides, rocky cliffs, scrub, woodlands clearings, uncultivated fields, inhabits crops, wood grassy mountains, wasteland, seashores, cracks in waterside rocks, woodland and Mediterranean forest (Maire 1961, Tutin et al. 1980, Greuter et al. 1984, Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987, Ali et al. 1989, Boulos 1999, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Le Floc'h and Boulos 2009, Marhold 2011, Tela Botanica 2013, Flora-On 2014).  

Silene vulgaris is a perennial herb, prefers moist humid to dry substrates, stony, clay, gritty loam and sandy soils, relatively poor with a basic pH. This species grows in full sun light to mid-shade and flowers from April to September (Maire 1961, Ali et al. 1989, Boulos 1999, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Le Floc'h and Boulos 2009, Flora-On 2014).

Silene vulgaris protects itself from the heat and from drying out with a bluish green covering of wax, roots reach down deep into the ground and the layer of air inside the calyx insulates the flower’s more delicate inner parts. Silene vulgaris attract the pollinators’ butterflies, small beetles, flower flies and bees by secreting a pleasant, clove-like fragrance by night as the flowers are open all day but their clove-like scent is only emitted in the evening.
threats: Silene vulgaris is widespread, largely distributed and common where it occurs with no significant threats cross its global range. However, the species is locally declining in some sites due to numerous low to medium impact threats especially coastal development, urbanisation, tourism, overgrazing, trampling, habitat fragmentation, demographic pressure, direct and indirect impact of human activities, collection practices and over collection by locals and collectors for domestic uses as a remedy or to trade with local herbalists especially in North Africa (Barbero et al. 1990, Bellakhdar et al. 1991, Bellakhdar 1997, Blondel and Aronson 1999, Benabid 2002, RBOSM 2008, Blondel and Medail 2009, Taleb and Fennane 2011).
population: Silene vulgaris is widespread and common where it occurs with several localities and subpopulations. As far as population size is concerned, no precise count has ever been made and the trend of the population remains unknown due to the lack of quantitative data, but it appears to be stable at all the sites due to the frequency of the species, the high number of mature individuals and the population density (Maire 1961, Tutin et al. 1980, Greuter et al. 1984, Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987, Ali et al. 1989, Boulos 1999, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Le Floc'h and Boulos 2009, Marhold 2011, Tela Botanica 2013, Flora-On 2014, Euro+Med 2015, USDA NRCS 2015).
range:
Silene vulgaris is widespread in the Mediterranean region, most parts of Europe, Macaronesia, Asia (to Siberia, the Russian Far East (west and east Siberia, Sakhalin, the Kamtschatka Peninsula), China, India (Kashmir) and Nepal), and North Africa (GRIN 2015). Silene vulgaris is frequent throughout Europe except for some northern islands, common to the whole of Europe, native in Turkey, the eastern Mediterranean, the Caucasus, Iran, Central Asia, and is naturalized in North America (Tutin et al. 1980, Greuter et al. 1984, Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987, Marhold 2011, Tela Botanica 2013, Flora-On 2014, Euro+Med 2015, USDA-NRCS 2015).  

The species is widespread in North Africa, common in Algeria (Maire 1961), Tunisia (Le Floc'h and Boulos 2009), Libya (Ali et al. 1989), Egypt (Boulos 1999) and Morocco where it is found in most of the major floristic divisions with several subspecies, varieties and forms (Jahandiez and Maire 1932, Fennane et al. 1999, Benabid 2002, Valdés et al. 2002, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Taleb and Fennane 2008, Romo 2009, Dobignard and Chatelain 2010, Valdés 2013). 

Silene vulgaris is found up to 2,200 m altitude.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) and the area of occupancy (AOO) are greater than 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2 respectively.
useTrade:
The decoction roots of Silene vulgaris in milk or water are used as an emetic, general antidote in poisoning, against constipation, intestinal pains, infusion, used externally to treat wounds, scabies, itching and various skin conditions.  This decoction with soft dates is used by the women for abortion or they introduced a long root into the cervix to burst the amniotic sac and cause abortion (Bellakhdar et al. 1991, Bellakhdar 1997, Benchaabane and Abbad 1997, Sijelmassi 2011).

The young leaves are sweet and very agreeable in salads, harvested when about 5cm long, have a flavour similar to green peas but with a slight bitterness. When pureed it is said to rival the best spinach purees. The leaves should be used before the plant starts to flower. Silene vulgaris should be used by caution for its toxicity (Bellakhdar 1997, Sijelmassi 2011).

Toxicity: Although no mention of toxicity has been seen for this species, it does contain saponins. This toxic substance is very poorly absorbed by the body and so tends to pass through without causing harm. Saponins are found in many plants often used for food, such as certain beans. Although saponins molecules are broken by cooking, it is advisable not to eat large quantities of food that contain saponins. Saponins are much more toxic to as fish.

Constituents: Silene vulgaris is rich in saponins especially the roots and there is also a large amount of lactosine, which is a mixture of oligo-saccharides, hydrolysis and mainly galactose.
conservationActions:
Although the species is common and widespread some conservation measures are recommended to protect Silene vulgaris and keep the population stable, particularly in North Africa; 

• Protection of the species sites from habitat loss and fragmentation, over-collection, and overgrazing. .

• Fencing the vulnerable sites to protect the species from over-collection and improve local practices of collecting the species. 

• Protection of living individuals of the species through legislation and legal protection which ban the species being picked or dug up.

• Pastoral and silvo-pastoral improvement through the organization of pastoralists and establishment of a rotation system for pasture to reduce overgrazing, trampling and the pressure on the species.

• Participative approaches with communities and local people for implementing the conservation actions.

rationale:
Ferula communis grows natively in southern and central Europe, in lands around the Mediterranean Sea, Middle East, the Canary Islands, the Balkan Peninsula, Apennine Peninsula, the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa. Ferula communis is common in the Mediterranean Region and North Africa with several localities and the abundance varies from occasional to dominant.

Ferula communis is least concern and common in most of the countries, the overall trend of the population is stable, the estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy are greater than 20000 km2 and 2000 km2 respectively. In addition, the threats affecting the species are of low to medium impact with a small scope and range, they are unlikely to cause the populations to decline quickly in the near future to a threatened category, if we apply the recommended conservation measures. 

Therefore, Ferula communis is assessed globally and regionally as Least Concern (LC).
habitat:
Ferula communis has typical habitats that include forest glades, rough grassland, banks, pastures, ruderal community, rocky glades, rocky pastures, uncultivated land, mountain plain, river banks, pond margins, river beds, olive groves, waste ground, stony places, woodlands, shrublands, low mountains pastures, coastal edges, steep hills and Mediterranean forest (Nègre 1961, Pignatti 1982, Valdés et al. 1987, Posada and Martin 1993, Conti et al. 2005, Blanca et al. 2011, Hand 2011, Tela Botanica 2013, Flora-on 2014).

Ferula communis is a tall herbaceous perennial geophyte plant; grows in a range of soils from light (sandy), medium (loamy) to heavy (clay); prefers wet to well drained acid, neutral and basic (alkaline) substrates and can tolerate drought due to the enormous root system; prefers open to mid-shaded habitats but it cannot grow in shaded habitats; flowers from May to July; grows in a humid, sub-humid, sub-arid to Arid climates; flowers are hermaphrodite, self-fertile and are pollinated by flies (Jahandiez and Maire 1934, Nègre 1961, Benabid 2002, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Collin 2012, Valdés 2013, Lamnauer 2014).
threats: Ferula communis is common, widespread, varies in abundance from occasional to abundant, the overall trend of the population is stable but some subpopulations are declining due to numerous threats of low to medium impact including; overgrazing, deforestation, habitat fragmentation, demographic pressure, tourism, collection practices and ruthless collection for domestic uses as a remedy or for national and International trade (e.g. Morocco local markets prices 300 -800 Dhs/kg) (Barbero et al. 1990, Bellakhdar 1997, Blondel and Aronson 1999, Blondel and Medail 2009). Ferula communis is threatened more generally by the direct and indirect impact of human activities such as leisure activities, infrastructure development and urbanisation (Benabid 2002, RBOSM 2008, Taleb and Fennane 2011).
population:
Ferula communis is common in the Mediterranean region and North Africa with several localities and sub-populations. Ferula communis is common on all its stations where it occurs and the abundance varies from occasional to dominant.

As far as population size is concerned, no precise count has ever been made and the trend of the population remains unknown due to the lack of quantitative data but the overall trend of the population appears to be stable.

The number of mature individuals and the subpopulation of Ferula communis are significantly high but some subpopulation are reduced during last decades.
range:
