Ferula communis grows natively in southern and central Europe, in lands around the Mediterranean Sea, the Middle East, the Canary Islands, the Balkan Peninsula, Apennine Peninsula, the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa (Tutin et al. 1980, Greuter et al. 1984, Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987 and 2012, Hand 2011, Flora-On 2014, Euro+Med 2015).

In the Mediterranean and Europe region, the plant is common, occurring from Portugal to Greece, Spain, France, Corsica, Italy, Sardinia, Sicily, Albania and Cyprus. In Portugal, F. communis found throughout the country but absent from Braga and Viana do Castelo regions (Sequeira et al. 2010, Flora-On 2014). In Spain, F. communis is frequent throughout the the country and occurs in most of the provinces (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987, Posada and Martin 1993, Blanca et al. 2011). In France,the plant is known from Corsica and from mainland France (Aude, Herault, Vaucluse, Var, Alpes, Gironde and Charente regions; Tela Botanica 2013). In Italy, the plant occurs in Sardinia, Sicily, Puglia and Abruzzo regions (Pignatti 1982, Conti et al. 2005). In Greece, F. communis is found in on the mainland and Crete (Dimopoulos 2013).

In the Middle East, F. communis is found in Turkey, Israel, Jordan, Palestine, Lebanon and Syria. In Israel, the plant is known from the Golan, Gallilee, Upper Jordan valley, Northern valleys, Gilboa, Samarian desert, Judean desert and Dead Sea valley, Sharon, Shefela, Northern Negev (Israeli Wildflowers 2015). In Turkey, the plant is known from seven sites (Istanbul, Bursa, Izmir, Antalya, Samsun and Elazig; Davis 1965, Fakir and Özçelik 2009).

In North Africa, the plant occurs mostly in Morocco and Algeria, but is also found in Tunisia and Libya, but not Egypt (Battandier and Trabut 1888, Quézel and Santa 1963, Pottier-Alapetite 1981, Ali et al. 1989, Le Floc'h and Boulos 2009). In Morocco, F. communis is found in many localities throughout the country, occurring mostly along the Atlantic coasts from Larache to Ifni, inside the country and up until the Mediterranean coast (Jahandiez and Maire 1934, Maire 1961, Nègre 1961, Benabid 2002, Valdés et al. 2002, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Terrab et al. 2006, Fennane et al. 2007, Taleb and Fennane 2008, Romo 2009, Dobignard and Chatelain 2010, Collin 2012, Valdés 2013, Lamnauer 2014). 

Ferula communis can be found up to 2,500 m altitude.

The estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy are greater than 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2 respectively.
useTrade:
Ferula communis is a source of resin gum (Fessoukh: rhizome and unopened inflorescence) used in traditional medicine for a variety of ailments and the pre-blossom inflorescences have culinary uses. The whole plant is said to possess antispasmodic properties. “Fessoukh” is commonly used in ritual or magic fumigation and in sorcery, is believed to keep away the “evil spirits” and the “evil” (Boulos 1983, Bellakhdar, 1997, Sijelmassi 2011, Plants for a Future 2012, Lamnauer 2014).

Ferula communis is prescribed to treat many diseases: externally with olive oil to treat a variety of skin diseases, in friction it is used against moths, ringworm, alopecia areata, rheumatism, to heal in the feet cracks and to add to some depilatory preparations. Orally it is prescribed by practitioners as an antihelmintic, diuretic, vermifuge, powerful analgesic, rheumatism, pains in the joints, female sterility, and as an emetic (Boulos 1983, Bellakhdar, 1997, Sijelmassi 2011, Plants for a Future 2012, Lamnauer 2014).

The roasted flower buds are absorbed as vermifuge, antihysteric, hysteria, dysentery, and as anaphrodisiac. The roots are also used for hair care (Boulos 1983, Bellakhdar, 1997, Sijelmassi 2011).

Ferula communis is also consumed as vegetable; “L’boubal” the young stems or pre-blossom inflorescence is consumed as a vegetable, the unopened inflorescence steamed with couscous, olive oil, vinegar, and other spices as desired. The consumption of the plant is not totally harmless (Boulos 1983, Bellakhdar, 1997, Sijelmassi 2011).

Toxicity: Poisoning in Man and animals depends on the amount of the plant materiel ingested and the duration of the ingestion. The toxicity of Ferula communis for livestock is well known especially in autumn when grass is scarce. Ferula communis poisoning in humans is reported as healing accidents, mainly by oral use of “Fessoukh” or after the overuse or continuous ingestion of the unopened inflorescence as a legume for several days (more than 5 to 6 days). Pregnant women or women during menstruation are the most affected due to haemorrhage and abundant bleeding childbirth or abortion. Persons under therapeutic use of drugs with some anticoagulant activity should avoid consumption of the pre-blossom inflorescence or fessoukh (Valle et al. 1987, Appendinno et al. 1988, Bellakhdar et al. 1991, Lamnaouer et al. 1990 and 1991, Faiz 1992, Tligui and Ruth 1994, Bellakhdar 1997, Benchaabane and Abbad 1997, Lamnauer 2014).

Toxicity symptoms: In animals: Produces an increase in prothrombin time and haemorrhage, loss of appetite, melancholy aspect, anorexia, diarrhoea, nosebleeds, hematuria, numbness, breathing difficulty, the pulse decreases, the temperature goes below normal, asphyxia and death. In Man: Great weakness with paleness, shortness of breath, diarrhea, ecchymotic plaques on the legs, rapidly a state of great numbness settles, difficulties in walking, the inside of the legs and feet are covered with bloody serous fluid and death occurs in serious cases. These effects are reversed by the injection of vitamin K1 (an antagonist of coumarin anticoagulants) (Valle et al. 1987, Appendinno et al. 1988, Bellakhdar et al. 1991, Lamnaouer et al. 1990 and 1991, Faiz 1992,Tligui and Ruth 1994, Bellakhdar 1997, Benchaabane and Abbad 1997, Lamnauer 2014).

Constituents: The most important characteristic of Ferula communis is its capacity to synthesize 4-hydroxycoumarins. The main compounds are: ferulenol, 20-hydroxyferulenol, omega-hydroxyferulenol, (ferulenoloxy-20’)-13 ferulenol and other derivatives. The brevifolia variety in Morocco contains only ferulenol, in addition to daucane sesquiterpenes, as a 4-hydroxycoumarin and ombelliferone (7-hydroxycoumarin) derivatives, which are absent in the genuina variety. “Fessoukh” compound are: 4-hydroxycoumarins are the major constituents, water (6%), essential oil (7.2%), resin (63.3%), salicylic acid (0.12%), soluble gum (14.4 %) and of minerals (0.6%). The main constituents of the inflorescence oil are: myrcene (53.5 %), limonene (6.9 %), a-pinene (6.6 %), aristolene (8.5 %), (E,E)-farnesol (4.3 %) and gurjunene (1.4 %). The oil obtained from the spike has a similar qualitative composition, but differs quantitatively in the major components: aristolene (70.0%) and myrcene (9.3 %) being. The root oil are characterized by the occurrence of sesquiterpenes and the lack of monoterpenes (Valle et al., 1987, Appendinno et al. 1988, Bellakhdar et al. 1991, Lamnaouer et al. 1990 and 1991, Faiz 1992,Tligui and Ruth 1994, Bellakhdar 1997, Benchaabane and Abbad 1997, Lamnauer 2014).
conservationActions:
There are no conservation measures in place for Ferula communis. Although the species is common and the threats are of low to medium impact, the following actions are recommended to protect the species and its habitats where it is declining in the North African parts of its range; 

• Protection of the species sites from habitat loss and fragmentation, deforestation, over-collection, and overgrazing.

• Improve local practices of collecting the species and fencing the vulnerable sites.

• Cultivated specimens should be used in the trade and medicinal uses instead of wild plants.

• Raising of public awareness.

• Estimation of population sizes and study of their dynamics, trends, biology and ecology. 

• Protection of living individuals of the species through legislation and legal protection which ban the species being picked or dug up.

rationale:
Aristolochia paucinervis is fairly common and widely distributed in the western Mediterranean region, the Iberian Peninsula and Macaronesia. Although the population decline appears to be ongoing at some sites, mainly in North Africa (Morocco and Algeria) but the overall population trend appears to be stable. The estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy are large.

In addition, the threats affecting the species are of low to  medium impact with a small scope and they are unlikely to cause the populations to decline quickly in the near future to a threatened category, if we apply the recommended conservation measures. Therefore, Aristolochia paucinervis is assessed globally as Least Concern (LC).
habitat:
Typical habitats include sandy and stony pastures, meadows, rocky cliffs, scrub, woodlands clearings, cultivated fields, weed of crops, wood grassy mountains and Mediterranean forest (Valdés et al. 1987, De Groot et al. 2006, Nardi 2009, Blanca et al. 2011, Tela Botanica 2013, Flora-On 2014).

The plant is a perennial geophyte, prefers moist humid to dry substrates, stony, clay and sandy soils, relatively poor with a basic pH. Grows in full sun to mid-shade and flowers in spring, found in humid and sub-humid to sub-arid Mediterranean bioclimates (Nègre 1961, Fennane et al. 1999, Benabid 2002, Talavera et al. 2003, Romo 2009). Aristolochia paucinervis attract their pollinators (flies) by producing a strong smell from the flowers which are typically saxophone-shaped.
threats: Aristolochia paucinervis has numerous low to medium impact threats including coastal development, tourism, overgrazing, trampling, over-collection, irregular fires and deforestation (Barbero et al. 1990, Blondel and Aronson 1999, Blondel and Medail 2009). Aristolochia paucinervis is threatened more generally by the direct and indirect impact of human activities such as leisure activities, infrastructure development and urbanisation (Peltier 1976, 1978, Taleb and Fennane 2011, Benabid 2002, RBOSM 2008).
population:
Aristolochia paucinervis is widely distributed and fairly common in most parts of its range. It is frequent with several sites in Portugal (Flora-On 2014), fairly common in southwestern Spain (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987, Blanca et al. 2011) and in the south of France (Tela Botanica 2013).

Aristolochia paucinervis is local and fairly common in Algeria and Morocco (with several sites in coastal areas, the Atlas Mountains, Middle and North Atlantic regions, but it is quite rare in the Eastern Mountains (Nègre 1961, Fennane and Mathez 1986, Fennane et al. 1999, Benabid 2002, Valdés et al. 2002, Bammi and Douira 2004, Talavera et al. 2003, Aafi et al. 2005, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Romo 2009, Dobignard and Chatelain 2010, Valdés 2013).

As far as population size is concerned, no precise count has ever been made and the trend of the population remains unknown due to the lack of quantitative data. Although, the population decline appears to be ongoing in few sites especially in North Africa (Morocco and Algeria) but the overall trend of the population is estimated to be stable.
range:
Aristolochia paucinervis is widely distributed in the western Mediterranean region, the Iberian Peninsula and Macaronesia. The species occurs in Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia (presence uncertain), France, Spain (including the Balearic Islands and the Canary Islands), and Portugal (including Madeira) (Tutin et al. 1980, Greuter et al. 1984, De Groot et al. 2006, Borges et al. 2008, Nardi 2009, Flora-On 2014, Euro+Med 2015).

Aristolochia paucinervis is frequent throughout Portugal (Flora-On 2014), commonly appearing in southwestern Spain (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Valdés et al. 1987, Blanca et al. 2011) and in the south of France (Tela Botanica 2013). In North Africa, the species does not exceed to the East, the western part of Algeria (Maire 1961) and is doubtfully found in Tunisia, and the material found there is likely to be A. navicularis (Le Floc'h and Boulos 2009, Le Floc'h et al. (2010; citing de Groot et al. 2006)).

In Morocco, Aristolochia paucinervis occurs in several major floristic divisions: Anti, High. and Middle Atlas, the Rif (Bab Bered, Ketama, Loukkos, Zerhoun), the Eastern Mountains, the Mediterranean coast, Middle Atlantic and North Atlantic (Tsoul, Aknoul, Marmora and Achach forests) (Nègre 1961, Fennane and Mathez 1986, Fennane et al. 1999, Benabid 2002, Dobignard 2002, Valdés et al. 2002, Talavera et al. 2003, Bammi and Douira 2004, Aafi et al. 2005, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Romo 2009, Dobignard and Chatelain 2010, Valdés 2013).

Aristolochia paucinervis is found between 500 and 2,500 m altitude.

The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is more than 20,000 km2 and the estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is more than 2,000 km2.
useTrade:
The dried powdered root of Aristolochia paucinervis is used in the treatment of aortic palpitations, constipation and intestinal disorders, colic, gas gangrene and as a poison antidote for snakebites. The root is also used to treat skin diseases and infections such us such as tinea, dermatitis, impetigo and mycoses. Historically, the roots have been used as a stimulant during labour and from this fact derives its name: aristos-lokia, excellent and delivery. The ingestion of a mixture of small amounts of A. paucinervis rhizome powder with either honey or salted butter is used by several traditional healers for the treatment of abdominal pain, particularly epigastric distress. The whole plant of Aristolochia paucinervis when dried and pulverized is used externally to treat ringworm and wound care (Bellakhdar et al. 1991, Bellakhdar 1997, Benchaabane and Abbad 1997, Gadhi 1999, Sijelmassi 2011, Ouarghidi et al. 2013).

Toxicity: Aristolochia paucinervis is highly toxic due to the presence of "aristolochic acid" which is also carcinogenic; it is particularly dangerous for the kidneys. When the roots are used over a long period, they can cause irreversible kidney damage, haematuria (blood in the urine) and limb paralysis.

Constituents: The roots of Aristolochia paucinervis contain aristolochic acid and its derivatives.
conservationActions:
There are no conservation measures in place for Aristolochia paucinervis. Although the threats are of low to medium impact, the following actions are recommended to protect Aristolochia paucinervis and its habitats in North Africa;

• Protection of the species sites from habitat loss and fragmentation,  random cutting, and overgrazing.

• Improve local practices of collecting the species.

• Fencing vulnerable sites to protect the species from tourism, collection and trampling,, especially coastal populations.

• Estimation of population sizes and study of their dynamics, trends, biology and ecology.

• Protection of living individuals of the species through legislation and legal protection which ban the species being picked or dug up.

• Pastoral, silvo-pastoral improvement and the establishment of natural sanctuaries.

rationale: The threat status of the Sickle-bearing Leaf Katydid (Phaneroptera sparsa) is Least Concern because it has a widespread distribution, a large extent of occurrence and its geographic range is not expected to be severely fragmented or to experience decline or extreme fluctuations presently or in the foreseeable future.
habitat: This species is most often found in tree canopies but in open areas such as the Succulent or Nama Karoo, they inhabit low bushes or dense vegetation along rivers.
threats: This species has a widespread distribution and has no known immediate threats.
population: No information on population sizes or trends is available.
range: The Sickle-bearing Leaf Katydid is widely distributed throughout Africa, the Mid-East, southern Europe and nearby oceanic islands. In South Africa, it can be found in all provinces.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No specific conservation measures are in place for this species but it has a widespread distribution.

rationale:
Citron, Citrus medica L., is a wild Citrus species that is believed to have contributed to the origin of lemon, bergamot and key lime. The native range for the species is somewhat obscure as the species has been cultivated and disseminated for millennia for culinary, medical, ornamental, and cultural uses, and numerous natural hybrids of citron are found in areas where it is indigenous. It is suspected that the species originated in west central Himalaya and that its native range extends from the western Himalaya to Myanmar. Genetic movement between wild and cultivated populations is believed to be ongoing and has led to speculation that no truly wild populations exist, however, genetically wild populations have been recently reported from northeast India, Bangladesh and Myanmar.

The extent of occurrence for the species greatly exceeds the threshold for threatened values and it is suspected that this is reflected in the number of locations for the species, especially if further research identifies additional genetically wild populations across the native range. Uncertainty around the distribution status of wild populations also hampers evaluation of population status and threats in action. In northeast India, an area representing a considerable proportion of the native range, wild populations have declined as a result of harvesting and deforestation and the majority of individuals are thought to be confined to home gardens and agroforestry systems. Despite this, large tracts of suitable habitat remain available across northeast India and the Himalaya region, and it is estimated that reduction in habitat owing to deforestation is not significant enough to qualify for threatened categories.

At present, Citrus medica is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Further research focussed on identifying wild populations across the historic native range is necessary to precisely evaluate the contemporary distribution and population status for the species, and to verify the assigned conservation status. Research into rates of harvesting from the wild is certainly required, and a more specific evaluation of threats in action is also necessary once the distribution of genetically wild population is more thoroughly elucidated. As germplasm accessions are not held from wild populations growing within the native range, collection of representative material is recommended.
habitat: Citron is a straggly evergreen shrub or small tree, ranging in height from 3 to 5 m, with fruit borne on thorny branches. It is relatively short-lived compared to other Citrus species with a life expectancy of 15–18 years and is very sensitive to frost and intense heat and drought; citron is considered the tenderest of all Citrus species. Citron flowers throughout the year and flowers are borne in clusters of 5–20 blooms (Klein 2014, Jones 2016). The fruit is fragrant and typically oblong but demonstrates considerably phenotypic plasticity, with various shapes and smooth or rough fruits sometimes occurring on the same branch (Morton 1987). The fruit ripens from green to yellow or even orange (Klein 2014). It occurs in both primary and secondary forests in the foothills of the Himalayas, and may also grow in rural gardens (Barbhuiya et al. 2016).
threats:
As the precise distribution of genetically wild plants across the native range is not wholly understood, the evaluation of threats in action is more challenging. However, it is reported that in the eastern Himalayan region of northeast India, an area representing a considerable proportion of the native range, wild populations have undergone rapid decline as a result of natural and anthropogenic disturbances.

Natural populations are affected by harvesting and deforestation and the majority of individuals are confined to home gardens and agroforestry systems (Barbhuiya et al. 2016). In areas of northeast India and the Eastern Himalaya region, deforestation and degradation of forest habitat is ongoing (Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund 2005, Chatterjee 2008) and, within India, the northeast states have been identified as the region of greatest contemporary deforestation, along with the Andaman and Nicobar Islands (Reddy et al. 2016). Major drivers of land use change across northeast India and the Eastern Himalaya are shifting cultivation (jhum), encroachment for grazing and timber extraction, and an increase in commercial agricultural plantations (Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund 2005, Chatterjee 2008).

However, despite the threat posed by ongoing deforestation, there remain large tracts of intact subtropical forests across the native range, particularly in Bhutan and areas of northeastern India and northern Myanmar with lower population densities (Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund 2005, Renner et al. 2007). Additionally, if the presence of genetically wild populations in the western Indian Himalaya is confirmed, this would represent another relatively intact area of forest habitat (BirdLife International 2020). In fact, with the exclusion of Assam and Tripura, forest cover in the northeastern states has fallen by less than 20% since 1930 (Reddy et al. 2016); as such, it is estimated that habitat availability across three generations would not qualify for threatened categories on the basis of past reduction.

The citron tree is subject to most of the pests that attack other Citrus species (Morton 1987), however, the pest and disease burden on wild individuals is not well documented. The severity of overharvesting as a threat is not clear. As the species is commonly grown in rural gardens, and plays a cultural rather than commercial role in southeast Asia (Jones 2016), it is suspected that the collection pressure on wild populations is somewhat mitigated. However, further research into rates of harvesting from the wild is certainly required, and a more specific evaluation of threats in action is also necessary once the distribution of genetically wild population is more thoroughly elucidated.
population: Numerical population information for citron is limited, and truly wild populations are difficult to isolate as numerous natural hybrids of citron are found in areas where it is indigenous, with genetic movement between wild and cultivated populations suspected to be ongoing (Barbhuiya et al. 2016, Jones 2016); together, these factors make it challenging to reliably assess the population status. However, it is reported that in the eastern Himalayan region of northeast India, wild populations have undergone rapid decline as a result of natural and anthropogenic disturbances (Barbhuiya et al. 2016). As this region represents a considerable proportion of the global native range, it is inferred that the global population trend may be decreasing. In order to ascertain the population size and verify the direction and magnitude of population change, it is recommended that quantification of populations is a component of research into identifying genetically wild populations across the native range.
range:
The native range for citron is thought to span from the western-central Himalaya to Myanmar (POWO 2019). All citrus forms are thought to have originated from South East Asia but it has been suggested that the citron may have had a comparatively westerly origin in the central Himalayan foothills (Weisskopf and Fuller 2013, Langgut 2017).

Delineating a precise native range for the species has represented a challenge as the species has been cultivated and disseminated for millennia, with seeds found in Mesopotamian excavations dating back to 4000 B.C. The armies of Alexander the Great are credited with introducing the plant to the Mediterranean region by about 300 B.C., although there is evidence that it may have been introduced earlier by coreligionists or local Persian rulers in ancient Palestine/Judea (Morton 1987, Klein 2014). Establishing the contemporary extent of occurrence for the species within this native range is also difficult as numerous natural hybrids of citron are found in areas where it is indigenous, and movement between wild and cultivated populations by natural or artificial means is suspected to be ongoing (Barbhuiya et al. 2016, Jones 2016). This has led to some speculation that the species no longer occurs in truly wild situations (Tropical Plants Database; Fern 2020); however, genetically wild populations have recently been reported from the Indian states of Meghalaya, Assam, Arunachal Pradesh and Manipur, as well as Myanmar and Chittagong District in Bangladesh (Morton 1987, Barbhuiya et al. 2016, Wu et al. 2018).

Citron has been observed to grow well up to 1,300 m asl in the tropics (Jones 2016). Further research focused on identifying wild populations across the historic native range is necessary to precisely evaluate the contemporary distribution status for the species.
useTrade:
Citron is a primary wild relative of cultivated Citron, and a close wild relative of all cultivated Citrus spp. (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020). Citron is considered to have been a parental contributor to several cultivated Citrus accessions, predominantly acting as the male parent (Nicolosi et al. 2000, Wu et al. 2018). Through combination with sour orange (Citrus x aurantium), citron contributed to the origin of lemon (Citrus x limon), bergamot (Citrus x bergamia), and key lime (Citrus x aurantifolia) (Barkley et al. 2006, Ollitrault et al. 2010, Barbhuiya et al. 2016, Wu et al. 2018).

The four main uses of citron are as an ornamental tree (Andrews 1961), a culinary plant, a medicinal plant and as a liturgical fruit (Brigand and Nahon 2016). In culinary use, the most important part of the citron is the peel (Morton 1987, Jones 2016). The peel is eaten with rice in Bangladesh, India and Indonesia, and the fruit may be pickled in India (Morton 1987, Sarker et al. 2019). In other areas of the world, the peel is used in culinary preparations on a commercial scale, particularly through candying of the peel for use in cakes and other sweet produce. The fruits are also made into marmalade and jams, and the fruit juice can be used in beverages and to make desserts. In Spain, the peel is used to make a syrup to enhance the flavour of medicines (Morton 1987). Historically, the leaves, flowers and fruit were used more widely in gastronomy (Brigand and Nahon 2016).

In traditional medicine, multiple plant parts have been used to treat conditions including asthma, arthritis, dysentery, headache, malaria, stomachache, intestinal parasites and some psychological disturbances (Tropical Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020). In India, the peel is used as a remedy for dysentery and halitosis (Morton 1987). In China, the candied peel is sold as a stomachic, stimulant, expectorant and tonic, and decoctions of the root are used to treat respiratory problems and backache (Morton 1987, Tropical Plants Database, Ken Fern 2020). In southeast Asia, a decoction of the fruit is used to deter spirits, while a decoction of the shoots is prescribed for stomachache and intestinal parasites. The seeds are given as a vennifuge, an infusion of the leaves is used as an antispasmodic, and the leaf juice is taken following childbirth. In Panama, the seeds are used in an antidote against poison, and in west tropical Africa, the citron is used to treat rheumatism (Morton 1987). Contemporary research has demonstrated that various parts of the plant exhibit anti-catarrhal, capillary protector, anti-hypertensive, diuretic, antibacterial, antifungal, anthelmintic, antimicrobial, analgesic, strong antioxidant, anticancerous, antidiabetic, estrogenic, antiulcer, cardioprotective, and antihyperglycemic properties (Lou et al. 2017). The nanoemulsion of essential oil from Citrus medica var. sarcodactylis has confirmed antioxidant, antibacterial and antibiofilm activity (Chhikara et al. 2018). The properties of specific cultivars have been recognised for their relevance to treatment of cancer, diabetes and Alzheimer's disease (Conforti et al. 2007, Entezari et al. 2009).

Citron juice has also been utilised in an eco-friendly method to synthesise copper nanoparticles (Shende et al. 2015). The fruit has long played an important role in Jewish ritual during the autumn harvest festival of Sukkot (Klein 2014, Langgut 2017). In east Asia, the fruit is prized for its fragrance and the essential oil was formerly used in perfumery. A ripe fruit is often used to air a room, dried fruits are placed with stored clothes as an insect repellent and the juice is used to wash linens. In India, branches of the tree are used as walking sticks (Morton 1987).

It should be noted that most of the described uses primarily rely on cultivated individuals grown outside the native range, but it is challenging to identify whether the use of wild individuals is excluded entirely; in southeast Asia, the fruit predominantly plays a cultural rather than commercial role and this is unlikely to change (Jones 2016).
conservationActions:
The genus Citrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009). Most germplasm collections of Citrus species also include citron (Jones 2016). There are 107 Citrus medica germplasm accessions held worldwide, with the majority held by the National Clonal Germplasm Repository for Citrus & Dates; however, only seven of these accessions are of wild origin and all were collected outside the native range for the species (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2020).

Seventy botanical gardens are listed as sites of ex situ conservation for this species (BGCI 2020), however, it is suspected that some of the listed living collections may hold cultivated varieties. The species is reported to have been collected in close proximity to the Nokrek National Park in India, and the Pyin-O-Lwin Bird Sanctuary in Myanmar (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2020); if the species occurs within the boundaries of these protected areas, passive conservation is presumed, however, it is not clear whether active management is apparent. As the native range overlaps with many more protected areas (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2020), it is suspected that the species may occur in some of these.

In 2013, the species was assessed as Least Concern in China (Qin et al. 2017). As germplasm accessions are not held from wild populations growing within the native range, collection of representative material is recommended.

rationale: Prunus lusitanica is a small tree and shrub found in south-western Europe and Morocco. In some parts of its range it is threatened by habitat modification, invasive species and water alteration. The range of the species is large, and although the population is fragmented and not common in parts of its range, globally it is not thought to meet the thresholds for a threatened category and for that reason it is assessed here as Least Concern. Further research is needed to determine levels of population fragmentation and the size of its African population.
habitat: In Macaronesia it is found in riparian areas and laurel forests. Further research is needed to gather information about the habitat of this species throughout the rest of its range. It can be a shrub or small tree.
threats: In the Azores, alteration of the water regime, the cutting of trees and invasive alien species are major threats to this species. In Spain, it is threatened by the construction of dams, habitat modification and climate change. A lack of pollinators and dispersal agents threatens the species in Madeira. The threats to this species in Morocco and France are unknown.
population: In the Azores the population comprises less than 250 individuals in total, with less than 30 individuals in each subpopulation. It is fragmented and in decline. In Spain and mainland Portugal the population is fragmented, localized and rare. It has a relic distribution in the Canary Islands. There is no population information from Morocco or France.
range:
Prunus lusitanica is native to southwest France, Portugal (including the Azores and Madeira Islands), Spain (including the Canary Islands), and Morocco (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2018). Prunus lusitanica ssp. azorica is endemic to the Azores (Silva et al. 2005).

In France it occurs in the eight southwestern departments of Gironde, Landes, Dordogne, Lot-et-Garonne, Pyrénées-Atlantiques, Hautes-Pyrénées, Ariège and Aude. It also occurs in the northwest department of Côtes d'Armor (Association Tela Botanica 2000–2010). In Morocco the species range is small.

The estimated extent of occurrence (3,357,300 km2) exceeds the criteria for a threatened category.
useTrade: It is a wild relative of, and potential gene donor, to Almond, Peach and Nectarine, Plum, Sloe and Sweet Cherry. It is also used as an ornamental (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2018).
conservationActions:
Prunus lusitanica is listed on Appendix I of the Bern Convention and in Annex II of the EU Habitats Directive.

P. lusitanica subsp. azorica was reported by Haggar et al. (1989) to be "the most endangered tree in the Azores". Both subspecies that occur in Spain (subsp. lusitanica and subsp. hixa) are listed as Vulnerable (VU) in the 2008 Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008). In Europe the species was regionally assessed as Vulnerable (Duarte et al. 2011).

It is known to occur in protected areas where it is passively conserved. It is recommended that the monitoring and management of this species is incorporated into the existing management plans of these sites.

The species is found in 88 in botanic garden collections (BGCI 2017). EURISCO reports only one germplasm accession of P. lusitanica which originates from Spain and is stored in the genebank of the Escuela Técnica Superior de Ingenieros Agrónomos, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid (EURISCO Catalogue 2010). There are seven accessions recorded in Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources (2018). Germplasm collection and duplicated ex situ storage is a priority for this species.

rationale: This species is widespread and still increasing its range. It an be locally common. It is considered invasive in many countries and does not face any major threats.
habitat: It is locally common in lakes, swamps, ponds, rivers and irrigation ditches in standing or slowly flowing water up to 3 m deep. This species is hardy and tolerant to heavy metals. Many studies have investigated the ecological role of this species in polluted waters (i.e., Wang et al. 2007, Bao 2008, Huang et al. 2009).
threats: No threats have been reported.
population: This is is a common and widespread species and populations are often very large. The plant may form monospecific stands.
range: Widespread throughout the temperate and tropical regions of the Eastern Hemisphere. It is considered a noxious plant in the USA and has been introduced to many European countries. This aquatic plant is believed to be native to Africa and south and southeast Asia.
useTrade: A dried powder from the plant has been used as detergent in the treatment of abscesses, burns and wounds. The plant is also often used to furnish aquaria.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are in place or likely to be needed.

rationale: The species is widespread and whilst it is possibly declining in parts of its range it is not thought that global population decline is likely to meet the threshold for any threatened category.
habitat: This species forms dense, extensive stands resembling and sometimes grading into beds of Phragmites australis. It occurs most often in strongly calcareous habitats such as fens but will also occur in acid habitats: it may be the case that it is more intolerant of nutrients than pH.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species. It has suffered habitat loss (e.g. in East Africa, where swamps are being drained for conversion to agricultural land) and is subject to local exploitation but these are not considered likely to threaten the survival of the species.
population: There is no information on population trends for this species throughout most of its range, but it is declining in parts of northern Europe (e.g. Preston et al. 2002).
range: This species has an almost cosmopolitan distribution as it occurs in all continents except Antarctica. It does not extend far north, ranging only as far as southern Scandinavia. It is absent however from northern Canada, Russia and the Far East.
useTrade: In parts of Turkey and England as well as in Uganda, this species is harvested and used as thatch for roofing. In Romania and Malaysia the leaves and stems are used in the manufacture of paper products.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are known or likely to be needed.

rationale: This species is widespread with stable populations and does not face any significant threats.
habitat: Juncus effusus is a tuft-forming perennial which may occur as scattered plants or stands in natural and semi-natural habitats. Extensive stands and become dominant to the exclusion of other species as a result of inappropriate land-use such as over-grazing of wet pasture. Juncus effusus occurs in most wetland habitats but is most typical of wet pasture and moorland. It is common on the margins of rivers, ponds, lakes and ditches and will occur as scattered stands in open, wet woodland. It apparently does not establish in base-rich soils and is most characteristic of sandy and peaty substrates, especially open heaths and moors.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. In suitable habitats it may occur in large, dense stands.
range: Juncus effusus is a cosmopolitan species which occurs throughout most of Europe, Asia south to Indonesia, North America, the Atlantic islands and Madagascar.
useTrade: The pith is used as a wick for oil lamps and candles, and also medicinally as a diuretic and tranquilliser (Chen and Yang 2005, Sun et al. 2006).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or likely to be needed.

rationale: The species is widespread with no known major threats. It is therefore assessed as Least concern.
habitat: This species is an annual fleshy herb that forms mats in open places in short grassland and bushland. It is a weed of cultivation and disturbed places, especially on sandy soils (African plant database 2020).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: The species occurs in tropical Africa to the Arabian Peninsula and the Mediterranean to Pakistan. It may have a nearly worldwide distribution, primarily in tropical and subtropical areas, but its native origin is uncertain and it is widely naturalised (USDA, National Plant Germplasm System 2020).
useTrade: This species has a long history as a medicinal plant, with uses not limited to muscle relaxing, wound healing and treating coughs, sores, infections, headaches, burns, skin diseases, insect stings and earaches. The leaves, stems and seeds are also eaten, and the seed can be ground into powder and mixed with cereals. The ash of burnt plants is used as a salt substitute. This species is often harvested from the wild for local use, and is also sold in local markets. It is cultivated on a small scale and in home gardens for its edible leaves, and it is also grown as an ornamental plant (USDA, National Plant Germplasm System 2020, Tropical Plants Database Ken Fern 2020).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions in place for this species, and none are thought to be needed.

rationale: Most records of the Canarian Tiny Cricket are from houses, even from urban areas. It does not seem to be threatened by human activities, but the effect of pest control in houses (e.g. against cockroaches or mosquitoes) on this species are unknown. Even though the species has a small extent of occurrence (EOO) of c. 4,000 km² and a known area of occupancy (AOO) of 16 - 200 km², there is currently no indication that the species may be declining. The species is therefore assessed as Least Concern (LC).
habitat: The species is often found in houses. Its natural habitat is probably beneath stones and in caves.
threats: The threats to this species are little understood. As it occurs in houses, it may be negatively affected by pest control (e.g. cockroach or mosquito treatments).
population: There is no information available on the population size and trends of this species.
range: The Canarian Tiny Cricket is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it has been reported from Tenerife and Gran Canaria (Bland et al. 1996). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is c. 4,000 km² and its area of occupancy (AOO) between 16 and 200 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species, and it is not known to occur in protected areas throughout its range. More research on its population trend, ecology and threats is needed.

rationale: This species is widespread and very abundant. It is apparently spreading through escapes from horticulture and there is no evidence of a decline or threat. It is therefore classed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species grows in swamps, wet grassland and beside streams. It is also cultivated as a garden plant (Lye 1997).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species, however it is widespread within its native range and occurs as a non-native throughout a very wide range. It seems likely that global populations are increasing.
range: This species is native throughout much of sub-Saharan Africa, including Mauritius, Madagascan and Reunion, as well as Saudi Arabia and Yemen. It occurs as a non-native in parts of south-western Europe, the Middle East, from Sri Lanka and Pakistan east to China and southern Japan south through Myanmar and Thailand throughout Indonesia to Norfolk Island, New Zealand, Fiji, Tuvalu, Cocos and the Society Islands and Hawaii and in the Americas from California and Texas south throughout much of Mexico and the Caribbean, as well as Venezuela and Chile (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2017).
useTrade: This species is cultivated as a garden plant throughout much of the world (Cook 1996, Lye 1997).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none are needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats, it occurs widely as a non-native and is considered by some to be potentially invasive.
habitat: This species occurs in wet grassland, ditches and wet, disturbed habitats (Ball and Reznicek 2002).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in the native range of  this species but it is spreading to many new areas.
range: This species is native to North, Central and South America and Easter Island, it occurs as a non-native in many regions including Europe, Africa and Asia (Ball and Reznicek 2002, The Trustees of The Royal Botanic Garden, Kew 2014).
useTrade: This species has been widely planted as an ornamental.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed.

rationale: Castanea sativa is a large tree species. It is native to the North Africa, the Caucasus, Turkey, Syria and Europe from Greece to Slovenia. The species has been introduced to much of Europe and is also naturalized here. The large native range of the species suggests the species has a large population, although its distribution is discontinuous. The species is globally assessed as Least Concern. There are no major threats to the species although it is susceptible to a variety of pests and disease. In the future these may be a greater threat to the species alongside being adversely effected by climate change causing habitat alteration and northward shift in species range. These future threats require investigation and monitoring. The species is well represented in ex situ collections. More information needs to be gathered for the species in Africa, Syria and Lebanon.
habitat: This large tree species can grow up to 35 m in height (Conedera et al. 2016). The species is relatively fast growing and can live for up to 1,000 years (Conedera et al. 2016). It is relatively climate sensitive, enjoying a mean monthly temperature of 10°C and rainfall of 800 mm a year. It is not drought tolerant and is sensitive to frost. The species can be found on nutritionally poor and fairly acidic soils but they must be well drained. The species is able to germinate in the shade but light is required for further growth (Conedera et al. 2016). The species is wind or insect pollinated but is also very good at re-sprouting (Fernández-López et al. 2003). Castanea sativa grows in pure stands or within mixed broad leaf forests in association with other hardwood species. Within mixed forests the species often makes up over 50% of forest cover (Conedera et al. 2016, Pridnya et al. 1996). The flowers are a good source of pollen and nectar for bees and other insects. It grows in the Habitats Directive listed habitat 9260 "Castanea sativa woods". It is also found within human landscapes; parks, gardens and orchards.
threats: Within the Caucasus the species has historically been threatened by disease and logging. Disease still threatens the species as it is susceptible to many pathogens, those of greatest concern are the fungal pathogen Chryphonectria parasitica and species of Phytophora which result in chestnut dieback and dessication (Pridnya et al. 1996, Aghayeva 2001). Loss of individuals to pests and diseases is likely to increase due to climate change making environments more suitable and international trade catalysing the spread of potential infections. Wild populations are at risk from genetic intogression with cultivated populations which is reducing the overall species genetic diversity (Fernández-López et al. 2003). This is of greatest concern where orchards are being abandoned across Europe (Fernández-López et al. 2003); this increases disease susceptibility of the species. A lack of management of forests can result in them being out-competed by other tree species (Conedera et al. 2016). Pridnya et al. (1996) reports a lack of regeneration of Castanea sativa within forests of The Caucasus Biosphere Forest Preserve where average age of trees is 130 years with very few trees being less than 40 years old. The species is also likely to be adversely affected by climate change, due to the species in tolerance to drought. It is likely there will be a decline in the suitable habitat for the species (EFDAC 2015). Wild populations may also still be affected by the species use for timber however this will be much reduced due to the management and cultivation of timber forests.
population: In the Caucasus 90% of Castanea sativa forest is found on southern slopes of the Caucasus Mountains, other isolated stands can be found on the northern slopes (Pridnya et al. 1996). In 1956 there was an estimated 70,000–80,000 hectares of C. sativa forest within the Caucasus but in western Caucasus this is estimated to have decreased by approximately two thirds or 50,000 ha between 1956 and 1996 (Pridnya et al. 1996). Within Azerbaijan pure Castanea sativa forests are rare. Here it is found in fragmented mixed forests on south macroslopes of the Great Caucasus and in the Minor Caucasus the species is found over 550 to 600 km in small fragments, not all of which are wild stands. Population decline between 45–50% in Azerbaijan has been reported (Aghayeva 2001). Thirty-eight semi-wild stands have been identified within Lebanon (Masri et al. 2009). The species is relatively genetically diverse; individuals within Turkey show the greatest genetic diversity (Fernández-López et al. 2003). There is no population information for the species within Africa. Within Europe the species is widespread, common and widely cultivated. Overall due to the wide native range of the species population is likely to be large and stable. It is however reported that the species population is discontinuous in most parts of its range (Fernández-López et al. 2003) and it is not considered a dominant species.
range: This species is native to North Africa, the Balkan Peninsula, the Caucasus, Russia, Turkey and western Asia. The species has been cultivated and naturalised outside its native range especially within Europe (GRIN 2017, EURO+MED 2017). It has been introduced to the UK south to the Mediterranean and across into central and eastern Europe (February 2017). Across some of this introduced range the origin of the species is uncertain such as in Spain (Arbolapp 2017) and in Belarus. As such the species native range may be wider but this requires further investigation. Within Russia the species is only found within Ciscaucasia (Pridnya et al. 1996) and within Lebanon the species origin is still contested (Masri et al. 2009). The species is more common at elevations below 1,000 m asl but can still be found above this, up to 1,300 m asl. The species has a large extent of occurrence (EOO) which exceeds the criteria for a threatened category under criterion B.
useTrade: This species is used for its timber (Mark et al. 2014). For this purpose the species is managed by coppicing. Wood produced is used to make barrels, furniture, poles, other small products and also for construction (Conedera et al. 2016). The wood can also be used to make charcoal and as fuel. The nut can be harvested for human consumption hence many cultivars of the species have been developed and the tree is grown in orchards (Conedera et al. 2016). In Croatia, more than 144,000 kg of fruits were collected between 2005–2011 (I. Boršić pers. comm. 2013). In Corsica, chestnuts are used to brew beer as they are similar to wheat (Kew 2017). In Greece it is used for reforestation on degraded lands for production of wood, nuts and food for all wildlife (Radoglou et al. 2003). Different parts of the trees can also be used for a variety of different medicinal purposes.
conservationActions: The species is found in several protected areas across its entire range and also Natura 2000 sites within Europe. Also within Europe the species habitat is protected within Annex 1 of the European Commission Habitat Directive – Castanea sativa woods (Code 1260). The species is regionally assessed within Europe as Least Concern (2013), and is Least Concern in Belarus (Ermakova 2005), Germany (Bundesamt für Naturschutz 2012), Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002) and the UK (Cheffings and Farrell 2005). However it is listed as Endangered in Bulgaria (Petrova and Vladimirov 2009, Peev and Vladimirov 2011). It is recommended that population and threat information for the species be gathered in Syria, Lebanon and within the species' African range. The forests should also be monitored for decline across its range due to pests and diseases. The impact of climate change on the species should also be investigated. This species is found in 140 ex situ collections (BGCI 2017).

rationale: This species is widespread and abundant throughout most of its known range and not vulnerable to any known threats. It is therefore classed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species typically grows in shaded, permanently moist crevices on calcareous rock face (typically limestones) and cliffs, often beside streams or waterfalls or growing directly in seepages (Paris 1993, Prelli 2001, Preston et al. 2002). In some areas, such as the Mediterranean, it will grow on non-calcareous rocks such as schists, sandstone grits and rhyolite (Prelli 2001), whilst in Australia and South Africa it will also sometimes grow on alkaline soil (Macarthy 1998, Paris 1993, South African National Biodiversity Institute 2009). In western Ireland, it grows in the grikes (fissures) in limestone pavement (Preston et al. 2002), whilst in the southern United States it grows on the walls of lime sinks and canyons (Paris 1993). It is also a typical colonizer of old mortared walls throughout much of its range (Allan Herbarium 2000, Piggott 1988, NZ Plant Conservation Network 2011), including foundations and the mortar of storm drains in the southern States (Paris 1993), concrete steps (Allan Herbarium 2000), railway sidings and canal locks (Preston et al. 2002). In the UK it has been suggested that populations on artificial substrates may derive mainly from cultivation (Preston et al. 2002). Throughout most of its range it grows inland as well as on the coast, but in the north of its range, such as in the UK (Preston et al. 2002, Page 1992) it is exclusively coastal, almost certainly as it is intolerant of frost and dependent upon the ameliorating effect of the sea on temperatures and freezing.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: Throughout the most of its range, this species is abundant and there is no evidence of a decline.
range: This species has a sub-cosmopolitan distribution, occurring on all continents except the Antarctic, including temperate and tropical Asia, Macronesia, throughout Africa, including Madagascar and the Mascarene Islands, Australia (where it is apparently considered to be native), New Zealand (where it is considered to be introduced) and the Americas from Canada south to Venezuela.
useTrade: This species is almost ubiquitous in plant sales, being sold both in specific plant retail outlets and in domestic furniture outlets. It is understood that almost all of the stock sold derives from horticulture and there is no evidence of collection pressure from the wild. The leaves of this species  are used as herbal medicine for respiratory problems.
conservationActions: The species is not the subject of conservation action at global level and there is no evidence that such action is needed. It is listed on the National Red Lists of Croatia and Canada as Near Threatened and <span id="_ctl0_cp_3__ctl0_dl__ctl0_lbl_regionalstatus">Endangered, respectively.

rationale: This species is native to a wide area of North Africa, south to Central Africa and parts of the Middle East. It has also been introduced to much of the tropics and is abundant throughout. There are no known major widespread threats and this species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in low-lying wet areas including aquatic meadows and lakes, and where introduced it may displace native vegetation in marshes and swamps. It will grow in water to 1.2 m deep in the tropics. The plant can form extensive monospecific stands, including forming floating mats in drainage ditches and irrigation canals where it may prevent the flow of water. It will occur on a wide range of soil types, from sand to clay soils of moderate to high fertility. It can tolerate moderate salinity, low pH to 4.5 and high levels of trace elements normally produced under water-logged conditions.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species across its native range. Locally, it may by threatened by drought, over-grazing and other agricultural activities.
population: This species is a dominant weedy species that is widespread and invasive in many countries. In its native range there are no known widespread threats, and the population is thought to be stable.
range: This species is native from North Africa south to Central Africa and parts of the Middle East. It has been introduced elsewhere more or less throughout the tropics, including Macaronesia, the Mascarene Islands, from India south through parts of Indonesia to Australia and many Pacific Ocean Islands, as well as south-central USA and Mexico, Mesoamerica, the Caribbean, and South America (Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2020).
useTrade: This species is planted for grazing in flat, poorly drained or high rainfall environments, and is also used as a cut-and-carry forage. It can be cut for hay but is generally slow to dry in the humid environments where it grows productively. Rested wetland areas can be used as dry season reserves of green feed. A similar system uses shallow water ponding on the edges of which para grass continues to grow as the water recedes. The leaves are antiseptic in action. The paste of mature leaves is used in cutaneous affections. Environmentally, it is used for erosion control and as fodder and forage. The grass is not normally poisonous but may contain enough oxalate to cause osteodystrophy fibrosa in horses at pasture.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species, and none are thought to be needed.

rationale: The species is assessed as Least Concern as it has a wide distribution in the tropics and sub-tropics with no known threats.
habitat: This species occurs in damp shady places near water, as well as in open swamps, marshes and sometimes in floating vegetation mats (Cook 1996). This species also occurs as a weed in cultivated fields (Khanna and Saran 2001)<span id="lblTaxonDesc">.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information on population size or trends in this species but there is no reason to suspect a decline. The population trend is therefore assumed to be stable.
range:
This species occurs more or less throughout the tropics and subtropics including in Africa, Asia and South America, as well as in parts of North America, Australasia and the Southern Pacific States. 

In India, it is found at an altitude of up to 1,400 m asl in the Western Ghats. It is widely distributed in Kerala (Thekkady, Periyar Tiger Reserve, Palghat), Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Bihar, Gujarat, Goa, Karnataka (Udupi); Mizoram, Punjab, Sikkim, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal, Maharashtra (Ahmednagar, Akola, Amaravadi, Bombay, Chandrapur, Kolhapur, Nagpur, Nasik, Osmanabad, Pune, Raigad, Ratnagiri, Satara, Sholapur, Sindhudurg, Thane), Madhya Pradesh (Balaghat,  Damoh, Dhar, Hoshangabad, Katni, Mandla, Panna, Rajnandgaon, Surguja) and Chattisgarh (Bastar, Bilaspur, Raipur) (Cook 1996, Lakshminarasimhan 1996, Khanna and Saran 2001).

In the Arabian Peninsula, this species occurs on the escarpment from Wadi Hidran north to Rujum, but mostly in the high rainfall areas of Ibba and the central escarpment in Yemen (Wood 1997, Al Khulaidi 2004).
useTrade:
The leaves of this species are widely used for poulticing sores in Peninsular Malaysia. The crushed leaves and stems are used for irregular menstruation. Dirty wounds are poulticed with the mucilage from the stems in Indonesia. In some areas, leaves used as an ointment and absorptive.

The whole plant is boiled and the water drunk as a charm for hunting the savanna deer by the Guyana Patomona. In north-west Guyana, it is used to treat biliousness, loss of hair, kidney disease, and to cleanse womb and tubes. Socially it is used as a ceremonial leaf (http://www.oswaldasia.org/species/c/comdi/comdi_en.html).

The bruised plant is locally used against burns, itches and boils in India (Cook 1996). The petal juice can be used as a dye for painting (eFloras 2011).

In the Arabian Peninsula, there is no evidence that this species is used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none needed for this species.

rationale: This species has been assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any significant threats.
habitat: P. nodosus will occur in most types of water body, from lake margins to ponds and even temporary pools, as well as streams and backwaters of larger rivers. It appears to tolerate nutrient enrichment and is most frequently found in mesotrophic to eutrophic calcareous waters. It will grow to a water depth of 2 metres.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species.
population: There is no detailed information available on population size or trends. However, this species is widespread and abundant throughout its range.
range:
P. nodosus has an almost cosmopolitan distribution, apart from northern Europe to the north of the UK, the Netherlands and Lithuania in each of which it is rare. It also appears to be absent from New Zealand; it is however present on many Pacific Islands. It occurs east through southern Russian regions, east to southern China and Japan, south through much of south and southeast Asia to Papua New Guinea. It is also widespread throughout much of Africa, north and south of the Sahara, the Middle East and the Indian Ocean Islands, throughout North America (except the extreme north; Alaska and northern Canada) south through Mexico, the West Indies and Central America to northern South America.

In the Indo-Burma region, it has been recorded from Quangbinh in northern Viet Nam and in northern Thailand. It may be present in Lao PDR, but this is not confirmed.
useTrade: Potamogeton spp. leaves and stems are edible. This species specifically has been used for medicinal purposes but no detailed information is available.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or likely to be needed.

rationale: The Strawberry Tree (Arbutus unedo) has a relatively widespread distribution across southern Europe. It has undergone some localised declines and is now rare and highly threatened in Cyprus and Bulgaria, but the overall population is believed to be stable. The species appears to be sensitive to drought and extremely low temperatures, and is valued for its medicinal properties and fruit which may lead to local exploitation of wild plants. It is classified as Least Concern due to its widespread distribution, stable populations and the absence of major threats.
habitat: This plant is a small evergreen tree or shrub found on heathy scrub, open woodland, rocky slopes and lake shores growing in limestone, slate and sandstone shallow soils. It reproduces by seed (Online Atlas of the British and Irish Flora 2012). The fruit take 12 months to ripen, therefore the tree has mature fruit and flowers at the same time and flowers in autumn. It is found in the holm oak forests of the lower mountains and flat areas of the Mediterranean where there is a mild climate with dry summers. Its fruit is an important food source for animals during winter (Benhouhou 2005).
threats: In Ireland it has declined for its use for charcoal (Online Atlas of the British and Irish Flora 2012). In Bulgaria, potential negative factors are forest fires and extremely low temperatures (Peev and Vladimirov 2011). In Tunisia, A. unedo are declining due to deforestation and over-collecting, and now only occurs in small scattered populations (Takrouni and Boussaid 2010).
population: The European population of Strawberry Tree is believed to be stable, though it has undergone localised and often quite severe declines. The native subpopulation in Ireland was much more abundant several centuries ago, but by the 16th century had become very rare, likely because of its use for charcoal; the population has been stable over the past century (Online Atlas of the British and Irish Flora 2012). The population in Bulgaria occurs at the northern climatic limit of its distribution area and is therefore represented by very few individuals (less than 50) (Petrova and Vladimirov 2009, Peev and Vladimirov 2011). In Cyprus very few individuals remain, located only on the west coast (Meikle 1985). In other areas (e.g. southern England) it has spread as an escaped cultivar, where it can be invasive (Online Atlas of the British and Irish Flora 2012). In Tunisia, A. unedo are declining due to deforestation and over-collecting, and now only occurs in small scattered populations (Takrouni and Boussaid 2010).
range: The Strawberry Tree (Arbutus unedo) has a Mediterranean-Atlantic distribution and is native to the coastal regions of the Mediterranean, extending from southern Europe to western Asia and northern Africa (Valdés et al. 2009), and up into Ireland (Online Atlas of the British and Irish Flora 2012).
useTrade: Strawberry Tree fruits are rich in sugar and vitamin C and are eaten and sold locally, usually cooked to make jams, sorbets and alcoholic drinks. The leaves and bark have been used for tanning and are also valued for their medicinal properties. The seeds contain essential oil with siccative properties. A decoction of the tannin rich leaves is used as a diuretic to treat urinary infections and diarrhoea; the leaves are antiseptic and highly astringent. The macerated roots are used as a drink and are depurative and decongestant. The flowers have sudorific properties and the fruits have a narcotic effect for diarrhoea. It is most effective for treating hypertension, diarrhoea, colic and renal problems. Pharmacopeias are not relevant for this species. Strawberry Tree is part of a European programme for improvement and should be subject to market authorisation. It is also used for reforestation strengthening dunes and soil protection, as it is fire-resistant and tolerant to high pollution levels in urban areas (Benhouhou 2005). It is grown as an ornamental and is best propagated through seed (Hammami et al. 2005). Its fruit is an important food source for animals during winter (Benhouhou 2005). In Tunisia, most use is from natural populations (Takrouni and Boussaid 2010). The wood is used to carve utensils (mortars, bowls, and spoons) and in Greece it has been used to make shepherds' flutes.
conservationActions: It is considered Least Concern in Europe. This species is listed as Critically Endangered [C2a(i); D] in Bulgaria, due to its extremely small and declining population; it is, however, protected under the National Biodiversity Act and remaining sites are within the Natura 2000 network (Petrova and Vladimirov 2009, Peev and Vladimirov 2011). It is also Critically Endangered [B1ab(iii,v)+2ab(iii,v); C2a(i)] in Cyprus, due to its restricted and declining distribution and population (Tsintides et al. 2007). It can be considered Least Concern in Greece (I. Bazos pers. comm. 2013). In Bulgaria, recommended conservation actions include searching for new individuals, monitoring known trees and marking them with a sign of protection, and raising local awareness among foresters and the public about the conservation value of the species (Peev and Vladimirov 2011). No specific conservation measures are required for the non-threatened parts of its distribution. There are over 100 known ex situ collections in botanic gardens worldwide.

rationale: White Poplar (Populus alba) is a large tree with a wide geographic range in Europe, North Africa and Asia. The population is large. It has declined in some areas of its native range in southern Europe, where it is under threat from alteration of the riparian forest habitat by human activities such as hydraulic engineering, agriculture and urbanisation of floodplain areas. However, due to its high adaptability, establishment and fast growth it is not showing significant declines. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: White Poplar is a fast-growing tree found in lowland Mediterranean riparian woodland and floodplain forests associated with Salix, Populus and Acer species (European Environment Agency 2010). It is planted along roadsides and in parks for urban landscaping and also occurs on coastal dunes (Online Atlas of the British and Irish Flora 2012). Poplars have dispersal distances of up to 16 km and seedling establishment relies on connection between patches of suitable habitat (Fussi et al. 2010). Its habitat is highly fragmented in some areas and its distribution range has been subject to long-term human interference; although this has caused range expansion, the origin of some populations is uncertain (Brundu et al. 2008). Many populations on Mediterranean islands are relicts of native flora which have spread through available habitats by vegetative propagation and human activities (Brundu et al. 2008). This tree can reproduce sexually, and also asexually through cuttings and root suckers. It is resistant to insect pests and fungal and bacterial pathogens, and tolerates diverse environmental stresses such as drought, wind, salinity and high temperatures (Brundu et al. 2008). The species is of ecological importance for maintaining the high biodiversity of  riparian woodland (EUFORGEN 2013). It grows in the Habitats Directive listed habitats 92A0 "Salix alba and Populus alba galleries" and 3280 "Constantly flowing Mediterranean rivers with Paspalo-Agrostidion species and hanging curtains of Salix and Populus alba".
threats: Threats to this species include afforestation with exotic tree species and cultivars, logging and deforestation (Bulgarian Academy of Sciences & Ministry of Environment and Water 2011). Populus alba is among the most threatened tree species in Europe due to alteration of the riparian forest habitat by human activities such as hydraulic engineering, agriculture and urbanisation of floodplain areas is another main threat (Richardson et al. 2014). Flood regulation has a negative impact on natural regeneration, causing gradual replacement by hardwood forests. White Poplar has locally highly successful regeneration capability, though there have been significant reductions or complete disappearance of the species in some areas of Europe (EUFORGEN 2013).
population: The total population size of White Poplar is unknown, but it is a common and widespread tree throughout Europe. Brundu et al. (2008) found that the Sardinian population consisted of a few hundred to several hundred thousand individuals over 30 sites; the total European population is thus presumed to number in the millions or more.
range: The White Poplar (Populus alba) is native to central and southern Europe, North Africa, and eastwards to Central Asia. It has established itself as a naturalised alien in northern Europe through large scale cultivation (Uotila 2011). This species is also found planted or naturalised in North and South America, and Australia (CABI 2012).
useTrade: It is commonly utilised as an ornamental or in afforestation and reforestation for its resistance to drought and salinity. The wood is not of high quality, but can be used for biomass energy, as pulpwood for paper, for packaging (crates and boxes), pellets and partially as saw-logs (Caudullo and de Rigo 2016). In the Mediterranean it is commonly used for production of matches and fruit boxes, and as a parent for cultivation of the hybrid species Populus canescens, used around the world as ornamental and landscape trees (EUFORGEN 2013).
conservationActions: White Poplar is classified as Least Concern in Germany (Bundesamt für Naturschutz 2012) and Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002). White Poplar galleries in south Bulgaria are Vulnerable (Bulgarian Academy of Sciences & Ministry of Environment and Water 2011). It is considered to be At Risk in Serbia and Montenegro (FAO 2006). In situ conservation is the most effective for maintaining the high genetic diversity required for evolutionary adaptation and future climate change (EUFORGEN accessed 2013). It occurs in thirty one Natura 2000 sites in Germany, Spain, Italy, Bulgaria and Romania (European Environment Agency 2010). The habitats 92A0 "Salix alba and Populus alba galleries" and 3280 "Constantly flowing Mediterranean rivers with Paspalo-Agrostidion species and hanging curtains of Salix and Populus alba" are listed on Annex I of the Habitats Directive.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: Juncus acutus is a perenial (Geophyte), growing in saline swamps, banks of rivers, and more or less brackish pools, often occurring at the upper edge of salt marsh.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species
population: This species is widespread and abundant throughout its known range. There is no detailed information available on population size.
range: Juncus acutus is a sub-cosmopolitan species with a worldwide distribution covering western and southern Europe, western Asia, northern Africa, Canary Islands, Madeira, Azores and Cape Verde. In Northern Africa it is present in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Egypt. Also recorded from the southern part of South Africa (Free State, Northern Cape, Western Cape, Eastern Cape), Namibia, and Lesotho. Although this species was known from one old herbarium specimen on Ascension Island, it was almost certainly mis-labelled and is therefore erroneous. It does not occur on St Helena or Tristan (P. Lambdon pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: J. acutus is harvested for the manufacture of  handicrafts.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is little or no information on the population size, trends, habitats and threats to the species. Further research should be conducted to establish the status of the species throughout its range.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitats of this species, although it can be assumed to occur on Mediterranean-type shrubland. It is on the wing from the beginning of February (Hohmann et al. 1993) until the end of April (Warncke 1968). The species is probably oligolectic on Brassicaceae like other related species, and the  flower records for the species include Cakile maritima (Hohmann et al. 1993).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information on the population size and trends of this species. However, it is a rather rare species, represented by only a few specimens in museum collections (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014).
range: Andrena notata is endemic to the islands of Lanzarote and Fuerteventura (Canary Islands, Spain) (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: The species is not used or traded commercially.
conservationActions: The species is not included in any National Red Lists or Red Data Books. It is not the target of any specific conservation action and it is not known whether it occurs in protected areas throughout its range. Further research should be conducted in order to establish the population size, trends, habitats and threats to the species.

rationale: Ulmus minor is a medium sized tree species. It has a wide distribution, ranging from Portugal across southern and eastern Europe to North Africa, the Caucasus and the Middle East. Population numbers are large but are suspected to be in decline due to outbreaks of Dutch elm disease (DED) –caused by pathogen Ophiostoma ulmi and O. novo-ulmi, which is damaging to the species. Although the species is listed as Threatened in some European countries there is a lack of data on species decline and numbers across its entire range; therefore the species is classed as Data Deficient. The species is also assessed as Data Deficient as we do not know the species origin across all of its range. It is recommended that information on the full extent of the threat of disease is gathered and the impact of other threats (such as habitat loss) on the population are investigated.
habitat: Ulmus minor is a deciduous, riparian tree inhabiting the banks of streams and rivers (EUROFOGEN 2016). The species is fast growing and can reach heights over 20 m. It is tolerant of waterlogging, saline soils and winds, drought and pollution and hence is often grown as a pioneer species (EUROFOGEN 2016). The species inhabits and preferentially grows in warmer, drier habitats that other Ulmus spp. (Collin 1999-2001). This species can be found in association with ashes (Fraxinus spp.), poplars (Populus spp.), alders (Alnus spp.) and other Ulmus species with which it is able to hybridise (EUROFOGEN 2016). It uses suckers as its main method of reproduction hence the species has good regeneration potential and can quickly take over abandoned sites (Collin 1999-2001).
threats:
Within Europe the species is severely affected and damaged by DED caused by the fungus Ophiostoma novo-ulmi and historically by Ophiostoma ulmi. The disease does not cause the tree to die; the species is able to re-sprout as a shrub however these are unable to produce seeds leading to population decline. The disease is present in Asian countries within the Ulmus minor's distribution but the impact of the disease on these populations is unknown (CABI 2017). The disease was also previously reported in Tunisia but is now thought to be absent, so African populations may be less at risk of from the disease then those in Asia and Europe (CABI 2017). The species exhibits great genetic diversity which is likely to have bolstered the species against greater declines.

Ulmus minor is also threatened by habitat reduction and water regulation within Europe (Caudullo and de Rigo 2016). There is also the risk of hybridisation with Ulmus pumila.
population: Historic outbreaks of DED have caused the death of many adults of this species: however Ulmus minor remains common within Europe (EUROFOGEN 2017). The effect of this pathogen is not known within the species wider distribution. Within Sweden specifically, Ulmus minor occurs in 50,000 locations but the population is expected to decline by up to 80% (Artdatabanken 2015). It is not known if this predicted decline is representative of the global population. There is also a lack of information and data on past declines of the species throughout it distribution.
range: Ulmus minor occurs across Europe, being found from Portugal, across to the Balkan states and south to Italy, Greece and Turkey. It is also found within the Caucasus, Russia, Israel, Palestine and North Africa (Dannin 2016, GBIF 2017, Tutin et al. 1964, GRIN 2017). The species origin within its more northern range needs clarification as the species may not be native here. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of over 11,700,000 km2. The species altitudinal range is not known.
useTrade: The timber of this species is of high quality and is thus suitable for furniture, flooring and firewood. It is very resistant to decay from water and is very useful for underwater applications and for building ships (EUFORGEN 2016). This species was traditionally used as a living support for grapevines and as fodder for grazing livestock in the summer months (Caudullo and de Rigo 2016).
conservationActions:
This species is recorded in 65 ex situ collections from across the globe (BGCI 2017). Often the species is protected within Riparian landscapes, but this does not always protect the species from DED (Collin 1999-2001). Within Sweden trees infected with dutch elm diseases are identified and burnt and the stumps treated to reduce disease spread (Artdatabanken 2017).

Ulmus minor has had a variety of country scale conservation assessments, listing the species as follows:
  • Least Concern in the United Kingdom (Cheffings and Farrell 2005)
  • Near Threatened in Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002)
  • Vulnerable in Albania (MEA 2013)
  • Critically Endangered in Sweden (Artdatabanken 2017)
