threats: Water contamination by diffuse pollution, drainage, land use change (to agriculture), and urban and tourism developments impact the habitat of this species, although the scope and scale of these impacts are not known.
population: Whilst isolated individuals or small groups can be found around the coastline of the islands, large wild subpopulations are scarce. The largest population (Dunas de Maspalomas, Gran Canaria) grows inside a protected area.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is thought to occur on all islands (Barry and Luque 1998) with the exception of the western-most island of El Hierro (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). It has been collected at 557 m above sea level, though its main subpopulations develop at lower altitudes, besides the sea.
useTrade: The wood was reported to be highly valued for carpentry (Bramwell and Lopez 1999), and more recently, it has been planted along roadsides and as ornamental plant.
conservationActions: Tamarix canariensis is reported as held in seven ex situ collections (BGCI 2017).

rationale: This species is a shrub endemic to the Canary Islands. It is assessed as Least Concern as it has a large area of occupancy and although there is little information about population numbers or trends, the species tolerates fire and colonises abandoned agricultural land. The species occurs within protected areas and is found in ex situ collections.
habitat: This is a leguminous shrub of up to 2-4 m. It is found on the borders of pine and laurel forests, and as understory within forests (Bramwell and López 1999), but also in juniper forest and in more open, often previously burnt areas, and in rocky areas, and it is also widespread in abandoned agricultural areas (del-Arco et al. 2009). It is considered a pyrophitic species, with populations able to recover rapidly following fire events (Arévalo et al. 2014), and it is commonly found in repeatedly burnt patches (del-Arco et al. 2009).
threats: Past conversion of forest into pasture led to habitat fragmentation and loss (Guimarães and Olmeda 2008), however the species tolerates fire well and colonises abandoned agricultural areas (del-Arco et al. 2009).
population: Bramwell and Bramwell (1990) noted that on Gran Canaria, Tenerife and La Gomera islands the species was fairly locally frequent. del-Arco et al. (2009) reported the range of the species (as a component of the Adenocarpus foliolosus -Chamaecytisetum angunstifolii association) on La Gomera to be increasing as a result of expansion in to deforested, burnt and abandoned agricultural areas, where it is widespread.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on all islands excluding the eastern islands of Fuerteventura and Lanzarote (Anthos 2016, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The species occurs between 500 and 1,800 m above sea level. The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is estimated to be c.20,131 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: Use of this species used as a forage species for livestock and as a bed for cattle is reported, and medicinal properties have been attributed to it.
conservationActions: Adenocarpus foliolosus is reported as held in five ex situ collections (BGCI 2015). The species was listed as not threatened in 1984 (Barreno et al. 1984). Laurisilva is listed in Annex 1 of the Habitats Directive as a priority habitat.

rationale: This species is a tree endemic to the Canary Islands. The species is locally common in some sub-populations on Tenerife, but elsewhere on the islands it is only found locally as individual trees, and it is considered to be severely fragmented. Populations are probably stable currently as a result of high levels of protection, and the decline of earlier high levels of habitat loss. It is assessed as Near Threatened (NT B1a+2a) as it has a restricted extent of occurrence of less than 20,000 km2, and an area of occupancy that is probably less than 500 km2. However there are no current threats to this species, and no continuing decline in EOO, AOO, or habitat area and extent. The population estimate in 1998 was fewer than 10,000 individuals, but there are considered to be more than ten subpopulations. The species is found in ex situ collections and protected areas.
habitat: This species grows as a tree up to 15 m on the edges and clearings of the Laurisilva (Bramwell and López 1999). It is found in steep and sunny places on ridges or slopes (Gómez-Campo et al. 1996).
threats: Fires may affect some areas, however there is no evidence of impacts and at present there are not thought to be any significant threats. Historical forest clearance impacted this species. Hybridisation with introduced Arbutus unedo is a localised problem on Tenerife.
population: This species is locally common in some sub-populations on Tenerife, but elsewhere on the islands it is only found locally as individuals. Populations are probably stable currently as a result of high levels of protection, and the decline of earlier high levels of habitat loss. The species is considered severely fragmented.
range: This species is found in the Canary Islands on the islands of Tenerife, La Gomera, El Hierro, La Palma and Gran Canaria (Anthos 2016). It normally grows between 500 and 1,000 m above sea level (Gómez-Campo et al. 1996). The estimated extent of occurrence is 19,119 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) has not been estimated but is likely to not exceed 500 km2, and may be less than 250 km2.
useTrade: This species is used as an ornamental tree (Bramwell and Lopez 1999) and the fruits were previously eaten (Gómez-Campo et al. 1996).
conservationActions:
Arbutus canariensis is reported as held in 35 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015) and is recorded as present in an ex situ seed bank collection (ENSCO 2015). The species was assessed as Vulnerable in 1984 (Barreno et al.) and not threatened in 1996 (Gómez-Campo et al.). The species was assessed as Vulnerable in 1998 (Bañares et al. 1998).

Several of the populations are found within protected areas and there has been work to multiply these species in ex situ. The species is listed in government legislation of 1991, but absent from the most recent list (2010).

rationale: This species is a small tree found only in Madeira. It is here assessed as Least Concern as although it has a restricted extent of occurrence the population is large and stable. There are no significant threats to indicate a risk of extinction currently. The tree is found in several protected areas.
habitat: This species is a small tree of up to 15 m. This species is one of the major components of temperate laurisilva forest.
threats: The habitat has been threatened in recent years by fire, but only in limited areas. The invasion of invasive species is the biggest threat to this species; Pittosporum and Acacia are reducing the quality of the habitat.
population: There is no information about population numbers of this species, but it is estimated to be above 100,000 individuals. The population trend is stable.
range: This species is endemic to Madeira and is invasive in the Azores. It is found between 200 and 1,300 m asl. The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is 310 km<sup>2</sup> and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 192 km<sup>2</sup>. Old records from Tenerife in the Canaries are uncertain in origin and identity (there is no voucher material), and it is no longer present on the island.
useTrade: This plant is used in horticulture. It was used for inlay and wood crafting. It was also used as walking sticks, fuels, furniture, fishing rods and other wooden implements.
conservationActions: This species was previously assessed as 'Lower Risk/least concern' (World Conservation Monitoring Centre 1998). Parts of its range are protected within the Natural Park of Madeira, Natura 2000 sites and the World Heritage Site. Invasive species control would be beneficial for this species. Clethra arborea is reported as held in 36 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015).

rationale: This species is a shrub or small tree found in Madeira, the Azores and the western and central Canary Islands. It is assessed as Least Concern as there is no evidence of declines and it occurs over a large area. The population is threatened in the Azores by deforestation and seed predation but there is no indication that the species as a whole is declining, with populations in Madeira increasing in size.
habitat: An evergreen shrub or small tree of up to 15 m, this species grows in laurisilva forest as well as degraded forest. It is also found growing on lava flows and exposed habitats such as cliffs (Silva and Tavares 1997). It is also found in coastal scrub land and Morella-Picconia woodland, laurel forest in the Azores. It grows marginally in pasture, along road sides, hedgerows and margins of agricultural fields.
threats:
On the Azores, the trees are threatened by deforestation and the invasion of alien species. The species that poses the most threat is the Australian species Pittosporum undulatum. There is some fruit predation from Argyresthia atlanticella but less than 10% of the fruits were affected. Rats and birds also eat the fruits. Historically stands of this species in the Azores have been removed for land conversion into pasture (Silva and Tavares 1997). In Madeira, Acacia mearnsii outcompetes this species after disturbances such as landslides and fire. Fire also increases because of the presence of the Acacia (M. Sequeira pers. comm. 2016).

On La Palma, there is continued cutting of this species in secondary forest.
population: The species is locally common in the western and central islands of the Canaries. In the Azores, there are likely to be more than 100,000 individuals. In Madeira, there are also likely to be many more than 100,000 individuals. Populations are thought to be increasing.
range:
This species is endemic to Macaronesia, occurring in the Azores (all islands; Borges et al. 2010), Madeira and the Canary Islands (western and central islands only; Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The species is not considered native to mainland Portugal, and has been introduced there. It is found between 400 and 1,500 m above sea level (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990). On Madeira, it is found between 0 and 1,000 m. The estimated extent of occurrence of this species exceeds 500,000 km2.

This species is invasive in Hawaii after being introduced in the 1800s, causing damage to native forests (Silva and Tavares 1997), and has been introduced elsewhere (Florida, Australia and New Zealand).
useTrade: The fruits were used to produce jams and the seeds were used as flour (Silva and Tavares 1997). The species is used for woodcraft, timber and fences. It is one of the most used species for landscape restoration in Madeira (M. Sequiera pers. comm. 2016). On La Palma in the Canaries, cutting of this species is permitted in secondary forest for use in agriculture for crop props (tomatoes, bananas etc), and the foliage as a green manure.
conservationActions: The species is reported as held in 29 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016). It was previously assessed as Lower Risk/least concern (Oldfield et al. 1998, World Conservation Monitoring Centre 1998). In Madeira, it is found in the Natural Park of Madeira, Natura 2000 sites and the World Heritage Sites. In the Azores, some of the population is found in protected areas.

rationale: This species is a large tree found in the laurisilva forests of Madeira and Canary Islands. It is assessed as Least Concern as it has a large extent of occurrence and there is no indication of current declines in the population. However the subspecies ceballosi has a very restricted extent of occurrence and a population of only 64 individuals. It is found in a large number of ex situ collections and occurs within protected areas.
habitat: This species grows as an evergreen tree up to 25 m within laurisilva (laurel wood forest) (Bramwell and Lopez 1999), with a preference for open rocky areas or drier parts of the forest. The species is also found in ravines.
threats:
The wood in the laurisilva was highly valued, and there are only remnants of forest left. There are pressures from grazing and burning. The population on La Gomera has suffered from timber extraction and was threatened by the removal of branches for sale (Bañares et al. 2004), but it is not known if this threat continues. The main pressure in Madeira was agriculture as it expanding, reducing the area of the forest. Abandoned agricultural land has been colonised by the forest, increasing its area but if agriculture re-expands, the forest will again reduce in size. Invasive species are affecting the Madeiran laurisilva with Acacia mearnsii being the most problematic.

The tree has become extinct on Porto Santo because of human usage.
population:
The population is described as 'scattered' in Madeira, in some parts locally abundant (Oldfield et al. 1998). In the valleys of Madeira, subpopulations can be bigger. Population size in Madeira is in the thousands, possibly reaching 10,000. 

On the Canaries the species is widespread, especially on La Palma, Tenerife and Cran Canaria. On Gomera, both subspecies are found; it is the only island in the Canaries where the subspecies ceballosi is present. The species population trend is at least stable, and may be increasing in some areas as a result of habitat protection. The subspecies ceballosi has a "small and fragmented" population (Oldfield et al. 1998) and has only 64 individuals in a single population (Bañares et al. 2004).
range: This species is found in Madeira (on both Madeira and Desertas, extinct in Porto Santo) and the Canary Islands (absent from the eastern islands of Lanzarote and Fueterventura, with historical records from the latter requiring confirmation. There are two subspecies recognised. Apollonias barbujana subsp. ceballosi is confined to La Gomera in the Canary Islands and was previously considered a separate taxon. The species occurs between 0 and 1,200 m asl. On Madeira the species is closer to 50 m above sea level and only reaches 800 m above sea level (M.P. de Sequiera pers. comm. 2016). The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is 89,503 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated, based on known points, at 564 km2, but is most likely much larger. On the Canaries, there was an historical decline in EOO and AOO associated with the loss of forest.
useTrade: The wood of this species was used locally on La Gomera to make very good quality furniture (Bramwell and Lopez 1999). The wood has been called "Canary ebony". There is trade in the branches of this tree (Bañares et al. 2004). On Madeira, the wood was used for naval construction. It is used ornamentally and can reach much more than 25 m in cultivation. It was used to make agricultural tools and in devices for winemaking.
conservationActions:
Part of its range occurs within the Natural Park of Madeira, and the Laurisilva of Madeira was declared a World Natural Heritage Site by UNESCO in December 1999, and goats and sheep, which caused some damage in the past, have now been eradicated from the area. On the Canary Islands, the species occurs in numerous protected areas. Apollonias barbujana subsp. barbujana was listed as 'LR/nt' and subsp. ceballosi listed as Endangered (Oldfield et al. 1998). Apollonias barbujana subsp. ceballosi was listed as Critically Endangered in Spain (Bañares et al. 2004). The taxon has been listed in national legislation in the Canary Islands (ANTHOS 2016). In the Canaries, the species is cultivated in forest tree nurseries and is included in forest restoration planting work. Apollonias barbujana is reported as held in 26 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015).

On Madeira, it is recommended that the invasive species in the forests are removed.

rationale: This species is a tree that can grow up to 15 m tall. The species is endemic to the Macaronesian Islands, with records from Madeira, the Canary Islands and throughout the Azores, and records of the species from the Iberian Peninsula (subsp. iberica) are considered to refer to I. aquifolium. Although some subpopulations (some of which are considered as subspecies and have been assessed as threatened) are small, fragmented and at risk, the species as a whole has a large extent of occurrence. The species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species grows as a tree up to 15 m in height. It grows on steep slopes and in the bottom of ravines, in areas with moist soils. The altitude range (on the Canaries) is from c.600 to 1,250 m asl. This is a common tree of laurisilva and forest at higher altitudes. It also reaches non-laurisilva stands in Madeira into the heath.
threats: No current specific threats are known, although the population on Santa Maria (Azores) and on Gomera were stated to be under threat (WCMC 1998) as a result of its very small population size.
population: The population on the Azores has been described as 'rare' (Clarke 1988) and on Corvo (Azores) only one specimen has been reported, however the species is reported from all the islands (Borges et al. 2010). The populations are small and fragmented on Tenerife and Gomera (Bañares 1998). On Madeira, the population is stable. The population is thought to be much less than 10,000 individuals.
range:
This species is restricted to the Azores (where it is recorded from all the islands; Borges et al. 2010, Portal de la diversidad biológica de las Azores 2017), the Canary Islands (northern Tenerife, La Gomera and La Palma (old records only, with presence requiring confirmation, although presence there reported (Gobierno de Canarias 2017)) and Madeira (Euro+Med 2015). Records of the species from the Iberian Peninsula (as Ilex perado subsp. iberica) are thought to be misidentified and refer to I. aquifolium (Benedi 1997). The extent of occurrence is more than 450,000 km2. The area of occupancy is 296 km2 based on available data, but probably exceeds this.

The species has been cultivated in Britain since 1760 (Bean 1970) and introduced elsewhere (e.g., the Iberian Peninsula, South America).
useTrade: The species has been identified as useful for planting (Galle 1997).
conservationActions:
This species is found in the Parque Nactional de Garjonay on La Gomera, in the Natural Park of Madeira, the World Heritage Site and Natura 2000 sites on Maderia, and probably occurs within protected areas in other parts of its range. Many of the subspecies have been classified as threatened, probably because of very small population sizes, and are protected by local, national and regional legislation (Anthos 2015).

The subspecies lopezlilloi from La Gomera has been assessed as Critically Endangered and is only known from a single individual. Subsp. platyphylla (Tenerife and Gomera) is considered VU, and subsp. perado (Madeira) and subsp. azorica (Azores) were both assessed as LR/nt.

Ilex perado is reported as held in 18 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016). It is important that subspecies are represented within ex situ collections and conservation programmes, and further taxonomic study is required to confirm the taxonomic identity of the subspecies.

rationale: This species is a shrub or small tree endemic to the Canary Islands. The extent of occurrence slightly exceeds 20,000 km<sup>2</sup>, however the area of occupancy (AOO) is less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. The species is considered to be severely fragmented as there are scatted individuals and no sign of active recruitment. The species is assessed as Near Threatened as whilst it is considered locally common and there are no indications of declines or threats, it is severely fragmented and the AOO is restricted, and population and habitat monitoring is recommended.
habitat: This species grows as a shrub or small tree to 4 m tall and is common in rocky areas and cliffs in the lower zone as well as in higher areas (at least on Tenerife) forest regions (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990). There were past declines in the area of thermo-sclerophyllous forest.
threats: Past declines in forest area have been largely halted, but very little remains. No specific current threats are known.
population: The species is locally common (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990), although there are not very many individuals on Fuerteventura and Gran Canaria (Gómez-Campo et al. 1996). The population trend is overall stable, however the species is considered to be severely fragmented as there are scatted individuals and no sign of active recruitment.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands and is found at elevations from 100-1,000 m (J.A. Reyes-Betancort pers. comm. 2017), found on all the islands apart from Lanzarote. The estimated extent of occurrence is 24,390 km<sup>2</sup>. The area of occupancy has not been calculated but is likely to be restricted; it is less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup> but greater than 500 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: The species is used ornamentally.
conservationActions:
Maytenus canariensis is reported as held in 15 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015). This species was assessed as 'rare' in 1984 (Barreno et al.) and as 'not threatened' in 1996 (Gómez-Campo et al. 1996).

The species is listed in government legislature of 1991, and it occurs within protected areas.

rationale: This species is a large tree which is found only in Madeira and the Canary Islands. It is assessed as Least Concern as the species has a large extent of occurrence and the number of mature individuals in the entire population exceeds the threshold for criterion C. However on the Canaries the species is generally rarer, found in small numbers, and it is impacted by declines in water availability; it benefits from conservation measures and habitat and population monitoring is required.
habitat: This species is a dominant element of the temperate laurisilva on Madeira, whilst on the Canaries it is much less common. This species grows as a tree up to 42 m, but trees of this size are uncommon today, and the usual size found on the Canaries is 15-20 m. It is found in humid forests and it is restricted to remaining areas of good quality forest habitat. The fruits are similar to acorns (Bramwell and Lopez 1999). It is seldom found outside the range of this forest in Madeira.
threats:
On Madeira, previously this tree was found more commonly in the south, however due to historical agricultural expansion and deforestation, the range of this species was restricted to the north of the island. Nowadays, the threat on Madeira is mainly from invasive species that could change the fire regime of the forest and therefore expose the best-preserved areas to large fires. The effect of changes in water catchment areas are unpredictable but surely would have some effect. There is no cutting or cattle in the forest (M. Sequeira pers. comm. 2016).

On the Canaries, changes to water catchments (spring water abstraction and surface water diversion) is the primary threat. Clearance of laurisilva forest greatly reduced the extent and quality suitable habitat for this species.
population:
Overall, the population is probably stable, however it requires monitoring. The subpopulation in the Canary Islands has not been properly surveyed but contains fewer than 10,000 individuals in total and on some islands it is known from very restricted areas and populations. The population may be decreasing as it requires humid soils and water is being abstracted from springs.

In Madeira, the tree is common in the north of the island and there are estimated to be over 10,000 individuals. It is no longer a common plant in the south of the island due to agricultural expansion. The population of Madeira is stable.
range: This species is endemic to the western and central Canary Islands (Bramwell and López 1999, Gobierno de Canarias 2017) and Madeira Island (and historically, it is thought the species was found in Porto Santo). The estimated extent of occurrence is 75,000 km<sup>2</sup>. The plant is found between 100 and 1,500 m above sea level.
useTrade: The wood is strong smelling and has a texture similar to ebony (Bramwell and Lopez 1999). The species is used medicinally locally in Madeira, including fever and hypertension. It is used for handicrafts and agricultural tools. It is used for construction and fuel. It is used as a honey plant and food for cattle. It is also found in gardens and as a road tree (L. Ramos and M. Sequeira pers. comm. 2016).
conservationActions: The species was listed as Endangered in the Canary Islands (Bañares et al. 2008), however most remaining populations are within protected areas, and the species is now a component of reforestation programmes on Gran Canaria. It is listed in government legislation of 1991 in the Canary Islands. It was previously assessed as Lower Risk/near threatened (Oldfield et al. 1998, World Conservation Monitoring 1998). The species is in the Natural Park of Madeira, the World Heritage Site and Natura 2000 sites. Management of invasive species in Madeira would be beneficial. Ocotea foetens is reported as held in 30 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015).

rationale: This tree species is endemic to Madeira Island and the Canary Islands. It is assessed as Least Concern as it is considered fairly frequent on several of the islands where it occurs and there are no current major threats affecting its populations.
habitat: The species is a tree that grows up to 15 (20) m, characterised by its whitish bark. It is found in laurisilva forests (Rivas-Martínez 2002), as an important element of the laurisilva forests in Madeira and the Canaries.
threats:
On Madeira, this tree was found more commonly in the south in the past, however due to historical agricultural expansion and deforestation, the range of this species was restricted to the north of the island. Nowadays, the main threat are invasive plant species that can affect the fire regime of the forest and therefore expose the best preserved areas to large fires. The effect of changes in water catchment areas are unpredictable but surely would have some effect. There is no cutting or cattle in the forest (M. Sequeira pers. comm. 2016).

The uncontrolled exploitation of forest resources on islands like La Palma and Tenerife is currently affecting the species.
population:
Although the population size is unknown in the Canary Islands, the species is locally frequent on Tenerife, El Hierro, La Gomera and La Palma. It has been identified as rare on Gran Canaria, and as very scarce in Fuerteventura. Population trends are thought to be stable in the Canaries.

On Madeira, the species has been reported to be a frequent species. It is difficult to estimate the population size, but it is likely to be of thousands of individuals although less than 10,000. The population in Madeira is stable and the population is mixed, with many seedlings.
range: This species is endemic to Macaronesia, where it is found in the Canary Islands (Tenerife, La Palma, El Hierro, La Gomera, Gran Canaria and Fuerteventura; Gobierno de Canarias 2017) and on Madeira Island (WCSP 2017). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is close to 113,000 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be 468 km2. The species can be found between 200 and 1,200 m above sea level.
useTrade: The species is used for reforestation, and as an ornamental species occasionally. The wood of this species has been used in carpentry (Lobo Cabrera et al. 2007). On Madeira, the species was also used for construction and inlay (M. Sequiera pers. comm. 2016).
conservationActions: The species was previously assessed as Vulnerable (Bañares et al. 1998, Oldfield et al. 1998), although not included in recent versions of the Spanish Red List. In the Canary Islands is present in several protected areas, such as Garajonay National Park, as well and in Natura 2000 sites. The species is included in regional legislation in the Canary Islands and more research on population size would be advisable in order to improve current knowledge on the species status across its distribution. On Madeira, the species is found in Natural Park of Madeira, a World Heritage Site and Natura 2000 sites. Management of invasive species in Madeira would be beneficial. Picconia excelsa is reported as held in 25 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015) and is recorded as present in an ex situ seed bank collection (ENSCO 2015).

rationale: This species is a small tree found in Madeira and the Canary Islands. The species occurs over a large area, and whilst it is a less-common species, populations are currently considered to be stable and most populations are within protected areas. The species currently has no significant threats but on Madeira control of invasive species and protection of water resources would be beneficial. It is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species grows as a tree generally up to 10 m (Bramwell and López 1999); on the Canaries it usually grows to 5-8 m but can exceed 10 m height in good condition laurisilva forest. It is restricted to riparian vegetation on medium-high altitudes in Madeira, where this type of habitat occurs in mosaic with temperate laurisilva. In the Canaries, the species is restricted to laurisilva forest (Gobierno de Canarias 2017).
threats: On Madeira, the species is threatened by invasive species, changing fire regimes in the forest, and increasing intensity of the fires. Changes in water availability will affect this tree if water continues to be abstracted from the habitat.
population: The species is locally common in Tenerife (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990), but less common on some of the other islands where it is present (Perez de Paz et al. 1992, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). On Madeira, it is an uncommon tree, with likely fewer than 5,000 individuals, however the population is stable there.
range: This species is found only on the Canary Islands and on Madeira Island (Perez de Paz et al. 1992). In the Canary Islands, the tree has quite a restricted distribution on Tenerife, La Palma, La Gomera and Gran Canaria (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). In the Canary Islands it occurs between 600 and 900 m above sea level (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990) and it is found between 800 and 1,200 m asl on Madeira. The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is 68,190 km2.
useTrade: The plant was used for inlay decoration, with timber being collected.
conservationActions:
This uncommon species is largely contained within protected areas, and on the Canaries, laurisilva forest has been the focus of extensive conservation and reforestation activities. On Madeira, it occurs in the Natural Park of Madeira, the World Heritage site and Natura 2000 sites. It is covered by regional legislation on Madeira and in the Canaries. This species was previously assessed as Lower Risk/conservation dependent in 1998 (Bañares et al. 1998, Oldfield et al. 1998). It has been assessed as Vulnerable in the Canary Islands (Moreno 2008). 

The use of water from the habitat in Madeira should be controlled and monitored to prevent issues in the future. Invasive species should be removed form the habitat to reduce the intensity of forest fires and improve the habitat quality.

Rhamnus glandulosa is reported as held in 11 ex situ collections (BGCI 2015).

rationale: Asplenium anceps is listed as Endangered in view of its small area of occupancy (AOO = 104 km²), the fact that it is considered to be severely fragmented and that it is experimenting a continuing decline in the habitat quality and in the number of mature individuals. Strict legal protection and enforcement are needed in order to protect this species.
habitat: Asplenium anceps is found on shady and damp places on rocks, walls of levadas, streams and roadside ditches, and among mosses in laurisilva (Press and Short 1994). In the Azores, it was found in the humid juniper forest above 700 m. Its altitudinal range is 400-1,400 m asl.
threats: Asplenium anceps has declined as a result of changes in its habitat quality. Where the species is found close to levadas, it can be affected by repairing works and by the recreational use of these areas. In the Azores, it went extinct probably due to the collection of botanists and habitat destruction as a result of the logging of juniper forest for pasture land.
population: The species is rare in the Canary Islands (Sanchez Velazquez 2002), where it is assumed to be stable (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016). It is frequent in Madeira (Press and Short 1994), although it is declining there (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016). Since the core of its population is in Madeira, the overall population trend is considered to be decreasing. It is extinct in the Azores, where it was last seen on Pico in 1973 (Lovis et al. 1977). The population is considered to be severely fragmented, as it occurs in small scattered subpopulations with little to no exchange with each other.
range: This species is endemic to Madeira and the Canary Islands, and it was formerly known from the Azores. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 104 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are in place for this species, but strict legal protection and enforcement are needed. The species is found in protected areas throughout its range, but where it occurs outside protected areas, its habitat needs to be protected. It is listed as Vulnerable D1+2 in Spain (Moreno 2008). If it is ever rediscovered in the Azores, it should be strictly protected.

rationale: Even though this Canary Islands endemic species has a small range, it is assessed as Least Concern in view of its stable population trend. There are no observed declines.
habitat: Asplenum aureum is found on shady, moist, mossy rock walls and eroded volcanic lava in subtropical laurisilva forest, usually in open areas (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016).
threats: This species is threatened by deforestation and habitat destruction through recreational activities.
population: The species is rare in the Canary Islands (Sanchez Velazquez 2002), but its population trend is assumed to be stable since there are no observed declines (Moreno 2008).
range: This species is restricted to the Canary Islands (Spain), where it is found on all islands. It is the ancestral species of A. lolegnamense and A. octoploideum. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 232 km².
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: The species is listed as Near Threatened in Spain (Moreno 2008). Habitats should be protected in order to preserve this species. It is found in protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: The species is assessed as Vulnerable due to its small area of occupancy (AOO) of around 20 km², the fact that there are less than 10 locations, and that there is a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and habitat quality. In addition, its population size is estimated to be between 250 and 1,000 mature individuals. Site protection is advised and research on the threats to this species is needed.
habitat: This species is found in decaying Selaginella and moss on volcanic rocky substrates, on roadside and garden walls and on some stream banks (Press and Short 1994). There is a continuing decline in habitat quality as a result of infrastructure development.
threats: The species is threatened in Madeira and the rest of the islands due to urban development. On the basis of this threat, fewer than 10 locations are estimated. In addition, it may be potentially threatened by renovation of the walls where it occurs or the widening of the roads along which it is present.
population: The population is estimated to be between 250 and 1,000 individuals (Martín et al. 2008). The number of subpopulations and of mature individuals in each subpopulation is unknown. The overall population trend is declining (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016), since the species is found on the drier parts of the islands, which are more subject to infrastructure development.
range: This species is endemic to the Macaronesian islands of Madeira (Portugal), La Palma and Gran Canaria (Spain). On Madeira it is rare around Funchal, and it is also uncommon on the Canary Islands. It has been suggested that it is derived from the hybridisation of Asplenium aureum and A. octoploideum, the latter of which does not occur in Madeira (Gibby and Lovis 1989, Van den Heede et al. 2004). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is ca 53,686-85,710 km², but the area of occupancy (AOO) within this range is estimated to be around 20 km².
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: Asplenium lolegnamense is rare in areas around the largest town in Madeira, where it is found on roadside walls. Half of the population falls within a nature reserve. It is advisable to protect the remaining sites and when development is planned that may threaten these subpopulations, ex-situ conservation and reintroduction should be considered. Research on the threats to this species is needed.

rationale: <span class="">This fern species is assessed as Near Threatened since its population size is estimated to be around 1,000 mature individuals and thus is close to qualify as threatened under criterion D. Further research on its population size is needed.
habitat: The species grows, often together with its tetraploid cousin A. ceterach, in rock fissures in natural pine forests and open savanna-like habitats dominated by Pinus canariensis (Van den Heede et al. 2004). A sterile hexaploid hybrid is also often present. Its elevation range is 700-2,000 m (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016).
threats: There are no current threats to this species. Hybridisation could be a potential threat, but since the hybrids are sterile this is not a major threat to the species. Other potential threats include infrastructure development and fire.
population: Due to the lack of surveys and introgression with related species, the exact number of plants in the population is unknown, although it is estimated to be around 1,000 mature individuals. The population trend is stable.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Gran Canaria, La Palma, Tenerife). It is an autopolyploid derived from hybridisation between A. ceterach and A. aureum. It was formerly known as A. parvifolium, an incorrectly applied name. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,109-13,451 km² and its area of occupancy (AOO) is 48 km².
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: Asplenium octoploideum was listed as Vulnerable on the Canary Islands (Sanchez Velazquez 2002). It is unknown whether it occurs in protected areas. Habitat protection is the only solution to preserve this species. Further research on its population size is needed.

rationale: <span class="">The species is assessed as Endangered since there are fewer than 250 mature plants, it has a restricted area of occupancy (AOO), the population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in habitat quality. It may experience fluctuations that depend on the use or abandonment of agricultural sites. Habitat preservation and restoration are recommended to protect this species.
habitat: Asplenium terorense grows at the foot of walls or chalky slopes in deep soil, often in the understory of laurisilva (Pruno-Lauretea azoricae), but currently more commonly on secondary laurel, elm, chestnut or fig forest remnants, due to human activities, and it is sometimes found even in the shade of bushes like Chamaecytisus proliferus of Rubus ulmifolius. It also grows together with A. billotii at the foot of agricultural or natural walls and at the base of lava sheets, in humid, shaded environments. It is found at altitudes between 750-1,250 m (Marrero and Sanchez Velazquez 2013).
threats: The species is found in an area of traditional agricultural use. Although the gradual abandonment of these activities since the 1980s has led to some recovery of that habitat through the forming of thickets or copses of secondary laurisilva, some agricultural activities persist and the continued habitat destruction, maintenance of tracks and roads, grazing and ploughing has negatively affected some subpopulations (Marrero and Sanchez Velazquez 2013).
population: The population consists of 48 plants at 13 localities on Gran Canaria, with a few more plants on El Hierro (Marrero and Sanchez Velazquez 2013). The population trend is assumed to be stable. The population is considered to be severely fragmented, as it is found on small and isolated subpopulations. The population size is estimated to be between 50 and 250 mature individuals.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Spain), where it is known from the islands of Gran Canaria (where the majority of subpopulations are found) and El Hierro (where only few are present). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,212-9,649 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 16 km².
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: Asplenium terorense was listed as probably endangered in the Canary Islands (Sanchez Velazquez 2002), but insufficient data were available at the time, resulting on its listing as Data Deficient in the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008). Further studies have been carried out (Marrero and Sanchez Velazquez 2013) and its population has been found to consist of less than 50 clumps in small subpopulations, limited to a few isolated locations (10-15). Some of the subpopulations are in protected areas which are not under immediate threat. The species is best protected through habitat preservation and restoration.

rationale:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 28 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This delicate fern species is endemic to Europe. It has a stable population trend, it is widespread and gregarious in many places where it occurs, and it is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Nevertheless, it is sensitive to habitat alteration and subpopulations ought to be protected as they are indicators of a unique microclimate.
habitat: Hymenophyllum wilsonii occurs in deep ravines and river gorges on vertical rock faces by waterfalls and along cascading stream sides. It is also present on tree trunks in valley woodlands and in sheltered ravines or among scree on mountainsides (Page 1997), in woods and other damp, shady, sheltered or slightly more exposed places (Tutin et al. 1964). It is most abundant in steep, sheltered and well-shaded stream ravines near western Atlantic coasts, where humidity is normally constantly high, where winter temperatures are mild, and where there is a long growth season, especially on more acidic rocks (Page 1997). In the Azores, it is an epiphytic species on juniper (R. Elias pers. comm. 2016). It is found from sea level to 1,200 m elevation (F. Rumsey and R. Elias pers. comm. 2016).
threats: The species is mostly affected by the alteration of its habitat. When the forest is cleared or the area dries out, the species disappears. Hydroelectric schemes and tourism disturbances may affect the species through changes in the levels of humidity (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016),
population: This is a gregarious fern within its range, forming many nearby patches within a subpopulation. It has declined in the past, but it is currently considered stable throughout its range. The species is not common in the Azores and in many other parts of its distribution (R. Elias pers. comm. 2016).
range: This species is restricted to areas in northwestern Europe with high rainfall levels. It is mostly abundant in Britain and Ireland, and is also found in coastal Norway and Brittany, southwards to Madeira and northwards to Iceland (Schaefer 2005, Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013). The subpopulations in Normandy and on Gran Canaria have disappeared, although it is still present in La Gomera. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 2,700 km².
useTrade: The species is not used.
conservationActions:
This species is often under-recorded because it is small and moss-like and thus frequently overlooked. It is present in protected areas throughout its range and listed on the following national Red Lists:
  • France: Endangered B2ab(iii) (UICN France, FCBN and MNHN 2012).
  • Spain: Critically Endangered D (Moreno et al. 2008), Endangered in Galicia (Romero Buján 2007) and Extinct in the Canary Islands (Sanchez Velazquez 2002), although it is present in La Gomera.
  • United Kingdom: Least Concern (Cheffings and Farrell 2005, Stroh et al. 2014).

rationale: This species is widespread, common and increasing in range in some parts of the world. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs at a wide range of running and standing, unshaded  waters including rice paddies and brackish lagoons. In the northern part of  its range it is mostly found at not too shallow, well vegetated waters. It is found in various terrestrial habitats, except dense forest, and prefers stagnant water.
threats: This species is not under any specific threat.
population: This species is common in most of its range, and in Europe it is steadily expanding its range northwards.
range: This species is widespread in Africa, southern Europe, the Middle East and west Asia, extending as far east as Yunnan in China. It is absent from southeast Asia and its Asian distribution is essentially Himalayan: Nepal (Asahina 1965, Mahato 1988) and northern India with records from Assam (Schneider 1995) and West Bengal (Peters 1981). In the last two decades it has been strongly expanding its range in the north of Europe, being now indigenous to many areas were it previously did not occur (Ott 2007). This species is common and widespread all over Africa and is known from all countries apart from Burundi and its presence is uncertain in Lesotho.
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are needed.

rationale: This is a widespread and stable species with no known major threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is known from any kind of standing and slow-flowing fresh and brackish waters, except in dense rainforest areas (such as the Congo Basin).
threats: Orthetrum chrysostigma is not under threat at the global scale, although local declines may occur due to habitat destruction and water pollution.
population: This species is omnipresent with large subpopulations all over its range. No decline is expected at the global scale.
range: This is one of the most common species in Africa and is widespread throughout the African continent, except in dense forests. It reaches southern Europe, the Middle East and the Arabian Peninsula.
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: This species does not need any conservation actions or further research.

rationale: This is a widespread species with no known major threats and it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Orthetrum trinacria is well adapted to various fresh and brackish slow-flowing and standing waters, including flood plain backwaters (oxbow lakes, seasonally inundated depressions on river sides), pools and permanent sections of discontinuous and temporary flowing rivers, large man-made dam lakes, large permanent rivers, irrigation ditches and collecting channels and cisterns in oases. It is still able to develop under high salinity (150% of that of sea water; Suhling et al. 2003). The larval period is short so that this species is able to reproduce successfully in temporary water bodies. Orthetrum trinacria is therefore well adapted to littoral dune lakes and desert and semi-desert environments with temporary waters showing increasing salt concentrations from the rainy season to the dry season.
threats: Habitat modification caused by agriculture and water pollution impacts this species, although it is not considered to be affecting this species at global level.
population: This Afrotropical species is generally met in large colonies where it is found in Africa and southern Europe.
range: Orthetrum trinacria is widespread throughout the whole of Africa, except in the tropical rainforest, and the Middle East, and reaches the south of Europe. The easternmost localities are in western Iran, the northernmost ones in northern Sardinia. Former records from Anatolia are doubtful but recent authenticated records from northern Syria, southern Turkey, Greece, Malta and southwest Iberia point toward a recent expansion and increase in density of this species to the north, probably due both to climate warming and construction of new man-made pools which are promptly colonised.
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: This is a widespread and common species and no specific actions are required at the global scale. Taxonomic investigations about the status of Iraqi subpopulations are recommended.

rationale: This is a widespread species with no known major widespread threats and it is therefore unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.  It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Trithemis annulata is an opportunist and ubiquitous species which is found in any type of freshwater whether standing or running. In Tunisia, imagoes have been found at brackish running waters with a salinity reaching almost 0.9% but it is not known whether they reproduce there. The larval period is short so that this species is able to reproduce successfully in temporary water bodies.
threats: Trithemis annulata is not under threat at the global scale, although local declines and extinctions may occur due to habitat destruction and water pollution.
population: This species is widespread and very abundant throughout its range. It is expanding its range to the north due to the present global warming.
range: Trithemis annulata is one of the most widespread and common species in Africa, Arabia and in the Mediterranean countries. Its eastern limit is in Iran, where it begins to be replaced by its Asian close relative T. aurora.
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: This species does not need conservation actions but new information on its genetic variability and its relation to closely related taxa would be welcome.

rationale: This is a widespread, common and stable species with no known major widespread threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in freshwater ponds and lakes and at permanent pools in temporary flowing wadis. It is also found along irrigation channels and ditches in oases and near large rivers.
threats: This species is not under threat at the global scale, although excessive use of water by humans and pollution may cause this species to decline at local levels.
population: This species is widespread and common over most of its range.
range: Trithemis arteriosa is one of the most widespread and common dragonflies in Africa, southern Europe and the Arabian Peninsula. It extends to Turkey, Crete in Greece (Boudot pers. comm.), and Iran.
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are needed at present.

rationale: Zygonyx torridus is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category. However, areas at the margin of its distribution and disjunct subpopulations deserve particular attention and monitoring.
habitat: This species is known from streams and rivers in bush, savanna, woodland and thin forest, often above or near rapids.
threats: The species is under threat in some parts of its range (e.g. the European subpopulations), but it is not thought to have widespread threats at the global scale.
population: This species is widespread but its population size is unknown.
range: Zygonyx torridus is widespread in Africa and reaches southern Europe, the Middle East, Arabia, Pakistan and India. It is not known from Madagascar, but is resident in La Réunion, Mauritius, Comoros and Socotra (Yemen).
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: Subpopulation trends should be monitored, particularly on the margins of its range and in the Mediterranean area (Spain, Morocco, Levant, Turkey, Arabia), India and Pakistan, where this species is present in disjunct subpopulations. The ecology and behaviour of this species have been imperfectly studied and need further investigation.

rationale: This species is widespread and is not facing any major threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Tribulus terrestris is an annual creeping herb. Its flowers are small and solitary with five yellow petals and its fruits are woody, bearing two sets of sharp spines which attach to animals and humans (Akram et al. 2011). Flowering and fruiting occur from April to August (Umadevi and Srinathrao 2017). Pollination is done by insects including ants and bees, but in the absence of pollinators, this bisexual species is able to self-pollinate through the stamens and corolla bending so that the stamens come into contact with the stigma. Insect pollinators are encouraged, though, through the provision of sustenance (Reddi et al. 1980). T. terrestris can grow in a wide range of conditions. It is most commonly found in sandy soil and in wind-blown areas, but also can grow in compacted soil, as well as heavier, more fertile soils (El-Ghareeb 1991). The spines on the fruit allow it to be dispersed over large distances (Sorensen 1984). It is a C4 plant and possesses adaptations for thriving in dry conditions, even enduring droughts (Chen et al. 2019). These adaptations include xeromorphic leaves and an extensive tap root system which is extremely efficient at extracting water from the soil. It is sensitive to excess water and grows poorly in waterlogged soils (Nikolova and Vassilev 2011). As a result of its efficient moisture extraction, as well as its leachate habit which inhibits growth in other plants, it often reduces populations of other species and is considered a weed and agricultural nuisance (El-Ghareeb 1991). It is reported as affecting many crops including cotton and maize (Memon et al. 2007, Verdu and Mas 2006). In addition, this species is poisonous when consumed by livestock and the fruits can puncture the stomach lining of animals (Sorensen 1984). In California, two species of weevil were introduced as a biological control, and after twenty years caused a substantial reduction in viability of seed and T. terrestris cover (Huffaker et al. 1983).
threats: There are no significant threats to this species, however, as the species is collected from the wild it is possible that in some areas it is over-exploited (Evstatieva and Tchorbanov 2011).
population: This species has a very large distribution over a number of countries so it is suspected that the population is large; there are no known major threats so it is also suspected that the population trend is stable. However, no numerical population information is available so research into population status and trends is recommended to verify this.
range: Tribulus terrestris has a wide distribution, with its native range covering most of Africa, central and south Asia, and south Europe and its introduced range covering the United States, some of Canada, and western South America (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2019). It grows at elevations of 0–3,000 m asl in the tropical and subtropical regions (Akram et al. 2011) and up to 3,800 m asl in Tibet (Wang 2003).
useTrade:
The use of this species has been traced back 5,000 years in India and China (Bartram 1995). It is still used today in traditional medicine systems of many countries, with its most common use as a hormone booster to help treat sexual dysfunction (Evstatieva and Tchorbanov 2011). It is also effective as a diuretic and in treating kidney stones and other kidney diseases. In Chinese medicine, the fruits are used to treat eye problems, edema, and abdominal problems, and the root is used for rheumatism, piles, menorrhagia, headaches, and dizziness. In Ayurveda, it is most well known for being a diuretic, treating venereal diseases, and for its aphrodisiac properties (Umadevi and Srinathrao 2017). Studies have found it is effective in decreasing blood sugar levels, protecting heart cells and improving heart function, inhibiting cancer cells, and increasing testosterone levels. Most of these biological effects are due to high levels of steroidal saponins (Umadevi and Srinathrao, 2017). 

This species has also been promoted and used as an herbal supplement to increase athletic performance; however, studies have found that it does not increase muscle mass or strength (Rogerson et al. 2007, Antonio et al. 2000). Bulgaria is a major exporter, with at least 900 tonnes collected annually from the wild (Evstatieva and Tchorbanov 2011).
conservationActions: This species is held at 35 botanic gardens (BGCI 2019) and there are 16 seed accessions held at various seed banks with accessions from the United States of America, Azerbaijan, Mali, Israel, Botswana, Lebanon, Burkina Faso, Cyprus, Slovakia, and Australia (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2019). There are numerous protected areas across its range, so it can be assumed that passive in situ conservation is taking place (Protected Planet 2019). Research is needed to understand if the population is being affected by over-collection.

rationale: Pinus canariensis is abundant on Tenerife and is clearly recovering from past over-cutting. Really big trees are rare because of past exploitation, enormous specimens are now 'monuments' for tourists to see. But trees in all age classes in extensive forests now occupy the entire pine belt ('Corona Forestal') on all sides of Pico del Teide on Tenerife. There is no evidence of cutting or recent fires and the authorities are well aware of the importance of retaining forest cover on the extremely permeable volcanic 'soil' of the island in order to ensure water supplies. Exploitation of its timber has been banned and this ban is strictly enforced. Similar improvements have occurred on other islands. Although the extent of occurrence and the actual area of occupancy fall below the IUCN's thresholds, there is no current or ongoing decline. Past decline has not only been halted, it has been reversed due to active management and protection. On this basis, and at this time, an assessment of Least Concern is appropriate.
habitat: In the Canary Islands this species predominantly occupies areas at altitudes from 1,200 m to ca. 2,200 m asl. It grows well on exposed mountain slopes of volcanic origin amidst or on old lava flows and on scoria. Winter snow and frost limit its altitudinal range upwards (Pico del Teide is 3,718 m); at lower elevations a thermophile woodland and/or xerophytic scrub vegetation, interspersed with rare evergreen lauraceous woodland on N-facing slopes and in moist gullies, dominates. Pinus canariensis is dominant within this pine belt where it exists, but spring-flowering legumes and other herbs and shrubs may be common. Some common shrubs are Adenocarpus foliolosus, Chamaecytisus proliferus, and Cistus symphytifolius. The pine woods are characteristically very open and sunny and often there is nothing else on the ground than rocks, pine needles and great numbers of the large seed cones rolled into hollows. Some remnant stands occur at altitudes as low as 500 m.
threats: Extensive logging in the past combined with destructive forest fires at one time reduced the area of occupancy (AOO) very substantially. However, extensive replanting since the 1950s and regrowth and better management, as well as cessation of exploitation, have restored most of the pine forests, even if large trees are now very rare. The fire hazard still remains and may become more acute with the ever increasing tourism and its ramifications, and with climate change if this tends to lengthen periods of drought on the islands where this species is indigenous. Development, especially on Tenerife, is encroaching into the pine belt ("corona forestal"), which once encircled the volcano and mountain spur to the northeast, but is no longer contiguous.
population: The largest populations are on Tenerife and Gran Canaria, the populations on La Palma, El Hierro and La Gomera are much smaller. All are recovering from over-exploitation, perhaps most spectacularly the population on Tenerife, which forms a belt of pine forest around the great caldeira of Pico del Teide. Most trees seen in the pine forest belt on Tenerife (A. Farjon pers. obs.) are now mature, seed producing trees and there is natural regeneration.
range:
The species is restricted to five of the Canary Islands (La Gomera, La Palma, Tenerife, Gran Canaria and El Hierro), mainly at altitudes between 1,200 and 2,200 m (Farjon and Page 1999). The largest populations are on Tenerife and Gran Canaria. On La Gomera, there are two very small populations at Garabato and Imada. The stand at Garabato grows at an atypical altitude of only 500 m. A similar small, low altitude population, disjunct from the main areas, exists on Tenerife at Anaga in the north (Vaxevanidou et al. 2006; Arevalo & Fernandez-Palacios 2009). On Fuerteventura and Lanzarote, Pinus canariensis is introduced.

The actual area of occupancy, excluding reafforested areas is estimated to between 300 and 400 km2. This rises to about 700 km2 when reafforested areas are included (Arévalo and Fernández-Palacios 2009).
useTrade: Heavily exploited in the past for construction timber. The present use is as a belt of forest to retain rainfall for use in an urbanizing coastal area, especially on Tenerife and Gran Canaria.
conservationActions: The pine forests are now under legal protection and active management (replanting) has largely restored them. The Canary Islands endemic pine forests are included in the Annex I of the EU Habitat Directive. Smaller isolated and marginal populations in La Gomera, Gran Canaria and Tenerife require special protection (Vaxevanidou et al. 2006). Invasive species that hinder natural regeneration, not just of the pine but also its associated species, need to be controlled.

rationale: This species is a small shrub endemic to La Palma in the Canaries. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 222 km<sup>2</sup>. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be much less than 500 km<sup>2 a</sup>nd probably c.200 km<sup>2</sup>. Despite its small range it is common in the habitat where it is found., and there are few known threats to the species, and whilst they are not likely to be significant, more research into these is required. More information is needed on the population size and trends. It is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a small shrub (to 1 m height, but usually less), found in pine forest rock communities (Garzón-Machado et al. 2011) and in thermo-sclerophyllous forest.
threats: Fire may impact some sub-populations, and introduced herbivores may be a threat.
population: This species is generally scarce but common in some of the plant communities on La Palma (Garzón-Machado et al. 2011). There is no information on the population size or trends. This is a short-lived perennial species and populations are likely to fluctuate according to environmental conditions (e.g., post-fire expansion, wet/dry years).
range: This species is endemic to La Palma in the Canary Islands (Pérez de Paz and Negrín Sosa 1992, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 222 km<sup>2</sup>. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be very much less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>. The species is found between 200 m and 1,200(1,700) m above sea level; there is a single record from 1,700 m in the caldera.
useTrade: The species is used locally in traditional medicine to treat coughs and heal wounds (Pérez de Paz and Hernandez 1999).
conservationActions: There are seven known ex situ collections of this species in botanic gardens worldwide (BGCI 2016). Most known localities occur within protected areas.

rationale: Although this European endemic species has a restricted distribution, the population trend is stable and it is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Research on its population size and trend are needed.
habitat:
Dryopteris guanchica is found in deciduous forests on the Iberian Peninsula, and in laurisilva forests and "barrancos" in the Canary Islands.

The species is considered as a relict, particularly in Iberian refugia, being characterized by a high mean annual precipitation, or in particular along river basins where the subtropical moisture is to some degree substituted by water flowing from mountain headwaters (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2011, Heywood 2014). Its elevation limits are 0-1,000 m.
threats: Although current threats are unknown, there has been considerable pressure on the subpopulations in the past due to land conversion for agriculture, particularly in the Canary Islands and especially on Gran Canaria (Anonymous 2010).
population: There is no information on the population trend since the taxon was only recently described (1977). However, although in the past the habitats of D. guanchica were turned to fields, which reduced the size of subpopulations, the main ones on La Gomera and Tenerife are stable. The overall population trend is therefore assumed to be stable.
range: This species is restricted to Europe, where it is found in Portugal, Spain and the Canary Islands (Gomera, Hierro, Tenerife) (Gibby and Jermy 1977, Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013). The area of occupancy (AOO) is calculated to be 248 km², but this may be an underestimation.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: The main subpopulations today are on the islands of La Gomera and Tenerife (Anaga region), which are protected following Spanish law. At Anaga, a site with high biodiversity, localities are today strictly prohibited to access without permission. In Spain it is listed as Vulnerable B2ab(iii); D2 (Moreno et al. 2008), and it is also categorized as Vulnerable in A Coruña where it is known from the locality at As Mariñas (Galicia, Spain) (Fragas do Mandeo 2010). It is extinct in Andalucía (Heywood 2014). Research on its population size and trend are needed.

rationale: This endemic species to the Canary Islands is locally common, its population trend is stable and it does not face any major threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Dryopteris oligodonta occurs mainly in shaded and humid habitats of the laurel forest (laurisilva) zone, where it is often abundant and as such it is a feature of the local landscape. Occasionally it also occurs in more humid parts of the evergreen forest zone (fayal-brezal vegetation) (Gibby and Jermy 1977).
threats: There are no threats to the species.
population: This species is fairly common on La Gomera, El Hierro, La Palma and Tenerife (Gibby and Jermy 1977), but rare on Gran Canaria. The population trend is stable.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on all islands except Fuerteventura and Lanzarote. In general it is found between 200 and 1,500 m elevation, but mostly at 800-1,200 m (Gibby and Jermy 1977, Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013). It has an area of occupancy (AOO) of about 200 km².
useTrade: This species is locally used as an ornamental, although it rarely adapts well to artificial habitats. It was formerly used as a drug against human intestinal parasitic worms.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place and none appear to be needed. The species is present in protected areas.

rationale:
A loss has been reported in area, quality and extent of habitat and number of mature individuals of this species due to threats such as fires, forest plantations and hydrological power plants. There are indications that its subpopulations in mainland Spain and Portugal have been decreasing seriously, but the rate of this decline in the last three generations is not known, particularly as individuals are very long-lived. Nevertheless, the Azorean subpopulations account for more than 10,000 individuals and seem stable, and the species is protected by law in Portugal. Therefore, the overall decline is not thought to reach 30% in the last three-generation length period.

However, the area of occupancy (AOO) of this rare species is smaller than 2,000 km² and a continuing decline in the extent of occurrence (EOO) and AOO is taking place. Therefore, the species is assessed as Near Threatened since it is close to qualify as threatened under criterion B. The habitats of this species need protection and its biology requires further research.
habitat: This tree fern grows on siliceous rocky slopes, especially in deep valleys under evergreen forest and near coastal areas, sometimes in scrubland up to 1,100 m elevation. It is usually found close to waterfalls or streams that provide moisture in the form of spray. This species requires shade and warm temperatures all year round, with high atmospheric humidity to flourish. The thickness of the soil does not appear to condition their development as they grow on earthy or stony slopes, skeletal soils and even directly on a diversity of acid rocks, basic or ultrabasic, although it apparently avoids limestone substrates (Bañares et al. 2004). In the Azores, it is a common species in the herbaceous layer of high elevation montane forests (R. Elias pers. comm. 2016).
threats: There is no evidence that subpopulations of Culcita macrocarpa are threatened by natural causes, although the knowledge of its biology is still scarce. The species could be affected by changes in the water supply, plantations and the cutting of trees (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016). In recent years, a reduction or even disappearance of several subpopulations in natural parks or areas proposed as Natura 2000 sites has been observed. The main causes appear to be the conversion of forests into plantations, the construction of small hydro-plants, vandalism and habitat destruction (Bañares et al. 2004). In Portugal, fire is the main threat to the species and eucalyptus plantations are causing desiccation of the soil, leading to an alteration of its preferred habitat (ICN 2006). Madeira has seen a decline of at least 25% on its subpopulations over the last decade, but the decline in the Azores is not substantiated (Martín et al. 2008).
population:
In Portugal, the population has been estimated to be of ca 300 individuals on the mainland (Commission of the European Communities 2009), but more than 10,000 plants occur in the Azores (Silva et al. 2009), where it is abundant. It has been indicated that the area of occupancy has been reduced in the last decades (ICN 2006) and a continuing decline in the EOO and AOO is currently taking place.

The subpopulation in Spain has been estimated to comprise ca 20,000 individuals distributed across six regions including Asturias, Cádiz, Cantabria, Galicia, the Basque Country and on the island of Tenerife (Bañares et al. 2004), and although it is very localised, subpopulations can be reasonably large. The overall population trend is assumed to be stable.
range: Culcita macrocarpa is endemic to Portugal and Spain. It is closely related to C. coniifolia, a tropical American species, and these are the only two species in the genus. It can be found in the north Cantabrian coast, northern Galicia, southern Spain (Algeciras), the Canary Islands (Tenerife), in the Serra de Valongo near Porto (Portugal), the Azores (Corvo, Faial, Flores, Pico, Sao Miguel, Sao Jorge, Terceira) and Madeira (Bañares et al. 2004). In Spain, the area of occupancy is 62 km² (Bañares et al. 2004). In Portugal mainland, the surface range of the species is 100 km² and it is 1,451 km² in the Azores and Madeira (Commission of the European Communities 2009). Overall, the area of occupancy (AOO) for this species is less than 2,000 km².
useTrade: This plant has been used commercially for ornamental purposes by florists in Porto. It is also of medicinal use (ICN 2006). Its rhizome scales were formerly used to stuff cushions, for example for old fashioned car seats, but this is no longer the case.
conservationActions:
Culcita macrocarpa is listed on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and is listed under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). This species is included in the Spanish Red Data Book as Endangered (EN) A2ce; B1b(i,ii,iii)c(i,ii) (Moreno 2008) and considered to be Endangered in the Canary Islands (Sanchez Velazquez 2002). It is protected by national law in Portugal. 
Several subpopulations are located in protected areas, with conservation measures underway. It is suggested to protect the species in micro-reserves, to reinforce and protect effective subpopulations, to manage the risk from fires and to preserve its forest habitat. Studies on its reproductive biology should be continued (Bañares et al. 2004, ICN 2006).

rationale:
European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 28 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

Trichomanes speciosum is a restricted to western Europe and Macaronesia. It is found at more than 500 localities in its range and is stable in some countries. Overall, it does not approach any of the threatened Categories at the European level. However, the species has a very specialized ecology and habitat preferences and is very slow-growing. In addition, it faces several threats including collection, recreational activities, habitat destruction, unfavourable forest management, modification of hydrological conditions, droughts and garbage disposal. Therefore, despite being assessed as Least Concern, the species should continue being monitored, site protection should be kept in place and appropriate management of the sites needs to be considered.
habitat:
Mature sporophyte subpopulations occur in widely discontinuous stations, mostly in steep, sheltered and well-shaded stream ravines on steep-sided rock faces, beneath overhangs or close to the splash zone of permanent waterfalls, dripping vertical cliffs, or from the roofs and sides of shallow caves. It is found almost unvaryingly in conditions of high humidity, permanent seepage, usually running ground water and extreme shelter, mainly on hard, acidic rocks, but occasionally epiphytic on tree boles (Page 1997). Gametophytes grow in small rock crevices or on the surfaces of dark rock faces, which can press for many years.
This is a strictly oceanic species, which is much less common than it formerly was and is extinct in many localities. Since 1990, several relict gametophyte populations have been detected in Europe at localities where the sporophytes are absent. Gametophytes have been found in France (Vosges), Luxembourg, Germany (Eiffel, Palatinate near Pirmasens, Elbsandsteingebirge), Italy and the Czech Republic (Hrensko). A sporophyte has recently been reported from Palatinate (Frey et al. 2006).
threats: This species has a very specialized ecology and habitat preferences, and is very slow growing. Therefore it is potentially threatened by a number of factors including sample collection, recreational activities, habitat destruction and desiccation. Unfavourable forest management (such as the removal of forest undergrowth), outdoor sports and leisure activities such as rock climbing, and modification of hydrological conditions have been reported as threats by some of the EU 28 member countries (Commission of the European Communities 2009). For Italy, additional threats of logging, droughts (probably more important in the future due to surface water abstraction and climate warming) and domestic waste and garbage discharge have been reported (Foggi et al. 2010). In Portugal, the  invasion of Acacia melanoxylon also poses a threat (ICN 2006).
population:
The following population data has been provided in country reports for the Article 17 consultation under the Habitats Directive (Commission of the European Communities 2009):
  • Belgium: occupying 7 grid cells with an unknown trend
  • Czech Republic: 230 localities with an increasing trend
  • France: 172 localities
  • Germany: 128 localities with stable subpopulations
  • Ireland: 66 localities with a stable trend
  • Italy: sporophyte subpopulations at 6 localities with a population size of 2,500 individuals and a stable trend that is expected to decline in the future. 
  • Luxembourg: 130-150 localities with a stable trend
  • Poland: 2 localities with 5 individuals and declining (Kalinka and Nowak 2004)
  • Portugal: 23 tufts with a declining population
  • Spain: 16 localities with a stable trend and more than 1,000 individuals on the Canary Islands
  • United Kingdom: 162 localities with an unknown trend
Its overall population trend is stable.
range:
Trichomanes speciosum is restricted to western Europe and Macaronesia. This species has a mainly extreme western range in Europe, with sporophytic subpopulations found from Scotland, western England, Wales and Ireland, Brittany, the western Iberian peninsula to the Azores, Madeira, the Canary Islands and Cape Verde. Isolated sporophytic subpopulations are known from Italy (Alpi Apuane) and Germany (Palatinate). Gametophytic populations are also found in Belgium, the Czech Republic (Hrensko), France (Vosges), Germany (Eiffel, Palatinate near Pirmasens, Elbsandsteingebirge), Italy (Tuscany, Liguria) and Luxembourg and Poland.
In France, it occurs in Brittany, Alsace and Pyrénées Atlantique. In Italy, the gametophyte grows in about 200 subpopulations in Tuscany and Liguria between 20 and 600 m elevation. The sporophyte has been recorded in about six localities in the Alpi Apuane between 165 and 275 m (Foggi et al. 2010). In Portugal, it is found at two localities close to each other in the Serra de Santa Justa, region Valongo (ICN 2006). In Spain, it occurs in the provinces A Coruña, Asturias, Cadiz, Guipuzcoa, Navarra, Santander, and Vizcaya (Castroviejo et al. 1986, Dirección General de Medio Natural y Política Forestal del MARM 2007). In the UK, it is found in at least 14 localities (UK Biodiversity Group 1995). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is over 2,400 km2.
useTrade: This fern is is not used, but it is unusual and therefore sometimes subject to collection by horticulturists. Its cultivation is often unsuccessful.
conservationActions:
Trichomanes speciosum is listed on Annex II of the Habitats Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). In Ireland, Trichomanes speciosum is protected under the Wildlife Act, 1976-Flora (Commission of the European Communities 2009). In France, it is protected at national level. In Italy it is included in the Tuscany Regional Law for the Protection of the Flora LR 56/2000, but is not included in any protected areas there. Recommended conservation measures include a constant monitoring of the subpopulations and the development of guidelines for forest management and water abstraction when nearby the species. It is listed on the following national Red Lists:
  • Czech Republic: Critically Endangered (Holub and Procházka 2000) or Endangered C2 (Grulich 2012)
  • France: Least Concern (UICN France, FCBN and MNHN 2012)
  • Germany: Not threatened (Ludwig and Schnittler 1996)
  • Luxembourg: Least Concern (Colling 2005)
  • Portugal: protected by regional law (Decree 15/2012)
  • Spain: Vulnerable B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii); D2 (Moreno 2008)
  • United Kingdom: Least Concern but nationally rare (Cheffings and Farrell 2005) and Vulnerable (Wigginton 1999). The species was first found in Britain in 1688 on Brent Down in Somersetshire, and it still grows there at a place now known as Bream Down.
