There are only 156 known individuals which occur in probably very much fewer than 100 subpopulations; Testroet et al. (2013) report 50 subpopulations on Tenerife, although only two subpopulations on  El Hierro and a single individual on Fuerteventura. It is assumed there are fewer than 250 mature individuals altogether.

Testroet et al. (2013) found an extremely low genetic diversity within and amongst subpopulations, suggesting a largely clonal structure and populations that propagate almost exclusively vegetatively. It seems that sexual reproduction between the different populations can largely be excluded because the long distance among them, and the species is considered severely fragmented.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on all the major islands apart from Lanzarote (Lobin et al. 2005, Santos Guerra et al. 2010, Testroet et al. 2013, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is 21,718 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) has not been calculated but is likely to not exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: There is no trade in this species. The leaves of this species have been used as livestock fodder.
conservationActions: This species is listed as held in a single ex situ collection (BGCI 2016). Much of the species is contained within protected areas, however it is not thought that the protection of these areas is removing all of the threat to the species. It is suggested that fences should be erected to protect this species from grazing to allow seedling development. Removal of invasive species from certain areas would also be beneficial. This species was assessed as Vulnerable in the Spanish national Red List (Santos Guerra et al. 2010). Taking into account the low genetic diversity of this species, a single ex situ collection will not be sufficient. Cultivation for reintroduction is being undertaken on Tenerife.

rationale: This is a small tree or shrub that is endemic Gran Canaria and Tenerife in the Canary Islands. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,852 km<sup>2</sup> and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 132 km<sup>2</sup>. The population size (mature individuals) is <250, and there is suspected to be a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals as result of ongoing threats, including drought, impacts from grazing, and competition with invasive plant species. The species assessed as Critically Endangered (C2a(i)) as a result of the restricted number of mature individuals, with fewer than 50 mature individuals in each subpopulation.
habitat: This species is a shrub or small tree up to a height of 15 m. It is found on rocky escarpments with other shrubs. It is also found in forests. The seeds of this species are dispersed by birds. It can also reproduce vegetatively (Mesa Coello and Oval De La Rosa 2004) and this results in a high longevity (Mesa Coello 2010), and the plants can form clones or genets that can sometimes form significant clumps.
threats:
Mesa Coello (2010) reports that no significant threats were observed during fieldwork, however competition with native vegetation (Rubus ulmifolius) and introduced plants (Pinus radiata, Eucalyptus globulus, Ficus elastica and Anredera cordifolia) impact some subpopulations, whilst one subpopulation (Barranco de La Goleta) is potentially impacted by land use change, and a second (Bebedero) by road widening. A general potential threat are landslides. Because of the small populations and the clonal reproduction that can occur, the genetic diversity of the species is low (Mesa Coello and Oval De La Rosa 2004).

On Gran Canaria, populations have been lost or depleted as a result of livestock grazing, forest felling, drought, and landslip and subsequent road reconstruction (Á. Marrero Rodríguez pers. comm. 2017).
population:
Mesa Coello (2010) reports 32 subpopulations in total; 32 on Tenerife (where the main populations are found in Monte del Agua (Cuevas Negras-Los Cochinos-Monte del Agua) and six on Gran Canaria, and counted 253 individuals (236 on Tenerife and 17 on Gran Canaria). However the number of reproductive individuals is very much lower, and many 'juvenile plants' close to reproductive individuals are often root sprouts (genet) (Á. Marrero Rodríguez pers. comm. 2017).

Mesa Coello and Oval De La Rosa (2004) report the population trend to be declining. Mesa Coello (2010) noted that whilst the number of individuals has declined since 2003, this was considered to be the result of in changes in survey methodology, with populations in good condition on Tenerife, with almost all subpopulations containing vigorous and healthy individuals. On Gran Canaria the condition of subpopulations was considered acceptable. However there were no juveniles observed in any of the well-sampled subpopulations (but differentiating a juvenile from a young basal outbreak is difficult).

However Á. Marrero Rodríguez (pers. comm. 2017) commented that population declines as a result of continuing reduction in habitat extent and quality have been observed; on Gran Canaria, of the individuals cited by Lid (1967) in the Barranco de Guiniguada (300 m asl), none have been reconfirmed, and of the individuals mapped by Marrero et al. (1989) at least two nuclei have disappeared: the one at Las Morenas (500 m, Las Palmas de Gran Canaria) apparently as a result of felling and drought, and the second on the road from Albercon de la Virgen to Palmital (Santa Maria de Guía), as a result of landslide and subsequent cleaning of the road. The population or group of individuals at La Colmenilla (Gáldar) is significantly depleted by the pressure of goat grazing, with respect to its state when it was first inventoried.
range: This species is endemic to the Canaries archipelago, where it is restricted to Gran Canaria and Tenerife (Mesa Coello 2010), where the species exists in fragmented subpopulations in inaccessible areas. This species grows between 275 and 975 m above sea level (Mesa Coello and Oval De La Rosa 2004). Based on subpopulation data provided by Mesa Coello (2010) the estimated extent of occurrence is 2,852 km2 and the area of occupancy is 132 km2. The species has been cited for other islands (La Gomera and La Palma) within the archipelago however there are no recent records from these islands, and records probably arise from confusion with Heberdenia excelsa (Mesa Coello 2010, Á. Marrero Rodríguez pers. comm. 2017) and presence on these additional islands requires confirmation.
useTrade: This species is used ornamentally.
conservationActions: The species is listed in government legislation of 1991. Some of the populations are found within protected areas. Seed collections have been made. It is recommended that the genetic diversity of the most isolated populations is increased by population reinforcement. It would be beneficial to have samples from all the populations in a germplasm bank. This species was listed as Endangered by Bañares et al. (2004). This species is reported in three ex situ collections (BGCI 2016).

rationale: The total area of occupancy (AOO) is calculated to be 29 km². The AOO is based on presence within 1 km² grid cells overlaid on 1:40,000 scale maps. Presence and absence records are derived from recent, extensive surveys carried out between 2004 and 2009 (Elliot 2009, B. Rumeu unpublished data 2010, Sequeira pers. comm. 2010). The total population (n = ca 600) consists of five subpopulations/ locations found on five islands (Gran Canaria (n =12), Gomera (n = 100), La Palma (n = 250), Tenerife (n = 200) and Madeira (n = ca 40)). Each subpopulation/location is more than 60 km from the next and no single subpopulation contains more than 50% of the total population. These subpopulations are regarded as severely fragmented. The total population is estimated to be less than 600 mature trees and no subpopulation contains more than 250 mature individuals. Regeneration in some subpopulations is poor or absent, possibly due to reduced seed set (Rumeu et al. 2009), the decline of avian dispersers (Nogales 1999, Rumeu 2009) and the effects of grazing. In some locations fires have led to the loss of mature individuals. Together, these factors contribute to a continuing decline in the quality of  habitat and number of mature individuals. On the basis of these data, Juniperus cedrus meets the criteria for Endangered.
habitat:
Canary Islands

In the Canary Islands this species has become adapted to different habitats. In Tenerife and La Palma, J. cedrus occurs at the timberline (2,200 m), which characteristically has low precipitation and great diurnal temperature variation. Here the dominant vegetation is of shrubs Spartocytisus supranubius and Adenocarpus viscosus. In contrast, on La Gomera, which is lower in altitude, (1,150 m.) the habitat is Laurel forest which has high levels of humidity as a result of the north-east trade winds. In Gran Canaria it only occurs on Montaña del Cedro, where it grows at altitudes between 800-900 m, here the temperatures are relatively warmer. At some of the locations (La Gomera and one location on Tenerife) there is evidence of regeneration but generally recruitment appears to be relatively poor. One factor that may be related to this, is the decline in ravens (Corvus corax) that are thought to have played a significant role in seed dispersal (Nogales 1999, Rumeu et al. 2009). Recent research has revealed that winter visiting Ring Ouzels (Turdus torquatus) also play a key role in seed dispersal (Rumeu et al. 2009). Additional research has indicated that the Canary Islands subpopulations produce seed with relatively lower viability, possibly due to lower pollination rates resulting from fragmentation of stands (Rumeu et al. 2009).

Madeira

The subpopulation on Madeira occurs on exposed rock faces above the laurel forest tree-line above 1,400 m in altitude. Here it belongs to the Polysticho falcinelli-Ericetum arboreae (Capelo et al. 2004). The main components include: Erica maderinicola, Ilex perado, Laurus novocanariensis, Polystichum falcinellum, Vaccinium padifolium & Sorbus maderensis. In Madeira there have not been any studies to establish whether or not there is any regeneration, however since the removal of goats in recent years the vegetation recovery rates are very encouraging.

The current distribution pattern and the restriction to almost inaccessible sites in the Canary Islands and on Madeira reflect past human disturbance. Formerly it was more widespread.
threats:
Canary Islands

There are a variety of threats, the most severe of which is fire. In 2007 a fire on Tenerife (El Teide National Park) destroyed 30 old-growth trees. Other threats, which are detrimental to recruitment, include goats and the release of Barbary sheep (La Palma) and Muflón (Tenerife) for hunting purposes. Global warming could affect the amount of seasonal rainfall and moisture from coastal fog.

Madeira

Historically over-grazing, cutting and burning have been significant threats to the population. Although these threats are less today, the fast expansion of Cytisus scoparius following grazing is certainly a potential threat as it greatly increases the fire risks.
population:
The population is estimated to be c.600 sexually mature individuals.

Canary Islands - 572 individuals: Gran Canaria 12; La Palma 250; Tenerife 200; La Gomera 100 (Elliot 2009).

Madeira - one population with c.40 individuals (Sequeira pers. comm. 2010, unpublished data).
range: Restricted to the Canary Islands (Gran Canaria, Gomera, La Palma and Tenerife) and Madeira (from Pico Arieiro to Pico Ruivo) (Silva and Menezes 1946, Rivas-Martínez et al. 2002, Borges et al. 2008).
useTrade:
Canary Islands

Historically the wood was exploited for its valuable, aromatic timber, and used by local people in carpentry for a various items of furniture, construction and for making boxes because of the wood's capacity to deter insect pests (Vieira 2002). Today, due to its rarity and protected status, J. cedrus is not utilized.

Madeira

In Madeira the wood was also widely used. Even in the 15th century there were already concerns on the overcutting of this species. Restrictions on harvesting this species were ineffective; according to Silva and Menezes (1946) there were still some small woods of J. cedrus by the end of the 19th century, but the tree had almost vanished by the first decades of the 20th century. Today the wood is no longer used, unless it is taken from cultivated sources.

The plant is extensively cultivated as an ornamental and used by the forestry service particularly  along the Laurissilva Levadas (manmade irrigation channels and pathways).
conservationActions: Juniperus cedrus is a protected species in the Canary Islands and occurs in three National Parks; Parque Nacional del Teide, Tenerife; Parque Nacional de Garajonay, La Gomera; Parque Nacional de la Caldera de Taburiente, La Palma. The area affected by fire in Parque Nacional del Teide is being restored by using local provenance material (seed). In Gran Canaria, the subpopulation in Montaña del Cedro is included within the Reserva Natural Especial de Güigüi. This sub-population is considered as 'in danger of extinction' in the Regional Catalogue of Threatened Species (Ministerio de Medio Ambiente 2009). On Madeira it is protected within the Parque Natural da Madeira (Natura 2000) where all goats have been removed above 1,400 m under  the authority of Direcção Regional de Florestas. This has had a positive effect on the general vegetation, but as J. cedrus is a slow growing tree, any benefits are unlikely to be seen for several years.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, and because it is unlikely to be declining at a sufficient rate for listing within a threat category.
habitat: This is typically a forest species, but can also be found on hillsides, savanna, grasslands, or wasteland often near to water (Vorontsova and Knapp 2016).
threats: There are not suspected to be any substantial threats to this species.
population: It is a generally common species with overall stable populations.
range: This species is a small shrub native to Africa. It is widespread, being found throughout the highlands of western, central and eastern Africa (sometimes found as far south as South Africa) (Vorontsova and Knapp 2016). Occurs from sea level to 1,600 m asl (Vorontsova and Knapp 2016).
useTrade: This species is a tertiary genetic relative of the Brinjal Eggplant (Solanum melongena), and is the progenitor of the Gboma Eggplant (USDA 2013). Its fruits are used medicinally.
conservationActions: Populations are reported in numerous protected areas throughout the range of this species, including the Parc National de la Comoe in Cote d’Ivorie, the Parc National de Lobek in the Central African Republic, and Kibira in Burundi (GBIF 2016). This species is also subject to ex situ conservation efforts (USDA 2013), and was identified during a preliminary assessment of crop wild relatives of the Brinjal Eggplant (Solanum melongena) as a high-priority target for future ex situ conservation (USDA 2010, Syfert et al. 2016).

rationale: This species is a small tree endemic to the Canary Islands. It is assessed as Least Concern as it has a large extent of occurrence. There are some known threats, but further research is required to understand their impact, but at present they are not considered likely to be significant. The species is held in several ex situ collections and is considered an important livestock fodder crop across the world.
habitat: This species grows as an evergreen shrub or tree of between 5 and 6 m tall, normally found in open or sunny places within laurisilva forest; subspecies angustifolius and meridionalis are found within pine forest areas in understory and in openings.
threats: Fire impacts some populations, and seed may be subject to predation by insects. Introduced animals (rats, mice, rabbits, Mouflon, and Barbary sheep Ammotragus lervia) impact some populations, but further research is required.
population: This species is common and populations are stable, although some sub-populations are impacted by fire and other threats.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on all the islands except Fuerteventura and Lanzarote (Gobierno de Canarias 2017, RJB/CSIC 2017). The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is 22,005 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is found from 300 to at least 2,000 m.
useTrade: The young shoots are highly valued as a fodder in the Canary Islands, the plants being cut back annually in the same way as some willows are. The species is found in cultivation (Bean 1970). The species is extensively planted around the world for fodder.
conservationActions: Research is required into the scope and impacts of threats, especially introduced animals. This species is reported as held in 12 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016). A subspecies of this taxon was assessed as Near Threatened in 2008 (under the name Chamaecytisus proliferus subsp. meridionalis) (Bañares et al. 2008).

rationale: This is a large shrub endemic to the Canary Islands (Tenerife and La Palma). It is found at altitudes above 1,700 m, and is a dominant species in the caldera on Tenerife. The species was at risk from grazing by goats and firewood collection prior to the establishment of a national park, but has since recovered. However, grazing of rabbits and the increase of bark beetles and fungal disease are new potential threats. There are no exact population estimates of the species and further research is required to understand the population dynamics of this species. It is listed here as Least Concern.
habitat: This shrub is usually 1.5-2.5 m in height, but can reach 3 m (Kyncl et al. 2006). The flowers are white or pinkish-white and occur in late spring or early summer. It grows at high altitudes from 1,700 m above sea level, but has been found up to 3,100 m. At lower elevations it is found in pine forest; it is often dominant in the caldera where it forms a specific vegetation type (Kyncl et al. 2006). It is considered a strong competitor and its roots have a symbiotic nitrogen-fixing Rhizobium.
threats: In the past, the habitat of this species was extensively grazed by goats in summer, and there was firewood collection. However, after the national park was established in 1954, it is thought these activities ceased and the density this species increased (Kyncl et al. 2006). Increased density in the past decades might have triggered effects such as decreased survival due to density-dependence, rabbit grazing, or insect herbivory. In addition, as the collection of old branches for burning after 1981 has stopped, there has been a accumulation of dead biomass, which has contributed to an increase in damage from bark beetles (fam. Scolytidae) and related fungal diseases (Kyncl et al. 2006). Mouflon are found on Tenerife and Barbary sheep on La Palma, but the impact of these introduced species requires research.
population:
The population is said to be decreasing, in contrast to a rapid growth rate observed between 1954-1995 (Kyncl et al. 2006), however it is not clear if this is an actual decline, or the result of natural turn-over following the rapid expansion of the population that was observed following the creation of the national park (and the subsequent removal of, especially, goat grazing). 

It has been described as "very abundant on the Peak of Tenerife" (Bean 2016). Data also show that recruitment is strongly episodic (Kyncl et al. 2006) and poor. On La Palma there has been significant reintroduction planting.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found the central high mountain areas of central Tenerife (mainly Las Canadas del Teide, but does descend lower in ravines) and in the mountainous areas of La Palma. The extent of occurrence is estimated to be 1,548 km<sup>2</sup>. The area of occupancy, based on known and inferred localities is estimated to be 150 km<sup>2</sup>, and is probably less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>. On Tenerife it is found from 1,300 m to nearly 3,000 m. On La Palma it is found around the northern rim of the Caldera from 1,800 to 2,200 m. On La Palma, there has been significant reintroduction planting.
useTrade: In the past the species was used for food and bedding for livestock, and firewood. However, the exploitation was unsustainable. At present its main use is in honey production (Serra Bonvehí et al. 2004). The honey produced from the vegetation on del Teide is very light in colour and delicate and flavour. It is a unique and famous honey that is very popular on the island. The species is also found in cultivation.
conservationActions: All subpopulations are within national parks or in protected areas. A moderate decrease in the rabbit grazing pressure should be sufficient to keep the population stable (Kyncl et al. 2006). There are eight known ex situ collections of this taxon (BGCI 2017).

rationale: This species is a tree endemic to the Canary Islands and Madeira. The species occurs in several ex situ collections and protected areas. It is assessed as Least Concern in the Macaronesian region as it is widely distributed over the Canaries and there are no significant threats to the populations. More research would be needed if this species is to be classified as threatened. However populations on Fuerteventura and Madeira are small and should be protected.
habitat: This species is a tree up to 15 m (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990). A widely locally scattered species in <span class="st">thermophilous forests and submontane laurisilva.
threats: There are no recorded threats to this species, although there have been reductions to the Canary Islands populations in the past due to habitat loss and fragmentation. The small population of Fuerteventura has been reported to currently not show natural reproduction patterns (S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017). The threats on Madeira include agriculture, which in the past possibly restricted the plant to well preserved habitats.
population:
The species is rare on La Gomera and considered a relict species on Gran Canaria (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990, Suárez Rodríguez 1994). The species has been identified as common on El Hierro and rare on Fuerteventura, where five individuals are known (S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017).

The subpopulations on the Canary Islands appear to be stable, although there have been reductions in the past. The tree is rare on Madeira, with a few scattered individuals found mainly on the northwestern part of the island. The population size has been reported to be between 500 and 1,000 individuals. The species is considered stable.
range: This species is endemic to Macaronesia, where it is recorded from Madeira Island and the Canary Islands (present on all the islands except Lanzarote; Gobierno de Canarias 2017). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 544 km2 in the Canary Islands and an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of over 109,300 km2. It occurs between 150 and 1,000 m asl in the Canary Islands (Bramwell and Bramwell 1990), and from 100 and 1,000 m asl on Madeira.
useTrade: The species is used for ornamental purposes in gardening. The wood is heavy and reddish and was used in the past for inlay. The species is very rare and it is not currently used (M. Sequiera pers. comm. 2016).
conservationActions: The species occurs within the limits of several protected areas and in Natura 2000 sites both in Madeira and the Canaries, and it is covered by regional legislation. It is also found within World Heritage Sites. Monitoring of species numbers is required to find out if the species is regenerating and its current population size. This species is reported as held in 35 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016).

rationale: This species is a small tree found only in the Canary Islands and Madeira. It is here assessed as Least Concern as it has a large extent of occurrence and there are no reported significant threats to this species. The species is found in an ex situ collections and extensively in protected areas.
habitat: This species grows as an evergreen small tree up to 10-15 m tall. The species is found mainly at middle altitudes in Mediterranean laurisilva and in substitutional Erica-Myrica thickets.
threats: The seeds of this species are predated on by introduced rats post-dispersal, but it is not known what the effect of this is on the recruitment of the species (Salvande et al. 2006). The threats to this species in Madeira are invasive species, increasing the risk and intensity of fire (mainly Pittosporum and Acacia). The plant benefited from the abandonment of agriculture and has expanded into this area, however agriculture may return in the future.
population: On Madeira, the population is between 1,000 and 5,000 and is stable. On the Canaries the population is very large and assumed to be stable.
range: This species is found in both Madeira and the Canary Islands where it is found on all the islands except Lanzarote and Fuerteventura (Anthos 2016, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The estimated extent of occurrence of this species is 82,165 km<sup>2</sup>. It is found between 200 and 1,300 m asl (S. Schulz pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: The tree is sold for use in horticulture. In Madeira, it is used for Christmas decoration. It was used for inlay and furniture.
conservationActions: The Madeiran populations are found within the UNESCO World Heritage Site and in Natura 2000 sites. It was assessed as 'Lower Risk/near threatened' globally (WCMC 1998). Management of invasive populations would be beneficial for this species on Madeira. On the Canaries, most of the distribution is within natural protected areas. This species is reported as held in 15 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016).

rationale: This species is a shrub or small tree that is endemic to Madeira Island and to several islands within the Canary Islands. The species is listed as Endangered in the Spanish Red List, and although its conservation on Madeira does not seem to be cause of concern, a decline and fragmentation of its geographic range, degradation and destruction of its suitable habitat and negative population trends have been observed in the Canary Islands for this species. The species is therefore assessed as Near Threatened (B2b(ii,iii,v)) as a result of its restricted area of occupancy (AOO = 258 km<sup>2</sup>), and the observed continuing decline on the Canary islands in AOO, quality of habitat, and in the number of mature individuals.
habitat: This species develops as a shrub or small tree up to 15 m tall, depending on the area where it grows. It is a dominant species in riparian communities and common along streams and damp ravines (Press and Short 1994, Afonso et al. 2011). Negative trends affecting suitable habitat for this species have been reported in the Canaries, mainly the canalization of water courses and changes in the level of the water table.
threats: On Madeira, the species is threatened in the south of the island by the expansion of the invasive species Arundo donax. In the Canary Islands the species is threatened by habitat degradation due to the exploitation of water resources and the diversion of water from ravines, and by competition with invasive introduced plants within ravines (Afonso et al. 2011).
population: On Madeira, the species is locally abundant, with an overall population that has been estimated at over 50,000 individuals and considered to be stable. In the Canary Islands, recent surveys suggested a negative trend affecting total population size of this species, which has been estimated at 33,400 individuals (Afonso et al. 2011) in 17 main subpopulation clusters (two on La Palma, six on La Gomera, five on Tenerife, and four on Gran Canaria).
range:
This species is endemic to Macaronesia, where it is found on Madeira Island and in the Canary Islands, where it is present on all islands except the eastern islands of Lanzarote and Fuerteventura (Gobierno de Canarias 2017), however recent survey work by Afonso et al. (2011) did not find the species on El Hierro, and previous records from that island require confirmation. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species is c.78,925 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) of 258 km2 (164 km2 on Madeira and 94 km2 in the Canary Islands). The species is found from 0 to 1,400 m above sea level.

Negative trends have been identified affecting the geographic distribution of this species in the Canary Islands, however the scale of decline is uncertain as the previous survey (Mapa de Vegetación de Canarias) was based on phytosociological association vegetation maps rather than detailed survey (Afonso et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species has been traditionally used for medicinal purposes, given that its bark has properties as an analgesic (Pérez de Paz and Hernández 1999). The wood of this species has been until recent times for several purposes, including building fences, while the leaves have been reported to be used to feed cattle.
conservationActions:
This species is recorded as held in six ex situ collections (BGCI 2016). Part of the geographic range of this species in Madeira is protected within the Natural Park of Madeira, Natura 2000 and the World Heritage Site.

The species was assessed as 'Lower Risk/Least Concern' globally (World Conservation Monitoring Centre 1998), this species has been assessed as Endangered (B2ac(ii,iv)) for the Canary Islands, however the application of 'severe fragmentation' is questioned (Dirección General de Medio Natural y Política Forestal del MARM 2007) and for Spain (Moreno 2008, Bañares et al. 2010) due to its restricted and fragmented distribution and reported fluctuating populations pattern. The species is protected in the Canary Islands by regional legislation.

rationale: Cistus chinamadensis is endemic to the Canary Islands. It is listed as Endangered due to its restricted geographic range, with an area of occupancy estimated in 11 km2. It presents a fragmented distribution, having been identified as different subspecies in the three different islands where it is found. Its distribution range is thought to follow a decreasing trend. Grazing, competition with more aggressive species, landslides, fires and droughts limit the expansion of this species.
habitat:
The species presents low ecological plasticity and slow propagation dynamics. Its grows within communities of sub-humid laurel-like evergreen forests "monteverde" and "fayal-brezal".

Cistus chinamadensis ssp. chinamadensis grows on ledges of communities of "monteverde" and "fayal-brezal", mainly within shrublands which could be included in Telino-Adenocarpion foliolosi. Frequent accompanying species are Paronychia canariensis, Lavandula canariensis, Micromeria varia, Pinus canariensis, Myrica faya, Hypericum canariense, Globularia salicina, Erica arborea, Ilex canariensis, Aeonium canariensis and Carlina salicifolia.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. gomerae also occurs within scrublands of type Telino-Adenocarpion foliolosi, in ledges of communities of "monteverde" and "fayal-brezal" (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008b). It can also develop in cracks and less commonly it can progress in shady under-canopy sites. Frequent accompanying species are Chamaecytisus proliferus, Erica arborea, Cistus monspeliensis, Teline stenopetala, Andryala pinnatifida and Dicheranthus plocamoides.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. ombriosus grows in gaps within Myrica faya-Erica spp. forests, on crags and cliffs (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008a). Frequent accompanying species are Erica arborea, Greenovia diplocycla, Asplenium onopteris, Carlina salicifolia, Micromeria hyssopifolia, Tolpis proustii, Myrica faya, Sonchus hierrensis, Pericallis murrayi and Ceterach aureum.
threats:
Threats affecting this taxon are grazing, competition with native and exotic species, landslides, fires and droughts.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. chinamadensis is affected by grazing and competition with exotic species (Mesa Coello et al. 2004). The location of Monte de Aguirre is as well affected by logging activities in the area.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. gomerae is affected by competition with more aggressive native species such as Erica arborea, Cistus monspeliensis and Cytisus proliferus. It was highly affected by a fire in 1983 (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008b, Gobierno de Canarias 2009). Grazing has been also reported as a threat.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. ombriosus is not clearly affected by anthropogenic threats. Threats to this subspecies are fires, landslides, droughts and natural competition with more aggressive species (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008a).
population:
Total population size for this taxon, including the three subspecies described, is estimated in around 2,700 reproductive individuals. Recruitment has been described as slow but constant, but under competition seedlings can not progress. Population trend at a species level seems to be more or less stable, given the trends reported for the three subspecies.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. chinamadensis has a population reported to be 2,280 individuals: 2,100 individuals in Roque de los Pinos; 80 in Mesa del Brezal and 100 in Monte de Aguirre (Mesa Coello et al. 2004). In 2009 the three known locations were visited and 2,186 adult individuals and 2,025 juvenile specimen were recorded (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). Population trend for this subspecies is thought to be increasing or stable.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. gomerae has a population size reported to be 436 and 451 individuals (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008b). In 2009, 473 mature individuals and 150 juvenile specimen were recorded (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). It seems that the natural population trend is decreasing, and higher population size is due to developed re-introduction plans.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. ombriosus present a population size of 49 individuals (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008a). The only known population has been reported to be well age-structured. In 2009, 47 mature individuals are recorded, and 46 juvenile specimen (Gobierno de Canarias 2009). Population trend for the last year seems to be slightly stable.
range:
Cistus chinamadensis is a taxon endemic to the Canary Islands, Spain. Three subspecies have been described: Cistus chinamadensis subsp. chinamadensis, Cistus chinamadensis subsp. gomerae and Cistus chinamadensis subsp. ombriosus. This taxon is present in a total of seven locations and its total area of occupancy is 11 km². Its total distribution range at a species level, seems to have decreased.

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. chinamadensis is endemic to the island of Tenerife, the Canary Islands, Spain (Mesa Coello et al. 2004), where it can be found between 400 and 700 m asl, in Anaga, on the northeastern part of the island. It is present in three locations: Roque de los Pinos, Mesa del Brezal and Monte de Aguirre with an area of occupancy of 4 km2. Distribution trends for this subspecies have been described as stable or increasing (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. gomerae is endemic to the island of La Gomera, where it can be found between 1,050 and 1,300 m asl, in two natural locations: Los Roques and Roque Imada (Bañares et al. 2008, Gobierno de Canarias 2009). One more natural population, known as Lerguito, was reported in the past but it has not been found since 1996. The taxon in also present in Cherelepín, where it was successfully introduced to in 1998. It has been introduced to three more sites but the viability of these populations is not known yet. Its area of occupancy is 6 km² (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008b) and its distribution is decreasing (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. ombriosus is endemic to the island of El Hierro, where it grows at 1,250 m asl, in one single location near Valle de El Golfo (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008a). Its area of occupancy is 1 km². It is believed that its distribution range was higher in the past (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).
useTrade: No information available.
conservationActions:
This taxon is listed on Annex II of the Habitat Directive and under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is included as species with “Protección Especial” in the national list of species in regime of special protection of Spain.

Cistus chinamadensis ssp. chinamadensis is listed as EN B2ab(iii,v) in the Spanish Red List 2008 (Moreno 2008). It is included as species "de interés para los ecosistemas canarios" in the catalogue of threatened species of the Canary Islands. All the subpopulations are within the protected area Parque Rural de Anaga (SCI). Plant material from some subpopulations is stored in the germplasm banks of E.T.S. de Ingenieros Agrónomos UPM and Servicio Biodiversidad Viceconsejería de Medio Ambiente Gobierno de Canarias.

Plant material from every subpopulation should be stored in germplasm banks, reinforcement plans and herbivorous control measures should be implemented, surveillance should be improved. The area of Roque de los Pinos should be proposed as exclusion area ("Zona de Exclusión").

Cistus chinamadensis subsp. gomerae  is listed as CR B2ab(ii,v) in the Spanish Red List 2008. It is included as species "Vulnerable" in the catalogue of threatened species of the Canary Islands. The subpopulations of Los Roques and Cherelepín occur within the protected area Parque Nacional de Garajonay (SCI) and the location Roque de Imada is included in the SCI Barranco del Charco Hondo (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008b). Plant material is stored in the germplasm banks E.T.S. de Ingenieros Agrónomos and Jardín Botánico Viera y Clavijo. A recovery plan has been developed in the Parque Nacional de Garajonay, which includes population monitoring and reinforcement measures. Proposed measures in order to ensure the conservation of this taxon include seed storage in germplasm banks, the maintenance of reinforcement of natural populations actions and the introduction of new populations in suitable areas for their progress. Herbivorous control measures should be established. Cistus chinamadensis subsp. ombriosus is is listed as CR D in the Spanish Red List (Marrero Gómez et al. 2008) and as species "En peligro de extinción" in the catalogue of threatened species of the Canary Islands. The only known location is included in the protected area Parque Rural de Frontera. Plant accessions should be stored in germplasm banks, population reinforcement and introduction plans should be developed.

rationale: This species is endemic to Madeira and the Canary Islands, with historical introduction the Azores. This species is here assessed as Least Concern as it has a large extent of occurrence and populations of this species are relatively large and considered stable. The species is currently threatened by changes in water availability and fires caused by invasive species. The species is found within protected areas and in ex situ collections. On the Canaries the species is generally much more scattered and is less common, but most remaining populations are within protected areas.
habitat: The species grows as a large tree up to 25-30 m tall. It is characteristic of the mature laurisilva riparian and humid slopes vegetation above 400 m.
threats: The species is recently expanding into abandoned agricultural lands, however in the future, agricultural lands might be reclaimed and the population numbers may be affected. The increase in invasive species negatively affects the population because of competition and increased fire risk. Both ground water and surface water is being diverted away from the riparian habitats for other uses which could negatively affect this species in the future. Introduced rats eat the shoots of this plant but consumption makes the rats ill.
population: Although the extent of the stands is much reduced as a result of past exploitation of the highly valued wood, the species is still abundant in parts of Madeira and the Canaries. In Madeira, the population is thought to be around 5,000 but definitely fewer than 10,000 individuals. The population of this species is stable, although recent fires have affected southern subpopulations on Madeira and in the Canaries (La Gomera).
range: This species is considered to be a native endemic of Madeira and the Canary Islands (Tutin et al. 1995, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The species was introduced to the Azores three centuries ago. The species is found between 400 and 1,300 m above sea level. The estimated extent of occurrence is 81,400 km2.
useTrade: The species has highly valued timber and used to be harvested to make furniture. The bark was used to treat animal furs. It was used to make dye and was used for fuel and handicrafts. This species is in the same genus as the avocado and can be used as rootstock for the avocado.
conservationActions: The species was considered Least Concern/conservation dependent by Oldfield et al. in 1998. It is included in the Natural Park of Madeira, Natura 2000 and partially in the World Heritage Site. On the Canaries, the species occurs within numerous protected areas. The species is found in 47 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016).

rationale: This is a small shrub endemic to the Canary Islands and naturalised on the Selvagens. The species is widespread and found on most of the Canary Islands. Although the population size are not known, and some populations are highly impacted by a range of coastal threats, especially agricultural development and urbanisation, the species is considered Least Concern at present as populations can be large and are widespread.
habitat: This is a halophytic shrub up to c.1 m tall. It is found up to 300 m in rocky areas, as well as on hillsides and sandy soils of coastal areas, being part of coastal communities. It is found in "Desertic nitrophilous scrub (Launaeo arborescens and Schizogyne sericea communities, etc.)" (del Arco Aguilar et al. 2010).
threats: The species is impacted by slow transformation of coastal areas arising from urbanisation and the development of greenhouse cultivation.
population: There are thousands of individuals on the Selvagens, whilst on the Canaries, the species is very common in disturbed semi-arid/desertic coastal areas.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (native to Gran Canaria, La Gomera, El Hierro, La Palma, Tenerife, introduced and naturalised on Lanzarote(?) and Fuerteventura; Euro+Med 2016, Gobierno de Canarias 2017) and the Selvagens Islands (Portugal). It is found in "Desertic nitrophilous scrub (Launaeo arborescens and Schizogyne sericea communities, etc.)" which covers 18,631 ha in the Canary Islands (del Arco Aguilar et al. 2010). A more or less strictly coastal species, from sea level to 100(250-300) m asl.
useTrade: The species is sometimes used as an ornamental plant. It is also used for medicines traditionally, as analgesic, astringent, anti-inflammatory and vulnerary (Venditti et al. 2016).
conservationActions: Some populations occur within protected areas. There are 11 known ex situ collections in botanic gardens (BGCI 2016).

rationale: This species is a large shrub or tree found on the Canary Islands and on Madeira. The primary threat on Madeira are invasive species, however these are not currently causing significant declines. On the Canaries (subsp. canariensis), the population size is very much smaller than on Madeira and is undergoing a decline; it is impacted there by a range of threats and has poor recruitment and is subject to conservation actions, and is considered threatened there. The species is listed as Least Concern globally as the extent of occurrence is large and there are large and stable populations on Madeira, however the subsp. canariensis is of significant conservation concern in Spain.
habitat:
This species is a shrub or small tree up to 15 m found in clearings and openings within laurisilva forest. It is restricted to areas whether other trees are not found such as ravines and disturbed areas on Madeira. On the Canaries it is found rather in remnant forest, but in more open areas.

It can not survive well in enclosed canopy forest and is impacted by forest succession and closure.
threats: On Madeira, this species is impacted by invasive plants, with Cytisus scoparius and Acacia outcompeting the species within new clearings. On the Canaries, there has been management interventions to maintain open canopy within laurisilva forest. Landslides (e.g., on La Palma and Gomera) the species has been impacted by land and rock slides on steep terrain, and by strong wind. Seed and seedling predation by mice have reduced recruitment.
population:
The population on Madeira is stable and definitely contains over 1,000 individuals. It is difficult to survey for on Madeira because the species grows in ravines.

On the Canaries, there were significant historical declines as a result of habitat conversion. Whilst the species is now well protected on the Canaries, the population is still declining and there is very poor recruitment. On the Canaries (2013-2014) there were 17 individuals on Tenerife, 96 La Palma, and 17 on Gomera (Programa de Seguimiento de Especies Amenazada (SEGA), Gobierno de Canarias (2013)).
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (La Palma, Gomera and Tenerife) (Gobierno de Canarias 2017) and Madeira. The extent of occurrence of this species is 52,534 km<sup>2</sup>. The species occurs from 400 to 1,100 m above sea level, but this varies between the islands.
useTrade: This species is popular in horticulture in England and perhaps elsewhere, from cultivated sources. It has no uses in Madeira.
conservationActions:
The species is found in 46 ex situ collections in botanic gardens worldwide (BGCI 2016). It was listed as 'Rare' in 1997 (Walter and Gillett 1998). It is found within the Madeira National Park, Natura 2000 sites and the World Heritage Site on the island.

On the Canaries, the species has been subject to conservation management and reintroduction and has been assessed as 'en peligro de extinción' (Endangered) (Comunidad Autónoma de Canarias 2010, Gobierno de Canarias 2013), and was assessed as Critically Endangered (Marrero Gómez et al. 2004) for Spain. A range of research and conservation actions have been proposed for populations on the Canaries (subsp. canariensis) (Gobierno de Canarias 2013), including survey and monitoring, seed collection and reintroduction, invasive species control, and habitat conservation.

rationale: This species is a shrub found in the Canary Islands and Madeira. It is widely distributed across the largest of the Canary Islands and Madeira. Although it is affected by the presence of invasive species in Madeira and it is rare and threatened by grazing in Gran Canaria and El Hierro, these are not identified as significant enough to threat the persistence of the populations of the species at an European level. The species is thus assessed Least Concern.
habitat: This is a shrub up to 2 m tall found on hillsides and cliffs among rocks and on rough grassland. It is also found in open spaces, like clearings, ravines and forest edges. It is an element of secondary succession in forests and can be found colonizing abandoned croplands. These are typical habitats on the islands where the species is abundant.
threats:
The main threat to this species in Madeira in the past was agriculture, as its expansion reduced the suitable habitat. Agricultural lands have since been abandoned and the range of the species has expanded. However, agriculture may expand in the future. Invasive species such as Acacia and Arundo are colonising areas before Globularia spp. can establish. These invasive species also increase the risk of fires.

In the Canary Islands, agriculture was also a major threat in the past in La Gomera, La Palma and Tenerife. In El Hierro and Gran Canaria the impact of livestock farming was significant in the past, and it is still a threat to the populations of these species.
population: There is limited information on population size and trends. The species has been described as common and abundant in areas of Madeira and Tenerife, La Palma and La Gomera, and identified as rare on Gran Canaria and extremely rare on El Hierro. In the western Canaries, the population trend is thought to be stable. On Madeira, the population is thought to include over 50,000 individuals and the population trend is stable.
range: This species is endemic to the Macaronesian region, where it is found on the Canary Islands (Gran Canaria, La Gomera, El Hierro, La Palma, Tenerife; Gobierno de Canarias 2017) and Madeira (Desertas, Madeira, Porto Santo) (Marhold 2011). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated in above 99,000 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at 432 km2. The species is found from 20 up to 850 m asl.
useTrade: It can be grown as an ornamental species, mainly in the framework of environmental education programs.
conservationActions:
This species occurs within Natura 2000 sites and several other protected areas such as the Madeira Natural Park in Madeira and the Reserva Natural Especial de Guelguén in the Canaries. It has been reported to be found in 21 ex situ collections in botanic gardens (BGCI 2016). 

Conservation actions should be implemented in the areas where the species can be identified as locally poorly represented, such as population reinforcement, monitoring and control of current threats in the locations of Gran Canaria and El Hierro.

rationale:
This species is endemic to La Gomera in the Canary Islands. The population is confined to three very small areas (sub-populations). The most recent survey data (Soto Medina 2007) estimated a total number of individuals of 584 (of which c.50% reintroduced and are assumed here to be reproducing), all of which were adult plants. The population trend is uncertain, although one subpopulation has been lost in recent years). The number of mature individuals undergoes extreme fluctuations from year to year, depending on conditions. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is measured at 12 km2, but is increased to 24 km2 to equal the AOO; the actual area of occupancy is <0.1 km2.

The species is assessed as Critically Endangered (CR B1b(iii)c(iv)) on the basis of its restricted extent of occurrence, decline in habitat quality, and the extreme fluctuation in populations.
habitat: This large shrub grows in thicket dominated by various legume species. The species colonises soil ledges, enclaves or overhangs within cliffs or steep slopes, within the area of laurisilva forest habitat.
threats: This species is threatened by trampling and grazing pressures from domestic livestock (goats) (Soto Medina 2007), especially during the juvenile phase. Pressure from alien species is another threat. In addition hybridization with Echium aculeatum and E. strictum has been observed.
population:
There are three confirmed native subpopulations: El Rejo (145 individuals), Agando (300 individuals), and Encherada (65 individuals) (Bañares et al. 2004); recent surveys have revised these numbers: El Rejo (78 individuals, some the result of reinforcement planting), Agando (447 individuals; probably the result of reinforcement planting and improved survey effort), and Encherada (59 individuals) (Soto Medina 2007). The disappearance of some small subpopulations was observed prior to 2006 (Marrero Gómez et al. 2006). The most recent survey (Soto Medina 2007) estimated a total number of individuals of 584 (of which c.50% reintroduced), all of which were adult plants; it is assumed here that the reintroduced individuals are mature and reproducing, and so are included in the estimate of 584 mature individuals.

This is a short-lived perennial species (c.15 years) and when environmental conditions are suitable (e.g., post-fire, or long drought followed by rain), the number of seedlings and, to a lesser extent, the plants, increases explosively (Marrero-Gómez et al. 2000, Bañares et al. 2004). As a result, it is difficult to infer population trends.
range:
This species is endemic to La Gomera in the Canary Islands, with three natural isolated subpopulations (Los Roques, El Rejo and Enchereda) known from the central sector of the island (Bañares 1990, Bañares et al. 2001, Carqué Álamo et al. 2003, Gobierno de Canarias 2013). In the last 15 years, the disappearance of some small subpopulations has been observed. A recovery plan has been put in place for the species, and within this framework, the subpopulations at Los Roques and El Rejo have been subject to reinforcement planting, and translocated populations have been established at four localities (Degollada Blanca, Lajugal, Bailadero-Ilala, and La Carbonera; Gobierno de Canarias 2013).

The area of occupancy (AOO) is 24 km2. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is measured at 12 km2, but is increased to 24 km2 to equal the AOO. According to Bañares et al. (2004), the actual area of occupancy is <0.1 km2.
useTrade: There is some ornamental use of this species.
conservationActions: The species is found in the Garajonay National Park (the population of El Rejo is located entirely within the park, with a small part of another subpopulation also within the park) and in the Majona Natural Park. The species is also included in a Site of Community Interest (SCI). Seeds are stored in various seedbanks. A recovery plan has been put in place for the species. and within this framework, the subpopulations with a new population established and the reinforcement of existing natural populations.

rationale: This shrub is endemic to Tenerife, Canary Islands. It has a restricted extent of occurrence of 645 km<sup>2</sup>. It is thought to be found in small subpopulations, although population numbers are not known. The threats are not fully understood for this species, however habitat loss and habitat shifts as a result of climate change are expected to impact the species in the future. The species is considered to be severely fragmented as whilst there are many localities there is little connectivity, with subpopulations isolated on cliffs of south- and west-facing ravines, and in the Cañadas del Teide, the species is normally found as single individuals or in small numbers. The species is assessed as Near Threatened (NT B1a) as a result of its restricted EOO and severe fragmentation, although at present populations and habitats are stable.
habitat: Rhamnus integrifolia is a shrub up to 1 m tall. The species occupies a wide altitudinal range in dry woodland and scrub.
threats: The species, due to its small population size, has been highlighted as being at risk from rising temperatures due to climate change (Petit and Prudent 2010; Heywood 2011, 2012). In many cases it grows as a rupicoline species, so the instability of the habitat is a threat to take into account.
population: This species is distributed across large parts of the island of Tenerife (south- and west-facing), although almost always represented by populations of few individuals, as refugees in escarpments and inaccessible areas (Pérez de Paz et al. 1992). The species is considered to be severely fragmented; there are many localities but without spatial continuity. Subpopulations are isolated on cliffs of south- and west-facing ravines, and in Cañadas del Teide normally one to a few individuals are found.
range: This species is endemic to Canary Islands, where it is restricted to Tenerife (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The extent of occurrence is c.645 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: No use or trade is known.
conservationActions: This species is found in a single known ex situ collection in botanic gardens (BGCI 2017). It was listed as Near Threatened in the Lista Roja of 2008 (Moreno 2008) and 2010 (Bañares et al. 2010), and as Vulnerable (VU D2) on the IUCN Red List (Bañares et al. 1998), although under a previous version of the criteria. The species occurs in protected areas, including the Parque Nacional del Teide (ES7020043), and the Natura 2000 sites of Barranco del Infierno (ES7020051), Teno (ES7020096), Barranco de Erques (ES7020070), Barranco de Fasnia y Guimar (ES7020055), etc. This species is included in the Annex II of the regional Order of February, 20th 1991 about the protection of the wild vascular flora of the Canary Islands Autonomous Community.

rationale: This species is a large shrub that is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on all of the islands, although found as relict populations on Lanzarote, Fuerteventura and Gran Canaria. It has an extent of occurrence of over 48,000 km<sup>2</sup>, however the area of occupancy is likely to be restricted. It occurs in dry Mediterranean scrublands, where it sometimes dominates. There are threats to some subpopulations, and on the eastern three islands the species is found only in areas inaccessible to herbivores. Whilst the population size and trends are not known, the extent of occurrence is moderately large and the species occurs on several islands, and the population as a whole is considered Least Concern, although conservation actions are required for the populations on the eastern islands.
habitat: This species is a large shrub, about 2 m tall. It is found growing in dry Mediterranean scrubland.
threats: Housing developments, grazing and invasive plants all pose threats to the remaining populations (Bañares et al. 1998), however the most significant threat is herbivory, and on Lanzarote, Fuerteventura and Gran Canaria the species is found only in areas that are inaccessible to herbivores.
population: The species is distributed fairly abundantly, it dominates certain habitats (Rodríguez et al. 2008) on Tenerife and La Palma. The species is more localised on La Gomera, and rare in El Hierro, and on Lanzarote, Fuerteventura and Gran Canaria it is considered a relict species.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it grows on all islands (Henning and Raab-Straube 2016, Gobierno de Canarias 2017); Tenerife, La Palma, La Gomera, El Hierro, and Fuerteventura. The species occurs as relict populations only on Lanzarote, Fuerteventura and Gran Canaria. It was considered extinct on Gran Canaria, but refound in the midlands of the northern slopes of the island, from Guia to Tafira. The species was reported as not present in Lanzarote (Pérez de Paz et al. 1992) but does occur in the north of the island in the Riscos de Famara. The extent of occurrence measures 48,626 km2. The area of occupancy has not been accurately estimated as comprehensive point data are not available, but is likely to range between 192 km2 (GBIF data) and 2,000 km2.
useTrade: No information available.
conservationActions: The species is listed in government legislation of 1991. There are nine known ex situ collections in botanic gardens worldwide (BGCI 2017).

rationale: This is a shrub endemic to the Canary Islands. It is considered common in its characteristic Tabaibal-Cardonal communities habitat, and there are potential threats to the species, they are not considered to be significant across the distribution of the species. Although more information on the population size and trends would be desirable, the species is listed here as Least Concern.
habitat: The species is a shrub that grows up to 1.5 m tall with yellow flowers. It is found within Tabaibal-cardonal community, a very mixed vegetable formation of the lowland and coastal areas of the Canary Islands where shrubby bushes predominate, with stony soils and low organic matter. It is pollinated by small solitary bees, ants and introduced honey bees; seeds are dispersed by lizards (Rigueiro et al. 2009).
threats: The lowland and coastal habitat of this species is likely to be impacted by coastal developments, including urbanisation and agricultural development.
population: The species is very common locally, being at times an abundant element in the communicates where it is present. Thus, no population estimates have been calculated for this species. Although a decline in population could have been identified in the past, the species populations are thought to be currently stable or even increasing.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found in lower areas of Gran Canaria, Tenerife, La Gomera, and possibly extinct, from El Hierro (Rigueiro et al. 2009). Although it has been also reported from El Hierro and La Palma, its presence in these islands is uncertain (Stierstorfer 2005, Á. Marrero Rodríguez pers. comm. 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) has been estimated in around 8,160 km2. It is a locally abundant species, and its area of occupancy (AOO) has been estimated at up to 1,000 km2.
useTrade: The species has medicinal uses (Pérez de Paz and Hernández 1999) and has been associated with mummification practices carried out by the indigenous population of the islands.
conservationActions: There are 14 known ex situ collections of Cneorum pulveruentum (also stored under the synonym Neochamaelea pulverulenta). No conservation action is identified as needed.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (extent of occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend appears to be increasing, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size is extremely large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.

This species is endemic to the Madeira and Canary Islands. The species is found on all the Canary Islands, where it is more common on the central islands of Tenerife and Gran Canaria and can be frequent in suitable habitat. There are no major threats. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a shrub that reaches one meter in height. It is found in ravines and rocky areas, usually within forested areas (Febles Hernández 1984).
threats: Although the species is likely to have been impacted by past forest loss on the islands, populations are now probably stable.
population: Febles Hernández (1984) described the species as 'frequent' in ravines of forested areas on the Canaries.
range: This species is endemic to the Madeira and Canary Islands (Greuter 2006-2009). In the Canaries, the species is common on the central islands of Tenerife and Gran Canaria (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). In Madeira, it is present on all three main islands. The extent of occurrence exceeds 160,000 km<sup>2</sup>. On the Canaries, the species is found between 200 and 1,300 m asl (Febles Hernández 1984).
useTrade: There is no information available on the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There is no conservation action required.

rationale: Plantago arborescens is a small shrub endemic to Madeira and central and western Canary Islands. There is little information about the population size or trends, and the threats to this species are not understood, and as a result it is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is s a shrub that grow up to 60 cm tall. It is found in open rocky habitats, usually without soils, often on, or at the foot of cliffs.
threats: Grazing by rabbits and goats is a probable threat to this species, but there is no information available.
population: There is no information on the population size or trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Madeira Archipelago and the western and central Canary Islands (Euro+Med 2017). Former records from Lanzarote are considered a separate species, P. famarae.
useTrade: No use of the species is known.
conservationActions: Research is required to confirm the distribution, population size and trends, and threats to this species. There are several ex situ collections in botanic gardens worldwide (BGCI 2017).

rationale: This is a large evergreen shrub found on three islands of the Canary Islands. Although its habitat, the laurisilva forest, has undergone a severe decline in the past, certain recovery trends are being currently identified in some areas. However, on La Palma the species is under high pressure due to the impact of introduced herbivores, while positive prospects identified on Gran Canaria may reverse if agricultural activities re-gain importance. The species is therefore assessed as Near Threatened (NT B1b(iii)+2b(iii)). The species is close to qualifying as Least Concern, however this would be conditional on the implementation and success of herbivore control on La Palma, and the continuation of the favourable trends in Gran Canaria.
habitat: This is an evergreen shrub that can reach up to 3-4 m in height. It is found within humid evergreen forests referred to as laurisilva. Since it grows best in sunlight, it can be found along roads, cliffs and canopy openings (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011).
threats: Although the regression of laurisilva forest was likely to have negatively affected this species, current threats to the species include browsing by the herbivorous species Arruí (Barbary sheep; Ammotragus lervia) on the island of La Palma, where it was introduced for hunting.
population: There is little information concerning the population size of this species. It is likely that the reduction of the laurisilva forest caused by its past exploitation negatively affected the populations this species. Currently, the laurisilva forest covers only 12.5% of its potential area (Fernández-Palacios 2009). However, in Gran Canaria and locally in other islands, certain recovery patterns can be identified due to the abandonment of farming activities. Although actual number of individuals is uncertain, prospects for the species are positive and the species is frequently identified as locally abundant across its populations.
range: This species is considered to be endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on the islands of La Palma, Tenerife and Gran Canaria (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). In the 19th century the species was reported to be present in Madeira, but this record referred to a cultivated specimen (Press and Short 1994). It occurs from 500 to 1,500 m above sea level (Tosco 2017). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of wild populations has been estimated to exceed 9,600 km2. Its area of occupancy (AOO) has been estimated to be c.335 km2.
useTrade: This species is used in reforestation and land restoration programmes and as an ornamental plant.
conservationActions:
Bencomia caudata is present in several protected areas. According to BGCI (2017), there are 27 ex situ collections including this species worldwide. The taxon was assessed as Near Threatened (NT) in Spain (Moreno 2008, Bañares et al. 2010).

Conservation actions needed would include the implementation of control measures on herbivorous predators. Further research on population status would be also desirable.

rationale: This species is a large shrub found on three of the Canary Islands. It has a restricted extent of occurrence (EOO) of 6,987 km<sup>2</sup> and an area of occupancy of c.156 km<sup>2</sup>, with severely fragmented populations within thermophilous forest communities. The habitat of the species underwent historical declines in extent and quality as a result of deforestation, and whilst that threat has now ceased, the habitat and the species itself is still impacted by herbivore grazing, and the species tends to be restricted to inaccessible sites out of the reach of herbivores. This taxon is thus assessed as Endangered (EN B2ab(iii)). Monitoring of current populations and further research to clarify population size and trends is required, and control of herbivores is recommended to allow populations to expand into suitable habitat.
habitat: This is a small tree or shrub with a height of up to 4 m. Its wild populations are present in thermophilous forest communities, in sun-exposed slopes and cliffs with shallow soils (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011).
threats: The major threat to populations of this species has been the conversion of thermophilous forests to land for farming (WWF 2017), which resulted in the loss of area and biodiversity in this ecosystem (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008). Grazing by herbivores is still causing negative impact to accessible individuals of this species.
population: It is likely that the past reduction in area and quality of the thermophilous forest has negatively affected populations of this species. The total population size has been estimated to be less than 1,000 individuals, however, the population is thought to be relatively stable, although in areas out of reach of herbivores. Grazing constrains the recovery of the species, causing damage and mortality of accessible individuals.
range:
This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found in the islands of Gran Canaria, Tenerife and La Gomera (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of the wild populations of the species is approximately 6,987 km2 (GBIF 2017, Gobierno de Canarias 2017). Its area of occupancy (AOO) has been estimated at 156 km2 and the populations are thought to be fragmented, distributed in marginal sites out of the reach of herbivores.

The species occurs from 200 to 800 m above sea level (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011), and even up to 850 m a.s.l.
useTrade: This species is highly regarded as an ornamental plant given its aesthetic appearance, and as a local medicinal plant given its astringent qualities. It is also used in restoration projects of degraded thermophilous forests in the Canaries (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011). The species has certain commercial value, in the framework of its use as ornamental in gardening.
conservationActions:
This species is present in several protected areas in the Canary Islands (Protected Planet 2017). The species is present in ex situ collections, including botanical gardens and seedbanks, and occurs in at least one protected area (the NATURA 2000 site, Cuenca de Benchijigua-Guarimiar - ES7020107). In 2008, the species was listed as Vulnerable (D2) in the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008, Bañares et al. 2010).

Conservation actions to be implemented include monitoring of current populations, further research to clarify population size and trends, and the control of herbivores.

rationale: This species is a shrub or small tree that is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it can be frequently found across its range. Its habitat is mainly xerophytic scrubs over coastal areas and mid-altitude slopes. Although suitable habitat for this species has been negatively affected by urban development, invasive species and other impacts, the situation has not reached a point where the conservation status of this species is threatened. The species is thus assessed as Least Concern. The introduction and rapid spread of the exotic species Acacia farnesiana could become a factor to be considered in the future. Confirmation of its current presence and distribution on some of the islands is required.
habitat:
This is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 4 to 5 m in height. It is found in xerophytic scrubs in coastal areas, in cliffs and hill slopes with rocky soils and plenty of sun exposure, and along the margins and channels of ravines (Kunkel 1981). Although suitable habitat for this species has been negatively affected by urban development, the situation has not reach a point where the conservation status of this species is threatened.

The fruit of this species is an important part of the summer diet of birds and reptiles such as sylviid warblers (Sylvia spp.) and lacertid lizards (Gallotia spp.) (Valido and Nogales, cited by Dennis et al. 2007), which act as seed dispersers. Invasive species are also related to P. pendula. In Tenerife by the European rabbit (Oryctogalus cuniculus) (Nogales et al. 1995, 1996); and in all of the islands by the feral cat (Felis catus) (Nogales et al. 1996).
threats: This species is impacted by the rapid spread of Acacia farnesiana, an introduced shrub originally from the North and Central American tropics (Arévalo et al. 2010), and by goat (Capra hircus) grazing (Fernández-Lugo et al. 2013). Its populations have also been affected by urban development.
population: There is little information regarding the population of this species although it is considered abundant throughout its distribution and the trend is assumed to be stable.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, where it is found on all the islands except Lanzarote (Gobierno de Canarias 2017), although its presence in El Hierro and La Palma requires confirmation. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of the wild populations of the species is estimated to be about 39,046 km2 , including El Hierro and La Palma (Gobierno de Canarias 2017) and the area of occupancy (AOO) has been calculated to be close to 1,700 km2 (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). It occurs from 50 to 500 m above sea level (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011), and even up to 700 m a.s.l.
useTrade: Given its resistance to drought, this species can be used in the re-vegetation of lower and dryer regions of the Canary Islands (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011). It has been traditionally used as a natural colouring element (Pérez de Paz and Hernández Padrón 1999).
conservationActions: Some of the known locations are found in protected areas in the Canary Islands (Protected Planet 2017). According to BGCI (2017) there are no ex situ collections of this species in botanic gardens worldwide. No other conservation actions needed have been identified.

rationale: This large shrub is endemic to the Canary Islands. It grows in coastal scrubs and thermophyllous forests, and has been exploited in the past for its aromatic oil. The species has also been impacted by the decline of the thermophyllous forest habitat, and although it is still affected by grazing in part of its distribution, no significant threats are identified for this species. It is relatively widely distributed and although there is no information on the full population size, population trend is thought to be stable, and the species is considered Least Concern.
habitat: This is a woody shrub that can reach 2 to 4 m in height. It is found in coastal scrubs and thermophilous forests, participating in transition communities between these ecosystems (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008). It can also be found in sunny cliffs and slopes, along with Euphorbia spp. communities (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011).
threats:
The largest threat faced by populations of this species is the conversion of thermophyllous forests to land for agriculture (WWF 2017), which resulted in the loss of area and biodiversity of this ecosystem, which has been reported to cover only 17.3% of its potential area (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008). Because of the aromatic oil that can be obtained from the branches and roots, this species was heavily exploited in the 19th century for international trade, which led to the rapid decline of its wild populations (D.M. 1989).

Gangoso et al. (2006) identified goat (Capra hircus) overpopulation and grazing as threats to populations on Lanzarote. On Fuerteventura, grazing has led to a restricted distribution of the species in non-accessible locations. In the rest of its distribution, because population size is larger and presence of palatable species is broader, grazing pressure is currently not as significant as in the eastern islands.
population:
Populations are present on all the Canary Islands, however populations on El Hierro, Lanzarote and Fuerteventura are restricted. On Fuerteventura the population size has been estimated at 50 individuals growing on abrupt slopes (Gangosos et al. 2006), and it is believed to be slightly lower (S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017).

Although there is no detailed population information from the other islands, population size is thought to be stable, after certain increasing trends in recent times due to the abandonment of former livestock related activities.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Gobierno de Canarias 2017), where it is found on all the islands, however, it is rare in Lanzarote, Fuerteventura and El Hierro. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of the wild populations has been estimated to be approximately 47,318 km<sup>2</sup> and the area of occupancy (AOO) at 837 km<sup>2</sup>. Its presence has been reported from 50 to 900 m above sea level.
useTrade: This species is often planted in gardens in the Canary Islands. A fragrant oil known as Rhodium oil or Rosewood can be obtained from its branches and roots (Wood et al. 2015). The species has been used as a component in environmental restoration programs (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011).
conservationActions: Some of the known locations of this species are found in protected areas (Protected Planet 2017). The species is present in several ex situ collections, including both seed-banks and botanical gardens. Control of goat grazing is recommended.

rationale: This species is a large shrub found on six of the Canary Islands. Its extent of occurrence is 24,835 km<sup>2</sup>. Its habitat is mainly the thermo-sclerophyllous forest that has undergone a severe decline in the past. Whilst populations are likely to have undergone a decline as a result of habitat loss, they are now thought to be more or less stable, and the species is considered Least Concern.
habitat: This is a shrub that grows up to 3 m tall. It is found in dense thickets of evergreen sclerophyll shrubs and abundantly in thermo-sclerophyllous forests (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008, del Arco et al. 2006, 2010). It can develop hanging branches of over 4 m in slopes exposed to high levels of sunlight and humidity. The species produces fruit which is consumed by birds, which favours its dispersal (Dirección General de Protección de la Naturaleza 2011).
threats: The largest threat that populations of Bosea yervamora face is the conversion of thermophilic forests to land for agriculture (WWF 2017), which previously has already resulted in the loss of area and biodiversity in this ecosystem (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008). However much of the conversion took place in the past, with most populations now occurring in less-impacted areas. Bosea yervamora is highly susceptible to goat (Capra hircus) grazing, especially on the island of Fuerteventura (Gangoso et al. 2006), however the remaining known individuals are inaccessible to goats.
population: There is no specific information on populations. Nonetheless, it is likely that the reduction of the thermophilic forest has negatively affected populations of this species in the past. As of 2006, the thermophilic forest covered only 17.3% of its potential area (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008).
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands (Gobierno de Canarias 2017), where it is present in La Palma, El Hierro, La Gomera, Tenerife, Gran Canaria and southern Fuerteventura (two individuals) (Fernández-Palacios et al. 2008). Based on the distribution of herbarium specimens, the extent of occurrence (EOO) of the wild populations is approximately 24,835 km2 (GBIF 2017).
