In the Jandía Mountains on Fuerteventura, the population size is estimated to be 1,500-3,000 plants, however, no precise survey has been undertaken. There is a small contact zone and a putative hybrid plant has been observed and photographed from some distance some years ago. Both species are known to hybridise in cultivation.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands where it is found on Gran Canaria (subspecies decaisnei), Lanzarote and Fuerteventura (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). Subspecies purpuriense is restricted to Lanzarote and Fuerteventura, with the nominal subspecies only occurring on these islands in cultivation (or originating from cultivation) (S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017). Subspecies purpuriense is now restricted to mountains influenced by the cloud of the trade winds: the Famara Mountains on Lanzarote and the Jandía Mountains on Fuerteventura, with a third small subpopulation (12-15 plants) on cliffs between 450 and 650 m height in Montaña Cardones, a large solitary mountain situated 5-6 km to the north of the Jandía Peninsula on Fuerteventura (S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017). The species is found between 300 and 1,500 m asl. The estimated extent of occurrence is 12,705 km2, and the area of occupancy is estimated at 196-250 km2.
useTrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: The species (and both subspecies) are legally protected on all islands (Gobierno de Canarias 2017). This species occurs in several protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2017), including (subsp. purpuriense), the Monumento Natural de Montaña Cardones, and the Parc Natural del Archipiélago Chinijo. The subsp. purpuriense is cultivated in nurseries of the Insular Cabildos and in the Botanic Garden Viera and Clavijo, and seed held in genebanks (Bañares et al. 2004). The subspecies purpuriense has been assessed as Endangered (Jaén Molina et al. 2006, Bañares et al. 2008). This species is reported as held in 18 ex situ collections (BGCI 2017).

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (Extent of Occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend appears to be increasing, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size is extremely large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: The species is a habitat generalist, breeding throughout forested and  open coastal, steppe, mountain, tundra and cliff regions of the Northern  Hemisphere. It generally occupies more open habitat in the south and  north portions of range where cliffs, sparse trees and human structures provide nest  locations. In middle latitudes it is generally found in coniferous and  broadleaf forests, where tree-nesting often more common than  cliff-nesting. It is abundant in temperate (coniferous) rainforest along the north Pacific coast of North America. It generally avoids large cities but is abundant in Anchorage, Alaska and locally abundant in California metropolitan areas (Marzluff 2009). Egg-laying begins in late February  over most of its range, although further north in Greenland and Siberia  it begins later in April (Madge and Burn 1993). The nest is a large and  bulky platform, made from dead sticks, lined with fine roots, grass,  string and other bits of rubbish, and with mammal fur to make an inner  cup. It is placed in the stout, lower branches of a tree, on a steep  cliff, or on an artificial structure such as a utility pole, building,  sign, radio tower, abandoned vehicle, oil derrick, bridge, irrigation  pipe or windmill. Clutch size is typically four to six eggs. It is an  opportunistic scavenger, consuming a huge variety of animals and plants.  It preys on adult and nestling birds, eggs, small mammals, sick and  dying larger mammals, toads, snakes, juvenile turtles, fish and  invertebrates. It also scavenges garbage and slaughterhouse offal, dung,  and nearly any kind of carrion and some plant matter is also consumed  (Marzluff 2009). The species is mostly sedentary but northern  populations are liable to move south in winter (Hagemeijer and Blair  1997).
threats: From mid-1600s to mid-1900s or later this species was widely persecuted  due to fear and superstition, resulting in European populations being  reduced, often to point of creating gaps in the species's distribution  (e.g. throughout much northern and central Europe). Persecution still  continues in Iceland and Greenland but throughout the rest of Europe it  is much reduced, allowing the species to recolonize areas it was  previously extirpated from. Increasing populations of this species in much of western U.S.A. have led to conflict and targeted killing campaigns with large numbers shot and poisoned in California, Oregon, Utah and Nevada with limited and short-term benefits to crops and other wildlife (Marzluff 2009). Currently, intensive  farming, the removal of woodland and human disturbance may also affect the  species (Hagemeijer and Blair 1997).
population: The global population is estimated to number > c.16,000,000 individuals (Rich et al. 2004). The European population is estimated at 611,000-1,160,000 pairs, which equates to 1,220,000-2,320,000 mature individuals (BirdLife International 2015).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
Active reintroduction efforts and increased subsidization, have aided its return to parts of Germany, the Netherlands, south-east U.S.A. (Marzluff 2009) and the Czech Republic (Hagemeijer and Blair 1997).


Conservation Actions Proposed
Although this species is not threatened the continuation in fall of persecution and the preservation of woodland stands within the landscape would help this species recover from past declines. Encourage land managers in North America to adopt non-lethal methods of deterring ravens from agricultural areas, rubbish dumps and other sites (Marzluff 2009).

rationale: Genista benehoavensis has been object of a recovery plan since 1988, when it was severely endangered, and its population has increased since. Regressive patterns in its habitat are being controlled through establishment of fences against herbivores, but degradation and predation occur as soon as the fencing is destroyed or predators manage to get in the fenced area. Although its total area of occupancy is 28 km², the species appears scattered and distributed into many small populations nuclei and the increasing population trends and current relatively wide distribution of the species could not occur without human intervention. Furthermore, due to the proximity of the scattered subpopulations, an impact on the distribution of the species, such as a fire, could destroy a huge amount of specimens. Therefore, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat:
This large shrub is characteristic of the northern edges of La Caldera de Taburiente, appearing associated to high mountain communities Telino benehoavensis-Adenocarpetum spartioidis (Carqué Álamo et al. 2004). It prefers sunny sites, with low slope, within communities dominated by Adenocarpus viscosus var. spartioides. It can also be found in steep slopes, along with rupicolous species as Tolpis calderae and Greenovia diplocycla.

It is a hermaphrodite species. Only 28% of the seeds reach maturity and present appropriate fertility.
threats: Predation by goats, rabbits and the introduced game species Ammotragus lervia, has been described as the main threat to this species in the past (Carqué Álamo et al. 2004). This impact has been reported to be currently moderately controlled by the establishment of fences. Other threats are natural competition, fires, strong winds and erosion.
population:
Its populations are relatively well structured. Proportion of young individuals exceeds 50%.

In 1999, 363 individuals were recorded. Due to the establishment of fences and reinforcement measures, the population size experienced a rapid increase, and in 2004, 3,000 mature individuals were counted. In 2006-2007 a total population of more than 7,000 individuals is recorded. Reintroduction and protection measures seem to have lead to increasing population trends (Gobierno de Canarias 2009).

Its population has been growing since the implementation of the recovery plan in 1988, due to reintroduction measures and through natural regeneration. Current population is 9,815 individuals, from which 5,639 are mature individuals (Á. Palomares pers. comm. 2011). The species presents a scattered distribution. It is frequently found distributed in small groups which do not comprise a viable population and the subpopulations counting more than 250 individuals are not common and are reintroduced: surroundings of Morro de la Cebolla, surroundings of Roque de los Muchachos, Parcela Quemada and Izcagua Dornajito.
range: This plant is endemic to the island of La Palma, the Canary Islands, Spain, where it occurs in the north of the island (Carqué Álamo et al. 2004). It is present in eight municipalities, comprising several population nuclei: Santa Cruz de La Palma (Pico de La Nieve); Puntallana (Barranco Hondo); San Andrés y Sauces (Barranco de Vizcaíno, Lomo Morisco, Fuente Juan Diego, La Mejorana y Rivero); Barlovento (northeast of Pico de la Cruz, Dormitorios Altos, Morro de la Cebolla, Barranco de Gallegos); Garafía (Barranco de Franceses, Los Andenes, foot of Pico Fuente Nueva, northeastern foot of Roque de los Muchachos, surroundings of Observatorio Astrofisico, Lomo de la Ciudad, Barrancos de Izcagua, Briesta, Dornajito and Las Grajas); Puntagorda (northern foor of Roque Chico, firewall Reventón, Llano de las Ánimas and Barranco de Garome); Tijarafe (Barranco de Garorme, western foot of Roque Palmero) and El Paso (Espigón Roque de los Muchachos, Barranco del Diablo) (Á. Palomares pers. comm. 2011). Its total area of occupancy is 28 km², comprising natural and introduced subpopulations.
conservationActions:
This species is listed under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is classed as Endangered B2ab(iii) on the Spanish Red List (Moreno 2008) and as species "de interés para los ecosistemas canarios" in the catalogue of protected species of  the Canary Islands.

It occurs within the protected areas Parque Nacional Caldera de Taburiente (SCI), Parque Natural de las Nieves (SCI) and SCIs of Barlovento, Garafía, El Paso and Tijarafe (Carqué Álamo et al. 2004). A recovery programme has been developed in Parque Nacional Cadera de Taburiente, which includes population monitoring, establishment of fences, reinforcement measures and benign introduction, introduced herbivorous species control and awareness plans.

Seeds are stored in the germplasm banks E.T.S. de Ingenieros Agrónomos and Jardín Canario Viera y Clavijo.

Plant material from every subpopulation should be stored in germplasm banks. Introduced populations have to be kept in place and enforced.

rationale:
Pistacia atlantica is a large tree species, found in North Africa, Canary Islands and a section of Eurasia from the Iranian Plateau. Pistacia atlantica is local, scattered in most of its localities. The abundance of the species varies from rare, occasional to abundant in just a few stations. The overall trend of the population size is decreasing, the number of mature individuals and the population density of P. atlantica are significantly reduced during the last decades due to many threats; ruthless collection for domestic uses as forage or firewood and for trade, collection practices, overgrazing, deforestation, desertification, phenomenon of silting, erosion and insects attacks. The population size is suspected to decline globally by 25% over the next 100 years based on the level of exploitation of the species, the poor health of the mature individuals due to competition and attacks from insects and the significant degradation of the habitats.  

Regionally, P. atlantica is threatened but globally the species is near the threshold for Vulnerable A3cde. Therefore, Pistacia atlantica is globally assessed as Near Threatened (NT: A3cde.).
habitat: Pistacia atlantica is a semi-evergreen tree that can reach heights of up to 20 m (Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 1998). Pistacia atlantica has a remarkable ecological amplitude with great plasticity ranging from arid Saharan areas, semi-arid forests, as well as in open areas and within agricultural landscapes. The species can occupy rock cracks and cliffs, plains on deep or very rocky soils, stony hillsides, steep dry slopes, sandstone hills, gullies or temporarily damp depressions (Jahandiez and Maire 1932, Nègre 1962, Ozenda 1983, Benabid and Fennane 1994, Charco 2001, Benabid 2002, Rezaeyan et al. 2009). Pistacia atlantica can grow in most soil types except sandy soil and does not require irrigation to survive. The species prefers open and sunny habitats but can be found in mid-shaded habitats; flowers from December to May and fruiting from March to September. It grows in a humid, sub-humid to sub-arid Mediterranean climates (Jahandiez and Maire 1932, Nègre 1962, Ozenda 1983, Benabid and Fennane 1994, Charco 2001, Benabid 2002, Rezaeyan et al. 2009).
threats: The population size and habitats of Pistacia atlantica are in continuous degradation and decline due to numerous medium to high impact threats, anthropogenic and climatic effects especially: ruthless collection for domestic uses as forage or firewood and for trade, collection practices, overgrazing preventing natural regeneration and development of young shoots, deforestation, desertification, phenomenon of silting, erosion and insects attacks such us the golden causing blisters or galls in the leaves (Benabid 2002, Dahmani  2011, Taleb and Fennane 2011, Benradje et al. 2012). Pistacia atlantica is heavily collected by locals and collectors for firewood, domestic uses as remedy or to trade nationally (e.g. in Morocco 800-1600 Dhs/kg) and for international export (tonnes a year). The bad collection practices of the wild species are destroying the entire species and preventing it from growing again. Pistacia atlantica is threatened more generally by the direct and indirect impact of human activities such as leisure activities, tourism, infrastructure development, long periods of drought and climate change and the lack of management activities.
population:
Pistacia atlantica is local and scattered in most of its localities. The abundance of the species varies from rare, occasional to abundant on few stations but most of the subpopulations are found as isolated trees or as small clusters of 2–3 trees. In Algeria, P. atlantica exists in small stands and small bouquets or as isolated individual trees scattered often outside forests. The species was widespread in Southern Algeria and in the arid regions where it associates with the Juniperus phoenicea, green oak and the olive trees (Belhadj 2001, Benradje et al. 2012). In Morocco, P. atlantica constituted a climax on the arid highlands of eastern Morocco. The species is scattered, isolated with few well-preserved small sub-population in the marabouts and cemeteries. The densities varies from 20 individuals over an area of 8,000 m2, 80 to 100 individuals over 1 km2 and 30 to 50 individuals over 1 km2 (Faouzi et al. 2015).

The overall trend of the population size is decreasing, the number of mature individuals and the population density of P. atlantica are significantly reduced due to many threats. Therefore, the population size is suspected to decline globally by a quarter (25%) over the next 100 years based on the level of exploitation of the species, the poor health of the mature individuals due to competition and attacks from insects and the significant degradation of the habitats.
range:
Pistacia atlantica is widespread across North Africa, Canary Islands and a section of Eurasia from the Iranian Plateau (Euro+Med 2017, WCSP 2017, GBIF 2017).

In North Africa, P. atlantica occurs in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya and Egypt (Charco 2001, Dobignard and Chatelain 2011, Al-Saghir and Porter 2012, Euro+Med 2017). In Morocco, P. atlantica is found in most of the major floristic divisions across the country within a range of altitude up to 1,950 m, the species is rare in the well-watered regions (Jahandiez and Maire 1932, Nègre 1962, Ozenda 1983, Charco 2001, Valdés et al. 2002, Fennane and Ibn Tattou 2005, Fennane et al. 2007). In Algeria, P. atlantica is widely distributed in South Algeria, mainly in the Sharan Atlas (AS2-AD3), occurs in Mouzaïa, Miliana, Tlemcen, Mascara, Aumale, Téniet and Dréat, with an average altitude between 700 m and 1,200 m but it can reach 2,000 m (Battandier and Trabut 1889, Maire 1932, Maire and Quezel 1957, Quezel and Santa 1962, Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 2001, Benradje et al. 2012). In Tunisia, P. atlantica occurs in the high regions mainly; Ghardimaou, Soukra, Resas, Djebel Zaghouan, Dougga, Djilma, Feriana, Kasserinne, Gafsa, Matmatas and Dehibet (Bonnet and Barratte 1896, Pottier-Alapetite 1979, Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 2001, Le Floc’h et al. 2010). In Libya, P. atlantica is recorded in many regions mainly in the west of the country; Zuwara, Tajoura, Msallata, Tawergha, Alzintan, Tiji, Nalut and Shwayrif (Ali et al. 1977, Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 2001). In Egypt, P. atlantica is one of the few large trees growing wild in the Sinai desert (Boulos 2000, Padulosi and Hadj-Hassan 2001).

In the Canary Islands, P. atlantica can be found between the lower level and the higher (0–400m) on La Palma, La Gomera, Tenerife, Gran Canaria and Fuerteventura (Arbolapp 2017). 

In Europe, P. atlantica is recorded from Greece (the East Aegean Islands and the Cyclades), Cyprus, Ukraine (Crimea), Turkey (Thrace), and the Canary Islands. However, the native range in Europe is highly uncertain as the plant has been very widely introduced through cultivation. Within Europe, the altitude range is probably from sea level to c. 1,500 m (Tutin et al. 1964-1980). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) and the estimated area of occupancy (AOO) exceeded the threatened categories threshold.
useTrade: Pistacia atlantica parts have been traditionally used for a wide range of purposes as food, medicine, forage and as source of wood. The resin is used as chewing gum, against stomach infections, purify the breath, sterility, colic, tonic, digestive, depilatory, gums strengthening, resolutive for furuncles and as an antiseptic for wounds and the respiratory infections (Boulos 1983, Bellakhdar 1997, Pourreza et al. 2008, Sijelmassi 2011). In addition, the resin is used in preparations of certain cosmetic products and perfumery, as an ingredient in conservative odontology, in the production of glue, restoration of works of art in glass, porcelain, wood and metal. The fruit is not only used as food but as an expectorant, sudorific, heart stimulant, expectorant, diuretic and to treat asthma, chest diseases and stomach disorders (crushed nut of the fruit). The seeds are used for tanning and for soap-making. Seedlings are used as rootstock for the widely cultivated species Pistacia vera (Rezaeyan 2009). Pistachio is also used in the treatment of eczema, diarrhea, throat infections, kidney stones and asthma (Marone et al. 2001). Toxicity: The raw resin without any prior treatment is reported as toxic. Chemical composition: Resin: soluble part (α-resin, C20H32O3). Essential oil: polyphenols and flavonoids contents. Fruit: essential and fat oils, polyphenols and flavonoids contents (Saber-Tehrani et al. 2013).
conservationActions:
Pistacia atlantica is found in 38 ex situ collections worldwide (BGCI 2017). The species is widespread but locally is threatened. It is recommended that the extent of decline in population across the species range should be investigated, and necessary action taken. However, the following actions are recommended to protect the species and its habitats: 
  • Protection of the species sites from habitat deforestation, and overgrazing. 
  • Fencing the vulnerable sites and creation of forests enclosures. 
  • The creation of protected areas to ensure complete regeneration of the species, ecosystems and to restore the quality of wild environments.
  • Raising of public awareness and identifying priorities
  • Ex situ conservation: artificial propagation, re-introduction, seed collections.
  • Pastoral and silvo-pastoral improvement.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (extent of occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2 </sup>combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend appears to be declining but it is not thought to be declining sufficiently to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size is extremely large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: In the west of its range this species is found mainly in cultivated areas with hedgerow trees, orchards, gardens and farmyards and less commonly in light woodland. In the east it is found increasingly not only in built-up areas, but also in open arid country. In the Far East where P. domesticus is absent it is common in built-up areas and is even found in urban centres. In the north of its range the breeding season begins from April or May and to January in the extreme south of Asia. It breeds in loose colonies. The nest is constructed of dried grass and rootlets, lined with feathers and animal fur and is domed (even when in a hole), with as entrance on the side. It is mostly sited in a hole in a tree, earth bank, cliff or artificial structure, sometimes in the base of a large nest of heron (Ardeidae), crow (Corvidae) or bird of prey. Occasionally it is a free-standing nest in a tree, but then usually hidden in thick conifer or creepers. Clutches are two to seven eggs. The diet is mainly seeds and it prefers smaller seeds of low herbs and grasses, including cultivated cereals but it also takes a significant proportion of animal food (Summers-Smith 2016). In Europe the species is largely sedentary (Hagemeijer and Blair 1997). In central Asia, the species makes more pronounced movements. Birds in the extreme north of the range withdraw to the south and those living in the countryside tend to move into built-up areas (Summers-Smith 2016).
threats: Declines in this species in Europe may be a result of changes in agricultural practices such as the increased use of pesticides and herbicides and the autumn sowing of cereals which have lead to decreases in food for this species (Hagemeijer and Blair 1997).
population: Rich et al. (2004) estimated the global population to number 20,000,000 individuals. In Europe, the breeding population is estimated to number 24,000,000-38,200,000 pairs, which equates to 47,900,000-76,400,000 mature individuals (BirdLife International 2015). Europe forms c.25% of the global range, so a very preliminary estimate of the global population size is 191,000,000-306,000,000 individuals, although further validation of this estimate is needed.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
In 1996 the species was placed on the U.K. Red List of Species of National Conservation Concern (Summers-Smith 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Management should create invertebrate-rich habitats, such as small-scale wetlands, and aim to increase heterogeneity in land use type in order to to provide the range of invertebrates at the required abundance for this species (Field et al. 2004).

rationale:
This species is considered native to the Canary Islands, Cabo Verde, Morocco, and Madeira, and of uncertain origin in the Azores; whilst this introduction may have occurred prior to 1500, records from the Azores are excluded here. In the Canaries, records are from Tenerife (most records), and also from Gran Canaria, La Palma, El Hierro and Gomera. Records from the latter three islands are considered to be the result of introductions, and on Gran Canaria only two natural individuals remain. On Madeira, the species is often cultivated in gardens but is extinct in the wild on the island of Porto Santo, and on Madeira itself only a single wild tree remains (with further individuals existing but it is strongly suspected that they have been introduced). In 2009, the Madeira Botanical Garden carried out reinforcement planting of 10 plants in its natural habitat, in 2018 eight survive. 

The total population of natural individuals is unknown but in Europe is estimated at 1,135 individuals of which 674 are mature. The overall population trend is uncertain but thought to be declining; only one juvenile natural individual remains on Gran Canaria, and a single wild mature tree remains on Madeira, whilst on Tenerife subpopulations are considered to be more or less stable as most remaining individuals are found in inaccessible areas and isolated from the more significant threats, although still impacted by storms, grazing and invasive plants. It is possible that it is recovering in some areas, and in areas where livestock grazing has been reduced, subpopulations have recovered. The species is considered to be severely fragmented as a result of the geographical separation of the subpopulations.

The species is assessed as Endangered (EN B2ab(ii,iii,iv,v)) as a result of the restricted area of occupancy, severe fragmentation, and the ongoing decline in the quality and area of habitat.
habitat:
Long lived, this species reaches maturity after 30 years. It is a component of the Mayteno-Juniperion canariensis association. It is found on rocks, on ledges on cliffs, slopes of ravines, and also within piedmont, in the potential area of thermophilic forest (Mesa Coello et al. 2015), coexisting with characteristic species of Rhamno-Oleetea cerasiformis and Aeonio-Euphorbion canariensis, and various elements of rock-dwelling species, mostly Soncho-Aeonion. It can be found in association with Juniperus turbinata subsp. canariensis, Pistacia atlantica, Olea cerasiformis, Maytenus canariensis, Heberdenia excelsa, Rhamnus crenulata, Jasminum odoratissimum, Rubia fruticosa, several taxa of Aeonium, Sonchus, Euphorbia, etc. Flowering and fruiting is generally low and irregular in their wild populations, depending on climatic and environmental factors (Almeida Pérez 2004). In Madeira, it's found on slopes of ravines in microphyllous and sclerophyllous microforests of Olea spp. and Juniper spp. coexisting with characteristics species of Rhamno crenulatae-Oleetea cerasiformis (Costa et al. 2012)

It can be found in the following Habitats Directive listed habitats (Commission of the European Communities 2009):
  • 1,250 Vegetated sea cliffs with endemic flora of the Macaronesian coasts.
  • 9,320 Olea and Ceratonia forests.
threats: Mesa Coello et al. (2015) considers the primary threats to be landslides impacting steeper areas of its habitat, and wind damage, especially in exposed areas. Grazing pressure from livestock (mainly goats) impacts seedling regeneration and juveniles. Browsing by rabbits may also impact some subpopulations. However most remaining subpopulations are in inaccessible areas, cliffs etc., where direct impacts are low. Competition with exotic plants (e.g., Opuntia maxima and Agave americana) has also been cited as a threat (Mesa Coello et al. 2015). Hiking, trekking and climbing may impact some areas (Almeida Pérez 2011), however most remaining individuals are in inaccessible areas. In Madeira, the main threats are landslides in steep areas of the habitat and competition with exotic plants (e.g., Opuntia tuna and Arundo donax).
population:
The wild subpopulations of the Canary Island Dragon Tree have been in decline for a long time. The species is present in five of the seven islands in the Canaries and the total population is reduced to a few hundred trees. In Madeira and Porto Santo, it was once an important component of the vegetation in more arid areas but is reduced today to nine individuals in the wild (in Madeira) (one wild mature tree and eight from reinforcement planting). A survey in 1996 revealed new subpopulations in North Africa, in the Anezi region of the Anti-Atlas Mts. in Morocco. Thousands of individuals exist on steep quartzite cliffs in inaccessible gorges. These subpopulations are likely to represent a distinct variant of the species.

The total population in the Canary Islands was estimated to be c.1,799 individuals (Mesa Coello et al. 2015, Gobierno de Canarias 2017), of which c.1,185 are mature, however, these estimates included introduced and cultivated individuals. Excluding the non-natural populations on La Palma, El Hierro, and Gomera, Mesa Coello et al. (2015) found there to be 1,373 individuals (corresponding exclusively to the population on Tenerife only), of which 897 are adults and 476 are juveniles. However, the 2015 survey (Mesa Coello et al. 2015) also included two subpopulations that are considered to comprise of predominantly non-natural individuals (R.S. Almeida Pérez pers. comm. 2017); Isogue, and La Laguna-Valle Tabares-Tahodio. The Isogue subpopulation contains three mature individuals that are considered to be of natural origin out of 168 in total, with the remainder resulting from reintroductions that took place in the Isogue ravine a number of years ago. The La Laguna-Valle Tabares-Tahodio subpopulation comprises 74 individuals (70 adults and four juveniles), however none of these individuals can be considered wild, since the whole environment is strongly anthropocised (R.S. Almeida Pérez pers. comm. 2017). Within the La Laguna-Valle Tabares-Tahodio subpopulation is included the reintroduction site at Los Campitos ('Las Mesas in Mesa Coello et al. (2015)), which represents more than 80% of the individuals within the subpopulation. Taking into account the above, from the total number of specimens on Tenerife (1,373) we would have to subtract 239 individuals corresponding to most the Isogue subpopulation and all of the La Laguna-Valle de Tabares-Tahodio subpopulation, resulting in a total of 1,134 wild individuals for the whole island, of which 674 are adults.

On Tenerife, subpopulations are generally small and highly dispersed and are mostly located in the ancient geological areas of the mountains of Anaga, Teno and Adeje. On Gran Canaria, the single wild individual in the Pino Gordo Gorge (San Nicolas de Tolentino) died in 2009 (Á. Marrero Rodríguez pers. comm. 2017), although there are two other autochthonous individuals in Meleguinas and in the ravine of Alonso (Santa Brígida). The dynamics of the subpopulations are kept relatively stable, being observed to even have a perceptible natural regeneration in some enclaves, indicating good germination. The population recovery is slow, with the species in general behaving regressively. Many aspects of their reproductive biology are unclear, and the reason for the rarity today on Gran Canaria is uncertain. It currently shows little or no ability to disperse over long distance (Almeida Pérez 2004).

On Madeira, the species is often cultivated in gardens but is extinct in the wild on the island of Porto Santo. On Madeira itself, one wild mature tree survives on a slope near the village Ribeira Brava, with two nearby adult individuals destroyed during strong storms that hit the island in December 2009 and February 2010. Another individual that existed near Ponta do Garajau in the east of Funchal fell into the sea in 1982 during a storm (Press and Short 1994). Another set of individuals exist at Funchal in the Núcleo dos Dragoeiros das Neves – IFCN (Instituto de Florestas e Conservação da Natureza), but it is strongly suspected that they have been introduced there (Constância 2005). In 2009, the Madeira Botanical Garden carried out reinforcement planting of 10 plants in its natural habitat, and as of 2018 eight still survive.

In the Azores, the species' origin is uncertain. At least two subpopulations, one in São Jorge and another in Flores, appear to have originated naturally due to the steep locations. There are around 200-300 individuals on the island of São Jorge (C. Aguiar pers. obs. 2010), and an updated census is recommended. There are apparently more individuals on Flores, Faial and Corvo but it is not known how many there are or of they can be considered native. Schäfer (2002) states that the species is rare on Flores and very rare on Faial. In this assessment, the species is considered to not be native in the Azores archipelago, and these individuals not included in assessments, until confirmation that these are indeed native.

The overall population trend is declining, with one natural mature individual now known on Madeira, and the species went extinct in the wild on Gran Canaria within the last ten years. On Tenerife, most remaining individuals are found in inaccessible areas and are isolated from the more significant threats. It is possible that the species is recovering in some areas on Tenerife, and in areas where livestock grazing has been reduced, subpopulations have recovered (Mesa Coello et al. 2015). The dynamics of their subpopulations remain relatively stable, showing a perceptible natural regeneration in some enclaves (bco. del Infierno, Roque de Las Ánimas, Roque de Tierra), indicating a good germination. However, population recovery is slow. It should be added that even in the core subpopulations where some natural regeneration is observed, several threat factors continue to occur, such as uncontrolled grazing, competition with exotic plants, and stochastic environmental factors such as rocky landslides and falls due to wind storms. Taken together, these factors cause losses of greater or lesser consideration. In addition, there is significant geographical fragmentation of the different subpopulations and the net separation of the three main population centres: Anaga, Teno and Adeje.

Little is known about the size and trend of the Cabo Verde subpopulation.
range:
This species is found in the south-west Atlas Mountains of Morocco (with records from there segregated as subspecies ajgal; Almeida Pérez 2004), Cabo Verde (subsp. caboverdeana), the Canary Islands, and Madeira. In the Canaries, records are from Tenerife (most records), and also from Gran Canaria, La Palma, El Hierro and Gomera; however the subpopulations on La Palma, El Hierro and Gomera are all considered to have resulted from introduction through cultivation (R.S. Almeida pers. comm. 2017). The species is also found on the Azores, but the subpopulation there is of unknown origin. The species is widespread in cultivation and the origin of some subpopulations remains uncertain, however even if reintroduced subpopulations on Tenerife were included, as these may have occurred within the natural historical range of the species, the extent of occurrence (EOO) and AOO would still be restricted. In this assessment, the species is considered to not be native in the Azores archipelago, where its presence is likely the result of early introduction by the Portuguese from seeds from Madeira (or even the Canary Islands) and from Cape Verde, with some individuals there observed to have the characteristic of the Cape Verdean subspecies (subsp. caboverdeana). However, there are possibly natural subpopulations in Azores in São Jorge and Flores.

The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at less than 412 km2. This value excludes records from the Azores and records of uncertain origin elsewhere, apart from Gran Canaria and Tenerife, and so this is likely to be an overestimate based on current knowledge of the species status across these islands (see population section).
useTrade: The species is widely cultivated in gardens. The dragon trees' blood had a wide range of uses as a medicine, for staining violins and for embalming the dead. The leaves and fruits are collected for animal fodder.
conservationActions:
The species is listed in regional, governmental and international legislation. It is widespread in cultivation. There are over 180 ex situ collections. This species was globally red listed as Vulnerable in 1998.

The species is listed in Annex IV of the EU Habitats Directive and is listed under Appendix I of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). In addition, it is also protected by regional law. It was assessed as Endangered (B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii); C2a(i)) on the Spanish national Red List (Moreno 2008) and as Endangered for the European Red List (Almeida Pérez 2011, Bilz et al. 2011, Almeida Pérez and Beech 2017).

On the Canary Islands, populations are included in Parque Rural Nublo (SIC), Parque Rural Anaga (SIC), Reserva Natural Integral Roques de Anaga (SIC), Reserva Natural Integral Ijuana (SIC), Interián (SIC), Parque Rural Teno (SIC), Reserva Natural Especial Bco. del Infierno (SIC), Parque Natural Corona Forestal (SIC), Monumento Natural Montaña de Tejina and Riscos de Bajamar y Bco. de Niágara (SIC). Seeds exist in a germbank (Almeida Pérez 2004).

In Portugal, the seeds of the species are stored in the seedbank of the Botanic Garden of Madeira and the same garden established a reintroduction plan (Commission of the European Communities 2009). This garden is also attempting vegetative propagation of one of the storm-damaged individuals of Madeira but without success. On February 13, 2009, the Madeira Botanical Garden led to the reinforcement of the population in a natural habitat with 10 plants, originated from seeds of natural plants. Further monitorization in 2018 observed survival of 8 plants, that means total of 9 plants.

rationale: Euphorbia dendroides is a semi-succulent shrub or small tree which has a wide distribution across across the Mediterranean. Although it is under threat from coastal urbanisation and fires in parts of its range, it is assessed here as Least Concern as it is a very widespread species.
habitat: This species is a semi-succulent large shrub or small tree which grows along the Mediterranean coast on mostly rocky habitats near to the sea (Eichberger 2003, Afferni 2012).
threats: This species is threatened by coastal urbanisation across its range. In Montenegro approximately 30% of area covered by this species was burnt in fires in 2007 and 2008 (Petrović et al. 2008).
population: In Montenegro the population area of this species has declined rapidly. This trend is expected to continue into the future (Petrović et al. 2008). There is no known major declines in other areas of its range.
range: Euphorbia dendroides is found across the Mediterranean from France through to Turkey as well as across northern Africa and parts of the Middle East. It has also been introduced into other regions of the world such as California, Argentina and Australia (Afferni 2012, Euro+Med 2015).
useTrade: In the past the latex which exudes from the species when cut was used to treat warts and verrucas. Powder from the roots was also used to cure rheumatic pains (Afferni 2012). No current uses can been ascertained. Some of the chemicals found in the plant are being researched for their anti-cancer properties (Pešić et al. 2011).
conservationActions: This species is recorded in 38 ex situ collections (BGCI 2016). This species is listed on CITES appendix II (CITES - Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora 2016). This species is listed as Vulnerable in Montenegro (Petrović et al. 2008), Vulnerable in Egypt (BGCI 2017), and Least Concern across its full European range (Harvey-Brown 2017).

rationale: Daucus aureus is widespread and common in many parts of its native range. With a large extent of occurrence (EOO) of over three million km2, the area of occupancy (AOO) is also inferred to exceed the values for a threatened category. Additionally, it has been regionally assessed as Least Concern in Jordan. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern. Further germplasm collections is recommended for this species.
habitat: This is an annual species growing from 1-3 m, occurring at altitudes of sea level to 600 m asl (Cambria 2012).  It grows in cultivated areas in Cyprus and Egypt (Meikle 1977, Boulos 2009).
threats: Threats to this species are currently unknown, further research is needed to gather information about the potential threats affecting it.
population: This species has been recorded as rare, very rare, common and very common in various publications (Meikle 1977, Danin 2017, Cambria 2012).
range:
Daucus aureus is native to Cyprus, Italy, Jordan and Spain, as well as northern Africa and western Asia  (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Further research is needed to gather information about the precise distribution of this species throughout its range.
useTrade: Daucus aureus is a primary wild relative of and potential gene donor to carrot.
conservationActions:
The genus Daucus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

According to Genesys (2017) there are thirty seven germplasm accessions stored worldwide. The Jordan Plant Red List has assessed this species as Least Concern (Taifour and El-Oqlah 2014).

rationale: Daucus durieua is widespread throughout its native region. This is a common species and occurs in a variety of habitats and over a range of altitudes and, within its large extent of occurrence (EOO), of over 3 million km2, the area of occupancy (AOO) is also inferred to exceed the values for a threatened category. Due to its extensive range in its native region, and no major threats the population is inferred to be large and stable. This species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Daucus durieua is a multi-stemmed, erect annual growing from 15-30(-60) cm tall (Tutin et al. 1968; Pujadas Salvà 2003). It is found in ruderal areas and cultivated land, pasturelands, open grasslands, on rocky, calcareous, granitic and shale soils. In Cyprus it is found on dry, stony hillsides from 150 to 300 m asl (Meikle 1977, Pottier-Alapetite 1979). In Iberia it occurs from 100 to 1700 m asl (Pujadas Salvà 2003).
threats: There are no major threats to this species but livestock grazing is a minor threat. More field research is needed to ascertain any major potential threats to this species.
population: It is widespread and common in the Mediterranean region, however the population distribution, size and trend for this species remains largely unknown, with this limited evidence it is suspected that this species is stable across its global native range.   Further surveys are required to ascertain its population status in Cyprus.
range:
Daucus durieua is native to southwestern Europe (Portugal and Spain), western Asia, northern Africa and Macaronesia (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

In Cyprus, it has been recorded at two localities with the last record dating back to 1974. During the national Red List assessment in Cyprus it was classified as Data Deficient (Tsintides et al. 2007).
useTrade: It is a wild relative of and potential gene donor to the crop carrot.
conservationActions:
The genus Daucus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) which aims to guarantee sustainable agriculture and food security through the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, as well as ensuring the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of their use (FAO 2009).

This species' native distribution overlaps with several protected areas, inferred using GeoCAT (Bachman et al. 2011) and so passive conservation is presumed in this area. However, there is no evidence of active management or monitoring of this species.

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017) this species has only one living collection in one botanical garden worldwide, although the size of the collections are not detailed in this resource. There are eleven germplasm collections held globally (Genesys 2017).

rationale: Myrtus communis is a widespread and common species that is a significant constituent of Mediterranean maquis vegetation. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO) and population are all inferred to exceed the values for a threatened category. It is suspected not to have any significant ongoing threats and any population declines in some areas are likely to be balanced by increases in others, for example, as a component in the vegetation colonising abandoned agricultural fields. The species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This evergreen shrub or small tree, generally grows between 0.5-3 m in height (Migliore et al. 2011). It is a common constituent of Mediterranean maquis vegetation, and pine and oak woodland understorey. The flowers are insect pollinated and it produces large numbers of seeds with high germination rates which are dispersed by birds or washed away by rains. The species has a wide ecological tolerance (Polunin 1969, Ahmed and Vardar 1973).
threats: Myrtle fruit and leaf material are often collected from wild subpopulations but are not thought to significantly affect viability. Increasing urbanization, natural fires, grazing by livestock and other wild herbivores, and the cutting of wood are all putting pressure on wild subpopulations (Melito et al. 2013), but are not suspected to constitute major threats.
population: This is reported to be a common and widespread shrub of the Mediterranean basin, Asia, and northern sub-tropical Africa, and it is inferred that the population is large. Urbanization and agricultural expansion may have caused loss and fragmentation of the habitat but are not suspected to be resulting in any significant overall population decline. This is because the species has a high ecological tolerance as it produces a large number of seed with a high germination rate making it an effective successional species in abandoned fields, where the population may be increasing (Santos 2000).
range: The species is considered native from Mediterranean coasts (north Africa and southern Europe), Eritrea and Ethiopia to the Irano-Turanian region (including Pakistan and Afghanistan), and Yemen, countries of the Middle East and Turkey (Mediterranean and Black sea coasts). Is also found in Macaronesia (Madeira, the Canaries and Azores) and Mediterranean islands such as Corsica, Sicily, Crete and the Balearics (Govaerts 2014, GRIN 2017 Migliore et al. 2011).
useTrade:
Essential oils are extracted from the young leaves and mature fruits. These are used in the production of local liquors known as mirto in Corsica and Sardinia. Extracts have antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties and the leaves and berries are used in various processed food and cosmetic formulations. It is taken internally in the treatment of urinary infections, digestive disorders, vaginal infections, lung congestion, sinus inflammation and dry coughs. Externally it can be used to treat acne and the extracted oil is used to treat gum inflammation. Other documented uses include the treatment of dysentery, diarrhoea, haemorrhoids, internal ulceration and rheumatism (Plants for a Future 2014). The plant is used in either fresh or dry form as a food additive, and its leaf can substitute for hops in beer manufacture (Bonjar 2004 and Barboni et al 2010 in Melito et al. 2013).

The flowers can be eaten in salads and the fruit can be eaten raw or cooked, made into a fruit drink or dried and used as a flavouring (Plants for a Future 2014). Dyes and tannins are also extracted and the wood is used as fuel (producing a high quality charcoal) and for wood working to produce, for example, tool handles and walking sticks (Plants for a Future 2014, GRIN 2014). A perfumed water, known as eau d'ange is obtained from the flowers. It is cultivated as an ornamental in gardens and often used as a hedging plant. It also has cultural significance and is associated with love and immortality and is, for example, used in wedding bouquets (Royal Botanic Gardens Kew 2014).
conservationActions: This species is listed as occurring in 21 Natura 2000 sites located in Italy, Spain and Malta and protected areas such as the Brijuni Islands National Park in Croatia. It is grown in ex situ in 149 collections worldwide and seed is stored in seed banks, for example in Cordoba, Spain (BGCI 2017, ENSCO 2014). To relieve collection pressures on wild subpopulations there have been attempts to identify candidate cultivars with a view to establishing managed stands for commercial cultivation (Mulas et al. 2002, Zilkah and Goldschdmidt 2014, and Melito et al. 2013) and in recent years myrtle plantations have been established. This species is reported as Least Concern within its European range (Chadburn 2014).

rationale: Lathyrus sphaericus has a very large extensive geographical range, is believed to be common throughout its range and is not considered to be specifically threatened. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The species is found on hillsides, in open shrublands and in pine forests, specifically grassland at forest edges (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
threats: There are no known major threats to Lathyrus sphaericus, although it is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires. Nevertheless, it may be affected with the increasing fire frequency, but the extent of this may affect the species is unknown (Le Houérou 1973).
population: The population is assumed to be common and stable.
range: Lathyrus sphaericus is a widespread species, found throughout Europe, western, central and tropical Asia, and northern, eastern and central Africa (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition to the countries listed in this assessment (from Shehadeh et al. in prep), the species has also been reported in Afghanistan, Israel, Jordan, Mauritius, Malta, Australia, Mexico and USA (ILDIS 2010, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). These countries are not believed to form part of the native distribution and are therefore not included in this assessment. Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 11,000,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 2,504 km2.
useTrade: It has potential applications as a poison of vertebrates (ILDIS 2010). In addition, it is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, the cultivated Grass Pea, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea, Cyprus Vetch, and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea, Caley Pea, and Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

The species is fairly well conserved ex situ when compared to other taxa in the genus. Genesys report 80 accessions, of which 51 are of wild origin. All but two of these originate from within the native distribution (one from UK, one from Germany), and of those that do 20 are backed up at a second genebank and 11 are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). Many of the countries which form the native distribution of this species are not represented in ex situ genebank collections, and should therefore be prioritised for future collections. These countries are: Asia: Iran Iraq, Lebanon and Nepal in Asia; Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Denmark, France, Hungary, Italy, Macedonia, Montenegro, Portugal, Romania, Serbia and Slovenia in Europe; Algeria, Democratic Republic of  Congo, Egypt, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Tunisia and Uganda in Africa.

According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in 13 botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

It is not known whether this species occurs within existing protected areas. However, it is very likely as it is widespread and there are several protected areas within the species' range.

The species has previously been assessed regionally and globally. Globally it has been assessed as not threatened (ILDIS 2010) and as Least Concern in 2012 (Groom 2012). Regional assessments have classed the species as very rare in Malta (Lanfranco 1989), as Critically Endangered in Sweden (Gärdenfors 2000, Gärdenfors 2005, Gärdenfors 2010), as Vulnerable in Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002, OFEV 2016), as threatened in Israel (although this assessment utilised non-IUCN criteria) (Sapir et al. 2003), and as Near Threatened in Hungary (Király 2007).

rationale: This species has a large global range, but occupies a relatively small area within that range; area of occupancy (AOO = 2,060 km<sup>2</sup>) nearly qualifies the species as Vulnerable. In addition, it may be threatened by overgrazing and Mediterranean summer fires so these threats should be monitored to determine if the species is actually threatened. However, due to the large population size and range these threats would be unlikely to be significant. The species is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern (LC).
habitat: It grows in fields, field edges and roadsides, and on rocky limestone slopes in oak scrub (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
threats: It is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires and so with increasing fires the species is potentially threatened (Le Houérou 1973). It is potentially at risk from overgrazing by wild and domesticated species in the pasture and agricultural margins (Bilz et al. 2011). However, it is not known if these threats are specific to this species.
population: The population of this taxon is known to be extremely large but there are no precise estimates (Taifour and El-Oqlah 2014).
range:
Lathyrus aphaca L. is widely distributed throughout southern, central and northern Europe, north Africa, and western and central Asia (Shehadeh et al. in prep).

The countries of occurrence are based on Shehadeh et al. (in prep), but the species has also been reported elsewhere, including Belgium, Great Britain, Netherlands and Switzerland in Europe; Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya and Mauritius in Africa; Bhutan and Saudi Arabia in Asia; Australia and New Zealand in Oceania; and Canada and USA in North America (ILDIS 2010, USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). However these countries are believed to correspond to introduced populations and are therefore not included in the assessment. Shehadeh et al. (in prep) also state that the species occurs in Austria, Hungary and Romania, and that these are naturalised populations. Extent of occurrence (EOO = 14,284,413 km2) is much larger than the threshold for threatened species, but area of occupancy (AOO = 2,060 km2) nearly qualifies as Vulnerable.
useTrade: This species is rarely used as a pulse and as fodder in Europe and North Africa (Sarker et al. 2001). Wild populations of Lathyrus aphaca are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, Yellow Vetch. It is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, the cultivated Grass Pea, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea, Cyprus Vetch, and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea, Caley Pea, and Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

The species is well represented ex situ in germplasm collections. The Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources (2017) reports 736 accessions, of which 424 are of wild origin. Of the wild accessions 246 are backed up at a second gene bank and 167 are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault. 

Furthermore, according to the Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in 33 botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

In Jordan, this taxon has been recorded in the Dibeen Forest Reserve, Ajloun Forest Reserve and Yarmouk Nature Reserve, but with no specific Conservation Action Plans (Taifour and El-Oqlah 2014).

The species is poorly conserved in situ and there is no monitoring, meaning the effects of threats such as climate change are not recorded. Therefore, active in situ conservation is recommended. 

Many of the native countries are not represented ex situ in genebanks (Asia: Iraq, Kyrgyzstan, Nepal; Europe: Albania, Bosnia, Croatia, Italy, Latvia, Macedonia, Moldova, Montenegro, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia; Africa: Egypt, Libya, Tunisia), so future collections from these countries should be prioritised.

The species has been previously assessed both regionally and globally. It has been assessed as Critically Endangered in Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002), although a more recent assessment listed the species as Endangered (OFEV 2016). It has been assessed as Near Threatened in Hungary (Király 2007), and as Least Concern in Luxembourg (Colling 2005) and in Jordan in 2014 (Taifour and El-Oqlah 2014). It has also been globally assessed as Not Threatened (ILDIS 2010).

rationale: Lathryus clymenum occurs in the Mediterranean area throughout southern Europe, western Asia, northern Africa and Macaronesia. It has an extensive range and is currently not known to be facing any significant threats, and it is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: It is found in lowland Mediterranean forests and shrubland and in cultivated fields as a weed (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
threats: This species is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires and so with increasing fire frequency the species may become threatened (Le Houérou 1973). However, it is not known if this threat is specific to this species.
population: No population data is available for this species. However, many geographical data points were included in the calculation of the extent of occurrence and area of occupancy. Assuming that each of these refers to an individual plant, the species has an extremely large population.
range: Lathyrus clymenum L. is found in many Mediterranean areas throughout southern Europe but also in western Asia, northern Africa and Macaronesia (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition to the countries listed in this assessment, provided by Shehadeh et al. (in prep), the species has also been reported in Kenya, Lebanon, Syria, and New Zealand (ILDIS 2010), but these are believed to be introduced subpopulations. Extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 10,000,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is around 3,600 km2.
useTrade: Wild populations of Lathyrus clymenum are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, Spanish Vetchling. It is also a wild relative of (in Taxon Group 2) of, and a potential gene donor to Cyprus Vetch (Vincent et al. 2013) and a wild relative of (in Taxon Group 4), and a potential gene donor to, cultivated Grass Pea, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea, and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea, and Caley Pea (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition, it has potential to introduce genes which confer resistance to Ascochyta Blight (Gurung et al. 2002). It is rarely used as a pulse in Kos, Greece (Sarker et al. 2001) and is also used as fodder (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

This species is fairly well represented in ex situ germplasm collections. Genesys reports a total of 107 accessions, of which 55 are of wild origin. Of the accessions of wild origin, only 38 are known to be from within the native distribution (five not specified, 12 outside distribution), and of these, 18 are backed up at a second institution and eight are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). According to the Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in 19 botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

Many of the countries which form the native distribution of this species are not represented in ex situ genebank collections, and should therefore be prioritised for future collections. These countries are: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Italy, Macedonia, Malta, Montenegro, Serbia in Europe; and Libya in Africa.

The species is likely to be passively conserved in situ in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as its sub-populations in these sites are not actively monitored it may be subject to population loss over time from factors such as climate change.

This species has been previously globally assessed as not threatened (ILDIS 2010).

rationale: Lathyrus setifolius L. is globally assessed as Least Concern because it has a large geographic distribution and is believed to have a large and stable population. Although area of occupancy (AOO) is 788 km2 and therefore qualifies as Vulnerable, it is not known to face any major threats, although it could be affected by increasing incidence of Mediterranean summer fires. Further ex situ conservation is required, especially from those countries not represented in existing ex situ collections. The population and habitat should be monitored to determine if the threat of fire is affecting the species, and if it is, to what extent. Additionally, further research is recommended into the population and threats to this species.
habitat: It is found on rocky slopes, in Mediterranean-type shrubland and in forests and woodland (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
threats: It is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires; with increasing fire frequency the species is likely to be affected (Le Houérou 1973). However, it is not known if this threat is specific to this species.
population: No quantitative population data is available for this species. However, many geographical data points were included in the calculation of the extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO). Assuming that each of these refers to an individual plant, the species has an extremely large population.
range: It has a widespread distribution throughout the Mediterranean area in southern Europe, north Africa and western Asia (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In Europe it is found in Albania, Bulgaria, France (including Corsica), Greece (including Crete), Italy (including Sardinia and Sicily), Portugal, Romania, Spain (including the Balearic and the Canary islands), Ukraine (Crimea) and former Yugoslavia; in Africa in Algeria, Libya, Morocco and Tunisia; and in Asia in Azerbaijan, Israel, Lebanon, Palestine, Sinai (Asian part of Egypt), possibly in Syria, and in Turkey (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition, the species has also been reported in Cyprus, Malta and Russia (ILDIS 2010) but this is not believed to be part of the native distribution so are not included in the assessment. In addition, ILDIS (2010) report that the species is extinct in Israel, one of the countries believed to form part of the native distribution. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 5,400,000 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 788 km2.
useTrade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and potentially a gene donor to, the cultivated Grass Pea (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It is also a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea, Cyprus Vetch, and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea, Caley Pea, and Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

The species is fairly poorly conserved ex situ. Genesys report 15 accessions, of which 10 are of wild origin. These all originate from within the native distribution, five are backed up at a second genebank and two are duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in three botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species). The species is likely to be passively conserved in situ in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as the sub-populations in these sites are not actively monitored they may be affected over time from factors such as climate change.

The species has previously been assessed globally and regionally. A 2010 global assessment found that the species was not threatened (ILDIS 2010). Regionally, the species has been assessed as Extinct in Malta (Lanfranco 1989), as Threatened in Israel, although this assessment used non-IUCN criteria (Sapir et al. 2003), and Endangered in Cyprus (Tsintides et al. 2007).

rationale: The species has an extensive range in Africa and Europe with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,971,742 km2 far greater than the threatened threshold. It has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,092 km2, which nearly qualifies it as Vulnerable. However, it is an abundant species which is not facing any threats. It is therefore globally assessed as Least Concern. However, it should be a priority for future ex situ conservation since there is currently only one wild accession from within the native distribution.
habitat: This species occupies sandy and rocky habitats from sea level to 1600 m asl. Annual precipitation is around 600 mm.
threats: There are no threats to this species (A. Shehadeh pers. comm. 2018).
population: This is an abundant species throughout the Mediterranean region and is especially common in France, Italy, Morocco, Portugal and Spain (A. Shehadeh pers. comm. 2018).
range: Lathyrus angulatus is found throughout southern Europe and northern Africa, namely in Albania, Algeria, Canary Islands, Corsica, Crete, France, Greece, Italy, Morocco, Portugal, Sardinia, Spain and former Yugoslavia (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is reported USA (ILDIS 2010) and the Balearic Islands (Anthos 2018) but these are believed to be introduced populations and are therefore not included in this assessment. It is also reported in South Africa (ILDIS 2010) but SANBI (2018) does not report it for South Africa, so this is likely to be a mistake. The species has a large extent of occurrence of 2,971,742 km2 but area of occupancy is 2,092 km2 and therefore is approaching the VU threshold of 2,000 km2.
useTrade: It is a tertiary wild relative of, and a potential gene donor to the cultivated Grass Pea (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). It is also a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea, Cyprus Vetch, and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea, Caley Pea, and Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the Grass Pea gene pool (FAO 2009).

Genesys reports a total of 24 accessions, only one of which is of wild origin. This accession was collected in Australia which is not within the species' native range. It is not backed up at a second institution, nor is it duplicated and conserved in the Svalbard Seed Vault (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017). According to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in three botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).The species is likely to be passively conserved in situ in many existing protected areas throughout its range but as its sub-populations in these sites are not actively monitored they may be affected over time from factors such as climate change.

It has been assessed in Switzerland (Moser et al. 2002) and Croatia (Nikolić and Topić 2007) as Data Deficient, in Andorra as Vulnerable (Carillo et al. 2008), and at global level as Not Threatened (ILDIS 2010).

rationale: Lathyrus annuus is relatively common and has a fairly wide distribution range from southern Europe to western and central Asia and north Africa. Although it is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires and is affected by overgrazing, these threats are not considered significant currently. However, it is important that these threats be monitored to determine if the species does become threatened. Due to its extensive range and because the threats are not currently significant, it is globally assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: It is commonly found on wastelands (Stace 2004), in scrub, hedgelands, water-meadows and among rocks (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In Portugal it grows in cultivated lands (Osborne 2011).
threats: Although this species is relatively common and has a fairly wide distribution, it is found in habitats prone to Mediterranean summer fires. With increasing fire frequency, the species is potentially threatened (Le Houérou 1973). It is also threatened by overgrazing by wild and domesticated species in pastures and agricultural margins (Osborne 2011). These threats are known to affect subpopulations in Europe but may also affect the species elsewhere in its range.
population: It is common throughout its range, where it is found in several habitats  which are not threatened; European sub-populations appear to be  stable (Osborne 2011).
range:
Lathyrus annuus has a large distributional range, occurring in much of southern Europe (including the Canary Islands and the Madeira Islands), western and parts of central Asia, as well as north Africa (Shehadeh et al. in prep). In addition to the native distribution, it is recorded by ILDIS (2010) as being present in Estonia, Great Britain, Malta and New Zealand, but these are believed to be introduced populations. In France it occurs in 22 departments across the south of the country. Also recorded to occur in the departments of Maine-et-Loire in the west and Somme to the north (Association Tela Botanica 2010).

It has a large extent of occurrence (EOO = 27,092,556 km2) and area of occupancy (AOO = 2,232 km2), both above the thresholds for threatened species.
useTrade: This species is rarely used as a pulse and as fodder in Europe and North Africa (Sarker et al. 2001). Wild populations of Lathyrus annuus are primary sources of genetic diversity with potential for improvement of its cultivated counterpart, annual vetchling. In addition, it is a tertiary genetic wild relative of, and potentially a gene donor to, the cultivated Grass Pea (Sarker et al. 2001). Lathyrus annuus is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 2) of, and a potential gene donor to, Chickling Vetch, Sweet Pea (Vincent et al. 2013), and other cultivated Lathyrus species, including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea and Caley Pea (Shehadeh et al. in prep). More remotely, it is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of, and a potential gene donor to, other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It may be used to improve their quality by altering the antioxidant content (Pastor-Cavada et al. 2009).
conservationActions:
The genus Lathyrus is listed in Annex I of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture as part of the grass pea gene pool.

Genesys reports 212 accessions, of which 116 are of wild origin. Of the accessions of wild origin, 105 are known to be from within the native distribution. 65 are backed up at a second genebank, and 52 are duplicated in the Svalbard Seed bank (Genesys Global Portal on Plant Genetic Resources 2017).

Furthermore, according to Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI 2017), this species has living collections in eight botanic gardens worldwide, although the origin and locality of the collections are not detailed in this resource (garden locations are undisclosed to protect rare and valuable plant species).

The species is likely to be passively conserved in situ in many existing protected areas throughout its range. However, its subpopulations in these sites are not actively monitored so may be affected over time from factors such as climate change.

It has previously been assessed as Least Concern in Europe (Osborne 2011), as Very Rare in Malta (Lanfranco 1989), and globally as Not Threatened (ILDIS 2010).

Many of the countries which form the native distribution of this species are not represented in ex situ genebank collections, and should therefore be prioritised for future collections. These countries are: Afghanistan, Iraq, Turkmenistan in Asia; Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, France, Georgia, Greece, Italy, Macedonia, Montenegro, Russia, Serbia, Slovenia in Europe; and Egypt, Libya, Tunisia in Africa. Active in situ conservation and monitoring is also recommended.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any significant threats.
habitat: Lemna minor is particularly common in lakes, ponds, canals, rice fields and ditch systems but will occur in most still or slow-flowing water bodies under most conditions, except in very oligotrophic or acidic water. It is even capable of growing in a trickle of water over vertical surfaces, such as canal lock gates or seepages in cliffs.
threats: There are no known past, ongoing, or future threats to this species.
population: This species is widespread and can form large colonies in suitable habitats throughout its known range, so the population trend is assumed to be stable. In parts of Europe it is heavily over-recorded as Lemna gibba and it would be difficult to know whether there has been a change in the population.
range: Lemna minor is widespread throughout Europe and exists in scattered populations in central Asia, on the west coast and in central North America, in the north, south and the eastern half of Africa, Australia (Victoria) and New Zealand. It is presumed to have been introduced to Australia and New Zealand (Landolt 1986).
useTrade: The whole plant is alterative, antipruritic, antiscorbutic, astringent, depurative, diuretic, febrifuge and soporific. It is used in the treatment of colds, measles, oedema and urinating difficulty in China. It is applied externally in the treatment of skin diseases and is used as a wash for ophthalmia in India. The plant may also be used homeopathically in India.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or likely to be needed for this species. Research is needed into its population size, trends and distribution.

rationale: This is a widespread species with no known major widespread threats.
habitat: This species is commonly found growing in moist and shady places such as seasonally moist grassland, on alluvial mud, swamps, in pond margins, lakes, streams and river beds, and it sometimes occurs in old cultivation.
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species. In some areas the habitat may be declining in area and/or quality but the wide-scale distribution of the species prevents qualification for threatened status.
population: There is no information available on population trends for this species but there is no evidence of a decline.
range: This species is native in Egypt, the Canaries and Cape Verde, throughout much of sub-Saharan Africa, the Comores, Madagascar and the Seychelles, and from Lebanon south to Yemen and east through Sri Lank, Pakistan, India and Bangladesh to the Andaman Islands and Viet Nam, south through Java and the Lesser Sundas to Australia. It occurs as a non-native in Florida and in the Leeward and Windward Islands (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2017).
useTrade: In some parts of the world, the leaves are considered to be antibiotic and its pastes are applied externally in cutaneous affections. It is also used as a fibre for mat making.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place or likely to be needed.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: Cyperus rotundus occurs in a wide variety of wetland habitats including seasonally wet grasslands, swamps, drainage lines and ditches, pond and lake margins, springs, stream and river banks. It is tolerant of disturbance and often grows in waste areas, as well as damp cultivated habitats. The species can become a serious weed within cultivated areas (Cook 1996).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information on its population size or trends, but this species can be very common and forms large stands in suitable habitats.
range: This species is considered to be native to the Mediterranean and throughout most of sub-Saharan Africa east through the Middle East and Indian sub-continent to China and to South-east Asia south to Australia. It occurs as a non-native in parts of Europe, the Pacific island states and through South and Central America, north to parts of the United States (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2017).
useTrade: There is no evidence to suggest that this species is used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place and none are required.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.
habitat: This species grows in a wide range of wetland habitats including swamps, lake shores and wet grassland. It frequently forms floating mats in open water (I. Larridon pers. comm., Flora Zambesiaca in draft).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
