During the 2020–2021 winter season, surveys found monarchs occupying 2.1 hectares of forest in Mexico (World Wildlife Fund Mexico 2021). While the estimated number of Monarchs per hectare varies from 6.9 to 60.9 million (Calvert 2015), 21.1 million is widely used as a best estimate (Thogmartin et al. 2017a). Therefore, there were an estimated 14.5 to 127.9 million, with a best estimate of 44.3 million butterflies at overwintering sites in Mexico during the 2020–2021 season. During the same season in California, surveys documented only 1,914 butterflies, a dramatic drop from already low counts around 30,000 in the two years prior (Xerces Society Western Monarch Thanksgiving Count 2021).

Long term declines for both eastern and western migratory populations of this subspecies have been reported (Brower et al. 2011, Semmens et al. 2016, Schult et al. 2017), possibly extending as far back as the 1970s (Zylstra et al. 2020). The most pronounced declines for the eastern migratory population were seen from 1996 to 2014, when the population declined by 84% (Semmens et al. 2016). In the last 10 years, declines have slowed, and the population appears to have stabilized around 55 million individuals, with butterflies occupying an average of 2.59 ha each year. However, given the high variability in population size from year to year, it may be premature to assume the decline has stabilized. When such annual variability exists, it is appropriate to fit a decline model to the whole time series and calculate a population reduction based on the fitted values (IUCN Standards and Petitions Committee 2019, Akcakaya et al. 2021). Therefore, yearly population estimates from 1993 to 2020 (World Wildlife Fund Mexico 2021) were fit to linear and exponential models of decline. These models suggest a population size reduction of 46–72% respectively, when measured over 10 years. More sophisticated population models have been developed to identify population growth rates of the eastern migratory population. In one example, a multivariate first-order auto-regressive state-spaced model was developed and fit using both area of forest occupied in overwintering grounds and total annual egg production in parts of the summer breeding range (Semmens et al. 2016). Voorhies et al. (2019) modified this model to include additional data from 2016 to 2019. Through this approach, an annual growth rate of 0.976 was suggested for the eastern migratory population. Under this estimated rate of decline, the population reduction calculated over the last 10 years is 22%. Therefore, the population reduction for the eastern migratory population, over the last 10 years, is estimated to be 22–72%.

As mentioned, current rates of decline for the eastern migratory population are less concerning than they were in past years. Presently, the immediate concern is whether enough individuals remain to bolster against the impacts of stochastic events. To assess quasi-extinction risk and provide a target population size for conservation purposes, Semmens et al. (2016) created a multivariate first-order auto-regressive state-spaced model. The model was fit using both area of forest occupied in overwintering grounds and total annual egg production in parts of the summer breeding range. It suggests 6 ha of occupied forest is needed to maintain a resilient eastern migratory population. Though the population may appear stable, below 6 ha of occupied forest, overwintering colonies may not be large enough to maintain the appropriate microhabitat conditions to prevent from freezing (Anderson and Brower 1996, Brower et al. 2008). The quasi-extinction probability suggested by the model is 1–26% over the next 10 years, depending on the quasi-extinction threshold considered (based on the current population size of 2.1 ha and with a population growth rate of 1.0) (Semmens et al. 2016). Under the same parameters, over 20 years, quasi-extinction risk is 5–43%. The quasi-extinction thresholds considered were between 0.01 and 0.25 ha of occupied forest. For context, as the density of monarchs in one hectare of forest is suggested to be between 6.9 and 60.9 million individuals (Calvert 2004), at 0.05 ha of occupied forest, there may be as few as 345,000 individuals, and at 0.01 ha there may be as few as 69,000 individuals (Semmens et al. 2016). Therefore, the lowest extinction threshold considered, 0.01 ha, is equivalent to the smallest colony size reported to date. If this threshold were reached, all but one small colony, vulnerable to extinction by winter storm (Brower et al. 2004), would remain. Therefore, expert opinion favoured an extinction threshold closer to 0.25 ha, and no lower than 0.05 ha (Semmens et al. 2016).

For the western migratory population, an estimated population size of 3 to 10 million in the 1980s had declined to 1,914 individuals in the winter season of 2020–2021, a decline of 99.9% (Xerces Society Western Monarch Thanksgiving Count 2021, Pelton and Knight 2021). Though preliminary data from the 2021 count suggests a modest rebound, with counts totalling above 247,237 individuals, the current population size remains extremely low compared to historic levels (Pelton et al. 2021). Based on log-scale geometric growth models developed by Schultz et al. (2017) and modified by Voorhies et al. (2019) to include additional data from 2016 to 2019, estimated annual population growth for the western migratory group is 0.839. Under this estimated rate of decline, the population reduction calculated over the last 10 years is 83%. Similarly, when yearly population estimates from 1997 to 2020 (Xerces Society Western Monarch Thanksgiving Count 2021) are fit to linear and exponential models of decline, as was done with the eastern migratory population, a population size reduction of 66–91%, measured over 10 years, was calculated.

The same models developed by Schultz et al. (2017) and modified by Voorhies et al. (2019) also determined the risk of quasi-extinction for the western migratory population. Based on a quasi-extinction threshold ranging from 20,000 to 50,000 individuals, Voorhies et al. (2019) suggest a 99.99% (99.47–99.95) risk of quasi-extinction over 20 years. While this estimate was considered a worst-case scenario, where growth rate has declined to 0.8089 from the current rate of 0.839, it is still considered plausible (Voorhies et al. 2019). For the western migratory population, the quasi-extinction threshold was again based on expert opinion on the densities required for adequate thermoregulation and mate finding (Wells et al. 1990, Schultz et al. 2017). However, it is possible this quasi-extinction threshold is set too high; while the western migratory population fell below this extinction threshold in 2019 and 2020, the most recent 2021 data has shown a slight rebound.

In summary, when the eastern and western migratory populations are considered together, using the same variety of methods discussed above, the estimated population size reduction over the last 10 years is 22–72%. This estimate mirrors that calculated for the eastern migratory population, as the number of individuals in this population far outweighs the number of individuals in the western migratory population. The risk that both migratory populations will reach their respective quasi-extinction thresholds over the next 20 years is 5–43% (calculated by multiplying 99.9%, for the western migratory population, by 5–43%, for the eastern migratory population).

Non-migratory individuals that overwinter in Arizona, Florida, and along the Gulf coast were not included in the population size or trend estimates or in the estimates for quasi-extinction probability. Due to occasional deep freeze events, these populations probably do not remain viable without influx from migratory populations (NatureServe 2015) and therefore provide no rescue effect. Individuals outside the naturally native range were also not taken into account.
range:
The Migratory Monarch Butterfly, Danaus plexippus plexippus, is primarily distributed within North America, and can be found at various times of year from southern Canada, through the United States, to Central Mexico (Smith et al. 2005). Throughout its native range, this subspecies undergoes an iconic annual migration. Every year, millions of monarch butterflies travel from overwintering sites in central Mexico and coastal California to summer breeding grounds throughout the United States and Canada. By the late summer and fall, after subsequent generations, the migratory generation embarks on the return journey, travelling distances up to 4,000 km (Brower 1996).

Monarchs probably belonging to this subspecies are also found in many other parts of the world, including Europe (southern Spain, southern Portugal, the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands), Bermuda, and many Pacific Islands (including Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan, the Philippines, and Hawai’i) (Neves et al. 2001, Zalucki and Clarke 2004, Smith et al. 2005, Fernández-Haeger et al. 2015, Nail et al. 2019).

In Europe, the Monarch is probably introduced, as it does not appear in collection records until the 1800s (Neves et al. 2001). Additionally, all three host plants utilized in this region, Gomphocarpus fruticosus, G. physocarpus, and Asclepias curassavica, are introduced, the former two from southern and eastern Africa and the latter from Cuba or Mexico (Fernández-Haeger et al. 2015). Historically, it was considered an occasional visitor or vagrant, but as recently as the 1990s, breeding populations were established in the Azores and elsewhere (Neves et al. 2001).

In the Pacific Islands, the most common host plants are also recently introduced, such as the common ornamental milkweed, Calotropis gigantea, in Micronesia and Hawai’i (Buden and Tennent 2017), although native host plants do occur in Southeast Asia. Curiously, there may be a long history of the Monarch Butterfly in New Zealand. For example, the Maori people have a common name for the species. Therefore, it is plausible that dispersion events across the Pacific occurred thousands of years ago (Zhan et al. 2014). Most argue, however, that monarchs did not establish breeding populations in the region until more recently, within the last 200 years or so (Zalucki and Clarke 2004). There are no known breeding populations of this species in Asia, so where it has been found it is likely to be a vagrant (NatureServe 2015). In many regions outside its native range, the monarch is no longer migratory, as suitable conditions exist year-round for breeding (Nail et al. 2019). In Australia, however, monarchs are partially migratory, with some individuals breeding year-round, specifically in northeastern coastal areas, and others migrating as much as 380 km, to form overwintering roosts (James 1993, Smithers 1977).

In the countries of occurrence table for this assessment, these populations are listed as "native" as the species reached these areas naturally. However, the Monarch is generally considered native only in the Americas and the Caribbean, because the host plants utilized elsewhere are non-native, having been introduced in the last several hundred years (Fernández-Haeger et al. 2015, Buden and Tennent 2017). These more recently established populations are not likely to be viable if the non-native host plants are eradicated in these areas. For these reasons, these populations are excluded from the Red List assessment.

The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species (including only the areas to which it is naturally native, and restricted to the overwintering grounds in central Mexico and coastal California) is almost 450,000 km². The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of this species (based on the same native overwintering grounds) is 444–1,030 km². The lower bound was calculated by considering the number of overwintering sites occupied during yearly counts for both migratory populations during the 2020–2021 winter season. This included 102 sites in California (Xerces Society Western Monarch Thanksgiving Count 2021) and nine in Mexico (World Wildlife Fund Mexico 2021). Each site occupies just one grid cell, as no site is larger than the standard 4 km² grid size. The upper bound includes all suitable overwintering habitat in Mexico, calculated to be 562 km² (Slayback et al. 2007), as populations fluctuate and colonies shift around from year to year. However, as only a fraction of this suitable habitat is occupied at any given time, the lower bound of the estimate (444 km²) is considered to be more accurate. In addition, while monarchs were counted at 102 historical overwintering sites in California, only 35 sites contained more than 10 individuals (Xerces Society Western Monarch Thanksgiving Count 2021). Historically, the EOO and AOO were probably larger, but many overwintering habitats have been lost or degraded. Non-migratory individuals that overwinter in southern California, Florida, and parts of the Gulf Region were not taken into account, as these populations would probably not remain viable without influx from migratory groups (NatureServe 2015). The number of locations is likely to be larger than 10, as there are around 35 sites in California alone, that are considered to be within separate locations as the main threat, habitat loss, will impact each site differently.
useTrade:
The Monarch is one of nine butterflies permitted for release across state lines by the US Department of Agriculture (Pyle 2010), except in Washington and Oregon, which have placed state limits on this practice. It is therefore often reared by commercial breeders to be sold, usually for educational or ceremonial purposes (Pyle 2010). It is also utilized by the Butterfly House Industry (BHI), which is estimated to be worth 100 million dollars (USD) a year (Boppré and Vane-Wright 2012). Some commercial operations collect a portion of their stock from wild populations (Pelton 2018), but as neither industry is regulated, it is unclear to what extent this is the case for the Monarch.

In Mexico, the Monarch is a tourist attraction at its overwintering sites in the Oyamel Fir forests of Michoacán and Estado Mexico (Vidal et al. 2013). There is a similar draw at some sites in coastal California including in the communities of Pacific Grove, Pismo Beach, and Santa Cruz. It is unclear whether this eco-tourism impacts this species.
conservationActions:
Many voluntary conservation efforts are underway across North America to protect the migratory phenomena of this subspecies (Shahani et al. 2015, Monarch Joint Venture 2020). Continued preservation of Monarchs and their unique migration entails protection of habitats in overwintering grounds, migration corridors, and summer breeding areas. This massive undertaking requires continued international cooperation and support from government agencies, scientists, and non-profit organizations. While progress has been made, further legal protections may be useful to prevent further habitat loss and degradation. Specifically, improved protection of overwintering sites in Mexico and in California is recommended.

In Mexico, after overwintering sites became known outside of Mexico in 1975, a reserve was established, although few specific protections were outlined (Center for Biological Diversity et al. 2014). Later, in 1986, a presidential decree established the Monarch Butterfly Special Biosphere Reserve, which protected a total of 16,110 ha, including a core zone of 4,491 ha, where no extractive activities were permitted. These protections were poorly enforced and by 1999, 75% of the highest quality forest patch was destroyed and 44% of patches with over 80% canopy cover were degraded (Brower et al. 2002). In 2000, the Mexican government set aside 56,259 hectares of forest, running in a belt along the border of Michoacán and Estado Mexico, to form the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve (MBBR), which remains in place today (Vidal and Rendón-Salinas 2014). Although this designation aimed to protect forests from logging and other threats, degradation continued. Finally, in 2012, due to increased support from local authorities and philanthropists, efforts to protect overwintering sites effectively halted illegal logging, and the amount of land impacted decreased from 731 hectares between 2005 and 2007, to only 5.18 hectares in 2014 (Vidal and Rendón-Salinas 2014). In 2008, the MBBR became a UNESCO World Heritage Site (UNESCO 2013). Currently, within the MBBR, 13,000 hectares of core habitat, with a buffer zone of 42,000 ha, has been set aside to preserve overwintering sites (Jepsen et al. 2015). In addition to the MBBR, the Monarch Fund (Fondo Monarca) was set up to compensate landowners for any monarch conservation measures they participate in, and as many as 25 Non-Governmental Organizations collaborate on Monarch conservation projects through the Monarch Network (Shahani et al. 2015). Despite this work, the need to prevent continued illegal logging and manage ecotourism in overwintering sites in Mexico remains (Vidal and Rendón-Salinas 2014, Brower et al. 2016).

Canada has also taken steps to protect Monarchs. In 1995, Canada and Mexico signed a declaration to create an International Network of Monarch Butterfly Reserves (Shahani et al. 2015). In 2003, Canada listed Monarchs as a species of special concern under the Species at Risk Act (Vidal and Rendón-Salinas 2014). This provides the species with legal protections. Habitat improvement projects, undertaken by volunteers and several governmental agencies, are also underway to conserve breeding habitats (Shahani et al. 2015). The Monarch is also listed as Endangered by the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC 2016).

In the United States, this subspecies has been petitioned for protections under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) (The Center for Biological Diversity et al. 2014). In December 2020, The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) announced that listing the Monarch was “warranted but precluded by higher priority actions” (USFWS 2020). With this decision, the Monarch became a candidate for listing under the ESA, so it will be reconsidered for inclusion annually. Over 85 federal and state agencies, non-governmental organizations, businesses and academic programs collaborate on monarch conservation projects, such as habitat restoration, milkweed planting, and community science data collection, through Monarch Joint Venture (Monarch Joint Venture 2020). For example, various milkweed planting initiatives, such as efforts undertaken by the U.S. Forest Service, US Farm Bill conservation programmes, and the USDA Natural Resource Conservation Service (NRCS) are underway across summer breeding regions (Shahani et al. 2015). Many conservation efforts in the United States have focused on the summer breeding range of the eastern migratory population. More attention on the western migratory population is essential, as the overwintering sites along the California coast are still in need of protection and management and the population may be teetering on the verge of collapse (Jepsen and Black 2015, Pelton et al. 2019), despite a recent modest rebound of the population in 2021 (Pelton et al. 2021).

In addition to habitat conservation and restoration, education and outreach as well as research and monitoring have been identified as necessary conservation priorities for the Monarch (Monarch Joint Venture 2021). Outreach is key to increasing habitat for monarchs, creating advocates for local policy changes, and educating the public on the harms of noxious weeds and pesticides, among other things (Monarch Joint Venture 2021). The main research needs to be identified, include monitoring overwintering habitats, coordinating existing habitat protection efforts, gaining a better understanding of threats and factors that influence breeding and migration, and evaluating the success of conservation actions (CEC 2021, Monarch Joint Venture 2021).
